pencil.name: pencil
pencil.description: An unnaturally straight, slender piece of pale, polished wood, smooth to the touch and uniform in thickness. From end to end runs a hidden dark vein, a narrow core of earth-hued pigment sealed beneath the surface. One tip narrows to a sharp point, the pigment peeking through. The opposite end is capped by a thin silver band holding a tuft of soft white fibers, forming a cylinder flush with the wood.

steps.description: The maker scouts hillsides and riverbeds for dark, shiny veins in rocky ground. He studies animal trails to find outcrops of soft minerals. He digs trenches where rainwater exposes black streaks on stone faces. He tests bits by rubbing them on bark to check for lasting marks. He questions nearby hunters about rumored lands with black rocks. Once he confirms a good seam, he marks its location for harvest.

An early artisan positions a sturdy pickaxe against a dark vein of graphite. He plants his feet firmly and swings the tool in a rhythmic motion. The pickaxe’s heavy head strikes the stone, chipping away fragments of the mineral. Small shards fall to the ground as he continues to strike, carefully deepening the incision along the vein. He removes larger blocks by levering the pickaxe handle, prying free solid chunks of graphite. After each swing, he inspects the exposed surface, seeking pure, dark gray material without impurities. He gathers the broken pieces and loads them into a woven basket, preparing the extracted core for further refinement into a slender marking rod.

The maker selects a sturdy, straight stick of suitable thickness. Using his axe, he scrapes away rough bark until the pale timber beneath emerges smooth and clean. He sets one end firmly on a broad, flat stump and stands with legs apart for balance. With a steady grip, he raises the axe high and delivers a sharp, controlled blow to the tip of the stick. The blade sinks slowly along the grain, forcing a narrow crack to travel down the center. When the split reaches halfway, he wedges the axe deeper and twists its haft to pry the sections wide. Finally, he smooths the freshly split faces with strokes, yielding two matching halves ready for shaping.

A primitive craftsman selects a slender stick of wood and splits it lengthwise with a small stone blade. He smooths the interior halves, carving a shallow channel. Next, he prepares a narrow rod of graphite, extracted from soft rock deposits and shaped by careful rasping. He lays the graphite rod into the carved groove of the bottom wood half and aligns the top half above. He presses the two halves firmly together, sandwiching the graphite in the wooden cradle. Then he wraps the seam tightly with a strip of treated hide, wrapping it several times to secure the set core without glue. He ties off the hide ends, ensuring a snug fit. Finally, he trims any excess hide and smooths the exterior surfaces with a piece of rough stone.

A craftsman selects a slender rod of raw graphite and pours a little water over a narrow strip of cured animal hide to soften its fibers. After a few minutes, he squeezes out excess moisture and lays the rod along the flat hide strip. He begins rolling the flexible hide tightly around the graphite to center the core. He secures the assembly within a simple clamp, tightening its jaws around the wrapped bundle. The pressure compresses the hide layers and fuses them firmly against the core material. He checks alignment and adjusts the wrap for straightness. He leaves the clamp in place until the hide settles and molds around the graphite. Finally, he releases the clamp, trims any excess hide, revealing a smooth, sealed shaft ready for marking surfaces.

A primitive crafter holds a slender wooden stick with a dark core. He grips the handle of a sharp knife in one hand and steadies the stick in the other. He positions the blade near one end of the wood and begins to shave thin curls off the surface, rotating the stick as he goes. He peels away the outer layer until the exposed core protrudes slightly. He trims around the tip, ensuring the point of the core remains intact. He tests the angle of the tip against a smooth rock and scrapes away any splinters. Satisfied with the sharpness, he wipes the shavings from the wood, ready for marking surfaces.

wood.name: wood
wood.description: Deep in the forest, a pale golden core layers itself within a rough, ridged covering. The material is firm yet yielding when pressed or snapped, revealing fibrous striations that run along its length. Concentric rings mark each season of growth, while occasional knotted bulges interrupt the straight grain. When freshly exposed, it gives off a subtle, resinous aroma. Fragments litter the ground, weathering to silver-gray over time. Sunlight sometimes warms its surface.

axe.name: axe
axe.description: A massive chunk of jagged stone sits bound with woven animal sinews at one end of a slender, smooth stick. The stone bears sharp, angled edges in sunlight. The stick extends more than half a human height, its bark remnants clinging along its length, its surface smoothed by water. Tight loops of sinew wrap the junction, holding stone and wood as a form. It catches light, promising weight, bold boundaries.

steps.description: He senses rocky outcrops along the riverbank and moves toward the water’s edge. He kneels to inspect smooth pebbles and jagged fragments. He lifts heavy stones, tests their weight and strikes two pieces together to check for conchoidal fracture. He selects a dense, fine-grained rock with sharp edges. He brushes away mud to reveal hidden veins of flint. Content with the find, he carries the suitable piece back to camp.

First, the maker selects a suitable rock as the core. They hold the rock firmly and strike its edge with a hammerstone, knocking off small flakes. Each blow follows a consistent angle to detach larger shards, gradually forming a symmetrical outline. As the blank takes shape, they use softer strikes to thin the perimeter and refine the profile. The maker rotates the stone between blows, checking for balance and symmetry. With repeated percussion, the edges become sharper. They focus on creating a straight, robust bevel along one side and a curved edge on the other. Finally, they use fine flaking to remove irregularities, producing a well-shaped implement ready for hafting.

The primitive human walks through the forest, scanning the canopy for mature trees that shed limbs. They look for a fallen branch with steady thickness, free of rot or cracks. As they approach, they test the weight and balance by lifting the branch. They trace the surface with their hands, checking for smoothness and strength. The person examines nearby undergrowth to ensure the branch is straight and sturdy enough to serve as a handle. Satisfied, they mark the location, then carry the chosen branch to the work area for shaping.

First the craftsman selects a sturdy branch about 60 centimeters long, firm and straight. He strips the bark by chipping along its length with a hammerstone, flicking away thin strips until smooth wood appears. He then positions the branch horizontally, holds one end steady, and delivers sharp, angled strikes to carve a shallow groove where he plans to attach his stone tool. Bit by bit, he peels away small chips of wood, narrowing one end into a tapered, flattened section. He rotates the branch and repeats the process, ensuring symmetrical thinning. Finally, he smooths rough spots with controlled hammerstone blows, achieving a firm, shapeable haft ready for further assembly.

He steps into a swaying field of tall grass. He grips a handful of sturdy stalks and pulls them free, roots and soil clinging to the fibrous strands. He shakes off the dirt and separates the green husks from the tough inner fibers. With nimble fingers, he scrapes away pith, revealing pale strands that stretch and bend without breaking. He gathers them into bundles, tying them with thin grass cords. Carefully he inspects each strand, removing weak bits to ensure durability. The collected fiber will serve as strong lashings for his tool.

A primitive human selects a sturdy branch and a sharp-edged stone. They cut a long, flexible vine and strip away the outer bark. They soak the vine in water to soften the fibers, then lash the stone snugly against the thicker end of the branch. They wrap the vine repeatedly around the junction, pulling each turn tight to remove slack. They tuck the loose end under the last coil and pull hard to lock it in place. They trim any excess vine, ensuring the connection remains secure for heavy use.

hide.name: hide
hide.description: A broad, supple, sturdy sheet of mottled brown leather. Its surface is smooth yet pebbled, with tiny ridges and soft hairs that waver in the breeze. The edges are irregular, and coarse stray fibers hang loose like dried grass. In bright sunlight, the rich, tawny hues shift from golden to russet. When pressed, it yields under the fingers, cool and firm, carrying the faint, earthy, slightly musty scent of animal.

graphite.name: graphite
graphite.description: Rock surfaces hold streaks of dark gray mineral that gleams when caught by sunlight. Its texture is soft and greasy, and when touched it leaves sooty smudges on fingers. Narrow veins snake through rough stone, flaking into fine, powdery dust under contact. At times it appears in lumpy chunks, each fragment weighted with a subtle metallic shimmer. It feels cool and slick to the touch, gleaming with an glow.

steps.description: A lone gatherer walks along a rocky outcrop, eyes scanning thin shards of dark stone. They kneel beside layers of slate, tapping each piece with a hammer-shaped rock. A dull metallic glint catches their eye, revealing a greasy sheen under the sun. They scrape at the surface, observing a black dust left on their fingers. Confident in its soft, carbon-like nature, they pry a larger chunk free to bring back.

A lone prehistoric gatherer kneels beside a barren outcrop where dark-veined ore protrudes. He grips a simple hammer fashioned from stone and wood, raising it above his shoulder. With measured force, he taps along natural fissures, breaking away chunks that reveal lustrous black flakes. Each hammer blow sends splinters scattering across the sun-dried ground. He gathers shiny fragments in a woven hide pouch, sorting finer bits from coarse chips. Discarding unwanted host rock, he piles richer pieces on a flat slab. Over days of careful pounding, he crushes them into a fine powder. Finally, he sweeps the dark dust into a small wooden bowl, ready for line markings, art, or trade.

pickaxe.name: pickaxe
pickaxe.description: A long staff of pale, dried wood rests easily in the hand. Welded at one end, a bar of gleaming dark metal stretches sideways, heavy and cool, its surface patterned with faint striations. On one side it ends in a stout, wedge-like blade, and on the other, it tapers to a narrow, curved point. Its balance feels precise, shaft smooth yet sturdy under calloused fingers. Shadows cling around its shape.

steps.description: A lone gatherer scans the sunlit slope of a rocky outcrop, pausing at every change in the landscape. He moves carefully over loose shale, testing each stone’s weight and hardness with a tapping motion. When a chunk of flint or basalt rings with a sharp, clear tone, he pries it free and tucks it into a leather pouch. Next, he edges toward a grove of saplings, selecting a straight, sturdy branch that shows no splits or rot. He strips away small offshoots and inspects the core for density, bending the wood slightly to ensure it resists snapping. Finally, he kneels beside a patch of tall grasses and vines, peeling long strands of fiber-rich bark from a bending bush. He bundles the flexible strands together, tugging gently to separate tough fibers that will bind stone to wood securely.

He grips a sturdy hammerstone in one hand, approaching a chunk of copper ore nestled among rocky debris. He lifts the rough stone high and slams it down on the ore’s surface. Each blow fractures small bits of copper, revealing bright flecks glinting in the daylight. He shifts the hammerstone’s angle, targeting cracks and weakness, gradually chipping away flaking layers until a handful of metal fragments scatter at his feet. He bundles these shiny shards together, gripping them carefully before turning to survey the surrounding woodland for a straight branch. Once he finds a length of dense wood, he strips away its bark with a sharp flake and smooths the surface against a larger rock. He lays out his raw copper and shaped handle, ready for assembly.

A solitary craftsman squats beside a shallow stream, sorting river stones and a sturdy branch. He lifts a rounded stone and strikes its edge with a hammerstone, driving flakes outward to reveal a rough, angular form. He turns the stone and taps along each ridge, coaxing a pointed tip and a broad shoulder. With a small knife, he carefully scrapes away tiny fragments, smoothing the cutting face. Next, he selects a straight section of hardwood, stripping bark with deliberate strokes of the knife. He shapes one end into a tapered tenon and hews the opposite end into a comfortable grip. He carves a shallow groove around the tenon to lock it in place. Returning to the sharpened stone head, he fits it onto the carved tenon and binds the joint with fibers from plant cordage. Finally, he tests the balance in his hand, readying the tool for digging and breaking compacted earth.

A sturdy branch serves as the handle. He uses a hammerstone to flatten the base of the stone tool head to fit snugly against the wood. He positions the stone against the carved notch in the handle. With sinew strips, he wraps tightly around the joint, weaving over and under in tight coils. He pulls each strand taut, securing the stone firmly to the wood. He wets the sinew to make it pliable before binding. Once the wrap covers the entire socket, he beats the bundle with the hammerstone, tightening the fibers and seating the head. Finally, he knots the sinew ends and trims excess, completing a sturdy hand tool.

knife.name: knife
knife.description: A slender, elongated shard of dull steel rests before the viewer, its surface smooth and cool to the touch. One edge tapers into a nearly seamless line that glints faintly in the light. The opposite side remains thicker, forming a sturdy spine. At its base, a short hilt of darker wood fans outward, forming a tight collar beneath the metal. The entire form feels balanced, as though shaped with deliberate care.

steps.description: At sunrise the human steps onto the riverbank, sweeping the shoreline with keen eyes. She bends to inspect pebbles and shards amid the gravel, feeling each’s weight in her palm. She drops those that feel too heavy or round. Sharp-edged fragments catch her gaze, their glint promising a clean break. She lifts them, testing the edge against a piece of wood. When the stone bites, she tucks it into her belt, ready for shaping.

The maker selects a tough chunk of flint and holds it securely in one hand. He grasps a heavy hammerstone in the other and positions the two stones with a slight angle. He brings the hammerstone down with controlled force onto the edge of the core, detaching a sharp flake. He inspects the strike platform, adjusts his grip, and repeats the blow along the perimeter. Each precise hit peels away a sliver of rock, gradually refining a cutting edge. He rotates the piece, striking from different angles to thin the material. With calculated strikes, he shapes a functional cutting implement through repeated flake removal. His focused rhythm yields an effective tool.

clamp.name: clamp
clamp.description: A small rigid shape of cold, hard material rests before you. Two curved arms meet at one end by a spiraled rod, its grooves catching sunlit dust. The arms’ inner faces lie flat and smooth, while their outer edges feel ridged. Turning the rough-knotted spiral shaft pulls the arms’ tips closer or pushes them apart. Each arm terminates in slightly flattened jaws that press together with firm resistance.

steps.description: He travels to the rocky hillside and picks up heavy stones, striking earth to uncover copper ore veins. He gathers fragments of copper ore and hunts for tin ore in riverbeds. He crushes ore chunks with a hammerstone and rinses fragments to clear dust. He carries refined bits to a clay furnace, builds a charcoal fire, and heats until a red glow. He adds copper and tin bits, watches them melt and blend into bronze. He stirs molten mix with a stick, then pours into a rough stone mold. After cooling, he breaks open the mold and retrieves a metal form. He brushes off charcoal and chips to reveal a blank.

A primitive craftsman selects a sturdy branch, trims away side shoots, and carries it to a clearing. He plants one end on an anvil and grips the opposite end of the axe. Raising the tool high with both hands, he brings it crashing down onto the midline of the wood. Fibers part with a crack, and a groove marks the intended split. Repeating the strike along the groove, he guides the blade carefully, keeping it aligned with the grain. Once the two halves begin to separate, he positions the haft in the fissure and twists it. The wooden pieces come apart, forming two blanks ready for further shaping.

He selects a straight hardwood branch from a fallen oak. He grips it and, with a sharp stone knife, shaves off bark. He then marks two parallel faces on the beam where the holding arms will sit. He carves each face with strokes that leave flat, matching surfaces. He cuts matching notches at the base of each arm to house a wooden pivot. He rounds the outer edges for comfort. Finally, he smooths the inner jaws with slices so that the arms press evenly against an object when tightened. He angles each inner surface slightly to concentrate force toward the tips and tests the fit by squeezing the two arms together.

Armed with a sharp blade, the early craftsman selects a sturdy, straight branch. He clears small knots or protrusions. He cuts it to a manageable length. Holding the wood firmly in one hand, he slices away thin chips along one side, guiding the edge of the blade toward a central line. He repeats this on the opposite face. He smooths the faces, trimming irregularities until the wedge fits snugly into a split or joint. He inspects each face for uniformity. He trims edges evenly. He uses steady, rhythmic strokes. The final form tapers to a fine point, ready to be driven between pieces, drawing them together by sheer force.

He picks a straight piece of oak. He rests it on a low stone. He marks two parallel lines with his blade. With the edge of his knife, he scores along the lines, deepening the cut. He pulls the knife toward himself, carving a narrow channel. He repeats from the opposite side to ensure uniform depth. He uses short, controlled strokes, stopping to clear wood shavings. He probes the groove with his fingernail and adjusts his angle to keep the walls straight. Gradually, the groove deepens until it fits the cross beam snugly. He smooths rough spots, ensuring the channel grips securely when pressure is applied. He tests leverage and firmness.

He picks a straight, sturdy branch and trims bark with a flint blade. He splits one end into two parallel arms and carves grooves along each. He drills a hole through one arm by twisting a stick, forming a round opening. He shapes a wooden peg to fit the hole. He carves a wedge to slide between the arms, drawing them together. He weaves fibrous cord around both arms and notches the ends to hold tension. He inserts the peg and taps it home, holding the arms against a beam.

hammerstone.name: hammerstone
hammerstone.description: A rough oval boulder sits among smooth river-worn stones, its surface dimpled and pitted by countless impacts. The edges bear small fractures like shallow scars, revealing a paler inner core where the outer patina has chipped away. Underfoot it feels sturdy and heavy, its dark brown flint gleaming faintly in the sun. Nearby, grasses bend around its base and pebbles nestle against its bulk, suggesting ancient origins hidden in water-smoothed rock.

steps.description: He crouches along the river’s edge, scanning flat cobbles for the hardest, most rounded shape. He lifts one candidate, hefting it to judge weight and balance. He tests durability with small taps, listening for a clear tone. Satisfied by its sound, he pockets the chosen piece and secures it in a leather strap. He returns to camp, ready to strike flakes from flint with rhythmic blows, creating sharp edges for cutting.

grass.name: grass
grass.description: All around, a soft carpet of slender, green blades covers the earth, swaying in the breeze like tiny banners. Each blade rises from the soil, pointed and narrow, standing shoulder-high at most. Their verdant hue shifts with sunlight, sometimes pale, sometimes deep. A faint rustle echoes when wind passes through, and dew-laden tips glisten at dawn. It spreads endlessly, blending gentle waves of color across the open land. In dim light, it appears almost silver.

stone.name: stone
stone.description: Scattered across the ground are solid, irregular lumps of various sizes. Their surfaces range from rough and jagged to smooth and worn, each bearing striations and pits etched by wind and water. In sunlight they reflect a dull sheen, shifting between shades of gray, brown, and flecks of white or black. When touched, they feel unyielding and cold, their edges sharp or rounded, heavy enough to anchor themselves in the earth.

branch.name: branch
branch.description: Before you lies a heavy length of rough wood, tapering from a broad base to a narrow tip. Its surface is ridged with grooves, mottled in brown and gray. Small knobbly protrusions jut out at uneven intervals, while delicate shoots reach skyward. Sunlight catches the rough shadows along its length, revealing patches of lichen and strips of peeling bark. The end feels ancient, rooted once in living earth.

steps.description: The early human scans the forest floor, eyes tracking fallen sticks amid leaf litter. He crouches low, brushing aside debris with rough hands. He eyes each thin wooden shaft, testing its weight by lifting and bending slightly. He smells the fresh-cut scent, selecting pieces with sturdy form and few knots. He discards curved or brittle ones, focusing on straight, firm sticks of manageable length. He gathers his finds proudly.

A solitary figure picks up a sturdy limb from the forest floor. He grips it firmly, aiming to create smaller sections for tools or fuel. He positions his hands evenly, one near the thicker end and one closer to the tip. He flexes his arms and shifts his weight, bending the wood downward. He listens for the strain as fibers creak. When the tension peaks, he exerts a sudden, forceful twist and pull. The piece snaps with a sharp crack, yielding neat segments ready for carving, immediate fire, or crafting.

A solitary early human crouches low and scans the leafy ground. Eyes settle on a sturdy wooden limb half-hidden by ferns. He advances, shifting loose stones with bare feet to avoid a stumble. Then he bends deeply, one leg bracing against a mossy log. Fingers curl around the rough, bark-coated surface, nails catching splinters as he tests its weight. He tightens his grip, muscles flexing along his forearm and shoulder. Feet press firmly against the earth as he straightens his back, lifting the heavy timber free from the soil and debris.

vine.name: vine
vine.description: In the forest, long slender green strands coil around tree trunks and branches. They weave through gaps in canopy, reaching sunlit heights. The outer skin is smooth, occasionally rough with small bumps. It bends easily when pushed but resists sudden force. Tiny tendrils extend from its sides, grasping bark or other greenery. Its surface is cool and slightly damp from morning dew. Some segments show heart-shaped leaves sprouting along length.

hammer.name: hammer
hammer.description: A sturdy, elongated branch with weathered, pale-brown bark tapers smoothly under your fingers, its surface marked by faint growth rings. One end is bound tightly by sinew around a polished, blocky mass of dark-gray stone, its sides flat and angled to meet at crisp edges. The stone’s weight pulls downward, giving the piece a clear balance. Together they form a single object of wood and rock, joined seamlessly. By itself.

steps.description: He scans the riverbank for a firm stone with flat surfaces. He taps pebbles against each other to test weight and resonance. He chooses a dense rock that emits a clear ping and feels solid in his grip. He checks for cracks and irregularities, favoring a compact, durable piece. He washes it in the stream, removing debris and revealing its true shape. He rolls it in his hand, noting its balance. Satisfied, he sets it aside for shaping, confident that this sturdy chunk of stone will serve as the striking head for his tool.

He stands in the forest, scanning trees for a sturdy branch. He seeks a straight piece about forearm length, free of knots or cracks. He tests hardness by pressing his thumb into bark. Satisfied, he snaps off the limb at its thinnest end, trims side shoots with a sharp flint blade, and strips bark while smoothing the surface with a stone scraper. He carves one end into a gentle taper to fit the stone head. Finally, he rubs wood with animal fat, sealing and strengthening grain.

The toolmaker steps into the forest and inspects the undergrowth for supple vines. He plucks one from a liana draped on a branch, tests its strength by tugging, and ensures it does not snap. He strips loose bark, exposing flexible fibers. Using a sharp flint shard, he slices segments into equal lengths. He chews an end to soften it and reveal inner strands. He twists fibers together, increasing tensile power. He coils strands into tight lengths ready for lashing. With these sturdy bindings, he secures the stone head firmly to the wooden handle.

He selects a suitable flint nodule and holds it firmly against a flat surface. With a rounded hammerstone in his other hand, he strikes deliberate blows along one edge. Each blow dislodges small flakes and begins to reveal a rough outline of the future striking head. He rotates the stone and examines the emerging profile, adjusting his angle and force. He lands precise taps near the edge to thin and shape the form. As the silhouette sharpens, he shifts to lighter strikes, refining curves and straightening facets. Through repeated percussion, he transforms the raw rock into a balanced, functional head. He pauses frequently to inspect the angles and ensure symmetry across both faces.

The human picks a sturdy branch of hardwood, choosing one with a slight bend and a straight grain. He cuts away bark with a flint-edged knife, revealing pale wood underneath. Holding the branch firmly, he slices longitudinal shavings to taper one end into a comfortable grip. He studies the curve as he whittles, removing small curls of wood to refine thickness and balance. His knife strokes alternate between controlled pushes and steady pulls, slowly rounding edges and creating a smooth contour. He stops often to flex the piece, ensuring it feels right in his palm. At last, the form offers a solid, ergonomic hold ready for further assembly and use.

Primitive human selects long blades of grass. They twist grass into a strong cord by rolling fibers between palms. They wrap one end of the cord tightly around the smooth part of the stone and the top of the shaft, forming a cradle. They loop grass strands under the stone’s groove, pull taut, and wrap around the shaft multiple times. They add more strands, pressing fibers close. After neat turns, they tie a knot with extra length. They press fibers flat and wet the wrap to clamp the head firmly.

The primitive human selects a straight, strong branch from a young tree. He uses a sharp knife to strip away the bark and remove rough patches. He marks the length needed for a solid hold near the burly stone head. Then he carves a groove at one end, hollowing a shallow slot that will cradle the weight. He shaves down the wood, tapering it slightly for a comfortable grip. He smooths the surface with the knife, rounding edges and testing its feel in his palm. Next, he gathers supple vine, cutting several long strands. He wraps the vine tightly around the slot, binding the head to the shaft. Finally, he ties secure knots, trimming stray ends and inspecting the fit. He tests the balance by swinging it in a short arc.

graphite ore.name: graphite ore
graphite ore.description: A traveler discovers a smooth, metallic-gray rock jutting from the rocky soil. Sunlight glints off its polished surfaces, revealing faint, swirling lines like charcoal strokes frozen in stone. When scratched against rough flint, it leaves behind a dark, sooty streak. Its texture feels slippery to the touch, as if wet, yet no moisture appears. Embedded in fractured cliffs, it seems layered in delicate sheets that flake away under gentle pressure.

stone flake.name: stone flake
stone flake.description: A thin shard of mineral juts from the earth, its edges gleaming with abrupt angles. One side holds a smooth, glassy surface reflecting sunlight, while the other reveals striations and rough patches. It feels cool to the touch. Its shape is irregular, tapering to a narrow lip along one side, as if split from a larger mass. Tiny flecks of darker mineral dot its surface, lending it a mottled appearance.

steps.description: He climbs rocky outcrops at the edge of a river valley, eyes scanning exposed nodules embedded in weathered layers. Light reflects off smooth surfaces, guiding his attention to nodules of dense, fine-grained material. He scratches surfaces with a tool to test hardness and conchoidal fracture. He discards irregular pieces and gathers uniform lumps, checking each for uniform texture and absence of large cracks. Satisfied, he carries them to his workshop.

Standing barefoot on firm ground, the primitive artisan grasps a block of flint in one hand. With the other hand, they raise a rounded hammerstone above their shoulder. They angle the edge to roughly thirty degrees, align the targeted spot on the block, and deliver a sharp blow. The force travels through the material, causing a thin sliver to detach. Grasping both tools steadily, the maker rotates the block, adjusting the angle, and repeats the percussive strike at new points. Each controlled hit removes a slender shard, gradually shaping a cutting edge. The artisan watches carefully, maintaining consistent force and angle to yield predictable, sharp pieces.

He crouches near a freshly struck rock and scans the ground for glint of slender chips. With careful fingers he lifts each fragment, inspecting its edge for sharpness. When a piece meets his needs, he tucks it into a woven bag made from animal hide. He pauses to clear debris away and finds any hidden bits. Once satisfied, he gathers the container and moves with care toward the shelter where he will store the collected fragments for future work. Every chip counts as he secures his tools before night falls.

stone hammer.name: stone hammer
stone hammer.description: A roughly shaped, dark-gray rock sits bound atop a sturdy, straight wooden branch. The stone’s edges show signs of being flaked, giving it a broad, flattened surface on one side and a narrower, tapered side on the other. The branch is stripped of bark where it meets the rock, and sinew strips wrap tightly around the junction. The whole object feels heavy and balanced in the hand.

steps.description: The primitive human rises at dawn and steps into the rocky terrain. He scans rough, exposed surfaces, focusing on areas near riverbeds where water has washed away softer soil. He listens for the clatter of pebbles underfoot and crouches to inspect fragments. Fingers brush over coarse, angular pieces, testing density by hefting each one. Once found, he discards light, crumbling bits and selects heavy, resilient chunks with sharp edges. Confident these chunks will withstand repeated strikes, he gathers a handful and carries them back to his camp for further shaping.

Standing beside a rocky outcrop, a primitive individual inspects the seam of exposed rock. They select a sturdy rock nodule and apply sharp impacts from a denser fragment, striking at an angle along natural cracks. Chips fly off as the tool maker continues precise blows, following the split lines. After repeated percussion, a piece detaches cleanly, revealing a roughly shaped block. They test the weight and balance in their palm, smoothing rough edges by further chipping. With a final adjustment, the extracted material transforms into a workable mass ready for further refinement.

He picks up a suitable block of stone, rests it on a stable surface, and grasps the hammerstone firmly. He lifts the hammerstone above shoulder height and brings it down sharply on the edge of the block. Fragments fly off with each strike. He rotates the block between blows to expose fresh angles and chips away unwanted bulges. He shifts his grip and taps more gently along curved sections to refine the shape. He pauses to inspect the outline, checking for symmetry and balance. When he identifies irregularities, he returns the hammerstone for heavier blows, then finishes delicate areas with controlled, light taps. Finally, he smooths edges for a comfortable grip.

sinew.name: sinew
sinew.description: Thick glistening bands stretch alongside the bones of creatures. Each strand is fibrous, pale cream and semi-translucent, with minute threads aligned in parallel. When pulled, it yields slightly and resists, then springs back taut. The surface feels silky yet sinewy, cool and damp to the touch. Beneath the flesh, these ribbons weave between muscle bundles, holding flesh and bone in a tight, intricate network of fibers. They appear damp with animal moisture.

steps.description: The hunter crouches behind a thick shrub, scanning the plain for signs of movement. He grips a sharpened spear in his hand, feeling the weight of its wooden shaft and stone tip. A herd of deer grazes by a stream, unaware of his presence. He takes a slow breath, steadies his aim, and times his step to match the wind. He inches forward, silent and careful, until he stands within throwing range. With a smooth swing, he hurls the spear toward the nearest animal. The point strikes true, and the creature stumbles. He rushes forward, plunging the spear home to secure his prize and provide ample raw material for cordage.

The primitive artisan sets an animal carcass, gripping a sharp knife. He slices along the limb, following the bands that run from muscle to bone. With careful pressure, he severs the tough strips from the joint, sliding the blade beneath the strands. Using his free hand, he pulls firm cords away from surrounding flesh, while the knife scrapes off fat and membrane. He repeats this process on each leg and shoulder, separating narrow bands of strength. He lays the ribbons in the sun or next to embers, letting heat draw out moisture. Soon he obtains flexible, durable fibers ready for binding or stitching. Once dry, he tests each strand for resilience.

A primitive human sits by a hide, working tough cords from beneath the skin. Holding a sharp scraping tool, they tension each strand between thumb and forefinger. Drawing the blade along its length, they shave away clinging tissue and fat. It continues, rotating the strand under the edge until the fibers gleam in firelight. They then soak the cleaned threads in cold water, flexing them to loosen any stubborn scraps. After a final scrape, the cords lie white and smooth, ready to twist into strong threads for bindings and arrow fletching. They cool and hang to dry over embers, ensuring the fibers remain supple when needed and store them for future use.

A gatherer cuts tendon from a freshly hunted deer. He trims away fat and membrane with a sharp flint blade, exposing long white strands. He soaks the strips briefly in cool spring water to soften unwanted tissue, then lays each length flat on river rock. Using his hand as a clamp, he scrapes along the fibers, peeling away connective tissue until only tough filaments remain. He pulls each strip taut, twisting several together into a thread. Finally, he hangs the cord in indirect sun and breeze until dry and stiff.

plant fiber.name: plant fiber
plant fiber.description: Thin strands extend from broken stems of leafy plants, forming wispy tufts in varying shades of pale tan and off-white. Each filament is smooth yet slightly coarse, whispering in the breeze as they sway. The mass drapes over branches, clings to stones, or drifts along the water’s edge. Under gentle tension, bundles of these fine, wiry threads reveal a subtle, delicate sheen, their length and flexibility hinting at hidden strength.

steps.description: The gatherer identifies suitable specimens by scanning the undergrowth for stems with smooth bark and long, slender form. He rubs a leaf, smelling sap for freshness. He tests a stalk, bending it gently to check flexibility without snapping. He peels section of outer bark to reveal the soft inner layer. He examines this strand, pulling it lightly to see strength and length. If it separates in long, strong threads, he marks the clump. He chooses several healthy stalks, avoiding ones that are brittle, overly tough or damp near the base.

He approaches a stand of tall reedlike stalks near the riverbank. He grips a rough flint blade in his hand and slices through the lower reaches of each stalk, separating them from their roots. He loosens the roots and shakes away dirt, then bundles several stalks together with a trailing vine. He repeats this until his arms fill with stiff lengths. He carries the bundle back to his camp, laying it across a stone. He inspects the stems to ensure they are undamaged and sets them aside for the next step.

A primitive gatherer grips a flax stalk near its base, resting the top end against a sturdy rock. With a flint blade, the gatherer makes a shallow cut along the stalk’s length to free the outer layers. Holding the stalk firmly, the gatherer pulls downward, stripping away the greenish rind in long, narrow bands. Each band peels away smoothly, revealing soft, pale strands beneath. The gatherer repeats the cut-and-pull rhythm along the length of each stalk. The resulting bundles of clean, silky threads lie ready for twisting into cordage.

Standing by a shallow pond, the gatherer rips long, narrow strips from a sturdy reed stalk or inner bark. They carry the strips back to a low bank, submerging them fully in the cool water. The gentle current swirls around the strips, loosening tough tissues. After a night submerged, the material softens, becoming pliable and pale. The person lifts each strip, drips off excess water, and lays them across smooth stones. The water’s minerals and steady soak break down rigid elements, leaving behind supple lengths ready for further splitting or twisting.

He sits by a flat stone. He lays a strip of bark across the anvil. He lifts the hammerstone and strikes along the length, evenly pacing. The bark spreads and thins. He shifts the piece, working each side. After repeated blows, the inner layers loosen. He flips the strip and taps along the edges to peel away fragments. The pounding flattens fibers, making the strips pliable. He watches the color change as the bark softens. With controlled force, he continues until the strip yields and fans out thin. He occasionally shifts his grip, rotating the bark to target stubborn spots and ensure uniform thickness. When the piece releases its tough outer skin, he stops. He gathers the tender, supple bands for weaving.

A gatherer collects dried flax stalks and lays them out on a flat stone. He breaks each bundle by bending and crushing the stems between his hands or against the rock. Next, he scrapes the broken stalks with a wooden board, knocking away the brittle outer husk. After scutching, he draws the remaining strands through a row of wooden teeth, pulling to separate the fine threads from the woody core. He repeats this hackling until silky strands remain, ready for twisting into strong, flexible cord. These strands await weaving into cloth.

A gatherer selects sturdy stalks from riverside grasses or wild vines. She cuts lengths with a flint blade and peels away the outer bark to reveal silky strands inside. She bruises each strand lightly between smooth stones to loosen any pulp. Next she arranges the strands in single layers on sun-warmed rocks. The bright heat pulls out moisture, leaving them crisp and ready for weaving. Once thoroughly dried, she bundles the strands into manageable hanks. These strong, supple cords serve for weaving mats, fashioning nets, or tying simple traps and tools.

flint knife.name: flint knife
flint knife.description: A slender shard of dark, glassy stone emerges, its surface glinting with pale striations like striated ice. One edge tapers into a razor-thin lip, serrated with tiny notches that catch the light. The opposite side is rounded, smoothed in places by repeated gripping. When held, the weight feels balanced in the palm, cold and solid against the skin. Fragments of quartz flicker along its length, hinting at its unforgiving sharpness.

steps.description: He searches riverbeds for glassy pebbles, turning over stones in gravel bars. He observes chalky cliffs and eroded hillsides, seeking out nodules along exposed layers. He knocks small pebbles together to test density and conchoidal fracture. He notes color, texture, and sheen in sunlit pockets of shattered rock. He collects promising shards, stores them in a leather pouch, and marks the spot with stacked stones for return trips.

He selects a suitable flint core and grips it firmly in one hand. With the other, he raises the hammerstone and examines the edge of the core to choose a striking platform. He positions the hammerstone so its rounded edge meets the platform at a low angle. He applies a quick, controlled blow, directing force inward along the core’s surface. Upon impact, a thin, sharp fragment snaps away. He inspects the detached flake, noting its thinness and straight edge. If it proves suitable, he sets it aside; if not, he repositions the core and repeats the strike. Each precise hit removes material, shaping a usable cutting edge.

An artisan holds a freshly detached stone blank in one hand and an antler retoucher in the other. He positions the retoucher against the edge at a low angle, placing his thumb on the back of the tool to apply precise pressure. With steady force, he presses inward, detaching tiny flakes along the margin and trimming away irregularities. Each pressure stroke moves slowly along the edge, gradually producing a uniform keen cutting surface. He rotates the fragment, refining both sides alternately, checking for symmetry. As he works, the fine striations reveal a light sheen under the sun. Finally, he passes a small sandstone smooth against the perimeter for a final polish.

rock.name: rock
rock.description: A heavy chunk of earth lies upon the ground, its surface cool, rough, and dull gray beneath the touch. It glitters faintly where tiny crystals catch the light, and small cracks run across its face like river paths. Its edges are jagged, and its weight pulls fingers with a dull promise of steadiness. It sits quietly amidst the soil, unchanged by wind or rain, solid and enduring under the sky.

copper ore.name: copper ore
copper ore.description: You come across rough, substantial stones protruding from rocky outcrops, their surfaces mottled with dull green and turquoise patches. Metallic veins glint within the earth-toned matrix, catching sunlight with a soft, reddish sheen. The weight surprises you—far denser than common rock—while small fractures reveal a brassy gleam. The stone’s heart feels cool and slightly waxy, and a fine, colored powder rustles free when it rubs against other stones.

animal.name: animal
animal.description: A large, living form moves across the grass, its four sinewy limbs pushing a thick body forward. A coarse covering ripples with each step. Two forward-facing bright orbs scan the world, while a widening slit beneath drips warm fluid. A damp, rhythmic expansion and contraction within hints at life. Soft, deep breaths stir the air around its form. Its presence carries a heavy, faint scent of moist earth and warmth.

scraper.name: scraper
scraper.description: A hand-sized rock, roughly oval, with one edge finely chipped into a thin, sharp line. Its surface is weathered and smooth to the touch, while the opposite side is knobbly and pitted. Tiny, deliberate flake scars run along the narrow rim, catching the sunlight as a subtle glint. The stone’s color shifts from dark gray to pale tan around the edges, suggesting origins from a creekbed bed.

steps.description: He stands by the shallow stream, eyes scanning the pebbled bed. He kneels and plucks a smooth, flat stone from beneath shallow water. He turns it over, feeling its weight and inspecting for a naturally sharp edge. He taps it softly against another boulder to test its toughness. Satisfied, he slips the chosen stone into a leather pouch, ready to shape its edge through rhythmic strikes at the nearby settlement.

A primitive artisan selects a dense quartzite nodule from the riverbank. He rests the raw core against his thigh and braces it with one hand. He turns the stone to reveal a natural edge that can serve as a platform. Holding a rounded hammerstone in his other hand, he carefully strikes the platform at a shallow angle. The blow detaches a thin, curved flake from the main mass. He inspects the removed piece, noting its sharp edge and flake characteristics. He repositions the core, adjusts the platform angle, and repeats the strike to extract another flake. Through repeated precision blows, he produces a series of sharp-edged tools from the quartzite.

A primitive human selects a quartzite flake and grips it firmly in one hand. They raise a rounded hammerstone in the other hand and bring it down at a low angle to the working edge. With controlled blows, they detach tiny flakes along the margin. Each percussion removes irregularities and sharpens the profile. The artisan shifts the flake to reach difficult spots and vary the angle. Small, uniform scars accumulate, transforming the perimeter into a crisp, continuous ridge. They pause to inspect the edge against the light, then resume striking to even out any rough patches. The finished tool features a thin, sharp edge suitable for slicing and scraping tasks.

animal carcass.name: animal carcass
animal carcass.description: A heavy shape lies still upon the forest floor, its coat matted with dried and sticky fluids. Limbs splay outward in unnatural angles, and the body sinks slowly into the loamy soil. A faint, sour scent drifts through the air, mingling with the buzz of insects that cluster at torn hides and exposed flesh. Nearby roots weave beneath, drawing moisture from the form. Its hair stands slicked by earth’s chill.

spear.name: spear
spear.description: A straight, slender wooden shaft stretches nearly shoulder-high, its surface smooth and pale. One end tapers abruptly into a rough, darkened flake of stone, its edges chipped in fine, angular facets. Thin strips of sinew coil tight where the two materials meet, their fibers taut and glistening faintly. The opposite end shows a thicker core, faintly mottled, suggesting plant fibers beneath a worn, oil-darkened bark. It rests against mossy ground.

steps.description: First, the maker scans the forest edge for a young sapling or branch as thick as a wrist. He eyes its length, seeking a straight piece free of knots and twists. He scratches the bark with his fingernail; a firm, resilient piece promises strength. He taps it against a rock to gauge sound and density. He bends the wood gently, ensuring it yields but does not crack. Satisfied, he removes small twigs and smooths rough spots with a sharp stone, ready for the next stage of crafting.

He braces a wooden shaft between his legs, gripping it firmly. He holds a flint-edged knife at the end of the pole, angling the blade against the grain. He draws the blade toward the tip, shaving off thin curls of wood. He rotates the shaft slowly, carving a tapered point. He checks symmetry with his eye, slicing away uneven spots. He repeats strokes, keeping pressure steady. When the tip forms a fine chisel-like edge, he then carefully smooths each rough ridge. Finally, he tests penetration into bark to ensure sharpness.

He selects a straight branch and trims away side shoots, leaving a smooth shaft six feet long. He sharpens one end with a stone tool, carving it to a point. He arranges smoldering coals in a shallow pit and holds the pointed end above the embers, rotating it slowly. The wood darkens and hardens, the fibers tightening under dry heat. He tests the firmness by pressing with his thumbnail; when it resists, he cools it in water to fix the process. He polishes the hardened tip, readying it for use.

tendon.name: tendon
tendon.description: It lies beneath the hide and among the red flesh, a glistening band of pearly white fibers. These cords form thick strands, tightly woven, bridging solid bone deep within. When the carcass moves, they stretch slightly and snap back, pulsing with silent strength. Their surface gleams moist under torchlight or dawn’s soft glow, translucent like thin sinewy ropes, tying rigid parts together with unseen resilience beneath the animal’s broken skin.

steps.description: The hunter crouches at dawn, scanning the clearing for movement. He grips a long wooden shaft with a sharpened stone tip and pads silently through sparse grass. His eyes track steady shapes and flickers in the undergrowth. When a deer steps into view, he freezes, lowering his body to blend with shadows. He draws a deep breath, then shifts weight forward, advancing with careful, measured steps. At fifteen paces, he steadies the spear overhead and whispers a soft chant before lunging. The spear flies forward, striking the flank and pinning the animal to the ground. He rushes forward, eagerly dragging quarry into the open for the immediate next task.

A primitive human selects a fresh leg bone from a hunted animal. They lay the limb on a flat stone and secure it with their foot. With a sharp knife in hand, they slice away coarse hair and split the hide along the length of the limb. Carefully, they peel back fleshy layers to reveal long, glistening fibers nestled between muscle and bone. Leaning close, they slip the knife beneath the fiber sheath and draw it gently along its length, freeing a strong, cord-like strand. They trim off any fatty remnants and lay the clean, white strands in the sun to dry, preparing them for binding and weaving.

quartzite flake.name: quartzite flake
quartzite flake.description: A thin sliver of pale gray rock catches the sun’s rays, its fractured surface gleaming like wet glass. One side is smooth and glossy, the other rough and matte, revealing bands of lighter and darker gray. Sharp, irregular edges outline its uneven shape, as though snapped from a block. Pits and striations mark its face, while its flatness hints at deliberate force. It feels cool and heavy in the palm.

steps.description: He walks along dry creek beds and rocky hillsides, scanning cliff faces and stream cobbles for dense, glossy stone. He crouches to tap a dark boulder, listening for a sharp, ringing tone that indicates quality. His keen eyes spot fractures and natural edges, where controlled strikes will produce sharp tools. He scratches the surface with a pointed stick to test hardness and selects heavy nodules free of cracks for refining.

The individual grasps the rough stone core in one hand and lifts a rounded hammerstone with the other. They position the core at a stable angle, creating a 60-degree platform. They align the hammerstone’s edge with a specific point along the core’s margin. With a controlled wrist motion, they deliver a precise blow. The force travels through the raw rock, causing a sharp fragment to detach. They inspect the newly exposed surface on the core and adjust the angle or reposition the hammerstone for the next detachment. Each strike removes a thin piece with a sharp edge, gradually refining the stone’s shape into a cutting tool through repeated impact.

He sits on the ground, selects a suitable quartzite core, and steadies it in his non-dominant hand. With a harder stone in his dominant hand, he strikes a precise blow at the core’s edge. The impact shears off a thin shard, sending it skittering across the surface. He shifts the core, resets his grip, and scans the newly exposed surface for the next striking point. He bends close to pluck the shard, examines its sharp edge in daylight, places it carefully into a hide bag at his side, and resumes striking.

quartzite.name: quartzite
quartzite.description: Along sunlit hillsides, a hard, pale stone emerges, its surface gleaming with silvery and rose-tinted streaks. When struck by light, it reflects a glassy sparkle, as if flecks of hidden crystals lie within. Fragments break off along jagged planes, revealing a smooth cross-section that contrasts its exterior. Covered in patches of lichen, this rock forms steep outcrops and scattered boulders across the landscape, catching the eye with its luminous sheen.

steps.description: A primitive human searching for robust stone for tools scans riverbeds and rocky outcrops. They wander along shallow streams, inspecting gravel bars for glinting pebbles. They tap stones together, listening for a bright, sharp ring. They examine cliff faces, spotting pale crystalline veins, and break off small fragments with a hammerstone. They test each chip’s flake potential until they find the right material for toolmaking, marking promising spots for later return.

A skilled artisan selects a large chunk of the hard stone from the riverbed and places it on a stable surface. He holds a smaller rounded hammerstone firmly in his other hand and positions the edge of the core at a low angle. With careful control he strikes near the margin, aiming to remove a thin flake. The blow travels through the grain, releasing a smooth fragment from the block. He repeats the motion, rotating the piece slightly after each hit, producing sharp flakes useful as cutting edges. As he works, he maintains a steady rhythm, ensuring controlled detachment and consistent shapes. He continues until he obtains needed flakes.

flint flake.name: flint flake
flint flake.description: A small shard of dark rock, thin and curved like a bird’s feather. Its surface glints with a metallic sheen under sunlight. The edges are crisp and angular, slicing through the air when moved. Touching it feels smooth yet cool, like water-worn stone. The interior subtly reveals layers, concentric rings of opaque gray and translucent silver. Fine radiating lines mar its sheen, catching the light. It lies half-buried among pebbles on sandy ground.

steps.description: Near riverbanks, the gatherer scans the banks for smooth, rounded stones that shine when the sun strikes their dark surfaces. He moves along shallow waters, stepping lightly over pebbles and coarse gravel. His trained eye seeks lumps hidden among chalky cliffs and loose rocks. Pausing beside a low bluff, he taps a small nodule with another rock; a clear ring tells him it is hard and brittle enough. Satisfied, he pockets this prize before continuing downstream, always mindful of color, texture, and sound that signal useful stone.

He grips the hammerstone firmly in his right hand, raising the rounded tool toward his shoulder. In his left hand he holds a raw flint core, its surface dull and unrefined. He examines a rough edge, selecting a spot for impact. He positions the striking point at a controlled angle, tilting the core slightly away from his body. With a swift, precise motion, he drives the hammerstone down onto the edge. A thin shard breaks free, flying off and leaving a fresh, sharp facet. He inspects the new piece, then adjusts his grip, rotates the core, and repeats the strike. Each blow detaches thin fragments, gradually shaping the core’s edge into a cutting tool.

After a solid strike, a sharp chip detaches from the core. The craftsman allows the hammering tool to drop gently beside him. He steps forward and crouches beside the core. His fingers brush the ground, lifting the friable fragment with care. He tilts it toward the light, both edges glowing along its newly formed ridges. He tests its cutting edge against a piece of hide, he feels a slight resistance as it slices. Satisfied, he places the piece on a bark mat beside other sharpened objects, preparing for the next extraction.

flint.name: flint
flint.description: In daylight, this unusual grey-black rock gleams with a dull sheen. Its surface is fine and glass-like, yet feels cool and weighty in your hand. When struck, its edges break away in sharp, curved slices, leaving smooth, almost mirrorlike faces. The fractured surfaces reveal bands of lighter and darker streaks. Despite its unassuming shape, fragments present razor-thin profiles that glint sharply under the sun. The whole feels steadfast and enduring.

bark strips.name: bark strips
bark strips.description: Thin, fibrous layers peeled from the tree’s protective outer covering lie in slender, elongated pieces. Their rough surfaces show uneven veins and faded brown and gray tones. Each remains flexible but retains a slight papery stiffness. Some curl at the edges, exposing lighter, smoother inner faces. The margins are frayed, with tiny fibers fanning out. When a breeze passes, they whisper softly, fluttering against one another on the forest floor.

steps.description: He approaches the forest edge, scanning for tall, straight trees with smooth trunks. He listens to the rustle of leaves to find sturdy oaks or elms. He tests the bark with a gentle tap, judging its thickness and maturity. He circles the trunk, feeling for ridges and loose panels. He judges the trunk’s diameter, seeking trees at least a foot wide. He notes any scarred or damaged areas to avoid thin or brittle surfaces. Once a suitable tree stands before him, he marks its base by carefully stacking small stones.

He selects a branch and rests it on a rock. Holding the tool, he positions the blade at the top edge of the outer layer. He plants his hand on the wood, thumb pressed beside the cut to gauge bark thickness. With a controlled tug, he slices beneath the surface, keeping the blade angled slightly outward. The outer layer peels off in sections, curling away under the knife’s pull. Rotating the wood, he works his way along the length, adjusting pressure when he encounters knots or rough spots. He tilts the blade to slide around irregularities, ensuring removal of the covering. Soon the pale core stands exposed, ready for shaping.

He lifts a section of its fibrous material from his gathered wood. Resting it across his knee, he grips one end and lays a sharp-edged flake at the center, pressing firmly. He draws the tool along the length of the material, following the natural grain. A thin layer peels away, revealing clean fibers beneath. He repeats the action at regular intervals, making parallel cuts down the length. Each segment peels free easily, yielding even widths. He collects these pieces for weaving or wrapping, saving them for later use.

flax stalk.name: flax stalk
flax stalk.description: The plant rises straight from the ground, its slender stems like pale spearshafts. Smooth and unbranched, each strand bears tiny, starlike blossoms of pale blue, petals fanning softly. Leaves lance-shaped, narrow, and arranged evenly along the shaft, they glint faintly in the sun. When the wind blows, these stalks sway together like whispered voices, forming a hushed ripple across the field at dawn. They stand nearly as tall as a man.

steps.description: He walks across the gentle slope, eyes scanning patches of damp, sunlit soil. He seeks slender green stems topped with tiny pale blue blooms. He notes their height swaying in the breeze among low grasses. When he spies the plants clustered near moist edges of streams, he crouches, parts surrounding grasses, and inspects the fibrous stems. Satisfied he’s found the right plants, he readies his tool to harvest them.

He gathers fresh flax plants at dawn. He grasps the slender bundle at its base and uses a sharp flint blade to sever each stem just above the root knot. He loosens the earth by stamping gently around the base, then pulls the remaining plant clear from the dirt. He shakes the cut piece to dislodge clinging soil and small stones. He lines them up on a split wood plank and snaps away leafy sections. He repeats along the row, stacking trimmed stems in a neat pile, preparing them for drying.

plant.name: plant
plant.description: It rises from soil as a slender green stalk, splitting into pairs of smooth, oval leaves. Each leaf breathes with a faint shimmer in sunlight, its surface a vivid chartreuse. From the base, thin tendrils thread into damp earth, anchoring the whole. Tiny buds form along the stem’s tip, opening to soft petals of pale color, their subtle pattern flickering in the breeze. The growth stands against rough stones and wind.

plant fibers.name: plant fibers
plant fibers.description: Thin, flexible strands hang from branches and stems, twisting loosely in the breeze. Their surfaces reveal fine ridges and tiny, silky hairs that glint in the sun. Bundles of these pale, intertwined threads cluster near bark crevices and along riverbanks, drifting into tangled mats on the moist earth. When they are pulled, they stretch slightly before springing back to their original shape. Their frayed edges release even finer, wispy filaments that float gently on the wind.

steps.description: A primitive human enters a patch of flax at sunrise. He clasps a handful of stalks near their base and tugs gently, pulling the plants from the earth to preserve their length. He shakes off clinging soil before stacking the stems on a mat. Once he gathers a dozen or more, he ties them into loose bundles using a thin cord. He stands the sheaves upright to dry in the sun. After several days, the stalks become brittle and ready for the next step in transforming them into useful cordage.

At dawn, the gatherer carefully selects bundles of flax stalks and carries them to a shallow pit near the riverbank. They slowly fill the hollow with fresh water, stirring with a wooden stick to remove debris. The worker lowers the bundles into the cool water, pressing them down under flat stones. Each stalk soaks fully, its tough outer layer softening in the steady warmth. Over the next few days, the water turns murky as material separates. The gatherer checks the bath daily, skimming scum and adding fresh water if needed. When the flax stems yield easily under pressure, the soak is complete, ready for the next step in crafting thread.

The gatherer carries soaked strands to a fresh, clear stream. He wades into the water and forms a wide coil in his hands. He lowers the bundle beneath the current, pressing gently to release bits of debris. He lifts and drops the strands, watching the water swirl away loose matter. After several turns, the liquid runs clear. He spreads the damp strands over a flat stone, letting excess drops fall away. Then he carries the rinsed coil to dry beneath the sun. Each movement is slow, careful, ensuring purity.

A person gathers tall stalks and trims off leaves. Using a sharp stone blade, they split each stalk lengthwise and peel away the outer layer. With hands and a wooden comb, they tease apart the inner strands, shaking away loose debris. They soak the strands in clear water for hours, then lift them out and squeeze them by hand to drain excess moisture. Next, they drape the strands across smooth rocks or branches under the sun. After hours of warm air, gentle breeze makes the strands crisp and ready for weaving.

The primitive human divides a flax stalk bundle into smaller handfuls. He lays each batch across a stone and pounds it firmly with a wooden mallet, cracking the brittle outer hulls. Next, he scrapes along the stalks with a flat wooden paddle, removing husks and shattered pieces. He then grips the loosened filaments and pulls steadily, drawing out the fine strands and discarding coarse fragments. He repeats this scraping and pulling until only smooth, aligned strands remain. Finally, he combs the yield with a bone comb, eliminating leftover debris before spinning.

flax.name: flax
flax.description: Slender stalks rise from the earth in clusters, their tall stems tinted with a cool, dull green. Along each stalk, thin lance-shaped leaves taper gently towards pointed tips. Tiny, cup-shaped blossoms of delicate pale sky blue emerge near the top, each flower sporting five narrow petals around a central gold spot. As the blossoms fade, small oval seed cases form in a tight cluster, their hard shells promising hidden round kernels within.

anvil.name: anvil
anvil.description: A squat, dense block of gleaming dark material rests firmly on the earth. One end extends into a sharp, curved horn, the opposite side a blunter edge. Its broad top surface is flat and polished, catching stray beams of light. The heavy form appears unnaturally still, its cool metal skin faintly ringing when tapped. Though its outline is simple, the object exudes solid permanence, standing apart from the forest’s chaos.

steps.description: A primitive maker walks across rocky ground, scanning for a broad, smooth surface that can bear heavy hammering. They crouch beside riverbeds, running hands over slabs, tapping them with a smaller rock to hear a clear ring. They seek a dense piece with minimal cracks, favoring stones with a flat top and sturdy shape. They brush off dust and debris, flipping the stone to find the most even face. When satisfied, they mark the spot, then wedge smaller stones beneath to steady it before shaping metal objects atop the platform.

The artisan lifts a stout hammerstone, positions the raw block on a ground surface. The artisan crouches for stability before a strike. They strike the surface at a low angle, focusing on weak points. Sharp flakes break away, revealing a fresh face. The maker rotates the block, identifying unwanted protrusions, and delivers measured blows to detach excess material. Each impact chips off small fragments, gradually flattening and shaping the surface. The artisan inspects the progress, brushing aside debris, then repeats the cycle. With rhythmic strikes, the rough mass transforms into a stable form suitable for heavy work. When the face reaches a smooth, even plane, the removal phase is complete.

water.name: water
water.description: A clear, shapeless fluid gathers in hollowed stones and trickles down rocky inclines. It glints in sunlight, forming shifting ripples and tiny waves. When it flows, it sings soft murmurs over pebbles. In deep pools, it mirrors sky and clouds, sparkling with flecks of light. Touching it feels cool against warm skin, and its form bends around every crevice, always renewing and slipping away the moment you try to hold it.

bark.name: bark
bark.description: Outside of tall standing giants lies a thick, weathered protective skin. It feels coarse and knotted, with deep grooves running up and down the trunk. Color shifts from pale gray patches to darker brown ridges, sometimes peeling in thin strips. Its surface holds tiny cracks filled with dust and moss, while edges curl away in places. To the touch it is hard and uneven, offering firm resistance beneath the fingers.

steps.description: He stands in the forest, eyes scanning the trunks of towering giants. He grips a stone tool at his waist, listening for the dull thud of sturdy wood. He approaches each tree, running his fingers over its rough outer layer to test for flexibility. He selects the straightest trunk, examining age rings and knot patterns. Satisfied by its smooth skin, he signals and marks the chosen specimen for harvesting.

A primitive gatherer grips a sturdy tree trunk that stands upright. With a sharp flint blade, he scores deep around the circumference. He wedges the edge under the fibrous skin, prying upward with force. His strong arms pull strips away, revealing pale wood beneath. He follows each cut, moving the blade in controlled strokes to avoid knots. Debris falls at his feet as the outer layer peels off in long, curling strips. He repeats this along the length until the log lies smooth, ready for shaping into tools or fuel.

tree.name: tree
tree.description: An immense living pillar rises from the earth, its thick, rough skin cracked in spiraling patterns. Its solid base sinks deep into the ground, anchoring it firmly. From the top, dozens of slender arms extend outward, each adorned with clusters of broad, flat green blades that tremble softly in the breeze. The whole structure sways gently, whispering rustling sounds. Its shadow stretches long, altering the light and shape around it.

tree trunk.name: tree trunk
tree trunk.description: An ancient, sturdy pillar of living wood rises above the forest floor, its bark rugged and deeply grooved. Broad roots extend outward, gripping the earth like strong limbs. Sunlight filters through high branches, casting flickering shadows across its weathered surface. Patches of moss and lichen cling to cracks and crevices, adding hints of green and gray. The wood feels cool and solid, its grain spiraling upward in tight, growth-worn rings.

steps.description: He scans the forest edge, eyes sweeping over tall, straight timber. He moves toward sturdy specimens with thick bark and even branches. He tests the base by tapping, listening for a dull, solid sound. He frowns at knots that may cause weakness and avoids leaning or damaged growth, seeking a lone sentinel standing firm on level ground. He notes accessible roots and clear space for felling. Once satisfied, he marks his chosen wood with chalky clay.

He stands before a towering tree, animal hide draped across broad shoulders. He inspects the base for rot, then plants feet in a firm stance. He grips the axe handle with both hands, raising it overhead. He swings in measured arcs, driving the blade deep into fibers at a forty-five-degree angle. Wood chips scatter across the forest floor. He shifts to the opposite side, repeating strokes to create a wedge. Dust drifts as the cut widens. Finally, the giant leans and tilts, then crashes to earth with a thunderous roar, branches quaking. He leaps back, ensuring a clear zone. The fallen column lies ready for splitting and shaping.

The human first selects a fallen log. He rests the base on uneven ground to prevent slipping. With a knife, he grips the handle firmly and positions the blade at the junction between a branch and the main section. He applies pressure near the wood fibers, sawing back and forth in short strokes. Each motion cuts deeper into the grain until the branch loosens. He repeats the sawing on the opposite side, widening the cut steadily. When the wood around the branch becomes thin, he scores a final shallow notch and twists the wood until it snaps away cleanly. He smooths the exposed area with light strokes, removing splinters.

hand axe.name: hand axe
hand axe.description: A roughly oval, pillow-sized chunk of cold dark grey stone sits balanced between two slightly curved wooden branches, gripped by a snug leather wrap. Its surface reveals dozens of fine, whorl-like flake scars, converging along a straight, razor-dusting edge. The opposite end is rounded, polished smooth from constant friction against ground and palm sweat. Tiny mineral flecks catch slivers of distant sunlight, casting subtle glimmers across its rugged form.

steps.description: At sunrise, I move along the riverbank, scanning the gravel bars for hard nodules. I bend over to pick up a smooth rock and tap it against another to hear a clear ring. I wade deeper where currents reveal hidden stones beneath sand. I examine each candidate, feeling its weight and inspecting for sharp edges or faults. When I find a firm, fine-grained flake, I tuck it into my pouch.

A maker selects a suitable stone core with a fine-grained surface and holds it firmly in one hand. The maker picks up a hammerstone, gripping it near the end to maximize force. With measured effort, the maker raises the hammerstone above shoulder height and strikes the core’s edge at an angle. Each impact detaches a sharp-edged flake from the core. After each strike, the maker inspects the flake and adjusts angle and position as needed. The maker repeats this process, removing successive flakes to shape a robust tool with a symmetrical cutting edge. Finally, the maker tests the edge against fibrous material to confirm its effectiveness before finishing.

A prehistoric craftsman holds a roughly shaped quartzite chunk in the left hand, supported by the knee or an anvil stone. In the right hand, he grips a pebble hammerstone. He positions a delicate edge to align with the striking platform and then delivers controlled, low-angle blows near the edge, detaching tiny flakes. Each percussion focuses on cleaning irregularities and sharpening the cutting surface. He rotates the implement, retouching both faces gradually from one end to the other. The rhythmic taps produce a jagged, bifacial ridge that enhances its slicing efficiency. As he works, he examines the edge’s profile and repeats the process until the edge is consistently sharp.

flax plant.name: flax plant
flax plant.description: A tall, slender-stemmed green plant emerges from thin, straight stalks crowned by clusters of delicate sky-blue blossoms. Each blossom’s five narrow petals open in morning light, revealing a pale yellow center. Beneath the blooms, smooth lance-shaped leaves grow alternately along the stem. As flowers fade, small round pods form, their surface marked by faint ridges. Inside this husk, tiny brown seeds cluster tightly, glimmering when sunlight filters through the foliage.

plant stalks.name: plant stalks
plant stalks.description: Long, slender columns rise straight from the earth in rows or clusters, each capped with broad, flaring leaves or buds. Their surfaces feel smooth yet fibrous, tinged in lively greens that brighten under the warm sun. When the wind stirs, they sway in unison, whispering soft, hollow murmurs. Their bases are thicker and often wrapped with dried layers, while their tips reach upward, seeking light against the sky.

steps.description: Morning light splashes across the forest edge. A hunter-gatherer crouches low, eyes scanning the underbrush for tall, straight stems with broad leaves. He moves slowly, listening for rustling wind that reveals sturdy shoots. Fingers brush mossy logs as he steps, following rich soil and nearby water. He narrows his gaze on green clusters reaching upward, noting their smooth, firm texture. He reaches out and grasps the firm stem.

At dawn, the gatherer moves through dew-laced grass, scanning for rigid, hollow shoots near the riverbank. With a sharpened flint blade, they cut each sturdy rod at its base, careful not to crush the fibers. They strip away the lower leaves and use their teeth to trim rough ends. Bundling ten to twenty lengths, they tie them with vines, forming sheaves. The gatherer shoulders each package and carries it to camp, arranging the shafts upright by the hearth where they dry in smoky air, ready for weaving into tools and shelters.

A gatherer kneels beside cut stems and grips the base of each leafy shoot. Fingers pin the main stem just above the first pair of leaves, pulling toward the tip. Leaves snap off cleanly and flutter to the ground. The gatherer moves up the stem, sliding thumb and forefinger along, stripping each blade. Discarded leaves form a compost pile. After several stems, the stripped shafts stand ready for drying before further shaping. They leave the stripped stems in sun to cure for several hours. Sunlight glints off the smooth cores.

retoucher.name: retoucher
retoucher.description: A small, flat slab of smooth dark stone, perfectly rectangular with sharp right angles. One face gleams like still water under a pale sun, edges framed by a thin strip of shining metal. Along one long side, tiny raised circles line up in a precise row. When held, it feels cold and weighty in the palm. Occasionally, faint flickers of mysterious shifting shapes dance beneath its smooth, glassy surface.

steps.description: He scans the river bend at dawn for stone, eyes tracking every pebble and rock. He kneels by the water’s edge, feeling the current. He lifts gray nodules from the gravel, rolling each between his palms to sense sharpness and hardness. He taps one gently against another, listening for a clear ring that signals flint. Testing the weight in his hand, he seeks a balance between heft and control. He watches the sun glint on faces, marking promising seams. When he finds a chunk, he sets it aside for shaping.

A primitive craftsman selects a fine-grained stone nodule and secures it in his hand. He strikes it with a harder rock to produce a thin flake, then precisely chips at one edge to form a slender, pointed tip. Holding the flake against a rough stone, he applies focused pressure to detach small spalls, rotating the piece to refine each side. He alternately grinds the tip and polishes its surface against sandstone. Through repeated shaping and smoothing, he forms a strong, compact point ideal for inscribing designs, piercing hides, or scraping wood.

tin ore.name: tin ore
tin ore.description: A rocky outcrop holds patches of dull grey stone, its surface speckled with bright, silvery veins that gleam in flickering firelight. Each fragment feels surprisingly heavy in the hand, its weight hinting at an inner density. Sharp-edged chips break from larger lumps, revealing a softer metallic gleam beneath the weathered crust. The color varies from matte slate to polished silver, catching stray rays and glinting with a steady, muted sheen.

linen tablecloth.name: linen tablecloth
linen tablecloth.description: Before you lies a broad, rectangular sheet of pale, off-white fibers, woven so tightly that each strand nestles against its neighbor in perfect, uniform rows. The surface feels cool and smooth under your fingers, with a faint gleam in sunlight. The edges appear neatly trimmed in straight lines, while the whole expanse drapes and folds fluidly, as if it were a silent, wind-rippled meadow frozen in motion, yet utterly delicate.

steps.description: A primitive human begins by turning over a plot of fertile soil, removing stones and weeds with a simple wooden hoe. They rub flax seeds between their fingers, then drop each seed into shallow furrows spaced a few inches apart. After sowing, they cover the seeds with loose earth, pressing gently with their feet to ensure good contact. They stand back and watch the ground for spring rains, occasionally sweeping away competing weeds around emerging shoots. This careful process ensures strong, straight fibers for later spinning and weaving.

He wades barefoot into the field at dawn, seeking golden stalks of flax swaying in the breeze. He grasps bundles, pulling each stem gently from the soil, roots loosening with a tug.
