He cuts stalks near the base with a sharpened stone blade, stacking slender fibers in woven baskets. His fingers stain yellow with fibers. Sweat beads on his brow while he carries the load to a shaded clearing. There he arranges the stalks in neat piles, ready for drying under the sun. The air fills with a sweet, earthy scent.

The human gathers bundles of flax stalks and submerges them in a slow-moving river or freshwater vat. The stalks remain underwater for days or weeks. The water’s gentle turbulence accelerates the breakdown without damaging the delicate threads. Bacteria break down the pectins, loosening fiber bundles from the woody stem. The primitive maker stirs the water daily, checks the stalks for softness, and ensures even exposure. When the fibers slip easily, they remove the bundles, rinse them in clear water, and lay them on clean grass to dry. After returning to the workshop, they beat and crush the dried stalks with wooden mallets, separating straw from the long, smooth fibers. These fibers become ready for further processing.

A primitive artisan spreads dew-retted stalks across flat stones or woven mats in full sun. They shake the bundles to open the stems and expose the inner fibers. The wind lifts moisture as the artisan carefully turns each cluster, ensuring even exposure. They watch the fibers change from damp green to pale gold, feeling dryness beneath their fingertips. When stems crack easily between thumb and forefinger, the artisan gathers them for the next step. This sun-and-breeze method removes lingering moisture, preparing supple fibers that will later be spun into strong, fine threads.

In the morning light, a primitive weaver stands before a flax brake anchored on an ancient sturdy stump. She gathers a small handful of tough flax stems and places them between two wooden slats. Gripping the handles, she clamps the device with measured force, cracking the outer bark. Releasing with a snap, she shakes and flips the bundle to expose remaining woody shards. She repeats the crushing motion, breaking down each stalk until soft white fibers peek through. Working in batches, she frees long, lustrous strands from the broken stems. After processing the harvest, she joins the next stage—cleaning and combing the fibers—to prepare them for spinning into fine yarn.

A solitary worker gathers soaked stalks of flax by a wooden post. She grips a stout flax brake and positions a handful of stalks between its wooden blades. She draws the brake’s arm, crashing the stalks to splinter the brittle outer stem. She repeats this motion, breaking the stalk into shorter lengths. Then she shifts to scutching. She lays the broken fibers across a sloping board and holds them firmly against its edge. With a sharp knife, she scrapes down along the board, letting the blade strike the wood. Each stroke knocks loose the coarse shives. Her bare hands feel each strand, gauging its readiness. She lifts the fibers, shakes out debris, and repeats until the slender, soft strands lie clean and straight. She gathers these fine fibers, ready for spinning.

A primitive human sits at a simple bench, dividing the dried stalks, then draws handfuls of flax through a hackling comb. They hold the fibers taut and press the iron teeth into the locks, pulling downward in a steady motion. With each pass, the short fibers and chaff entangle in the comb’s gaps, while the long strands slip free, smoothing and aligning. The person rotates the comb’s spine on a support beam or benchrest to secure it. After several strokes, the fiber gleams. They then shift to a finer-toothed comb, repeating the motions until the tow is removed and a soft, even bundle of long fibers remains, ready for spinning.

First, the person prepares flax fiber by breaking and scutching the stems, then combing out strands. They seat themselves on a low stone, balancing a wooden spindle. Holding a handful of fibers, they tie a few strands to the spindle’s whorl. With one hand they spin the spindle, giving it a gentle twist. The wheel darts upward, and the fiber twists into a fine thread. They guide the draft by pulling lightly on the fibers held between thumb and forefinger, maintaining even tension. Once a length of yarn forms, they wrap it around the spindle shaft below the whorl. They repeat this process until they gather enough thread for weaving.

In a simple shelter, a weaver sits before a wooden loom. She takes bundles of fine flax yarn and carefully threads them evenly through the warp beam, tensioning them across the frame. With practiced hands, she passes the shuttle carrying weft strands back and forth between the upright warp threads. Her foot pedals lift alternating warp threads, creating a clear shed for the shuttle to glide smoothly. She then beats each new weft line against the emerging fabric edge with a wooden beater, ensuring tight interlacing. Over hours, the cloth grows inch by inch. As she works, her motions remain steady and rhythmic, forging durable cloth from slender flax fibers.

He gathers a bundle of woven cloth and carries it to the riverbank. He dips it repeatedly, submerging the fibers in clear water. He unfolds the damp fabric and kneads it between his fingers, squeezing out dust and debris. He lifts the cloth, letting water drip back into the current. He rinses again, slapping the folds against a flat stone, driving out grit. He wrings the fabric tight, twisting it until only a few droplets remain. Finally, he spreads the clean cloth over a sunlit rock to dry under the open sky.

loom.name: loom
loom.description: A broad wooden frame stands with two parallel beams supported by sturdy posts driven into the earth. Crossbars brace the side posts, forming a rectangle nearly as tall as a person. A series of taut cords stretch between the top and bottom beams in evenly spaced rows, fibers glinting in sunlight. A long beam lies across the front, linked by wooden pegs and notches, its surface worn smooth by motion.

steps.description: He moves into the forest and searches for straight, sturdy trunks. Using an axe, he chooses long, slender branches with knots. He lifts each branch to test its weight and balance. Once he finds a suitable limb, he swings the axe at its base, cutting through the grain with strokes. He repeats this until four beams lie on the forest floor. Next, he trims small branches and smooths patches. He cuts the beams to equal lengths and taps away loose bark. He observes the grain direction before striking to prevent splitting beyond the desired length. Finally, he gathers them in a bundle, ready to build the supporting framework for weaving.

First, the maker selects a straight-grained board. He scores layout lines with a sharp point and places the chisel at each mark. He grips the handle firmly and pushes the blade to pare away thin shavings, guiding it along the line. With repeated strokes, the craftsman deepens recesses for joinery. He removes excess material to form tenons and shoulders, checking each face with a simple square. He refines the profile of each piece, smoothing rough surfaces with careful paring. He chips away stray fibers and rounds corners for a snug fit. He inspects each part under daylight, ensuring uniform thickness and clean edges. Each piece now sits ready for assembly.

A primitive human arranges four wooden poles into a simple rectangle. They strip plant fibers from reeds or grasses, soak them to soften, and twist into sturdy cords. At each corner, they wrap the cord tightly around the crossing poles, looping several times and pulling the fibers taut. They run diagonal lashes in an X-pattern for added strength and tie a square knot to lock each binding. After completing all corners, they adjust angles to keep right angles and trim excess fiber close to the knots to prevent fraying and tidy the joints.

flax yarn.name: flax yarn
flax yarn.description: Thin, gleaming strands of pale straw emerge from bundled fibers, each one twisting gently like slender vines. They feel smooth and flexible beneath calloused fingers, their hue shifting between silvery beige and soft gold under sunlight. The fibers reflect light with a subtle sheen, swaying softly in a breeze as if alive. They cling together in delicate filaments, faintly earthy-scented, offering a supple, resilient texture that beckons exploration.

steps.description: A man moves through a sunlit field of flax, eyes scanning slender green stalks. He grips each plant close to the earth with one hand and tugs gently yet firmly, pulling roots and all from the soil. Soil flicks free as he shakes each stem, then he sorts the longest, straightest stalks into tight bundles. Wrapping a vine strip around the center, he ties the bunch with a simple knot. He lays the bundles in neat rows on dry grass, leaving them to rest in the morning dew and sun exposure.

A primitive weaver harvests long flax stalks. She bundles them and immerses the stalks in a slow-moving stream or a wooden vat filled with warm water. The stalks remain submerged for up to a week, allowing bacteria and moisture to loosen the plant’s bark and separate the fibrous strands. She stirs the bundles daily. She watches the water turn tea-colored, signs that retting progresses. When the outer tissues feel soft and the inner fibers slip easily, she lifts the bundles, rinses them in fresh water, then spreads them to air-dry in the sun. This retting step readies the fibers for breaking and heckling, preparing them for spinning into fine threads.

A primitive artisan harvests mature flax stalks and lays them on sun-baked stones under the open sky, turning the bundles daily until the stems become crisp and brittle. They then use a wooden flail to break the dried stalks, loosening the outer shives. Next, they scutch with a flat blade to strip away the woody bits, revealing soft pale fibers beneath. The freed filaments undergo further cleaning by drawing small tufts through a wooden comb. Finally, the spinner draws and twists the slender strands on a simple spindle, forming continuous linen thread.

He stands at a flat rock and arranges harvested stalks in small bundles. Grasping each bundle around the middle, he lifts it and brings it down hard onto the rock’s surface. With his hammerstone he taps along the length, moving from one end to the other, crushing the woody core. He repeats the action, shifting the bundle’s position to ensure even pressure. Fibrous strands loosen from the brittle inner core as he breaks the stalk. He unfolds the broken pieces and inspects for remaining hard bits, using the hammerstone’s blunt edge to crush any stubborn fragments. When the stalks feel soft and pliable, he sets them aside for further cleaning.

A primitive human sets bundles of flax straw against a wooden bench. She holds a handful upright and draws a scraper along the lengths. The blade bites pulp and shives, breaking them free from the long fibers. She repeatedly strikes each stalk, rotating the bundle to reach every side. The broken woody fragments fall away, leaving smoother fiber beneath. After several strokes, she feels the fiber slip past the tool. She taps bits with her hand, then arranges clean bundles for drying. She repeats the action until each stalk looks smooth and white, collecting shives at her feet. The process yields long strands ready for spinning into thread.

He kneels by embers, warming his wooden board, then spreads the flax fiber across its surface and uses two coarse combs carved from bone. He places one comb at the fiber’s end and presses the tines deeply. He holds the second comb above the first and draws it through the fiber, teasing out tangles. He repeats this motion, moving steadily toward the tips. Short fibers remain caught in the comb teeth and fall away. Long strands align into smooth bundles. He rolls the prepared fibers into a thin roving ready for spinning.

He aligns handfuls of long flax fibers on a distaff held secure at his waist. With his thumb and forefinger, he teases out a tug, pulling slender slivers from the bundle. The loose threads gather on his palm as he sets a spindle spinning. He guides the fiber toward the whirling shaft, allowing the turning motion to twist the strands tightly. He coaxes the emerging spiral downward onto the spindle’s shaft, winding each fresh turn neatly. He continues drafting and twisting until he builds a length of strong, even thread.

flax stalks.name: flax stalks
flax stalks.description: In gentle fields, slender pale-green stalks rise a foot or more, each topped by a small, open blossom of sky-blue petals. Narrow leaves sprout in opposite pairs along the smooth, wiry stems, which stand stiff yet sway in light breezes. Below the blooms, tiny round pods form, clustering close to the stalk, each containing several hard, glossy seeds. The overall image is one of delicate elegance against the meadow’s green expanse.

steps.description: He scans low hills and damp fields for slender green stems crowned with tiny golden seeds. His eyes note the soft pale fibers shining in the morning light. He crouches among the dew, brushing soil from the base of each stem. With a firm grip he tugs gently but firmly, uprooting each plant by its roots. He bundles the collected stems, ready to carry them back to his hearth.

He squats beside the field, grasps a handful of tall slender plants, pressing them with one hand near the ground. With his other hand, he wields a small flint knife, guiding the blade in a swift horizontal motion. The edge bites through the fibrous stems, severing them close to the soil. He repeats the cut along the row, moving his hand in a steady rhythm. Each snip frees a bundle that he shifts to his side. When he fills his arms, he ties the stems into sheaves. He stands, resting the knife against his hip, and surveys the line of trimmed stems waiting for the next step. He breathes slowly.

He moves through a swaying field, his bare feet pressing into soft soil. He scans the gently ripening plants until he finds stout, tall stems ready for harvest. Bending close, he grips a small bundle at ground level and snaps them clean with practiced force. He repeats this, gathering a handful at a time, stacking the stems beside him. When his armful is full, he carefully ties them together with a thin strand plucked from earlier cutting. Once bound, the sheaf stands upright, waiting for the next stage of processing.

hackling comb.name: hackling comb
hackling comb.description: You discover a flat slab of aged wood, its surface worn smooth by time. Driven into its length are dozens of gleaming pins—thin, stiff, and evenly spaced. The steel points rise in regimented rows, catching sunlight and reflecting tiny sparks. Each slender spike tapers to a fine tip, standing upright like a miniature forest of metal. The wood beneath is darkened with wear, the whole object exuding a quiet, strange precision.

steps.description: A lone craftsman wanders at dawn into woodland, scanning for a straight, sturdy trunk. He raises an axe, grips its handle, and positions the blade at the base of a small tree. He leans his weight behind each blow, chips of bark flying free. The tree loosens from the earth with a crack, and he drags the fallen length to a clear patch. He trims away irregular limbs, using angled blows to shave bark and smooth the surface. He cuts a section of trunk into a manageable piece and lays it on a flat stone. He then splits the log, prising out a long, narrow wood block ready for shaping.

First, the primitive human selects a sturdy branch of straight-grained wood near the riverbank. He places it on a flat stone platform and raises his axe. With measured, sweeping swings, he strips away bark and irregular limbs, exposing the pale core. He holds the wood firmly against his thigh and brings the axe edge down its length, shaving thin curls to achieve a rectangular profile. He pauses frequently to inspect symmetry and correct deviations, adjusting shallow gouges in long, controlled strokes. Next, he trims one end to form a square shoulder, then slices off excess until both faces are flat and parallel. Finally, he smooths all edges with a river-worn pebble, removing rough splinters.

He begins by heating a small lump of copper until it glows hot in the embers. He lifts it with tongs and lays it on a flat stone anvil. With a rounded hammerstone, he taps the metal’s surface, gradually flattening it into a long, narrow strip. Once the sheet reaches the right thickness, he lays it flat again and positions a sharp chisel along one edge. He grips the chisel firmly and, using the hammerstone, strikes its head to drive the blade into the copper. He repeats this strike-and-advance routine, carving out a succession of evenly spaced grooves. Each blow gouges a tiny notch, and each notch becomes one cutting point. As the line of notches grows, he pauses to straighten any blades that bend, reheating the copper if it cools too much. Finally, he brushes away stray filings, smooths each tooth edge with gentle taps, and inspects the row of prongs for uniform depth and spacing.

A primitive artisan holds the rough wooden frame in one hand and glides an abrasive stone across each tooth. He presses firmly, moving the block back and forth to shave away splinters and uneven ridges. With steady strokes, he turns the stone’s finer side, refining the points until they look uniform. He inspects each projection with careful eyes, smoothing away tiny burrs. Finally, he wipes the dust with a piece of cloth, revealing a polished surface ready for use. The entire process transforms a crude tool into a precise implement.

spindle.name: spindle
spindle.description: A long slender handcrafted shaft of polished wood stands balanced on one pointed end. Midway along its length a heavy, simple circular stone disk is bound tight, its surface worn smooth by repeated turning. The opposite tip tapers to a fine point, allowing the shaft to spin freely when flicked between fingers. Its sides bear faint grooves and striations, evidence of careful carving and constant motion around a central axis.

steps.description: A primitive human moves through the forest margin, scanning fallen branches for a straight piece of wood. He tests each branch by bending and snapping small twigs, seeking strong fibers. When he finds a suitable limb, he snaps it close to its base and carries it back to camp. Then he searches along riverbeds for smooth stones with flat faces. He turns over rocks, listening for a dense, solid sound. He touches surfaces to find ones free of cracks. He gathers several stones that feel heavy and unbroken, knowing they will serve as carving tools. He arranges the wood and stones beside his work area. He selects undamaged bark sections for shaping.

He selects a straight limb of hardwood and secures it between his knees on a flat stone. He grips the crude chisel in his right hand and taps its back gently with a sturdy stick to drive the blade into the wood. Starting near one end, he carves away small curls of bark and sapwood, slowly turning the limb to remove irregularities. With each cut, he checks alignment, aiming for an even taper. He hollows the center slightly along its length, ensuring a firm yet slender form. His motions are deliberate and rhythmic, using the chisel’s edge to refine the curve until the length feels balanced and smooth to touch.

A lone artisan selects a firm, rounded piece of river stone and holds it steady on a slab. With a sharper flint shard, she begins to chip away uneven edges, tapping gently to carve a flat face on each side. She turns the stone in her palm, inspecting its balance, then grinds its surface against a coarse sandstone slab to smooth rough spots. When the shape becomes a near-perfect disc with a slight central depression, she drills a shallow hole through the center using a pointed bone awl and steady pressure. The finished weight hangs true and spins evenly.

One kneels by the work surface and places a flat, circular stone on a smooth rock. He mixes coarse sand with water in a shallow bowl to create an abrasive slurry. He positions the tip of the hand drill at the center mark and grips the wooden shaft firmly. He begins to rotate the shaft between both palms, applying consistent downward pressure. The sand-and-water mixture gathers at the drilling site, its rough particles grinding away the stone. He pauses occasionally to sprinkle fresh sand and water, keeping the cutting edge sharp and cool. He watches the developing bore, ensuring it remains centered. The rhythmic twisting continues until the bit breaks through both faces. He clears the debris, then smooths the inner edges with wet sand. The hole stands perfectly round and ready.

First, the maker holds a smooth wooden shaft upright in one hand. In the other, they grip a flat, disk-shaped whorl carved from bone or stone. They slide the whorl’s central hole over the lower end of the shaft. With gentle taps using a pebble, they seat the whorl snugly against a carved notch. Finally, they wrap a bit of sinew around the joint to secure the whorl firmly in place.

He stands by a fire and gathers a straight piece of hardwood branch about the thickness of his thumb. He carefully trims off twigs, then holds the wood against the palm. With a knife, he shaves away bark fibers, slicing long thin curls. He turns the wood in his hand and carves off uneven bits, drawing the blade toward himself in smooth strokes. He rounds the form into a near-uniform cylinder, focusing on balancing both ends. At one extremity he carves a gentle taper, pushing the blade away to form a point. He smooths the surface with finer cuts, testing the straightness by rolling it on a flat stone.

scutching board.name: scutching board
scutching board.description: A roughly rectangular plank of pale wood lies half-hidden in the grass. It measures about a forearm’s length and a hand’s width, the edges hewn but smoothed by skilled hands. On its upper side rise four shallow ridges, each crowned with jagged, hardened flakes that catch the sunlight. The wood’s grain swirls around these raised lines like river currents. Notches scar its surface near the ends, carved by careful fingers.

steps.description: He wields a curved blade in his right hand, walking along the narrow field of tall flax stalks. He patiently bows at the waist, gripping a handful of stems near the base, and slices through the cluster with a swift downward motion. The slender fibers fall free from the earth, their pale threads shimmering in the sun. He moves steadily row by row, stacking each bundle with care. Between swings he straightens, wiping sweat from his brow, then returns to the stems. When the field yields enough bundles, he ties them with a strip of leather, then carefully sets them aside in a shaded spot to dry before the next step.

A primitive human grips a sturdy plank of wood, its grain running lengthwise. They lift a sharp axe, its blade glinting in dawn light. They plant feet firmly, raise the axe, and bring it down with force, biting into the wood. Chips fly as they pare away rough bark and high spots. They circle the plank, striking each edge to square it. They tilt the blade and slice thin shavings off the surface, smoothing deep gouges. With measured swings, they flatten the face, lines straightening under each blow. Sweat beads on their brow as they rotate the timber, hewing it to an even thickness. The board begins to take shape.

First, the artisan chooses a sturdy log with straight grain. He places the timber upright on a flat stone. He grasps his axe with firm hands and raises it overhead. He aims at the center of the end grain and brings the axe down with a solid blow. The iron blade sinks into the wood’s fibers, splitting the section into two halves. He repeats the strike along the length of each piece, following the natural lines of the grain. When the halves open, he inserts the blade at new points, widening the gap until the timber separates cleanly. He sets aside the halves for further shaping. He checks the grain for weaknesses.

He rubs an abrasive stone back and forth across the wooden plank, applying steady pressure. He moves the stone in long strokes along the grain, lifting it rhythmically to avoid uneven spots. He shifts to finer areas of the board, using a sharper edge to target grooves or ridges. With each pass, he feels the surface becoming less rough, checking by running his fingertips along the length. When deeper cuts smooth out and the wood shimmers in daylight, he ends with circular motions, ensuring the plank is uniformly sleek.

He selects a sturdy slab of oak that he has felled from a nearby grove. He places it on a low stump, securing it with one knee. He grips a chisel made of sharpened iron and lays its blade against the wood surface. He positions his free hand on the opposite side to steady the block. He raises a wooden mallet and strikes the chisel’s haft with force. The blade slices into the grain, removing thin chips of wood. He moves the tool along marked guidelines, angling it to hollow out shallow grooves. He repeats each blow, checking his progress until he achieves smooth, even channels across the plank’s surface.

flax fiber.name: flax fiber
flax fiber.description: Long, slender strands hang from tall stalks swaying in the breeze across open meadows. Each stalk holds clusters of delicate seedpods that split to reveal silky, pale-golden threads catching sunlight like the first light of dawn. They feel slightly coarse to the touch yet yield under pressure, exposing fine ribbons that glisten faintly. Gathered in loose bundles, these elongated fibrous ribbons hiss softly as they brush past each other in wind.

steps.description: The gatherer moves through the field at dawn, tall green stalks swaying in the breeze. With a sharpened stone blade, she slices each stem close to the earth, letting bundles fall into her waiting arms. She ties groups of ten stalks with a strip of birch bark, forming small sheaves. These sheaves rest beside her as she clears the next row, working methodically until the ground stands bare of standing plants. Once finished, she loads the bundles onto a wooden rack and carries them to a sunlit clearing, ready for the next step.

First, the gatherer cuts the harvested flax stalks, removes the leaves, and sorts them into bundles. He submerges the bundles in a shallow pit of standing water or places them in a slow-moving brook. Over days the stalk skins break down as microbes feed on pectins, loosening the inner threads from the outer woody core. The worker checks the bundles daily, pressing a few strands between thumbs to test slippage. When the fibers slip free of the rind with a gentle pull, he lifts the bundles out and spreads them on stones or mats to drain and cure in the sun. This process readies the threads for breaking and cleaning.

First, gather bundles of flax stems and allow them to dry in the sun. Once they are brittle, the human grips bunches and strikes them against a surface, breaking the wood and loosening the strands inside. They then crush the stems with a beetle, pounding repeatedly to split the outer shell without wetting. Next, they use a toothed comb to draw through the crushed stalks, teasing out the long, hairlike strands. Finally, they gently rub and roll these threads between the palms to smooth and align them, ready for twisting into twine.

He gathers stems from the retted bundle and ties them in small handfuls. He places a handful between the hinged arms of a wooden break and presses down firmly, cracking the woody core. He opens them and shakes out the brittle pieces, then rotates the stems and repeats until the central pith fractures and falls away. He strips off the larger shards by hand and discards them. Finally, he draws a simple wooden comb through the remaining strands, teasing them into smooth, aligned lengths ready for spinning.

He grasps a handful of retted stalks and presses them against a flat wooden plank. With the blade of a knife held at a shallow angle, he drags it down the length of the bundle, shaving away the brittle outer coating. With each downward stroke, he slides the knife along the stick to adjust for a sharp edge. He turns the stalks, repeating the motion until only smooth, delicate strands remain. Any loose particles and coarse bits fall off, and he taps the bundle to dislodge them. The removed scraps collect at his feet, destined for fire starter or ground cover, while the strands lie ready for the next step.

He gathers the dried stalks and ties small bundles. He sets up a wooden comb, its steel teeth fixed in a board. He takes one bundle and secures its thick end against the comb’s base. He draws the loose ends down and pulls the bundle firmly through the teeth. Each pass separates and straightens the strands, leaving shorter bits behind. He repeats, shifting the comb to a fresh row of teeth when clogged. The separated strands slide through smoothly, emerging as long, aligned ribbons. He strips away the coarse fragments trapped between teeth. With each pull, the material becomes cleaner, finer, and ready for further processing. This process ensures uniform length and quality.

flax seeds.name: flax seeds
flax seeds.description: Near low, slender stalks, small oval pods hang in clusters. Each pod holds tiny, smooth, flat ovals, shimmering golden-brown under sunlight. They lie within the brittle husk, glinting like polished amber chips when the pod splits. The seeds measure a few millimeters, uniform in shape, with a gentle curve and a glossy surface. Scattered across the earth after the pod breaks, they form a tiny mosaic, glinting on the soil.

steps.description: He stands at the edge of a wild meadow, scanning the gentle slope for delicate flax stalks crowned with tiny blue blossoms. He moves toward bright clusters, eyes tracing slender stems rising above surrounding grasses. He kneels at the base of each plant, parts leaves to inspect ripening pods hidden within. He marks every stand of fiber-producing plants and readies himself to return with tools for harvest.

The gatherer steps into the dew-kissed field, grasping a wooden sickle. Eyes scan the slender stalks for plump, bursting pods. Bending low, the gatherer cuts a handful of stalks and lays them on a mat. Fingers carefully strip each pod from its stem, dropping the rounded husks into a woven basket. The stalks build a pile nearby. The basket fills with small, golden-brown pods. Periodically, the gatherer settles on a flat stone to remove broken bits of plant material from the haul. By midday, the harvest stands ready for processing.

The primitive gatherer spreads a coarse mat in the sun. She snips clusters of brittle pods from slender stalks, bundling them for ease. Holding a fistful overhead, she taps each bundle against a sturdy stone, cracking open the pods and releasing tiny kernels. She rubs the pods between her palms, coaxing more kernels free, and shakes them through a woven basket to catch stray bits. A gentle breeze lifts the light chaff as she blows across the kernels settled on the mat, leaving only clean, plump kernels ready for storage and later use.

flax brake.name: flax brake
flax brake.description: A stout wooden frame stands waist-high, its long, flat beam carved with a series of short, blunt prongs protruding at intervals. The beam rests on two crossed logs lashed together with cordage, forming a stable X-shaped base. The timber is worn smooth by handling, pale at edges and darker in crevices. Fibrous strands of pale gold cling stubbornly between prongs, and the whole structure gives a dull knock when tapped.

steps.description: A primitive human stands at the forest edge, adjusting a stone axe in leather straps. With sturdy steps, they enter among tall oaks and birches. They scan for dead or fallen limbs, checking each trunk for hardness. When they spot a suitable branch, they grip the axe handle firmly and swing, biting deep into wood fiber. Splinters fly as the cut grows deeper with each measured stroke. They hew logs into manageable lengths, then strip off twigs and bark with sharp axe edges. Shouldering a bundle of split timber, they tread back with steady balance. At the camp clearing, they stack the collected pieces to dry in the sun, ready for later use.

A primitive worker selects a sturdy tree trunk and sets it on level ground. He positions a sharp stone wedge at one end of the wood where he wants the split to begin. With a heavy hammerstone raised above his shoulder, he brings it down firmly on the wedge. The force drives the wedge deep into the grain, creating a crack. He repeats this action, lifting and striking, until the wedge cuts through the narrowest fibers. If the wood resists, he shifts the wedge into the new opening and pounds it again. As the split grows, he moves quickly along the length of the trunk, inserting the tool and delivering solid blows. Soon the log divides into two long sections. He repeats this process along each section to form narrower strips.

A primitive human stands before a felled tree trunk. He places his axe head against the bark at one side, angling the blade toward the centre. With a firm grip, he swings the axe downward, carving deep into the grain and sending curls of wood flying. He follows a guideline, moving along the length of the log in controlled strikes. Each blow removes a chip, gradually squaring the surface. He then flips the log to the other side, repeating the process. With each cut he transforms the round trunk into a flat-sided beam. When both faces lie flat and parallel, he splits the length into a board.

He selects a stout branch from fallen wood, splits it into a rectangular billet, and strips away the bark. Then he holds one end on a low stump and smooths a face with the knife before marking evenly spaced dots along its length. Pressing the blade into the wood, he carves narrow channels at each mark. He flips the blade, tilts it at an angle, and lifts slivers until a small triangular notch emerges. He advances to the next guide, repeating with even strokes. As the teeth appear, he refines each edge by scraping away splinters, ensuring uniform height and spacing. He glides his thumb over the row to test the catch.

Standing near the workbench, the maker selects sturdy wood for each tooth. He carves small wedges and positions them along the edge of the frame. With the awl in hand, he pierces precise holes at regular intervals, rotating the awl with his palm to ensure uniform depth. After spacing each slot, he lifts a wooden wedge and taps it gently into place with the hammerstone, aligning the tip to catch fibrous strands. With each tap, he checks that the wedge sits flush against the frame’s surface. When one tooth fits snugly, he moves to the next slot, repeating the process. Steadily, a row of sharp wooden teeth forms, ready to draw and separate the fibers. He inspects the alignment and adjusts any loose pieces with the awl and stone.

flax stems.name: flax stems
flax stems.description: Delicate, upright stalks rise from the earth, straight, slender and green, reaching knee-height in clusters. Each stem is smooth to touch, crowned by a spray of tiny, pale blue blossoms that open in the morning light. When blossoms fade, fine seedpods appear along the upper shaft, ripening to a soft tan hue. The stems shift together in gentle breezes, forming a sea of slender lines waving under the sun’s warmth.

steps.description: He wanders along river edges at dawn, eyes scanning muddy banks and low-lying fields for slender pale green stalks crowned by tiny pale blue blossoms. He senses a faint sweet scent rising from damp soil. He kneels, pushes aside tall grasses and reeds, and inspects each stalk’s rough fibers for quality. He notes leaf shape and flower pattern, verifying the right species. He marks clusters with small stones and returns during midday, when fibers hold firm. He maps damp hollows and streamside patches, ensuring a steady harvest of wild plants.

First, the gatherer scans the patch for tall, slender plants dressed in pale green leaves and golden pods. Once selected, the gatherer grips a handful near the base, leans back, and jerks the plant free by its roots. They tie groups of a dozen plants into small bundles with a simple twist of vine. The gatherer moves along the row, repeating until the harvest pile grows heavy. Finally, they carry the bundles to a drying rack where the sun gently bleaches and readies the fibers for the next stage.

scutching knife.name: scutching knife
scutching knife.description: A thin, crescent-shaped slab of dark gray metal glints faintly under sunlight. Its one side curves smoothly to a sharp rim, while the opposite edge shows a rougher taper. At its center, a stubby cylinder of the same material extends outward, riddled with dents and shallow scratch marks. Embedded in this stub is a short, rounded haft of pliable wood, tightly bound by fibrous vines. The object feels cold and solid in the hand.

steps.description: A primitive human seeks nodules of flint along riverbanks or from exposed chalk beds. He often visits river valley outcrops to find larger chunks. He scans the shoreline for smooth stones and tests weight and ring when struck. Upon spotting a promising vein, he pries flakes from larger rocks using a hammerstone. He carries only the sharpest fragments with conchoidal breaks. After gathering several nodules, he shelters by a fire to begin flaking. He then sorts stones by size and quality, setting aside those best suited for careful thinning into sharp-edged tools.

He places a flint pebble on his knee, grips it, and lifts the hammerstone. He strikes the edge with glancing blows, causing flakes to detach in a predictable pattern. He rotates the flint, honing each side, removing bulges and crafting an even cutting edge. He works along the length, striking near the desired bevel line, thinning the core until the blade emerges. He inspects and retouches the edge with lighter blows, pressing to refine points. Next, he applies pressure flaking by levering small flakes from the edge using the hammerstone’s shoulder, creating micro-bevels. He alternates sides for symmetry, balancing removal until the blade feels keen and ready for use.

He quietly moves into the grove, seeking a straight, sturdy branch free of knots. He selects hardwood like hazel or ash, carefully testing its weight and feel. With a flint blade, he trims side twigs and lopps a length about as long as his forearm. He splits the branch with wedge-like stones, prying a straight billet from the core. He scrapes away bark fibers, smoothing the surface with a sharp shell. Finally, he sands the piece on sandstone until it feels even and firm, ready to clasp in the hand.

The craftsman selects a straight-grained hardwood branch roughly six inches long. He trims the ends with a sharp knife to remove bark and loose fibers. Holding the piece firmly, he carves shallow facets along its length, forming a comfortable grip that follows the curve of his palm. He then shapes one end into a tapered tang by slicing away excess wood at an angle. He chisels a narrow slot near the tang’s base to accept a metal blade. With the slot formed, he rounds off sharp edges and smooths all surfaces by shaving thin curls of wood. Finally, he tests the fit of the blade, ensuring a snug, stable handle.

He chips a sharp edge from a suitable flint fragment. He holds the flint against a piece of hardwood, shaping the handle with a stone grinder until it fits comfortably in his hand. He carves a small groove or notch near the end of the handle to seat the blade. He moistens animal sinew, then places the flint blade into the notch. He wraps the sinew tightly around the blade and handle junction, crossing the bindings to lock the edge in place. Each pass presses the blade snugly against the wood. He ties off the sinew with a secure knot and trims the excess fibers. Once dry, the sinew contracts, firmly binding blade and handle. He coats the binding evenly with pine resin to waterproof and further strengthen the joint.

stone chisel.name: stone chisel
stone chisel.description: This slender piece of dark stone is roughly the length of a forearm, tapering to a narrow, flattened edge. Its surface bears faint grooves from careful shaping, with one side ground smooth and the other rough and uneven. It feels heavy in the hand, cool and solid, and its edge gleams faintly in sunlight. The overall form is simple and purposeful, a single rock shaped into a sleek, pointed wedge.

steps.description: He walks along a rocky outcrop at dawn, scanning the ground for solid, fine-grained fragments. He picks up each piece, tapping it gently against a larger rock to test its ring and hardness. He discards porous or crumbly bits, favoring dense, sharp-edged forms. He inspects surfaces for flat planes and natural ridges that promise good leverage. When he finds a suitable chunk, he sets it aside, brushing away dirt and loose pebbles. This careful selection of raw rock ensures he has the right material to fashion a reliable cutting implement.

He selects a suitable cobble from the riverbank, adjusts his grip and angle to control flake size, and holds it firmly in one hand. He identifies a platform edge that will serve as the striking point. With a rounded hammerstone, he strikes the platform sharply at a low angle. The blow detaches a thin, elongated flake, which separates from the parent rock. He inspects the flake’s length and thickness, ensuring it resembles the desired form. If needed, he repeats controlled strikes along the platform, removing additional flakes to refine the blank’s profile. Once the blank has straight edges and a pointed tip, he sets it aside for further shaping and usage.

A primitive artisan selects a durable stone blank that has a naturally sharp edge. He grips the blank firmly in one hand and brings a hammerstone striking the edge near the midsection. At each blow, small flakes detach, gradually refining the profile. Through careful percussion, the artisan sculpts a tapered point and a slightly concave face. He alternates between hard strikes and softer taps to control flaking. Periodically, he inspects the emerging form, ensuring symmetry and an acute angle for precise cuts. As the shape nears completion, he shifts to finer percussion, producing a smooth bevel. The resulting implement displays a robust tip and even slender body ready for use.

flax straw.name: flax straw
flax straw.description: In open fields, slender upright stalks rise in clusters, each stem barely thicker than a finger. Their hues shift from pale green at the base to golden tan near delicate pods clustered along the upper reaches. Sunlight glints off the smooth surfaces, revealing faint longitudinal lines. A gentle breeze rustles them like distant whispers, creating a soft susurration. Beneath, the dry, papery sheath crackles at each movement, hinting at hidden strength.

steps.description: He stands barefoot among a patch of tall flax plants glistening at dawn. He grips a handful near the base, pulling upward to free a bundle from the soil in one swift motion. He lays stalks in neat heaps on a wooden frame, allowing sun and breeze to extract moisture. Once dry and crisp, he sorts them by length and color. He lifts a mallet, beating the stems lightly to loosen inner fibers. He shakes each heap over a hide, separating chaff from the valuable strands ready for further processing.

He gathers the slender flax plants at dawn and cuts long, fibrous stalks at the riverbank. He ties them into small bundles and gently lowers them into a shallow pool. The stalks sink beneath the cool water, where they rest for several days. The man periodically lifts each bundle, shakes away debris, and re-immerses the stems. As the days pass, water and natural microbes work to loosen the gummy substances that bind fibers to woody cores. The worker watches the murky water and tests a stem by rubbing it between his fingers. Once the fibers slip free, he spreads the bundles on a sunlit bank to drain and dry before further processing.

Each morning, the gatherer grips stalks and trims away leaves and seeds. He ties the stems into small sheaves and places them upright on a wooden drying rack under the sun. He returns to lift and rotate each bundle, ensuring even exposure. Over several days, moisture vanishes and the fibers turn crisp. He taps the dried stalks, listening for a brittle crack that signals readiness. Once all bundles reach this stage, he carries them to a hut. There, they rest until the next step in transforming plant into thread begins.

A primitive human gathers bundles of dried flax stalks and secures them over a wooden beam. Standing on the earth, they lift each bundle and forcefully bend it over the beam. With a wooden mallet or club, they strike the stalks repeatedly, crushing the hard woody cores. They rotate the bundle, ensuring each side meets the beam. As they work, the outer long fibers loosen from the shattered inner pith. The person pauses to shake out debris, then repeats the beating until the stalk walls break away, leaving clean strands.

They collect flax stems. They hold each stem by the base and use a wooden rod to beat the stalks, loosening woody pieces. As the stem cracks, they peel away bundles of long inner fibers, pulling them through a comb of sharp wooden teeth. They shake the comb to dislodge stubborn bits. They gather soft threads, align them on a flat stone, then scrape remaining bits from the fibers and arrange into even bundles. The process continues, repeating on each stalk until all inner threads emerge clean and separate from brittle chaff.

flax stem.name: flax stem
flax stem.description: Slender upright stems rise in even clumps from soft earth. They stand at waist height, smooth, slightly glossy green, with occasional knobs marking where broad leaves sprout. The leaves are long, narrow, and tapered, touching the air with thin points. Clusters of tiny, pale blue blossoms gently hover around the stem tops, each with five minute petals. A breeze sets them to shivering, flickering like ringing light among the green.

steps.description: The person scans the meadow at sunrise, eyes tracing slender, blue-green stalks swaying in soft breezes. They move slowly, feet stirring dew-kissed grass, seeking clusters with small, delicate blossoms of pale blue. Fingers brush the stalks’ fibrous bodies to confirm their strength and pliability. Once confident, the gatherer kneels, parts surrounding greenery, and grips the base of a sturdy stalk, ready to cut close to the earth.

He stands in the sunlit flax field where rows of slender plants sway. Grasping a handful near their bases, he tugs upward, loosening fibrous stalks from damp earth. With steady pulls, he extracts long, pale strands, freeing them from soil and tangled leaves. He bundles each handful with a cord, stacking them on a flat stone to dry. He uses a wooden tool to scrape away bits of bark, exposing smooth inner fibers. Sweat drips down his brow as he repeats the process, filling woven baskets until the day wanes.

bone.name: bone
bone.description: It is a hard, chalky-white fragment protruding from the earth like a pale root. Its surface is smooth in places but rough and porous where broken, revealing a honeycomb of tiny cavities. Some pieces arch, others break into flat shards. Under your fingers it feels cool, rigid, and brittle, producing dust when scratched. Occasionally a hollow channel runs through its length. Sunlight makes its pale surface gleam against the soil.

steps.description: He scans the valley floor at first light, eyes sharp for pale fragments scattered among stones. He crouches near a half-buried jaw, brushing away dirt with a stick. He lifts a small ivory shard, testing its weight and texture, then examines cracks and ridges. With careful steps he circles fallen carcasses, peering beneath tangle of brush. When he finds solid white pieces hidden in earth, he plucks them up with reverent hands.

They scour the shoreline and forest floor for white fragments discarded by predators or left after a kill. They scan carcasses of fish, birds, and small mammals, prying loose the sturdy scraps with sharp implements. When they discover bleached and weathered shards, they probe cracks with pointed sticks, then snap off manageable portions. They shake off dirt and blood, then tuck each fragment into a leather pouch. At day’s end, they return to camp where they rinse and sort the pieces by size and quality, ready for crafting tools and ornaments.

He selects sturdy fragments from a fresh carcass, removing any adhering tissue with a sharp flint. He scrapes each piece thoroughly, using an antler scraper to detach bits of flesh and gristle. He then submerges the fragments in a shallow stream, allowing clear water to rinse away loosened debris. After rinsing, he dries the pieces in sunlight, rotating them to ensure even exposure. Once fully dry, he heats each fragment near embers to harden the surface, then rubs with animal fat to seal and preserve the cleaned material for toolmaking.

wild flax.name: wild flax
wild flax.description: Stems rise slender and straight from damp ground, each bearing pairs of narrow, lance-shaped leaves that glint with morning dew. Atop these stalks sit small, cup-shaped blooms of pale sky-blue, each flower showing five delicate, pointed petals. Between blossoms, thin, ovoid pods cluster tightly, their surfaces smooth and firm. The plant reaches knee height, its stalks unbranched and slightly stiff, swaying gently in the breeze with a quiet grace.

hand drill.name: hand drill
hand drill.description: A slender staff of pale, smoothly polished wood sits in the palm, its smooth shaft tapering to a blunt point. Near one end, a short bar of darker timber crosses in a tight X, tied with sinew and thongs. The wood grain curves in swirling patterns along its length, catching the light. Knots and small grooves mar its surface, the whole form feels balanced, ready to be grasped and turned.

steps.description: He moves slowly among the trees, his eyes scanning for a straight dead limb that fits easily between his palms. He tests twigs by bending them until they snap; a clean break shows dryness. He taps bark to listen for a hollow sound, signaling old wood. He seeks a piece roughly the thickness of his thumb, free of knots and resin. He breaks off a suitable stick for making fire.

A primitive human chooses a sturdy branch and examines its straight length. He clears bark and small twigs from its surface with the axe edge. He sets the branch on two stones or a low stump, gripping the axe with both hands. He positions his feet for balance and brings the axe down at a shallow angle, slicing cleanly along the grain. He repeats firm, controlled strokes until the branch severs. He tilts the severed section away and inspects the cut end for smoothness. He trims rough fibers by shaving the outline and rotates the piece for an even finish. The result is a straight, manageable length ready for further shaping.

She selects a straight, knot-free branch about twenty centimeters long and trims it to length with her knife. Holding the wood lightly, she slices away bark and bends the shaft to check straightness. She planes each side, rotating the shaft between her palms as she carves away irregularities. At one end she whittles a sharp, conical tip for piercing the hearth board, slicing thin curls in even strokes. At the other end she carves a shallow, circular notch to seat the spinning cord. She tests the diameter, shaving slivers until the shaft rotates smoothly. Finally, she smooths the surface by rubbing her palms along its length to remove tool marks and ensure balanced motion.

sand.name: sand
sand.description: Beneath the sun’s glow, countless tiny stone crystals carpet the riverbank, each fragment gleaming like pale gold. They flow endlessly between toes and slip through grasping fingers, drifting softly under every breeze. They shape small dunes where wind gathers, creating smooth ripples along the shore. At midday, this expanse radiates warmth that lingers on the skin. In shallow streams, it hollows to reveal darker pebbles below and shimmers under moonlight.

abrasive stone.name: abrasive stone
abrasive stone.description: My hand grasps an ancient, rough, pale chunk of earth. Its surface is studded with tiny, rigid grains, each jutting like a miniature cliff. Sunlight picks out a patchwork of dull gray and warm tan, fractured by shallow grooves and pits. It feels heavy for its size, cool and dry, with every move sending a faint, whispering grit beneath my fingers. I sense its unyielding, silent hardness and uneven surface.

sickle.name: sickle
sickle.description: I see a half-moon arc of cold, silvery metal, its inner edge finely sharpened and reflecting dim sunlight. The outer curve remains slightly dull, pocked with tiny pits and scratches. A stout wooden grip, pale and smoothed by hand, lies nestled against the metal’s flat side, secured by two rounded pins. The wood bears faint grooves from many touches. Together, these parts form a light, slender shape, balanced between metal and earth.

steps.description: He climbs down into a gravelly streambed and scans for a flint nodule. He lifts it, feels its weight, and strikes it with another stone to flake off a sharp shard. Next, he searches the forest edge for a supple branch. He examines young saplings until he finds one straight and sturdy, then hacks off a length with his sharp stone blade. He strips away the bark with cuts, smoothing the surface with scraping. For binding material, he gathers long strands of grass and strips inner bark fibers from a broadleaf branch. He separates and twists these fibers between his palms into a cord. Finally, he positions the flint edge against the wood and wraps the cord tightly around both parts, knotting it securely. The cutting implement is now ready.

He collects a flint nodule by the stream. He lifts a rounded hammerstone and places it against the flint. He strikes firmly, removing a sharp flake. He repeats the blows around the edge, producing thin, razor-like segments. He examines each piece, selecting the longest, straightest flake for a cutting edge. He holds a chunk of wood, stripping away bark with the knife, revealing pale fibers beneath. He crafts a slender handle, smoothing the surface until it fits comfortably in his grip. He carves a shallow groove along the top side, adjusting its depth with precise shavings. He positions the flint blade into the groove, tapping it into place with the hammerstone. He winds a strip of sinew around the junction, pressing it tight with the knife’s edge. He tests the alignment, trimming any excess wood. The resulting implement gleams, ready for harvesting wild grasses.

He cuts several long strands of fibrous bark from a pliant plant, then soaks them in water until they soften. He wraps the softened fibers tightly around the wooden haft and the curved stone edge, aligning them carefully. With firm fingers, he twists the ends together and loops them in a crisscross pattern, pulling each coil snug with steady pressure. He secures the final strand by tucking its tip under the last wrap. After the fibers dry and shrink, the stony tip and haft lock together, fully ready for use.

flax pods.name: flax pods
flax pods.description: Slender green stalks rise in tangled clusters, each topped by narrow, lance-shaped leaves and tiny, pale blue blossoms. As sunlight warms the stems, each blossom fades into a small, elongated shell with a subtle fuzz covering. The shells cluster along the stem veins, their edges faintly ribbed and pointed at one end. When ripe, they shift from soft green to tan, each segment swelling slightly before splitting to reveal smooth, round seeds.

steps.description: The gatherer steps cautiously across the meadow, eyes scanning each flax plant for slender stems and delicate blue blossoms nestled among green leaves. He follows the sun’s path, seeking patches where the soil is rich and moisture lingers. He kneels, brushing aside grass to expose tight clusters on upright stalks. He notes the uniform rows left by earlier planting, judging their readiness by firm seed cases before returning with bounty.

He moves among the tall stalks in early light. He crouches to inspect stem health. He works with practiced motion. His strong hands reach out to gentle seed clusters at the stem tips. He grasps each vessel firmly between thumb and forefinger and pulls carefully. The dry vessels detach, and he lets them drop into a woven basket at his side. He inspects each vessel to ensure seeds remain inside before moving on. When the basket grows heavy, he transfers its contents into a container. At midday, he rests and surveys the field.

awl.name: awl
awl.description: A small, slender shaft of gleaming bone or dark, polished wood rests before you. It measures only a few palms in length, smooth and cylindrical along its rounded body. One end tapers gradually to a fine, piercing point that glints faintly. The surface bears subtle striations and tiny pits from careful shaping, while the opposite end remains slightly thicker and dull. Held, it feels balanced and firm in callused fingers.

steps.description: He scans the shoreline for a sturdy long bone shed by a sea creature, selecting a fragment of shin or rib about the thickness of a finger. He cleans away flesh and membrane with a flint blade, then splits the piece with controlled strikes to yield a straight segment. He scrapes marrow from the hollow interior, rinses the bone in a stream, and leaves it in the sun to dry. Once rigid, he marks a central line, then hammers the piece gently between stones to begin forming the basic shape.

He selects a rough fragment of sandstone from a riverbed. He grips one end firmly against a flat, coarse slab. Tilting the piece at a slight angle, he presses it into the abrasive surface and moves it back and forth. Particles scrape away the edges, gradually creating a sharp point. He pauses occasionally to inspect his progress, rotating the fragment and feeling for even taper. With each motion, the point grows finer until it penetrates hide or bark. He also moistens the slab occasionally with clear river water to reduce dust and reveal finer grain. Satisfied, he tests the tip by pressing it against wood and adjusting abrasions until even.

sandstone.name: sandstone
sandstone.description: A reddish-beige rock stands in the river bed, its surface coarse with tiny mineral grains pressed together. Light tan bands run across its length, forming thin, irregular stripes. Underfoot it feels gritty and sturdy, yet small fragments flake off where water smooths edges. In sunlight, it gleams faintly with embedded flecks of quartz. Along cliff faces, broad slabs weather into gentle curves and flat steps, revealing layers of compacted sand.

clay flowerpot.name: clay flowerpot
clay flowerpot.description: The object is a small vessel made of hardened earth. It stands alone on the ground; symmetrical sides curve upward from a broad base, narrowing slightly toward its midpoint before flaring outward to a wide open rim. Its surface is smooth but bears faint ripples from shaping by hand. Dull reddish-brown hues shift under sunlight, and tiny speckles of mineral glint subtly across its curved walls, giving it a quiet, earthy presence.

steps.description: Early human kneels at the river’s edge, running fingers through wet sediment. He tests the texture, pinching a handful to check for grit and moisture. With a blade, he scrapes the bank, gathering soft, malleable clay into a pit. He adds water from a bowl, stirring until the mixture becomes smooth and elastic. He discards pebbles and roots, working the material until it feels uniform. He rolls lumps into his palms, shaping them into smooth balls that he stores under a leaf to await the next step in vessel creation.

A primitive maker kneads damp clay with bare hands. He rolls the malleable mass into a smooth coil, stacking loops one atop another. Each ring he pinches and refines, smoothing seams with fingertips. He cups his palm inside the rising form, rotating it gently on a flat stone. His thumb marks the interior curve, while his other hand shapes the exterior wall. As the vessel grows, he taps its base to settle the material evenly. Finally, he polishes its surface with a bit of water and a smooth pebble.

A primitive human kneads earth with water and shapes a round vessel with thick walls, smoothing its surface with a flat tool. They trim the base and use their finger to refine the rim. They pat down any emerging cracks. Then they set the piece on a woven mat under the sun, turning it to dry evenly. After a few days, the surface feels firm and cool, ready for firing or decoration.

Early human selects fresh earth, kneads it with water until it feels smooth and pliable. They shape a vessel with base and sides, pinching as they work. They leave the vessel in sun to harden enough to hold its form. They build a tripod of stones over a shallow pit, place twigs and branches around the vessel, then ignite the kindling. They tend the fire, adding fuel until the stones glow and the vessel hardens through heat. Once cool, the sturdy container stands ready for holding fresh soil and seeds.

clay.name: clay
clay.description: A patch of earth along the riverbank glistens under the sun. When touched, its surface feels cool, smooth, and heavy, sliding between fingers like damp dough. Its hue ranges from pale ivory to deep ochre, streaking hands with earthy pigments. Small imprints from drops of water or animal tracks hold shape instead of quickly filling back in. The ground here clings together firmly yet yields under pressure, its moisture balancing softness with resilience.

shepherds pie.name: shepherds pie
shepherds pie.description: A low, rough mound of pale, soft matter sits atop a flatter layer of darker chunks. Steam rises, carrying creamy, earth-scented fumes tinged with herbs. The top is dimpled and cracked, fine, finger-like ridges dot the surface, crisping at the edges, revealing oozing, yellowish clouds. Beneath, small irregular brown shapes glisten in a rich, amber liquid that seeps around the edges. The whole exudes warmth and a faint sweet-and-salty aroma that drifts to the nose.

steps.description:
A lone gatherer moves through rolling grasslands at first light, carrying a woven basket slung over one shoulder. He scans the horizon for a grazing herd of wild sheep. Spotting a small group, he creeps forward, bow in hand, and waits for a clear shot. The arrow flies, and he kneels beside the fallen mutton, thanking the land before carefully cutting away a generous shoulder roast. He wraps the meat in large leaves and tucks it into his basket.  

Next, he follows a narrow stream uphill where pockets of rich, loamy soil cradle clusters of tubers. He pries the earth with a sharp stone and lifts several potatoes, flicking away dirt before adding them to his haul. Further on, he nears a stand of tall, fragrant stalks. He pulls onions free by their green shoots, brushing away any cling­ing soil, and places them gently beside the potatoes.  

Finally, he descends to a shallow salt pan near the riverbank. He uses a flat rock to scrape crystalline grains into a small hollowed gourd. With ham­mocked goods secure in the basket, he turns homeward, ready to transform these simple stores into a nourishing stew.

The primitive human kneels beside the sheep, gripping a crude knife. He slices across the throat, blood wells and trickles into the grass. Lifting the carcass upright, he vents the belly with a careful slash to spill the entrails. He scoops out organs, sorting heart and liver for later roasting. He strips the wool-bearing skin from the carcass, peeling it down in rough sections. With steady hands he divides the animal at joints, separating forequarters and hindquarters. He trims away sinew and excess fat, then cuts the lean muscle into bite-sized chunks. Once the meat lies in a pile, he wipes the blade on grass and readies the next sheep.

A primitive human grips a small, roughly sharpened stone knife; he cuts off the top of a bulbous onion. He peels the papery layers, discarding them. He slices the onion in half, placing each cut side down on a flat stone. Then he holds one half with fingers splayed and begins to slice thin slivers lengthwise, moving the knife in steady strokes. He turns the slices 90 degrees and chops repeatedly, rocking the blade back and forth to break the strips into tiny pieces. He sweeps the roughly chopped bits together, adjusts his grip, and continues until the onion is reduced to fine, even bits, ready to flavor the simple dish.

The primitive cook pours water into the pot until it stands a finger above the mutton chunks. He sets the pot over glowing embers and waits while small bubbles form at the sides. Once the water roils, he lifts the pot from the heat for a moment, allowing the boil to ease. He returns it to the fire at a lower height so gentle ripples dance across the surface. He shifts coals beneath the pot. Steam coils upward as the meat softens. He skims any scum that gathers at the edges and sets it aside. Over the next hour, the pot breathes spurts of steam. He occasionally stirs the meat pieces, checking their tenderness. The slow heat coaxes rich flavor from the mutton, yielding tender morsels ready for the next stage.

A primitive gatherer crouches by the hearth, scraping earth from a tuber. He slices the potato into uneven chunks with a flint blade. He fetches a round iron pot from glowing embers, rinses it in cold stream water, and carries it back. He fills the pot with cool water, submerging the potato pieces. He sets the pot atop sturdy stones arranged around the fire, adjusts burning embers until flames lick the vessel’s base. Soon, bubbles rise as the water simmers. He watches closely, patiently humming an ancient tune, stirring the potatoes with a wooden stick pulled from a nearby branch. Steam curls around his face, smelling of earth and hearth. After several turns of the sun, the chunks yield to gentle pressure, and he calls the boiling process complete.

A primitive human kneels by a crackling fire and holds a rough pebble knife. He slices thick rounds from tubers. He drops them into a leather skin of boiling water, heated by red-hot stones. The flesh softens, and he lifts each piece with a stick. He places the soft slices into a wooden bowl. Using a heavy stone pestle, he pounds the boiled flesh, pressing and twisting until it turns into a lumpy paste. He sprinkles salt and a spoon of fresh milk, stirring the blend into a creamy mash.

A gatherer stands over a fire hearth, a clay vessel at hand. He breaks boiled tubers, mashing them with a wooden stump until smooth and warm. Then he reaches for a pot of seasoned ground meat, scooping spoonfuls into the dish to form a base. Next, he spoons the root mash atop the simmered flesh, smoothing it with a flat stone. He repeats these steps, pressing each stratum firmly. Once the vessel is full, he slides it close to the embers, letting the heat meld each tier into a hearty feast.

He lifts the vessel filled with his layered creation, sliding it onto a flat wooden paddle. He walks to the hot oven, pushes the paddle, releases the vessel inside. He closes the heavy door, sealing heat within. He stamps his foot to steady as warmth glows through the metal front. He whisks a handful of wood into the fire below to keep embers steady. He listens for faint crackles and peeks through the iron grate when embers dim, adding a twig or two. After long minutes, he withdraws the vessel by gripping thick cloth and drags it outward. He rests the dish on a sturdy slab until steam fades and the golden crust feels firm to a touch ready for serving. He carries the dish toward the table with care.

potato.name: potato
potato.description: A cluster of tuber-like roots beneath low, leafy stems. The underground bulbs are irregularly oblong, with earthy skin mottled in pale brown and dusty gray. Each knobby form is coated in thin soil, with tiny root hairs protruding from dimples. When uprooted, they reveal crisp, starchy flesh inside pale white. Small, emerald-green leaves arch above ground, casting dappled shade over the hidden, clumped or solitary rounded nodules beneath. They sometimes lie near shady mossy stones.

basket.name: basket
basket.description: A shallow vessel emerges, its walls formed by thin, pliable strands woven in an irregular crisscross. The sides bow outward, rising in a gentle curve to a wide, circular rim. Narrow strips of dried grass or bark twist tightly together, creating a sturdy yet flexible mesh. In the open center, gaps between the fibers reveal glimpses of the ground below. The edges are slightly uneven, the strands’ ends frayed and splayed.

steps.description: He creeps along the forest edge, searching for supple vines twisted among low branches. He eyes sturdy, flexible lengths that show no signs of rot. Kneeling, he grasps a vine and uses a sharp flint tool to slice cleanly through its base. He tears away tangled leaves and shoots, gathering several long strands into a coil near his feet. He repeats the search, moving under the canopy to find fresh growth. After collecting enough strong, pliable fibers, he ties the ends in loops and carries the bundle back to camp.

First, the primitive artisan gathers tall grass stalks from damp lowlands at dawn, selecting the firmest and most flexible stems. They carry a sharp chisel and position one stalk across a sturdy wooden block, pressing the blade’s edge firmly at the tip. With measured force, they draw the chisel downward, peeling off the coarse outer sheath to expose the softer fibers within. They rotate the stalk, repeating the slicing motion until the stem yields long, even strips. Thicker portions receive additional shaving to reach uniform thickness. Finally, they soak the slender bands in clear water, leaving them to soften and strengthen before moving on to the subsequent fine weaving phase.

The artisan selects long, flexible strands of reed and trims them to uniform length. They soak stalks in water to enhance pliability. When soft, they lay sturdy rods radiating from the center to form a flat foundation. The weaver then takes a thin strand and threads it alternately over and under the uprights, pulling to create the base. As the structure rises, the rods bend upward and the craftsperson continues interlacing reeds, shaping curved walls. At final row, they fold and tuck ends into the rim for a secure finish.

A primitive craftsperson selects supple vines and soaks them to increase pliability. They strip away outer bark, splitting vines into uniform strands. As the form grows, they secure ends by tucking the free tail beneath three or four weft strands, pulling it taut so it locks into place. If a longer tail remains, they sew it back through rows in a zigzag pattern, hiding it among surrounding fibers. After tightening, any excess vine is trimmed close to the structure, with tucks burying stubs beneath outer coils for lasting stability.

salt.name: salt
salt.description: Jagged seams of bright, pale crystals line the edges of wind-swept rocks near dried lake beds. Each fragment glitters like tiny shards of ice dusted in fine, chalky powder. When rubbed between fingers, these grains feel coarse yet light, the sun reflecting off their faceted surfaces. In damp hollows, small white crusts bloom along the stone, their brittle forms shattering into countless sparkling specks at the slightest touch.

mutton.name: mutton
mutton.description: A chunk of flesh torn from a wool-covered creature lies on a flat stone. It glistens with moisture, soft ridges and fibrous strands catching the light. Thin white veins weave through the deep red tissue, while a faint sheen of oily crimson drips at its edges. Warmth radiates from its core, and small insects circle and settle on its surface. A sharp tang of raw life hangs in the air around it.

steps.description: The primitive person moves quietly at dawn, scanning the rocky hills for drifting shapes. He crouches behind scrub bushes, eyes narrowed as he watches the sheep grazing near a stream. He listens for soft bleating and watches dust clouds stirring among distant stones. He follows faint tracks pressed into damp ground, tracing the herd’s usual path. He holds a sharpened spear, ready to stalk closer when the wind favors his scent.

He grasps the knife, the blade shining in the dawn light. He presses the knife at the sheep’s throat, finds the pulse, and cuts swiftly across the windpipe, letting blood drain. Once the animal stops struggling, he places it belly-down. He slices along the midline from throat to tail, opening the chest. He pulls out the organs carefully, setting heart and liver aside. He skins the carcass with steady strokes. He splits the carcass at the backbone with a cut. He removes the legs by cutting through joints. He trims away excess fat and sinew. He rinses the flesh in cold water from a stream, ready to roast or preserve.

A primitive human stands before a freshly felled sheep laid on a flat stone slab. They grip a crude chisel carved from flint and brace its edge against the animal’s hide. With steady pressure, they press the chisel against the skin at the nape and slice carefully along the backbone. The stone blade parts fibers of hide and flesh as they peel the hide back to reveal shoulder joints. Next, they sever sinew around forelegs, then split pelvis and hindquarters by striking the chisel into bone at the groin. They open the ribcage to free organs and clean the cavity, discarding unwanted parts. Finally, flesh and fat are cut into usable portions.

sheep.name: sheep
sheep.description: A small to medium-sized animal roams grasslands. Covered in thick, curly fibers, its coat appears soft and dense, hiding slender legs that end in cloven hooves. Its head bears short curved horns or a gentle muzzle with a twitching nose. It moves slowly, pulling at tender shoots with a split lip. Its bleating call echoes across open fields, and it often gathers in flocks for safety. Breath puffs in cold air.

oven.name: oven
oven.description: A squat clay structure rises from the ground, its exterior formed of sun-dried bricks arranged in neat rows. A dark rectangular opening punctuates the front, revealing an empty chamber laced with metal bars that shimmer faintly. The surface bears a patchwork of ashen stains and soot smudges. Along its side, a small metal handle juts out, its edges cool and dull. The top is flat and broad, scattered with tiny cracks.

steps.description: A craftsman moves to the riverbank at first light and kneels beside exposed clay deposits. He scoops handfuls of moist clay, tests its texture, and discards any that crumble or feel gritty. He packs the chosen clay into a basket. Next, he wanders along a slope, eyeing flat stones that will line the structure’s floor. He pries loose slabs from outcrops, tapping them to ensure they produce a ring. He selects stones of varying sizes, rejecting cracked or weathered pieces. Each rock and lump of clay he transports attracts attention, for this foundation demands sturdy, heat-resistant walls. He stacks them in a spot until the pile is ready for shaping.

In a shallow pit, the maker gathers generous handfuls of natural clay. They bring water from a nearby stream in a hollowed-out gourd. Slowly, they pour drops of water onto the clay, raking the edge of a hand around to swirl the mixture. They press and fold the damp clay repeatedly, working out air bubbles and creating a smooth, malleable paste. More water is added in small amounts until the texture resembles soft dough but still holds its shape. A pinch tested between thumb and forefinger feels firm yet pliant. Kneading continues for several minutes until the clay is uniform and free of dry clumps or overly wet spots.

A lone maker gathers a lump of damp clay and pours in a slow stream of water. Hands press the mix, kneading until the material feels smooth and pliable. Fingers pinch off small portions, rolling them between palms to form even coils. One coil settles on the ground, the next pressed snugly beside it. Layer by layer, the coils climb upward, shaped into a rounded chamber with a narrow opening at the front. The maker uses a flat wooden paddle to press and smooth each join, blending ridges until the surface appears seamless. Small tools carve a ventilation hole above the entrance. The new structure stands ready for final drying.

A primitive human collects clay from a riverbank and kneads it with water to remove air pockets. He shapes thick walls, pressing the moist clay around a simple stick frame. He smooths the surface with a flat stone and seals any gaps. He carves a small opening for fuel and a larger chamber for baking treats. He adds horizontal ridges for strength and leaves the form in the sun, turning it occasionally to ensure even drying. After several days, the clay hardens into a sturdy, heat-resistant shell ready for use.

A primitive human builds a fire structure from clay and water. They mix thick clay paste carefully, kneading it into a malleable mass. They shape a flat circular base and press it firmly into the earth. Then they sculpt sturdy walls in concentric rings, smoothing each layer with simple tools. They carve a front opening for adding fuel and a narrow vent at the back for airflow. A domed cap with a small hole crowns the top. The clay dries under the sun for several days until it hardens. When ready, they stack dry wood inside, carefully light the fire, and tend the gentle glow within the warm, clay enclosure.

onion.name: onion
onion.description: A rounded bulb emerges just beneath the earth’s surface, its papery outer sheets tinted pale brown and curling softly at the edges. When broken open, concentric white rings lie hidden within, cool and moist to the touch. A sharp scent rises, tangy and slightly sweet, drifting on the breeze. Droplets of milky juice bead along the crisp layers, glinting under sunlight, while thin green shoots stretch upward through the grass.

pot.name: pot
pot.description: A rounded container stands among stones, its walls smooth but uneven, molded from river mud. Its color ranges from deep brown to pale ochre, streaked with black char around the lowest curve. The mouth widens, the rim thick and sturdy, often rough where fingerprints remain. Inside, the surface is coarse yet firm, specks of sand and ash embedded in the clay. It rests upon small feet carved at its base.

steps.description: The craftsman rises at dawn and heads toward a muddy riverbank. He kneels on the damp earth, eyes scanning for damp, pliable lumps. He digs his fingers into the soft bank, teasing out lumps of rich, sticky clay. He wipes away excess grit, pressing a handful between his palms to feel its smoothness. He loads the glistening clay onto a hide sling. Then he steps downstream to a clear pool, scooping cool water in a hollowed wooden bowl. He pours the liquid into the sling, letting it seep through the clay, creating a workable mass. He kneads this mixture underfoot, ensuring even moisture. He carries the mound home to shape.

He kneads lumps of clay between rough hands to soften it. He presses the clay onto a flat stone, mashing edges upward to form a shallow bowl shape. He cups the form with both hands, smoothing the surface and pinching walls thinner.
