He trims any irregularities along the curve, ensuring a uniform bend. He scrapes the surface smooth. He ties a sturdy cord between the notches, completing the shaping of his curved hand tool.

The primitive human gathers flax stems and soaks them to loosen the fibers. He strips away the brittle outer rind and teases the fine strands free. Next, he dries the fibers until they remain supple but not brittle. He groups small bundles of fibers and twists each bundle with his hands, turning them in the same direction until they coil tightly. Folding two twisted strands together, he lets them twist around each other, forming a strong, even cord. Finally, he tests the cord’s strength and adjusts its tension.

He selects a heartwood block and uses a sharp knife to carve a small handhold. He trims sides to shape a comfortable grip. Then he marks a shallow cup in the center and slowly carves a depression just wide enough to cradle the spindle. Each stroke removes thin curls, smoothing the interior. He pauses to test the fit by spinning the stick in the hollow, adjusting depth and shape until it cradles the tip snugly without slippage. He dusts away wood shavings and inspects the socket’s symmetry under direct light. Finally, he smooths the surface with firm strokes, eliminating ragged edges and ensuring even contact for steady rotation.

The person selects a straight, sturdy branch and carves it into a smooth rod. They smooth its surface with a sharp stone, ensuring the ends are even. Next, they choose a flat hardwood board and carve a shallow socket at its center. They gather plant fibers, twist them into a strong cord, and wrap it tightly around a flexible stick, creating a loop with enough tension to spin the rod. They place one end of the rod into the socket and grip the curved stick. Their foot presses down on the board. With a steady back-and-forth motion, they spin the rod. They keep downward pressure, centering the rod in the socket.

stone axe.name: stone axe
stone axe.description: A weighty stick of wood stretches out, about a foot long, its surface polished smooth by rubbing against bark. One end carries a dark, teardrop-shaped rock, its edges chipped into a sharp, jagged rim. The fragment nestles tightly in a slender groove carved along the shaft, bound with sinew strips that glint pale under the sun. The whole feels solid in the hand, balanced where stone meets wood.

steps.description: In a riverside bed, the hunter gathers suitable river cobbles, tests each for density by hefting it. He scans exposed ledges for flint nodules, prying at seams with a deer antler. When he finds a flint fragment, he taps it with a hammer of hard rock to detach a sharp flake. He examines every chip, discarding brittle pieces. He selects a rounded boulder with fine grain and flat surfaces, washes it to reveal flaws, then carries it back to the workshop site for shaping. He stores each rock close to the hearth.

A primitive craftsman wanders into the forest, eyes scanning for a branch. He grips a small blade to cut through underbrush, then selects a straight section of oak or ash. Assessing its diameter, he tests for knots or cracks. Once chosen, he uses a sharp flake to sever the branch near its base, leaving a clean cut. Holding the timber, he smooths rough areas by scraping with a hard flake. He trims off twigs, shaping the piece into a durable handle ready for further work. He tests its weight and balance.

He selects a sturdy tree with fibrous bark and uses a sharp flint fragment to cut away a strip. He slices along the grain, peeling off a long, flexible ribbon of bark. Holding one end, he twists the strip, stretching and loosening the fibers. He lays the ribbon on a flat rock and beats it with a wooden club to soften and separate the strands. He scrapes the bundle with a sharp flake, removing bark residue and aligning the fibers. Finally, he gathers the cleaned fibers for binding and cordage.

An early craftsman holds a chunk of hard stone in one hand and grips a hammerstone in the other. He sets the stone on a leather hide or soft ground to cushion impact. With measured force, he raises the hammerstone and strikes the stone’s edge at an angle to detach flakes. Each blow chips away unwanted bits and shapes a cutting edge. He rotates the stone and repeats strikes along opposing sides to create symmetry. As the form emerges, he shifts to lighter, more precise taps to refine the bevel and sharpen the edge. Periodically, he examines the shape and tests against wood, adjusting strikes until the form meets functional requirements.

The primitive craftsman selects a sturdy piece of hardwood and secures it between his knees. He grips the sharp knife and slices away rough bark in long strokes. He carves a gentle curve along one side, checking the grain to avoid splits. He holds the wood and whittles thin curls, revealing a smooth surface underneath. He forms a beveled edge at one end by shaving small chips. He smooths the handle area, shaping it to fit comfortably in his hand. With each careful cut, the wood takes form. Finally, he inspects the surface for any rough spots and removes them with the knife, creating a tool ready for heavy work.

A prehistoric craftsman selects a sturdy wooden handle, trimming its bark with a sharp flake. They pick a dense cobble with one flattened side and press it to the handle end. Next they harvest long fibers from grasses and inner bark, then strip them to extract strong veins. They wrap these fibers tightly around the junction, weaving back and forth in overlapping coils. They maintain even tension with each turn. Finally they moisten the bindings so they contract as they dry, producing a secure joint ready for heavy use.

gold.name: gold
gold.description: I find soft, heavy nuggets shimmering with a warm, yellow light. They catch the sun’s rays and sparkle like tiny suns. Smooth on the surface, yet occasionally jagged along edges. These bits lie nestled in rocky crevices and riverbed gravel, illuminated by the moving water. When held, they feel dense and cool against my palm. Their color is unlike any stone I know—a rich, glowing hue that stands apart.

stone wedge.name: stone wedge
stone wedge.description: A roughly triangular piece of dark, dense rock rests in your hand. Its base is broad and flat, while the opposite end tapers to a narrow, sharp ridge. One side bears chipped, uneven faces where thin flakes break away, revealing lighter streaks within the stone. The surface feels cool and slightly gritty, and faint striations run along its length. Despite its simplicity, it seems alive with quiet strength and real purpose.

steps.description: He rises at dawn and travels to outcrops along riverbanks and hillsides. He scans the land for exposed rock faces. He examines surface texture and color, seeking fine-grained, hard material. He picks up loose fragments and taps them together, listening for a sharp, ringing sound. He hefts candidate pieces, judging weight and balance in his hand. He rejects rounded pebbles and chooses angular blocks with visible fracture planes. He tests small flakes for hardness by striking against other rocks. When satisfied, he selects a suitable piece and carries it back to camp.

A gatherer selects a suitable rock with fine grain. He holds it firmly in one hand and raises a rounded hammerstone in the other. With a firm strike, he hits the edge at a low angle. Flakes break off with each blow, gradually creating a tapered shape. He shifts his grip to control the angle of each impact. The hammerstone delivers precise force, and the rock yields predictable shards. As he works, he rotates the core to chip away unwanted portions from both sides. Little by little, the form narrows into a sharp-edged tool. He inspects the emerging surfaces to keep edges symmetrical, adjusting strikes as needed to maintain balance.

hackle.name: hackle
hackle.description: A ring of narrow, pointed plumes encircles the slender neck of a large ground-dwelling fowl. Each feather is firm and glossy, tapering to a fine tip. In sunlight they glint with shifting hues of bright copper and bronze, revealing subtle lines of darker shade. When the bird moves, the plumes quiver and ripple along its throat and shoulders, creating a soft, rustling whisper that follows each graceful motion.

steps.description: A barefoot gatherer moves through the damp woodland, eyes scanning for fallen limbs of strong hardwood. He tests each candidate by lifting and snapping a small twig to gauge stiffness, then pries a straight branch roughly a foot long from the underbrush. Using a sharp flake of stone, he strips away bark and smooths rough spots, then lays the wood aside. He then climbs toward rocky outcrops where green staining marks hidden veins. With a hammerstone, he chips away at the weathered rock face, prying out heavy nuggets of copper ore. He slips the ore into a simple woven pouch and carries both wood and metal back to his clearing, ready for the next step.

The craftsman selects a sturdy piece of seasoned oak and lays it on a stable workbench. He grips a small, curved adze with strong, steady hands, raising it above the wood. With controlled swings, he peels away large chips, establishing the rough outline of the base. Each stroke flares the edges, guiding the adze to hollow the center. Periodically he rotates the block, checking symmetry from every angle. As the shape emerges, he shifts to lighter passes, refining the curves and flattening surfaces. The craftsman smooths the platform and carves shallow grooves along its length, ensuring consistent spacing. Finally, he inspects the form, readying it for the next phase of production.

An ancient artisan selects a solid length of hardwood and holds it steady against a stump. He grips a sharp knife with his strong hand and begins to score parallel lines where each socket will sit. Pressing the blade into the wood, he cuts a small cross shape, then pries out the shape, carving a shallow cup. With careful strokes, he widens and deepens each cavity until it perfectly fits a thin, pointed rod. He tests the fit, adjusting the edges to ensure a snug grip. In this way, he creates a row of secure seats along the beam, ready to hold the iron or bone spikes that will comb fibers.

First, the craftsman selects a roughly shaped piece of copper. He heats the metal over glowing coals until it reaches a dull red. He lays it on the flat stone anvil and strikes it firmly with his hammerstone, flattening and elongating the metal. He repeats this cycle of heating and hammering until the metal takes on a long, thin edge. Next, he inscribes shallow parallel grooves along one side by tapping gently with the hammerstone’s corner. With each repeat of heat and blows, these grooves deepen. He then positions the grooved edge across the anvil’s raised ridge and drives the hammerstone down to split the metal into narrow strips. He finishes by lightly tapping the emerging prongs on the anvil face to square and sharpen each tine.

He lays out a flat plank and grips the awl in his rough hand. Bracing the board, he twists the pointed tip of the awl along one edge, carving a row of evenly spaced holes. He cleans debris from each cavity. He selects a slender copper rod, smooths its tapered end against a stone, then pushes it into the first opening. Resting a small wooden block atop the rod’s exposed length, he raises the hammer and taps sharply until the metal seats firmly. He repeats the process for each remaining rod, spacing them at regular intervals. When every prong stands straight, he presses each with his finger, tapping loose ones into place. He brushes away stray splinters and admires the neat line of stiff copper tines ready for combing fibers.

stone blade.name: stone blade
stone blade.description: A slender shard of dark grey rock emerges, its edges thin and razorlike. One face is smooth and slightly convex, the other marred by a network of tiny ridges and flaking scars where chips once gave form. Sunlight glints across the glossy planes, revealing faint swirls of cold charcoal and subtle silver. From its base the silhouette tapers evenly, ending in a flawless, insectile line that catches the eye immediately.

steps.description: He moves to the river’s edge and examines the weathered boulders scattered across the pebbles. He kneels and taps a few candidates with a harder rock to test for sharp fracture. Finding a dense piece with even grain, he pries it loose from the ground. He wipes away the clinging dirt, then lifts the block to his chest. He sets the newly selected mass on a flat surface and rubs it in his hands to feel its weight and balance. This raw form will become the basis for further shaping.

First the human selects a medium-sized flint pebble with a good homogeneous texture. He holds the flint in one hand and grips a hammerstone in the other. He strikes the edge of the flint to detach large flakes, shaping a convex surface. He removes cortex by applying firm blows along the edges, creating a flat platform. He angles the flint against his palm, testing the angle of percussion. He trims the platform margin with light taps, generating a small lip that directs each blow. He continues striking around the core, rotating it to expose new edges and maintain a sharp angle. He adjusts his grip, ensuring each surface is ready for consistent flake removal.

An early toolmaker sits on a rock, holding a rounded hammerstone in one hand and a stone core in the other. He positions the core with one smooth face exposed at the edge of his knee, angling it slightly. With measured force, he raises the hammerstone overhead and brings it down sharply on the platform prepared at the core’s edge. A chip flies off, revealing a sharp surface. He checks the flake’s edge for a serrated line. He repeats the blow sequence, rotating the core to remove more thin, sharp flakes. Each piece becomes a precise cutting implement for slicing, scraping, or carving. His rhythm and skill refine the form.

He selects a flint nodule, examining its shape and flake potential. Holding it firmly in one hand or braced against the leg, he positions a hammerstone at the edge. With a swift, controlled strike, he detaches a thin, elongated flake. The fresh surface reveals a sharp ridge. He turns the core, targeting different angles to refine parallel edges. Percussion removes irregularities, producing a narrow segment. He repeats the action, monitoring fracture patterns and adjusting force. The process yields a slender cutting tool with precise, symmetrical sides. Finally, he inspects the edge and performs light retouches to perfect its shape. He continues until the tool meets requirements for thickness and balance.

blowing tube.name: blowing tube
blowing tube.description: A long, slender cylinder lies half-buried among fallen leaves and broken twigs. Its surface glows pale brown, streaked with faint lines that hint at layers once tightly bound around a core. Both ends open straight, their rims smoothed and gleaming. The inner channel runs uninterrupted from tip to tip, its walls polished to a dull sheen. When a breeze stirs, it emits a soft, hollow hum that shivers across the forest floor.

steps.description: He selects a straight stalk of reed and cuts a length from the stand. Using a sharp flint blade, he slices away leaf sheaths. He splits the reed lengthwise to expose the pith, then scrapes with a pointed stone to loosen the spongy core, shaking it out. He smooths the inner walls with a small scraper, rounding the edges, and trims each end for uniform length. He leaves the piece to dry in the sun, then taps an end to check its tone, yielding a hollow cylinder ready for use.

He positions a segment of bone on a flat stone slab set into the ground. He secures the piece with one hand and lifts a sturdy chisel carved from hard stone with the other. He marks the target length by scratching a shallow line across the circumference. He positions the chisel blade in the notch and strikes the back with a hammer pebble, first lightly then more firmly. The groove deepens under each tap until a crisp crack echoes through the hollow shaft. He twists off the extra length using the chisel edge, then refines the newly exposed end by shaving away jagged bits and smoothing the surface. He assesses each cut for straightness.

The maker selects a straight long bone, scrapes off any adhering tissue. He clamps one end with his knee against a flat stone. He pushes the awl’s sharp tip into the natural opening, twists it slowly to widen the core channel. He pulls out bone shavings, clearing them by exhaling through the hollow. He repeats insertion, rotating to reach every nook. He brushes away debris, then rinses the cavity with water from a gourd, expelling grit. He inspects the interior, ensuring smooth walls. Once breath flows freely, he coats the passage with animal fat. He tests with breath. He polishes the exterior and leaves it to dry in the sun.

tuy\u00e8re.name: tuyère
tuy\u00e8re.description: A slag-encrusted hardened cylinder emerges from a dark, earthen mound, its surface gleaming with spots of metallic sheen. One end flares open in a perfect circle, the other narrows to a tight, rust-speckled mouth. Its reddish-brown walls bear streaks of cinders melting into glassy veins. The hollow core stretches deep and silent, cool to the touch yet pocked with tiny pits and ridges whispering of ancient fires long remembered.

steps.description: He walks along the riverbank, kneeling to examine exposed clay layers. He pinches a small lump, feeling its smooth, sticky texture and pressing it for plasticity. He observes its color, noting fine grain and absence of grit. He tastes a bit for saltiness, smells for impurities. He traces the clay seam upstream, marking spots where the bank overhangs. He selects the richest patch, removing earth to reveal fresh clay below.

A primitive craftsman explores the riverbank at dawn, watching for patches of moist, dark clay exposed by receding water. He kneels and scrapes the soft earth with a stone blade, prying loose heavy lumps. He tests each bit between his fingers, discarding gritty or root-laced fragments. He piles pure lumps on a broad leaf, rinsing them lightly to wash away sand. He kneads the gathered clay into a cohesive mass, ready for further refinement. He carries the supple block to his shelter, leaving behind only small divots in the sun-baked shore.

A craftsman collects dense lumps of earth clay and dumps them into a shallow pit. He breaks the lumps into small bits and spreads them underfoot. He sprinkles water from a skin bag and lets it soak. After some hours, he kneads the softened material with his hands, pressing and folding to remove pockets of air. He adds small amounts of water as needed until the mixture feels moist yet firm. He tests the consistency by rolling a small coil, seeking a smooth, pliable texture that holds shape without cracking. When the clay mass is uniform and free of grit, he carries it to the work area, ready for shaping.

A primitive craftsman scoops a handful of earthen clay, adding water drop by drop. He kneads the mixture on a flat stone, pounding until no dry crumbs remain. Forming a thick sausage, he rolls it between his palms to create a uniform cylinder. Pressing thumbs into the center, he begins a hollow core, gradually sliding fingers through the length to widen and smooth the interior channel. He trims uneven edges with a small flint blade and checks wall thickness by feel, spinning the cylinder within open hands. A polished pebble glides along the outer surface, removing ridges. Finally, he sets the tube aside to air-dry before firing near embers.

Early humans collect fine earth, removing stones and roots, and mix it with water until it has a firm, workable consistency. They roll a small loaf into a cylinder, then thrust a straight stick through its center, carving out a channel for air. They wiggle the stick to widen the opening, pull it free, and smooth the edges. After sun drying, they fire the piece in embers, creating a hard, air-conduit nozzle.

He collects fine clay, kneads with water, and forms a long hollow cylinder around a stick. After smoothing, he sets it in the sun to air-dry. He trims rough edges with a stone. When the clay feels firm, he builds a pit lined with stones. He fires coals around the tube, adding fresh embers to raise heat. He watches the color change to pale cream. After several hours, he lets the fire die. He cools slowly under ash to prevent cracks. The result is a hard tube ready for use.

A primitive craftsman gathers a straight branch and carves it into a hollow cylinder. He shapes the inside with a pointed stone and smooths the walls by rubbing with wet clay. He embeds this cylinder in a shallow trench beside the fire. He pours water into one end and it seeps through the moist clay lining, absorbing heat as it trickles down. The cooled interior channel draws in fresh air, feeding the embers with a steady breeze while resisting high temperatures. He maintains a slow drip and checks for blockages.

stick.name: stick
stick.description: Nestled among fallen leaves on the forest floor lies a slender, dry, woody limb, measuring almost the length of a forearm. Its surface is rough, marked by cracks and patches of peeling bark that reveal paler wood beneath. One end tapers to a narrower tip, the other widens slightly. It feels lightweight yet sturdy when lifted. Moss fragments cling to its crevices, and lichen webs stretch across its weathered surface.

copper ingot.name: copper ingot
copper ingot.description: A roughly six-inch by two-inch smooth, heavy block gleams with a warm orange-red luster under sunlight. Its edges are sharp but slightly rounded, hinting at shaping by great heat and press. The surface feels cool and metallic to the touch, uninterrupted by cracks or veins. It pulses light with every movement, reflecting a fiery glow that stands apart from stones or earth. Its uniform shape suggests careful crafting by unknown hands.

steps.description: He walks along rocky hills and riverbeds, watching for greenish stains on stones and soil. He tests rocks with a sharp stone, looking for telltale bluish or emerald veins. He examines outcrops for weathered surfaces and breaks pieces to spot metallic flakes. He notes where rust-colored crusts form on weathered rock. He marks promising spots with stone markers. He tests nearby streams, dipping a leather pouch to sift sand and gravel.

The primitive human lifts a chunk of copper ore and sets it on a stable rock platform. He grasps the hammerstone firmly and brings it down against the ore with rhythmic strikes. Each blow chips away outer layers, cracking the rock and exposing glimmering metal veins inside. He rotates the ore, repeatedly tapping along natural fractures until small flakes and fragments break free. He discards barren shards, sorting the richer bits carefully for further processing. Dust and sparks fly with every hit, and he pauses occasionally to clear debris. Through patient pounding and sorting, he gradually liberates thin metal pieces from the rocky matrix, preparing them for the next stage.

A solitary craftsman kneels before a clay furnace built of stones and clay. Beads of sweat dot his brow as he crouches near the furnace. He places charcoal in the base and arranges broken chunks of copper ore atop it. He puffs steadily through a hollow reed tuyere, fanning the glowing embers until a fierce orange flame leaps. The intense heat strips oxygen from the ore, turning it molten and glowing like liquid fire. Periodically he stirs the bubbling mass with a heated iron rod, coaxing impurities to rise as slag scum on the surface. With patience and steady breath he tilts the crucible with care, letting the liquid metal flow into a prepared stone mold. Once cooled, the solid bar falls free, shining with a bright reddish hue and ready for further shaping.

A lone craftsman breaks raw copper into small fragments and piles them into a clay crucible. He builds a charcoal fire in a shallow pit until embers glow bright orange, then positions the crucible atop the coals. Using simple leather bellows, he pumps air to raise the heat until the copper melts into glowing liquid. He tests the temperature by dipping a small iron rod; once the metal clings and runs smoothly, he lifts the crucible with wooden tongs. Nearby, a stone or clay mould carved with a rectangular cavity waits on a flat stone. Steadily and carefully, he pours the molten copper into the mould, taking care to fill every corner. When the fire dies down, he waits for the metal to cool and solidify into a neat bar. Finally, he taps the mould open and retrieves his newly formed metal block.

antler tine.name: antler tine
antler tine.description: On the dappled forest floor lies a slender, gently curving rod of pale, polished bone. Its smooth surface is streaked with faint, natural grooves tracing its length. One end flares into a broader, rough, jagged base where it separated from its parent structure. The opposite tip tapers to a sturdy, rounded point. Sun and rain have faded its color to a soft, creamy hue, while subtle cracks hint at ancient growth.

steps.description: A primitive hunter crouches at the edge of a clearing, heart steady. He grips his knife in hand. He moves downwind, eyes fixed on the grazing deer. He slows every breath, sliding behind low brush. Stealth guides each step. Once within striking range, he shifts weight forward, coiling like a cat. He lunges, plunging the blade into the animal’s chest behind the shoulder. The deer shudders, legs folding as life ebbs. The hunter holds firm, twisting the knife to sever major vessels. When movement ceases, he kneels beside the still form. He lifts the branching horns to inspect the heavy skull. He then begins tasks for transporting the body and horns to camp.

The human grasps the raw antler in one hand, securing it against a stable surface. With the knife held in the dominant hand, they start by scoring a line at the base of the desired projection. They rotate the piece, deepen the cut, and apply steady pressure, slicing through the rough bone. Small chips fly as they work the blade back and forth, widening the groove. Rhythmic strokes help them gradually penetrate the core, feeling the resistance lessen. As the cut reaches full depth, they lever the projection away from the main beam. Finally, they separate it completely, leaving a clean break and a shaped piece ready for further refinement.

A craftsman selects a solid piece of antler and examines its side branches. He spots a short projection and scores a narrow groove around its base using a sharp flint flake. Holding the beam steady against a flat rock, he strikes the notch firmly with a hammerstone until the branch cracks loose. Then he twists the fragment by hand to finish the break. Once detached, he smooths the fresh cut with sandstone, removing jagged edges. He inspects the separated piece, ensuring the fracture is clean and removing any irregularities with light pecking.

antler.name: antler
antler.description: You notice a rigid, branching structure sprouting from a fallen beast’s skull. Its surface is rough and bony, mottled earthy browns and tarnished whites. Thick beams swell near the base, splitting into narrower tines that reach outward like tree forks. Each tine bears growth rings and occasional ridges, hinting at seasonal cycles. The whole form feels heavy and solid, yet hollow partway toward the tips. Faint dried velvet clings in crevices.

steps.description: A hunter moves through dense woods at dawn, eyes scanning fallen branches and animal remains. He slows near a clearing, noticing sheds from last season snagged on low branches or half-buried in mossy earth. He crouches, brushing away leaves to reveal its shape. He tests each piece for size and integrity, tapping to gauge density. When satisfied, he lifts a suitable tine and slings it across his back, ready for crafting.

He scans the carcass for the curved beam that holds hardened branches. He lifts his slab and positions the hammerstone against the base where it meets the skull. He strikes with steady rhythm, chipping away bone until the lobed beam loosens. He applies prying pressure to pluck the material from the cranium. He drops the skull and hefts the beam, feeling its weight and balance. He taps off flesh and debris with the hammerstone, revealing smooth length and branching points. He carries the resource to his work area for shaping.

antlered animal.name: antlered animal
antlered animal.description: This creature moves with soft-footed grace along the forest fringe. It stands on four slender, tapering legs tipped with hard, cloven ends. Its sleek coat ranges from tawny brown to pale fawn, and a lighter patch gleams at its flank. Atop its head, two branching crowns of bone extend outward, each prong curving skyward. Its large, dark eyes survey the clearing, ears pricking at any distant stir of wind or twig.

needle.name: needle
needle.description: A tiny, slender fragment of gleaming gray metal lies hidden among grasses. It stretches straight and narrow, smooth yet unbending. At one end it tapers almost imperceptibly to a fine, glinting tip. The other end is blunt and solid, forming a rigid metallic spine flickering in the light. It feels colder than any stone and holds a perfectly straight form that seems too precise to be born of earth.

steps.description: He scouts for a fresh kill or carcass near his hunting grounds. He selects long, durable limb bones from a deer or bison, avoiding cracked, rotten, or warped fragments. He breaks the chosen bone with a hammerstone and a sturdy rock, splitting it along its grain. He scraps off any remaining sinew and marrow with a sharp flake blade, rinsing the piece in running water. He sun-dries the cleaned bone on a flat rock to harden it. He carries the dried section back to his shelter, ready for detailed crafting.

First, the maker selects a sturdy long bone and splits off a small segment. With a sharp knife, he scrapes away thick outer layers, shaving thin slivers until the piece narrows. He whittles each side to a consistent taper, rotating the fragment between grips. The artisan shapes the tip into a fine point, carving away uneven ridges with precise strokes. Then he hollows out a tiny groove near the opposite end, slicing carefully to form an eyelet. To refine the shape, he rubs the tool’s surface against a coarse stone, smoothing edges. Finally, he tests its strength, ensuring the slender implement resists bending. Sweat beads on his brow as he works.

He selects a short splinter of bone and holds it firmly against a flat surface. With the blade, he carves a pointed tip at one end. Then he marks a tiny spot a few millimeters away, pressing blade tip to score a circle. He inserts the tip into the score, twisting the blade back and forth to bore the eye. He clears fragments by flicking chips away with the edge. As the cavity deepens, he repeats the twisting motion, gradually enlarging the aperture. When the opening is wide enough to thread sinew, he smooths the edges by shaving thin slivers around the rim. He tests passage until it glides cleanly.

mould.name: mould
mould.description: On a damp, fallen tree limb in the forest, soft, fuzzy patches spread across the wood’s surface. The growth starts as pale, almost ghostly white, then shifts into shades of grey, green, and deep charcoal. Its texture resembles cotton or spiderwebs, delicate filaments intertwining in intricate patterns. Where the patches thicken, they form circular colonies studded with minuscule, dust-like specks. A musty, earthy scent lingers around the spreading veil.

comb.name: comb
comb.description: This object lies flat, slender and rectangular, its edges rounded by a careful hand. One side holds a line of narrow, evenly spaced teeth that rise like little columns, each smooth and tapering to a fine tip. The surface bears faint carving marks, while the color shifts in pale cream or warm brown. It feels light yet sturdy in the palm, the teeth casting tiny shadows on the ground beneath.

steps.description: He scans the surroundings for discarded remains. He locates a deer skeleton, leftover from a fresh predator kill. He approaches, watching for scavengers. He grips a sturdy femur, testing its heft, thickness. He inspects bone surfaces for cracks or rot, selecting those dense and unblemished. Ribs and limb bones rise to the top of his choices. Satisfied, he gathers several pieces and carries them to his shelter. He stores them near a flat stone, ready for the next step in transforming raw remains into a useful tool.

He selects a sturdy length of bone and holds it firmly against a wooden block. He draws the edge of his flint knife along the surface until a thin sliver loosens. He presses the tip against the fragment’s base and twists gently to separate it from the parent material. As the bit detaches, he catches it carefully, mindful of its thin edges. He trims away fibers with short, precise, careful strokes to free the fragment. He inspects the fragment’s shape, tapping it to refine its form. If needed, he repeats the process to harvest additional fragments of desired length from the bone. After enough, he sets them aside for shaping.

A figure kneels by a shallow stream and lifts a slender piece of material from the muddy bank. He dips it in clear, cool water and tilts it to wash away loose earth. He rubs his fingertips along each jagged edge, coaxing clinging grit away. Then he slaps the fragment gently against a smooth stone to dislodge stubborn bits. He returns it to the flow and watches the current carry off particles. Finally, he pats the surface dry with a leaf and sets it aside for the next shaping step.

The primitive artisan holds a cleaned bone fragment firmly under one arm. With a sharpened knife, he carefully slices away irregularities to form a slender rectangle. He slowly smooths the surface by running the blade edge lengthwise, removing chips and achieving even thickness. Then he marks a row of shallow notches along one side and deepens each groove one by one, carving out slender teeth. He turns the piece to check alignment, ensuring each element stands evenly spaced. Finally, he refines each point with the knife tip and rubs the surface to remove sharp edges, creating a simple tool for untangling fibers through hair or hides.

He selects a sturdy piece of bone and examines its length, imagining it as a tool for hair. He trims and shapes it with a sharp stone blade, removing excess to form a flat body with evenly spaced prongs. He repeats gentle strokes, breaking off splinters and rounding edges. He rubs the item against a grinding stone, moving it to remove rough patches. He follows with finer grit, smoothing each projection until the surface glows. He inspects every groove, ensuring no burrs remain. He holds the object to check its weight and balance. He washes the piece with water, drying it in the sun before testing its glide through hair.

grinding stone.name: grinding stone
grinding stone.description: A heavy, rounded slab of mottled gray rock rests on the ground. Its surface is smoothed in the center, with faintly carved grooves tracing gentle curves. Rougher, jagged edges circle the perimeter, giving it an uneven outline. Its underside is coarse and darker, speckled with tiny white flecks. The shape fits snugly in both hands, solid and cold to the touch, sitting low against the earth.

steps.description: A primitive human approaches a riverbank at dawn, eyes scanning for heavy, dense rocks. He crouches beside the flowing water and probes for smooth, flat boulders. He hefts a few candidates, gauging weight and heft. He strikes each with a smaller rock to hear the tone—seeking a clear, ringing sound. He checks the surface for durability and uniformity. Satisfied, he selects a suitable rock and carries it to camp.

He searches for a coarse-grained boulder at a streambed. He lifts his hammerstone and positions it against a protruding section of rock. A precise strike detaches a shard, so he chips along natural fissures, producing a thick, flake-strewn core. He rotates the core and delivers successive blows, thinning its edges and flattening one surface. He inspects the fragment, rubbing it across an abrasive outcrop to smooth rough spots. When satisfied with thickness, he leverages a pointed stone to pry loose a flat circular section. He finishes by pecking small pits along its surface, preparing it for later use. Each step relies on patient strikes and tactile feedback, shaping its final contour.

A primitive craftsman selects a firm, fine-grained stone and holds it on a stable surface. He strikes the stone blank repeatedly with a hammerstone, producing controlled fractures. He chips away irregular bits, rotating the piece after each blow to maintain an even profile. Once roughly shaped, he applies lighter taps around the perimeter, thinning edges and refining the outline. Then he uses the hammerstone’s face to peck the surface, creating shallow depressions. By alternating strikes and careful inspection, he achieves a flatter, more uniform form. He smooths high spots with controlled percussion, ensuring both sides approach the desired thickness. The result is a durable, shaped implement ready for further smoothing.

drill bits.name: drill bits
drill bits.description: A cluster of slender rods, each long as a finger, glints like cold river stones in the sun. Each rod bears a tight spiral groove from tip to base. The tips narrow to a fine, glimmering point. Some rods end in thicker collars while others remain uniform. They feel heavy and smooth under fingers. Their twisted channels spiral around the shaft like coiled vines, catching light in rhythmic, metallic gleams.

steps.description: He scans the riverbank at dawn, eyes peeled for nodules that glint in shallow pools. He wades into water, probing beneath pebbles with a stick, seeking strong rock. He taps suspect pieces together, listening for a clear tone. He examines each piece for cracks or impurities before setting off, ensuring a durable yield. He gathers fist-sized chunks of flint, quartz, or basalt, prying them from mud with a sharpened stick. He carries the chosen stones back on a strip of hide, ready to shape and refine them into piercing heads for tools.

A craftsman selects a fine-grained stone nodule and grasps it firmly. He studies the surface to identify a flat platform near an edge. Placing the core on his thigh or holding it in his non-dominant hand, he lifts a hammerstone. He positions the edge of the hammerstone against the platform at a low angle. With a steady motion, he strikes the core’s edge, watching the force transfer through the material. A thin flake detaches, curving away from the platform. He inspects the flake’s length, thickness, and edge angle to ensure suitability. By rotating the core and repeating precise strikes, he produces multiple sharp flakes ready for further refinement. He continues until he has gathered enough flakes.

The flintknapper holds a sharp flake firmly against a piece of wood. He raises a hammerstone in his other hand and strikes the edge of the flake at a low angle. Small chips break away, creating a refined ridge along the edge. He rotates and repeats strikes on the opposite side to shape a symmetrical bevel. He inspects the tip, adjusting the angle to achieve a fine point. Each blow is controlled, removing only a little material to prevent a large fracture. He occasionally shifts his grip for soft percussion with the rounded hammerstone surface, producing gentle, precise removals. The result is a strong, razor-sharp tip ready for penetrating wood.

flake.name: flake
flake.description: A small, slender shard of dark stone lies half-buried in soft earth. Its surface is smooth and glassy, catching sunlight in sharp reflections. Both sides curve gently toward ultra-thin edges that are almost translucent at the corners. Minute ripples flow across the face, like frozen waves captured in rock. No dirt clings to its glossy planes, and it seems unnaturally uniform, as if cleaved cleanly from a larger mass.

steps.description: He squats by the ridge of river pebbles at dawn. His eyes scan for a solid chunk of stone with sharp edges and consistent texture. He picks up several cobbles, tapping one lightly against his thigh to listen for a clear, ringing tone. He examines its smooth surface, feeling for tiny cracks or uneven spots that might cause unwanted breaks. He weighs each candidate in his palm, judging heft and balance. When he finds a clean, fine-grained rock, he sets aside the rest and carries the chosen piece to his work area.
Unfortunately, the model refused to describe step {'step': 'grip rock', 'tools': [], 'raw_materials': ['rock']}

A primitive human crouches by a flat stone base and grips a rounded hammerstone in a strong palm. They examine a raw rock, turning it to find a fine-grained edge. Holding the raw rock in their other hand at a slight angle, they raise the hammerstone high and bring it down hard against the edge. A thin shard snaps free, and they catch it on the palm of their free hand. They adjust the angle, aiming each blow just below the surface. Heat from the impact glows faintly at the point of contact. Each strike yields a sharp-edged shard, and the human repeats the motion until they shape a tool edge.

He kneels beside a flat rock surface, eyes fixed on the newly detached chip lying at his feet. He lowers one hand toward the earth and braces himself with the other planted firmly on the ground. With a steady grip, he lifts the thin shard, mindful of its sharp edge. He inspects the fragment’s shape and thickness, turning it to examine its potential uses. He brings it closer, feeling its weight and testing its balance. Satisfied, he sets it on a hide or in a basket to keep it safe for later toolmaking.

adze.name: adze
adze.description: A piece of stone, taking the form of a flattened blade with a sharp edge, is bound firmly to a sturdy wooden shaft. The blade’s face slopes back, offering a narrow, rectilinear cutting surface offset from the straight handle. The handle feels worn and rounded at one end where the blade is secured. The tool balances in the hand, its edge sweeping outward at an oblique angle to the shaft.

steps.description: At a slow pace, a primitive human searches along a rocky streambed for a fractured chunk of hard stone. He crouches beside the water, eyes scanning smooth, river-worn cobbles and angular shards. He plucks up promising candidates, feeling their weight and texture, then taps each gently with a smaller rock to test for clean, sharp flakes. He seeks a roughly rectangular piece about palm-length, with fine-grained structure and no visible cracks. Satisfied with its size and flawlessness, he sets the selected stone aside as the blank for his cutting implement.

A primitive craftsman selects a suitable flint nodule with a bulb and fracture. He clears a striking platform by removing small flakes with the hammerstone, creating a smooth surface angled about 60 degrees to the core’s contour. He steadies the core in one hand against a support or holds it at arm’s length, gripping the platform edge. With controlled force, he drives the hammerstone into the platform, aiming to detach a flake whose dimensions suit a tool head blank. The blow releases a sharp-edged flake that detaches cleanly along the core’s plane of weakness. The craftsman inspects the flake for even thickness and a cutting edge, ready for further shaping.

He selects a flat, dense stone from the riverbank and holds it firmly in one hand. With the hammerstone in the other hand, he strikes the edge of the raw block to knock off large flakes. Each sharp blow follows the curve he envisions, and he inspects the emerging outline after every few strikes. When the rough shape resembles a blade with a straight cutting face and a broad heel, he stops percussive work.

Next, he rubs the newly flaked edge against a coarse grinding stone. He presses evenly and moves the tool back and forth, wearing away irregularities. As powdery grit appears, he checks for symmetry and adjusts pressure. Gradually, the edge becomes thinner and straighter. When the blade feels both smooth and keen to the touch, he considers the shaping complete.

A craftsman steps into the grove, scans fallen wood for a branch roughly thumb-thick, free of knots and twists. He tests length, holding it against his arm to check balance. He taps along its shaft, listening for hollow or rotten spots. He examines the bark, seeking smooth, unblemished grain. He breaks away twigs, judging strength and flexibility. When he finds a straight, sturdy segment with the right dimensions, he snaps it off at the base. He wraps cord or vine around one end to mark the future handle, ready for shaping.

He selects a sturdy branch and marks the shape of the handle with charcoal. He holds the wood firmly and uses the knife to pare away thin shavings, working along the grain to avoid splintering. He carves a gentle curve for gripping and eases the rear end into a narrower point for fitting the blade. He smoothes each surface by slicing with controlled cuts, feeling the form emerge under his blade. He tests the diameter by wrapping fingers around it and refines areas that feel rough. He fashions notches or grooves at the top to secure the metal against rotation. He polishes the wood surface with sharp final trimming cuts.

First, he selects a sturdy piece of hide and soaks it in water until pliable. After drying it slightly, he cuts narrow strips. He positions the stone blade against the carved wooden handle, aligning the bevel. He wraps a strip tightly around the haft, pressing the hide into the notch. He ties a secure knot and continues to spiral the wrap, overlapping each turn. After covering the joint, he tucks the end under the last coil. He lets the hide dry, tightening the lashing as it shrinks, binding the blade firmly in place.

whetstone.name: whetstone
whetstone.description: It is a nondescript piece of stone, shaped by water and time into a compact slab. Its surface is smooth yet subtly pitted, revealing a dense weave of pale gray grains. The edges are gently rounded, and the top face bears faint striations like river channels. It feels cool and heavy in the hand, its weight surprising for its size. Under daylight its hue shifts from stone-gray to an ash tone.

glass vase.name: glass vase
glass vase.description: A translucent bulb stands upright, its slender neck widening into a curving chamber. Its surface is impossibly smooth, cool to the touch, rim perfectly even as though shaped by moonlight. Pale green or clear walls pass light, scattering soft glimmers around. No seam mars its form, and it rests with unearthly stillness, its glow hinting at hidden depths. The eye cannot trace its origin, and its beauty feels born of dream.

steps.description: He stands at the edge of sunbaked dunes, searching for fine pale grains for his craft. He dips his leather pouch into the shifting sands and lifts a handful, letting the wind carry away coarse bits until pale grains settle. With his hands caked in dust, he moves to a nearby salt flat, where white crusts line the ground. He breaks away lumps of natron with a sharp flint and tucks them into a woven basket. He selects only the whitest pieces. Next, he treks toward a limestone outcrop, prying chunks free with a club. He hefts each chunk to test its durability and adds it to his load. He carries his haul back under the sun, wary of loose stones, then stores each material in clay bins near a fire pit.

He gathers clean sand, small lumps of natron and chunks of limestone on a flat stone. He weighs together two parts sand, one part natron, and half part limestone. He smashes the limestone into fine crumb with a hammer. He breaks the natron into small fragments, discarding impurities. He holds a wooden paddle and stirs the powders on a low hearth. He carefully blends the grains, pushing them back and forth until the mixture looks uniform. He tips the mix through a coarse woven cloth to sift away large bits. He returns the sifted material to a clay container, smoothing its surface. He repeats stroking and folding until the powders appear perfectly even in color and texture. He stores the blend away from moisture. He murmurs a blessing before resting.

A primitive human prepares to melt a mixture for crafting. He selects fine sand, natron and crushed limestone, measuring each by eye. He places a pile of sand into the bottom of a crucible, then adds a layer of natron to act as a flux. Next, he sprinkles crushed limestone around the edge. He shakes the crucible carefully to distribute the ingredients evenly. Carrying the crucible with tongs, he sets it inside a furnace fed with charcoal. He feeds bellows, watching the temperature rise as glowing coals turn white-hot. The mixture inside the crucible begins to bubble and smoke as the flux lowers the melting point of the silica particles. After minutes of constant heating, the mass turns liquid and translucent, forming a glowing pool. He opens a vent in the furnace arch to release excess gas, monitoring the molten material until it achieves uniform clarity. He removes the crucible, stirs the molten mass with an iron rod to ensure homogeneity, and prepares to shape the material before it cools.

He lights a fire and places raw chunks of glass among the coals. When the material softens, he uses a charred stick to pull and spin the glowing mass. He rolls it along a flat stone to smooth the surface, then re-heats and continues to press the sides inward, forming a narrow neck atop a rounded bottom. His steady hands guide the stick to carve gentle curves, and he taps rhythmic patterns on the side to thin the walls. After a final smoothing with a damp leaf, the shape stands hollow and ready to hold water. He lets it cool slowly, avoiding sudden shifts that could crack the delicate form.

A lone artisan shapes molten sand into a shimmering vessel over a flame. He collects beads on the tip of a hollow reed, spinning the mass with skillful hands. Each turn smooths the walls, coaxing curves that catch the light. The artisan breathes into the tube, controlling the flow, while embers dance. As the form grows, he marks it with patterns, then quenches it in cool water, revealing its translucent beauty.

glass.name: glass
glass.description: Scattered along riverbanks, shards shine with an eerie clarity. The pieces are smooth yet jagged, their edges catching sunlight in sharp glints. They feel cold and slick beneath the fingers, as though they whisper of water suspended in solid form. Transparent slices reveal distant objects warped behind them, while some fragments flash pale rainbows when tilted toward the sky. Each fragment holds an uncanny, haunting stillness, both fragile and unyielding.

steps.description: He rises before dawn, grabbing a woven basket and a sturdy digging stick. At the riverbank, he scoops fine, pale grains of sand into the basket, sifting out small pebbles and rinsing the load in a shallow pool. Once the basket fills, he carries it across rolling grassland to a dry lake bed. There he scrapes salt-like natron crystals from exposed, sun-baked clay, carefully depositing each glittering shard into his basket. Next, he treks toward low chalk cliffs where nodules of soft, white limestone lie half-buried. Using his stone scraper, he chips away fragments, gathering angular chunks in a second woven container. When his harvest brims, he binds the baskets to his back with leather straps. With his raw materials secured, he heads home to begin the next stage of his craft.

They gather fine streams of sand, scoop lumps of natron and shards of limestone. Using a carved bowl, they pour in two parts sand, one part natron and half part crushed limestone, estimating by handful. They grasp a pestle and grind the particles, pressing to break any small rocks. Then they tip the powder onto a flat slab and use a spatula to fold the components. They paddle the heap, pushing lighter grains over heavier, ensuring each glint of natron and fragment of limestone evenly spreads. They heap the blend near the hearth for melting and rub a small pinch between fingers to feel for gliding grains, ensuring no coarse bits survive. They tap the bowl’s side, listening for a uniform dull thud that signals a well-blended batch.

A craftsman loads the crucible with a measured blend of fine sand and crushed natron. He slides the crucible into the glowing heart of the furnace and closes its door to trap heat. Coals crackle as the fire climbs past 1,100 degrees Celsius, and the contents begin to soften. Every few minutes, he pries open the furnace, tilts the crucible slightly, and stirs the molten mass with a long iron rod, watching for a uniform, flowing texture. Bubbles rise and break on the surface; he gently skims away any dark scum that gathers at the rim. As the mixture becomes clear and viscous, he tests its fluidity by dipping a small iron loop into the melt and lifting a ribbon of material. Satisfied by its smooth, consistent flow, he withdraws the crucible and prepares to shape the glowing, malleable substance before it cools.

The artisan gathers a glowing bead from the kiln, using a hollow iron tube called a mandrel. He dips the heated rod into the molten silicate mixture, spinning it as layers cling to the tip. With careful rotation, the fluid mass stays even and round. He controls the shape by gently sweeping a metal paddle, coaxing it into the desired form. As the material cools slightly, he adds color with crushed minerals, rolling them onto the surface. He shapes necks and bulbs, pulls out slender threads, and forms small beads. When the piece is complete, he lets it rest on the mandrel until it solidifies.

At midday, the maker builds a fire from heated sand and crushed ash. He dips a long reed into the glowing melt, pulling a blob of molten material. With steady breaths, he spins the glowing drop as it darkens and stiffens. He rolls the soft mass on a stone slab, smoothing its surface with a wet twig. Tiny sparks fade as the mass cools, leaving a solid, shimmering orb ready for adornment.

natron.name: natron
natron.description: A broad, shining plain stretches before you, its crust gleaming pale like frozen foam under the sun. The ground is brittle beneath your feet, breaking into chalky fragments that crumble easily. When wet, it slurps underfoot, slick and greasy, leaving white streaks on skin. Wind carries fine, powdery dust that stings light as ash in the lungs. Scattered in shallow hollows are irregular, pure-white lumps that sparkle in bright light.

limestone.name: limestone
limestone.description: A pale, chalky rock emerges from the cliff, its surface worn smooth by water and wind. White to creamy gray hues blend with faint veins of darker speckles. The edges break in flat planes, revealing a crumbly interior that glints in the sunlight. When touched, it feels cool and slightly rough, with occasional pits where tiny fossils lie hidden in its layers. Sturdy and heavy in the hand.

mandrel.name: mandrel
mandrel.description: A long, slender rod of gleaming, cool metal lies half-buried in the earth. Its surface is unnaturally smooth, reflecting sunlight in a silvery shine. One end tapers to a subtle point before widening into a uniform cylinder. The weight feels solid and unyielding in the hand, its form unbroken by knots or bends. It makes a hollow thud when tapped against stone. Its ends feature clean, squared-off faces, each edge biting the air.

steps.description: He moves among fallen logs, seeking a straight branch. He tests a chosen limb by rolling it on the ground until it steadies. He strips bark with a chipped flake, revealing smooth grain. He places a carved wooden disc against the shaft to gauge thickness. He marks each spot with a notch from his stone. He holds the shaft upright, studies its balance, and checks its diameter. He rubs the shaft between his palms to feel irregularities. When the shape feels balanced, he settles on this section as his working core.

He selects a straight hardwood branch. He holds the blade firmly in one hand and strips away rough bark, revealing wood grain beneath. He sketches the desired outline with shallow incisions. He uses the sharp edge to shave thin layers, gradually shaping the profile. Each stroke follows the grain, preserving strength. He carves down toward the core, hollowing the central axis. He flicks shavings away with a practiced wrist motion to keep symmetry. He refines ridges and smooths protrusions with gentle slicing. He runs his fingers along the form, checking for high spots and low areas. He repeats measured cuts until the shape feels even and ready for use.

A solitary metalworker stands before a low clay-and-stone anvil, gripping a glowing copper rod with sturdy iron tongs. She heats the rod in a simple charcoal-fueled hearth until it glows bright orange. Lifting it from the fire, she lays it across the anvil’s flat face and delivers firm, controlled hammer blows. Each strike spreads and thins the metal, and she rotates the rod in the tongs so every side meets the hammer’s eye. As one end begins to taper, she shifts her grip and focuses on refining a smooth, rounded tip. When the copper cools enough to lose its glow, she returns it to the fire, reheating until soft and malleable. She alternates between heavy blows to shape the overall profile and lighter taps to refine curves and eliminate irregularities. After several cycles of forging and reheating, the shaft grows straight and uniform. Finally, she cools it in water and uses a flat stone to polish its surface, revealing the bright copper finish of her crafted tool.

camera.name: camera
camera.description: A small, angular box rests in the hand, its sides forged from smooth, dark metal with precise edges. A glassy orb protrudes from one face, its clear surface catching light like a dewdrop spun from crystal. Tiny ridges circle its edge, offering a faint grip under rough fingers. On the top, a flat panel mirrors the sky, framed by minute buttons, engraved with lines that hum silently beneath paling sunlight.

steps.description: A primitive craftsman selects sturdy planks of wood from a nearby grove. He examines each piece for straight grain and minimal knots. Holding a plank steady, he marks outlines for side panels. He uses a saw to slice through wood fibers, creating two identical rectangles for front and back faces. Next, he saws four narrower strips to form side walls of the box. He arranges panels on a work surface, aligning edges precisely. With a hammer in hand, he drives wooden pegs through predrilled holes to securely join each corner. He tightens each joint and taps gently to avoid splitting the wood. After assembly, he checks that all joints sit flush. He sands rough spots until each surface feels smooth. The result is a wooden enclosure, ready for further refinement.

At the hearth, the artisan scoops greasy animal fat into a hollowed stone bowl. He scrapes soot from a charred wood surface, letting fine black powder drifts into the bowl. With a wooden spatula, he kneads fat and soot until the mixture becomes a thick paste. He lifts the small wooden box and tilts it so that the opening faces him. Then he dabs the paste onto the inside walls, pressing and spreading in circular motions. Gradually the interior darkens to a deep matte black. He smooths the final layer, ensuring no streaks remain. The light is now unable to reflect, and the tiny space holds only darkness.

A primitive maker selects a thin disc of copper and secures it on a flat stone. He grips an awl and positions its tip at the center of the disc. He presses firmly, rotating the awl in small circles. The copper resists, but he persistently twists and pounds the tool, piercing the metal. Once a small hole appears, he wiggles the awl to widen it just enough to admit a beam of light. He inspects the aperture, smoothing rough edges against the stone. He polishes around the opening with a scrap of hide, ensuring the rim remains clean and precise. The result is a perfect, tiny pinhole for focusing light.

In a sheltered hut, a hunter-polisher marks a wooden frame, fitting a round pane of glass ground to a smooth curve. He carves a darkened chamber from hollowed wood, cutting a small aperture at one end. He mounts the curved pane opposite the hole, shifting its position until distant trees appear sharply on the far wall. He drapes animal hide around his shoulders to block stray light, pressing his eye close to the opening. In the dim space the inverted shapes of birds and branches glow in crisp detail.

saw.name: saw
saw.description: A single long strip of cold, gleaming material lies before you. One side glimmers with a row of identical triangular points like the tooth of a great, unseen creature. The other side feels flat and smooth, its surface reflecting light. This rigid form maintains straightness, its edges unblemished. Weighing heavier than wood yet thinner than bark, it emits a metallic ring if tapped against stone, as though alive with energy.

steps.description: He selects a dense flint nodule and grips it firmly in one hand. With a rounded hammerstone in the other, he strikes the flint’s edge at a low angle, detaching long, slender flakes and forming an elongated blade blank. As the blank grows, he shifts his grip and uses lighter, more precise blows to refine its outline. Then he focuses on the cutting edge: he taps small, evenly spaced notches along one side by placing the blade against a soft wood block and striking each point with controlled force. Each tap deepens and widens the notch, creating a row of sharp projections. He tests the finished tool by drawing it across a piece of wood; the toothy edge bites in smoothly, and he adjusts any irregular notches until the cut feels consistent and efficient. Satisfied, he reserves the new implement for daily splitting and carving tasks.

He positions a sharp chipped stone edge against a length of sturdy wood. He cuts long strands of woven plant fiber and soaks them to increase flexibility. He twists each strand, strengthening the cord. He drapes them around the base of the stone. He pulls fibers tight, winding them along the wood, pressing the flint firmly into place. He compacts the fibers with a stick, ensuring no slack remains. He repeats the wrapping until the blade fits snugly against the handle. The assembly holds fast, ready for cutting tasks.

animal fat.name: animal fat
animal fat.description: In a fresh carcass beneath the hide, layers of a pale, creamy substance sit glistening in the sun. Soft and pliant, it yields a tacky sheen under gentle pressure. When warmed by midday heat, small beads ooze like molten cream, pooling around joints and cavities. Its mild scent mingles with blood, hinting at richness. Strands connect muscle to bone, slipping away in gentle coils as the flesh is torn apart.

soot.name: soot
soot.description: On the underside of heated stones or in hollows near smoky fires, a fine, black dust settles like the softest ash. It clings to fingers and the smooth surfaces of stones, brushing away to reveal pale rock beneath. In shaded crevices, it darkens the walls with a dull sheen. When disturbed by a breeze or a hand’s movement, it drifts as tiny specks, swirling briefly before sinking onto darkened patches.

helicopter.name: helicopter
helicopter.description: Above the treetops hovers a massive creature of gleaming metal. Its smooth, curved panels glint in sunlight as it drifts above the canopy. Four broad, flat arms spin in furious circles, carving the air with a thunderous roar. Its round belly hangs heavy below a spinning crown, and its straight tail extends like a spear behind. Each rotation shudders the earth, stirring dust and wind in relentless motion, an ominous presence.

steps.description: The craftsman selects sturdy oak trunks from the forest. He fells tall trees with sharpened stone axes and splits logs into beams using wooden mallets and iron wedges. Nearby he locates a rocky hillside rich in iron ore. He digs pits with pickaxes carved from bone, hauling ore chunks in woven baskets. Along the riverbank, he follows copper veins, chiseling fragments from rocks. He gathers sand from the riverbed to serve as silica. At a seep, he skims crude oil from shallow ponds, storing it in clay pots. In a forge, he builds a charcoal fire with bellows made from hide. He smelts iron ore in a clay furnace, pouring metal into molds to form plates. He repeats the process with copper ore to create coils and conducting wires. He forges small iron gears and wooden shafts to assemble moving linkages. He melts silica over high heat to form glass panels. Finally, he distills crude oil in a clay still to extract lubricants and fuels, preparing every essential component for his flying device.

The craftsman selects a piece of hardwood, free of knots and cracks. He marks the center with charcoal and measures distances for blade sockets. With his sharp blade he carves a thick, cylindrical block, concentrating on smooth, even surfaces. He hollows the center, creating a cavity that will hold the swing of each blade. Around the edge he chisels four recesses, ensuring they are equidistant and level. He tests fit by inserting wooden sticks, adjusting each slot until it grips. He sands rough edges with fine wood shavings and polishes the hub’s face by hand. He inspects the hub, confirming balance and alignment for smooth rotation in the air stream.

The craftsman selects a straight, sturdy branch of hardwood. He measures equal lengths for two blade blanks. He uses his knife to split the wood along the grain, producing rough billets. He trims each billet to uniform thickness, carving the leading edge with a curve and tapering toward the trailing side. He shapes the tips into tapered ends, ensuring aerodynamic form. He scrapes fibers and smooths surfaces. He hollows a shallow groove along the midline to reduce weight and maintain strength. He checks the twist of each blade for balance, adjusts contours for symmetry, and rubs the wood against a stone to polish. Blades mount on the central hub.

He places the rough-hewn central block on a stable log. He fits one long wooden strip onto the block, aligning the slot on the strip with the groove at the block’s edge. Holding the blade tightly, he drives a thick nail halfway through to hold it in place. He then positions a second strip at a right angle over the block’s center, ensuring both strips cross evenly. With careful aim, he hammers another nail through the overlapping pieces and into the block, checking that the blades sit level on both sides. He repeats this with two more strips, pounding each nail firmly so the four arms spin freely around the hub.

He carves a thick wooden disk to form the rotor hub. He shapes a sturdy straight wooden pole to serve as the central shaft. He drills a square hole at the hub’s center that matches the shaft’s dimensions. He slides the hub onto the shaft until it fits snugly. He wedges small wooden shims into the gap, tapping them into place for a tight bind. He wraps tough vine around the joint, drawing it tight, knotting it securely. He coats the wrapping with pine resin to seal the bond.

A lone craftsman stands before a sturdy trunk of oak. He hefts his axe, marking the rough dimensions of the central keel. He swings the blade, carving away bark and unwanted sections, revealing fresh timber beneath. With an eye for balance, he rotates the log, repeating precise strikes. Next, he uses the saw to slice beams to length. He braces each piece atop a stump, guiding the teeth through the wood with steady force. The cut timbers fall, ready for refinement. He positions a beam on the workbench and grips the chisel. Tapping it with the mallet, he sculpts mortises and tenons at the ends of each piece. Wood shavings curl away as the joint takes shape. He tests the fit, adjusting angles until each beam slots snugly. As the framework emerges, he assembles the parts, driving wooden pegs through drilled holes. The skeleton of the flying vessel grows, each brace, strut, and crosspiece aligned in perfect harmony. He admires the lattice of wood, confident it will bear heavy load.

A solitary craftsman places two sturdy timbers crosswise to form a stable support. He carves a cylindrical beam from hardwood, leaving it slightly tapered at the ends. He forges a bronze bushing by heating copper and tin, then hammers it into shape around the carved beam. He bores matching holes in the timbers, ensuring a snug fit for the bushing. He slides the bronze-lined shaft through the frame, rotates it to check alignment, and adjusts until the beam turns freely. He fashions bronze collars that fit around the shaft ends and hammers them tightly against the timbers. He drives wooden wedges beside the collars to secure the shaft in place.

He carves two beams from wood as push rods. He hollows each end with a flint chisel, then drills holes with a vine cord. He shapes a central block with matching holes that acts as a pivot hinge. He fastens one end of each rod to that block with wooden pegs, then aligns opposite ends to blade mounts. A hand lever attaches to the block and he wraps its handle with vine for traction. When he moves the lever, the rods slide, tilting the blades and altering their angle.

He places the carved rotor onto the knife-edge, which is firmly set into the support stand. He spins the assembly gently on the wooden axle, watching the blades settle. If one side drops lower, he marks the heavier blade with a charcoal grain. He pauses, lifts the assembly off the iron, and shaves a sliver of wood from the thick end using his sharp flint. He repeats the test, spinning it again to see if the rotor remains level. With patience, he files rough edges until the blades hover perfectly horizontal. When each blade stays still and does not tilt, he knows the balance is correct. This trimming ensures rotation when he sets the rotor into the winding mechanism. He confirms that the wooden axle fits snugly through the rotor hub.

At dawn, the early maker binds four long stems of tough vine in thick plant fiber, twisting them into rigid rods. They carefully carve small stone disks and tie them at each rod’s end. Next, the maker wraps more fiber around a central pivot of bundled reeds, forming a simple axle. Two helpers grasp opposite rods and slowly pull, causing the rods to spin overhead. As the device whirls, the stone disks rise from the ground, lifting gently. The maker watches the steady climb, judging whether it holds under weight. Testing again, they swap one disk for a larger stone, spin the axle, and marvel at the newfound lift.

crude oil.name: crude oil
crude oil.description: A dark, thick liquid seeps from cracks in rocks, forming deep black pools that glisten under the sun. It has a heavy, sticky feel as it clings to bare fingers, leaving a coating that is difficult to remove. A sulfurous odor rises from its surface, drifting on the wind. It collects in hollows near waterways, where insects struggle on its viscous surface and the ground around remains wet and glossy.

silica.name: silica
silica.description: A cluster of pale fragments glistens under sunlight. Each piece feels as hard as stone yet smooth along certain edges. Some shards shine like trapped water, shining with faint colors when light touches them. They are cold to the touch, heavier than most stones of the same size. Scattered in sands and lodged inside rugged cliffs, these clear, glasslike bits sparkle amidst rough rocks, catching the eye as small, shining jewels.

nail.name: nail
nail.description: A small, narrow, elongated piece of cold, gleaming grey substance lies on earth. One end is flattened to a thin, circular disc, while the other tapers to a sharp point. Its surface is smooth and hard, reflecting flecks of sunlight in brief flashes. The form is rigid and straight, barely bending under pressure. Despite its size, it feels unusually weighty, seeming made from a forged, metallic core.

steps.description: At dawn, a solitary craftsman ascends rocky slopes in search of metal veins. He carries a small wooden pan and a sturdy stone hammer. Pausing by a trickling stream, he dips the pan into rushing water and swirls gravel to reveal shimmering copper fragments. When bright specks glint, he drums earth from his chisel with precise taps, inspecting fresh rock faces. Satisfied, he pockets heavy fragments, then searches lower banks for darker grains that signal tin deposits. He taps rough stones to test their density, setting aside those that ring clear and hard. By midday, his bundle of ore grows, ready to carry back for smelting, alloying into sturdy tools.

A lone figure crouches at the edge of a rocky outcrop. He grasps a wooden-handle pick with a sharpened stone head. He raises it high then brings it down in steady strikes, flaking off layers of earth. Dust swirls as bits of copper ore break free. He shifts his grip and angles the tool to target veins of tin ore deeper in the seam. Chunks of ore fall into a woven basket. His breathing stays even as he repeats the motion. Morning light filters through branches, illuminating glints in the fractured stones. He pauses to brush away dust, revealing hints of glowing copper. With renewed focus, he delivers precise blows along natural cracks, prying larger fragments free. Sweat beads at his brow, but he maintains rhythm, drawing precious metal from the earth.

Standing before a low clay furnace, he shovels glowing charcoal and fragments of copper ore into the hearth. He inserts a slender clay tuyere into the furnace wall and breathes through a hollow reed, intensifying the flow of air. Flames surge around the ore, and molten copper trickles into a trench at the base. He adjusts the airflow with measured puffs, maintaining the steady heat that separates metal from slag. He taps the furnace wall with a stone to gauge its temperature before adding fresh fuel. As impurities float to the surface, he scrapes them aside with a wooden paddle. Eventually, the bright pool of copper gathers at the bottom. He withdraws the air pipe and pours the liquid metal into carved stone molds, where it solidifies for later shaping.

At dawn the craftsman gathers copper ingots and arranges them in a hearth filled with glowing embers. He builds the fire until coals radiate intense heat. He dons a hide apron and grips a heated bar with sturdy iron tongs. He lifts it from the fire and places it on an anvil. He strikes the glowing metal with a heavy hammer, each blow stretching and flattening the bar. Sparks scatter as he rotates the piece, maintaining a uniform cross section. Periodically he returns it to the coals, restoring its malleability. Once it reaches the proper length and thickness, he tapers one end with precise hammer strokes, then bends the other end around a small peg on the anvil’s horn. After shaping, he polishes the surface on rough stone to remove scale. Finally, he cools the forged piece in water, then inspects it for straightness and strength before setting it aside.

A primitive smith grips a glowing rod with tongs, pounding it against a stone anvil with rhythmic force. Each strike extends the metal’s slender form. Sparks flurry around the workspace as sweat beads on the brow. When the piece reaches a deep orange heat, the artisan lifts it and plunges the tip into a shallow pool of water. Bubbles hiss as steam rises, and the metal’s surface hardens with a hiss. The craftsman cools the shaft with swift, gentle splashes, inspecting its rigidity before fashioning its head with precise blows.

wooden axle.name: wooden axle
wooden axle.description: A slender length of pale wood lies on the ground. Its bark lies stripped away, revealing a smooth grain that runs uninterrupted along its length. Each end is neatly rounded to identical diameters, lacking knots or irregularities. The surface bears faint linear grooves in precise, parallel lines. It seems out of place among jagged branches and gnarled roots, its uniform shape hinting at careful shaping beyond what nature provides.

steps.description: He walks through the dense forest, eyes scanning trunks and limbs. He looks for a straight, sturdy young branch, free of knots or twists. He tests each candidate by tapping the bark, listening for a solid tone without hollow echoes. He examines the grain, seeking close growth rings that promise strength. He peels away loose bark to reveal any hidden cracks. He chooses a species known for hardness. Once he finds a smooth, straight piece, he marks it with a carved notch, ready for shaping into the rotating shaft.

At dawn the craftsman stands before a fallen tree trunk. He lifts the axe with both hands, planting his feet firmly in the soft earth. He raises the sharp blade above his head, then swings it down toward the thick log. The steel edge bites into the bark and fiber as he strikes. He repeats the motion, shifting his stance slightly each time to find a fresh angle. Wood chips scatter across the ground while fresh splinters fall away from the cut. With steady rhythm he carves through the trunk, the echo of each strike sounding through the clearing. Soon he separates a section of timber for shaping. He admires the fresh surface.

A prehistoric craftsman selects a sturdy log section and secures it between two forked supports. He grasps a sharp adze and brings the blade down at a shallow angle, shaving away irregularities along one side. Spinning the timber slightly, he continues slicing thin curls of wood, working patiently around the length. With each rotation, the rough exterior becomes smoother and more uniform in diameter and solid form. He shifts grip and adjusts the angle to smooth grooves left by earlier cuts. After smoothing with the adze, he rubs the surface with sand or grit to polish the cylinder. Finally, he tests its rolling motion, ready for use in his wheel mechanism.

He selects a stout branch and strips its rough bark with a flint blade. He holds the timber firmly and picks up a block of gritty sandstone. Pressing the stone against the wood’s curved surface, he rubs in long, even strokes while rotating the shaft between his palms. Fine wood dust falls away as ridges vanish and the surface grows uniformly smooth. When he notices shiny grain emerging, he wets the timber lightly to raise fresh fibers, then resumes grinding with the stone. He follows every contour patiently, alternating pressure and angle to avoid gouges. At last, the shaft gleams with a sleek finish, ready for its fitting.

support stand.name: support stand
support stand.description: A rigid structure rises from the earth, composed of three straight poles of gleaming grey metal, each of uniform thickness. These tall, slender legs sprawl outward at equal angles, forming a stable triangle. At their apex they meet in a smooth, rounded hub. Midway up, a flat horizontal bar spans between two poles, its surface smooth and unblemished. The whole contraption stands balanced, motionless, as though awaiting unseen forces.

steps.description: He walks through the grove, scanning fallen branches and limbs. He examines each piece, looking for a natural division where a single trunk splits into two sturdy arms.
