After quenching, he inspects the steel for straightness and gently bends it back into alignment if needed. Finally, he polishes the surfaces and performs a low- temperature temper by warming the blade again at the edge of the coals, balancing hardness and toughness.

The craftsman lifts the cutter and studies the blade’s edge. He grasps a slab of coarse sharpening stone and wets it with water. He sets the blade at a shallow angle on the stone, pressing down lightly. He draws the metal across the rough surface in smooth strokes from base to tip, repeating evenly along each side. He pauses to brush away metal filings with a strip of cloth between passes. After several passes, he moves to a finer-grit face and continues stroking until the edge gleams. Finally, he tests its sharpness by slicing a scrap of hide.

zinc.name: zinc
zinc.description: In a rocky outcrop, I see solid lumps of pale gray stone with a faint blue sheen. When struck, these pieces ring with a dull metallic note and break into crisp shards. They feel unusually heavy and cold to the touch, their rough surfaces glinting in sunlight. The edges are sharp yet brittle, crumbling under pressure. Buried among darker rocks, they stand out by their silvery hue and subtle sparkle.

shears.name: shears
shears.description: It looks like twin, elongated metal arms joined at the center by a sturdy pivot. Each arm flattens into a blade with a sharpened inner edge, its glinting surface reflecting sunlight. The arms extend into cylinder handles, wide enough for fingers to slip in, tapering toward the end. When moved, the top arm slides past the bottom in a smooth, twin-blade motion, the steel mouths aligning, parting on tongues.

steps.description: A solitary artisan travels to rocky slopes. He carries a sturdy hammerstone and a digging stick. At the outcrop, he taps exposed veins with the hammerstone, cracking the surface to reveal copper ore glimmering beneath. He pries loose fragments with the digging stick, levering them out of seams. When the earth hides tin deposits in softer soil, he thrusts the digging stick into the ground, loosening dirt to uncover tin-rich pebbles. He uses the hammerstone to pound larger nodules free from matrix, careful to extract chunks intact. Each piece is examined by weight and sheen; matte gray hints tin, reddish traces indicate copper. He sharpens the digging stick before each day and supports his work with water. He packs selected fragments into a woven basket and, as dusk falls, returns to the hearth laden with ore ready for smelting. His eyes learn to read rocky patterns, guiding every strike.

A lone craftsman begins by crushing chunks of copper ore with a heavy stone until they crumble into small fragments. He stokes a clay-and-stone furnace with dried wood, then works a pair of leather bellows in steady rhythm to feed fresh air into the glowing embers. As the fire intensifies, he tucks handfuls of copper fragments into a small crucible. The metal softens, glowing bright orange, and impurities rise to the surface as molten slag. With tongs, he lifts the crucible and pours off the slag into a pit of sand. Next, he repeats the cycle with tin ore, watching its pale metal pool at the crucible’s bottom. He cleans both crucibles, then combines portions of molten copper and molten tin in a third vessel. Within minutes, the metals fuse into a new alloy, its heat causing it to flow like thick honey. Finally, he pours the glowing bronze into a simple stone mold. After it cools, he cracks the mold open to reveal a solid bar ready for further shaping.

The smith builds a small charcoal fire and heats a lump of copper ore with tin ore until it melts into a glowing bronze alloy. Using hot coals and bellows, the metal pools in a simple stone crucible. When blended, the smith dips long iron tongs into the forge and withdraws the molten mass. They pour it into a shallow stone mold to form a rough ingot. Once cooled, they clamp the bar with tongs, then position it atop the anvil. With strong, measured blows of the hammer, the smith compresses the center and begins drawing the ends into two slender, elongated forms. They reheat the work frequently, keeping the metal at a malleable state. After each strike, they rotate the bar, ensuring uniform thickness along its length. When the length is sufficient, the smith tilts the edges against the anvil’s surface and lightly hammers, forging a pair of crisp bevels. The cycle of heating, hammering, and shaping continues until both halves have a balanced profile, ready for final finishing and mounting.

A craftsman heats a short bronze rod until it glows bright orange, gripping it with tongs and laying it across the anvil. With firm, measured blows of the hammer, he tapers one end into a narrow peg and smooths its surface. He returns the rod to the fire, then strikes again to harden and refine the shape. Next, he holds two matching bronze blades side by side, each with a small notch marked at the intended joint. Using the hammer and a pointed punch or the rod’s sharpened tip, he carefully drives a hole through both layers, reheating as needed to keep the metal pliable. He aligns the holes, inserts the newly forged peg, and ensures the halves can rotate. Finally, he reverses the tapered end of the peg against the anvil and hammers it flat, creating a riveted head that locks the joint in place while still allowing the blades to pivot smoothly.

He lays two roughly forged blades side by side on a flat anvil surface. He adjusts them so that their narrow ends overlap by a small margin. He grips a slender iron punch with one hand, positioning its tip where the blades meet. He raises a heavy hammer in the other hand and brings the punch sharply down. He repeats this at two or three spots along the overlap until a series of holes appears. He cuts a short length of bronze rod, made earlier by mixing heated copper ore and tin ore. He drives one end of this rod through the aligned holes on the blades. He places the projecting metal piece over the anvil and strikes the end with the hammer. He shapes the end into a small head, locking the blades together. He tests the joint, ensuring it pivots smoothly without wobble. He files off any rough edges and polishes around the rivet. He inspects the joined blades for firmness and free movement. He checks for alignment.

A primitive artisan begins by soaking a coarse whetstone in a bowl of water, allowing the surface to become damp. Holding one cutting edge at a shallow angle, they draw it across the stone in smooth strokes, moving away from the body. After several passes, they flip the piece and repeat on the other blade, listening for a ringing sound that signals a sharp burr. If needed, they sprinkle water to maintain lubrication and rinse away metal filings. With a finer grit face, they hone each edge, alternating strokes to refine the bevel. Finally, they wipe the instrument clean and test its performance on a thin strip of plant fiber.

iron sheet.name: iron sheet
iron sheet.description: A broad, flat expanse of heavy, metallic surface glints dully in sunlight. Its edges are sharp and straight, unlike the curves of naturally broken stone. The face is smooth and cold to the touch, ripples and faint lines running across it as if cast by a flowing stream of molten metal. Tiny pits and scratches mar its sheen, revealing a dark gray core beneath the silvery shimmer. Rust speckles it.

steps.description: A solitary gatherer moves along a rocky slope at first light, scanning outcrops for rust-toned streaks. They run a crude hammerstone across each exposed slab, listening for a metallic ring that hints at hidden ore. When they detect a dull thump, they set the slab by their side and kneel to loosen soil with a pointed digging stick. They prod deeper, revealing flecks of dark metal mixed with sand. Encouraged, they strike the rock again, breaking off a rugged fragment. With care, they pile the best specimens in a pouch slung over the shoulder, planning to carry them home. Each fragment promises new strength when heated and hammered into thin plates.

A primitive craftsman mines nodules from a hillside and breaks them into chunks. He arranges charcoal and ore layers inside a clay-lined furnace that bulges. He seals gaps with damp earth and ignites fuel at the base. He pumps a leather bellows rhythmically, driving air through the tuyère to intensify heat. He watches the glowing embers and adjusts air flow to maintain steady reduction conditions. After several hours, the ore interior transforms into a spongy mass of metallic bloom mixed with slag. When the furnace cools, he dismantles the hearth, removes the bloom, and reheats it. Through repeated heating and hammering, he expels melted residue and condenses the bloom into a lump. By alternating furnace work and forging, he produces a flat, malleable metal form ready for further shaping.

A primitive human builds a small furnace of clay and packed earth inside a shallow pit. He places charcoal at the bottom and stacks crushed iron ore on top in alternating layers. He embeds a clay tuyere into one side of the furnace, pointing toward the center of the fuel pile. He lights the charcoal and lets it glow red. Then he straps a set of leather bellows to the back of the tuyere and begins pumping steadily. As he works the bellows, air surges through the tuyere, raising the internal temperature above the melting point of impurities. Dark slag drips away, and a spongy mass of nearly pure metal forms at the base. After several hours of steady blowing and occasional addition of charcoal and ore, he stops the bellows. When the furnace cools slightly, he breaks open the clay walls and extracts the bloom. He then reworks it with hammer and heat to consolidate the metal.

A lone craftsman gathers rough ore from a rocky seam and breaks it into small fragments. He builds a low clay-and-stone bloomery furnace, packing alternating layers of charcoal and ore into its shaft. At the base he fits a simple tuyere, a clay pipe aimed at the burning fuel. He works bellows by hand, forcing air into the tuyere so the charcoal glows white-hot and reduces the ore to a spongy mass. After several hours of steady pumping, he uses tongs to pull out a slag-encrusted bloom. Still glowing, he hammers this lump over an anvil, driving out pockets of waste and welding the metal into a more homogeneous piece. Reheating and hammering again, he gradually flattens the mass into a broad, thin plate. As he works, dark impurities flake away, leaving a smooth, silvery surface ready for final trimming and shaping.

At dawn, the maker lifts the glowing bloom from embers with sturdy tongs. They rest it on the broad face of the anvil. With each swing of the hammer, small fractures close and slag expels, coalescing the metal. After several strikes, the mass grows flatter and longer. The artisan returns it to the coals, forging heat until the surface pulses red. Again on the anvil, repeated blows shrink impurities and further thin the form. As the face broadens, they tap the edges to square the corners and correct uneven parts. When the metal reaches a uniform, pliant glow, the worker shoes the hammer lightly, smoothing minor bumps. Every few minutes they pace between heat and anvil, folding and hammering, coaxing the mass into a slender, wide plane. Finally, the piece lies thin and even, ready for final flattening or finishing. The maker sets it aside to cool slowly, awaiting its next transformation.

glass jar.name: glass jar
glass jar.description: A smooth, translucent cylinder stands upright, its walls unbroken and evenly thick. Light passes through effortlessly, casting shimmering bands on nearby surfaces. The rim is circular and precise, its edge cold and flawless. A flat lid seals the top, matching the body’s clarity, with a slight reflection dancing across its dome. Its base is firm and unyielding, holding it perfectly level on any flat ground. Its contours are seamless.

steps.description: He travels to the riverbank and kneels by the water, sifting grains of coarse quartz-rich sediment through his fingers. He works methodically, letting the current wash away unwanted clay and pebbles until only the fine pale grains remain. He carries the bowl of sediment to the shoreline beneath a cliff, where white crusts flare along the base. He scrapes fibrous crystals from the face of a dried lake bed, tapping loose fragments with a stone blade and gathering them in a woven container. Next he climbs a rocky slope spotted with creamy outcrops, breaking off chunks of pale stone with a hammerstone and chipping them into smaller pieces. He piles these materials separately beside his fire site, ready for smelting. He samples alkali crystals from salt flats, testing purity with taste.

First, the crafter gathers river sand, crumbly natron crystals, and shells. They spread material in a shallow stone basin. Using a wooden scoop, they measure three parts sand to one part natron and sprinkle in powdered shells. With a smooth basalt pestle, they press and rotate in a circular motion, crushing lumps and blending particles until the mixture shifts color. They lift the basin, tilting it to let finer grains sift through their fingers while a breeze carries away excess dust. They use tapping to settle the blend and run their palm over the surface to check for uniform texture. They fold the edges inward repeatedly, pressing the heap toward the center. They repeat grinding, sifting, and folding until the pale mixture gleams evenly. The batch is ready for firing.

A primitive craftsperson takes ground sand and powdered natron, measuring proportions of about three parts sand to one part natron. They pour the dry mix into a clay crucible. Then they stoke the furnace fire with coals, blowing air through a simple bellows to raise the heat. Once the interior glows bright orange, they set the crucible within the hottest zone. Over several hours, they maintain the flame, adding charcoal or wood to keep the temperature high and constant. Inside, the sand and natron begin to fuse, forming a molten, viscous liquid. The craftsperson uses an iron rod to stir the melt, skimming off impurities that rise to the surface. Periodically they lift the crucible with tongs, observing the consistency until the mixture flows smoothly. When fully dissolved, they pour the glowing fluid into a mould or over a core, and allow it to cool and solidify into a strong vessel.

A primitive artisan heats raw material to a molten state in a furnace. He dips a heated mandrel into the glowing mass and lifts out a glob. He begins shape vessel by rolling the mandrel between his palms, coaxing the molten matter into a smooth, rounded form. He returns the work to the fire to maintain plasticity. Leaning over the hearth, he presses one side against his damp palm on the rod, creating a shallow bowl. With steady rotations, he gently pulls the lip outward using his fingers, forming a uniform flare. He repeats rolling and reheating until the walls achieve even thickness, leaving a finished container ready to cool.

For a cool vessel, he stands on the frozen shore, using a flint blade to slice into thick lake ice. With measured strikes he carves a shallow basin, watching glinting shards tumble away. When the cavity deepens, he wedges a bone pick beneath the block and pries free a smooth, transparent disk. Back at camp he hammers the rim with a stone tool, shaping a lip. He polishes inner walls by pouring runoff over them and buffing with deer hide. The result is a frosty creation that keeps its contents chilled.

jar.name: jar
jar.description: It sits upon the ground with a stable, circular base. Curving outward into a rounded belly, its walls rise in a graceful arc toward a narrow neck, where a clean rim frames the opening. The warm earthen surface is firm yet slightly rough beneath the fingers, flecked with darker specks. A faint sheen clings to the fired clay, and when tapped lightly, it echoes with a hollow, resonant note.

steps.description: A lone craftsperson wanders to a riverbank where soft earth clings to stones. They knead handfuls of damp clay, feeling its texture and testing its smoothness. With a carved wooden scoop, they pry lumps from the bank and drop them into a basket. They examine each piece for grit, scraping off bits of debris and discarding coarse fragments. The gatherer returns to camp with the heavy load, careful not to crush the moist lumps. They drape a wet cloth over the harvest to preserve pliability until they shape the earth into a vessel.

He begins by mixing clay and water until a soft pliable mass forms. He crushes dry clay in his hands, pours water into the heap and mashes it, then kneads it against a flat stone. He hums softly as he breaks and folds the mixture, pressing air bubbles out with his thumbs. He rolls the damp lump between his palms, creating a smooth cylinder. He places it on a flat slab, pinches the spinning walls upward and outward, guiding the curve with pressure. He smooths the surface with wet fingers, tapping the base to even the thickness. He uses a thin stone flake to refine the rim. Finally, he lifts the piece for sun-drying.

He shapes wet clay into a wide-mouthed container using his hands and simple tools. Once the walls stand firm, he leaves the piece in a shaded spot. Warm wind moves around it, drawing out moisture. Throughout the day, he gently turns it to expose every side. Small cracks appear as the clay hardens. He watches for even color and dryness, ensuring no hidden damp spots remain before the next stage.

A primitive human kneads soft clay and shapes a small clay container on a flat stone. The artisan collects dry twigs, grass, and flint stones. The human rubs two sticks together near a pile of kindling, coaxing faint smoke. Eventually a glowing ember appears, nestled in shredded bark. The ember touches the dry grass, bursts into flame, and the potter uses the fire to harden the clay vessel over glowing coals.

pliers.name: pliers
pliers.description: A small, dark-grey object with two long, flat arms joined by a round, central hinge. Its arms curve inward toward their tips, which end in thin, slightly serrated edges. The metal surface is shiny but cool to the touch. When the two arms are pulled apart, they spring back together. Light glints off the hinge, hinting at precise craftsmanship. It feels weighty, balanced, like two branches bound at their midpoints.

steps.description: A primitive human walks along a rocky riverbank, scanning exposed outcrops for copper ore streaks. When a greenish vein appears, they heft a hammerstone and strike the rock, chipping off small copper-rich nuggets. They tap each blow carefully to avoid shattering the desired fragments. Collected pieces fall into a woven basket beside them. Later, they travel to a nearby granite hill, where patches of tin ore gleam like pale lead in fractured quartz. Again using the hammerstone, they fracture the host rock and extract shimmering tin fragments, sifting them by hand to remove lighter waste stones. Back at camp, they empty and inspect their haul, selecting only the richest copper and tin bits, then pile them by the hearth for future smelting. They wash metal bits in a stream to remove soil.

The craftsmaker fills the rough-hewn furnace with charcoal and stones, then stacks copper ore and tin ore among glowing embers. He draws air through sturdy leather bellows, each rhythmic squeeze intensifying the heat until the stones’ interior glows bright orange. As time passes, the ores begin to soften and liquefy, and dark slag rises to the surface of the molten metal. Using a narrow iron ladle carved from a earlier casting, he carefully skims off the frothy impurities. He continues to pulse the bellows, stirring the crucible with a length of iron, ensuring the copper and tin merge into a uniform molten alloy. At the peak of its glow, he tips the vessel, releasing streams of molten bronze into preheated stone molds. Once fully cooled, he knocks the solid bars loose, revealing smooth ingots brimming with potential for shaping. Each ingot carries the fruits of patient fire and steady breath.

The metalworker heats a small bed of charcoal in a low clay hearth until it glows bright. He breaks copper ore and tin ore into rough chunks, then drops them together into the fire. As the metals melt and mingle, he uses long iron tongs to pull out a glowing, golden lump. He places the hot mass on a sturdy anvil and strikes it firmly with a broad-faced hammer. Each blow spreads the metal into a flat bar. When the bar cools, he returns it to the hearth for reheating, then hammers it thinner and longer. Once the bar reaches a workable temperature and shape, he lays it against the anvil horn and bends one end into a gentle curve, tapping it in place with precise hammer strokes. He reheats the piece again, then forges a small, hooked tip at the opposite end by hammering against the anvil’s edge. With tongs, he dips the lever into a shallow basin of cool water to harden the metal. He repeats the entire sequence—smelting, hammering, bending, quenching—to produce a second lever that matches the first in length, curvature, and strength. Finally, both warm pieces rest on the anvil, ready for final trimming and adjustment.

He sets two flattened copper bars on a stone block and marks each center point near one end. He chooses a sturdy punch held upright against the mark and brings the hammer down firmly. Each strike drives the punch deeper until it pushes through, forming a clean circular aperture. He flips the bars and repeats the process from the reverse side to prevent tearing. He clears any jagged edges by tapping lightly around the rim with the hammer face. Next, he stacks the two bars so their holes align perfectly. He inserts the punch through both layers and taps again, widening and evening the opening. Finally, he tries a rough copper pin to ensure the joint turns freely, then polishes the edges for a smooth pivot with a practiced hand.

First, the human cuts two similar lengths of copper and positions them on an anvil. Using a hammer, they flatten one end of each piece into a paddle shape. They use the punch to bore matching holes near the flattened ends. They align the two pieces so the holes overlap, creating a pivot point. Next, they insert a short copper rod through the holes, leaving equal lengths protruding on both sides. The maker uses the hammer to spread and flatten the rod’s tail, forming a rivet head that locks the bars together. They hammer the opposing end down to secure the joint. They trim rough edges for comfort. Finally, they test the action by squeezing the handles; the joined levers pivot smoothly around the newly formed copper rivet, ready for use.

The smith lifts the bar halves from the hearth and places them together on the anvil face. He grips the bars with tongs and taps the inner edges with the hammer, nudging them until the faces meet evenly. He flips the tool, striking lightly along the joining surfaces to ensure parallel alignment. He uses measured blows to coax the two arms into symmetry, checking by sight and feel. He repeats the fine strikes until both sides mirror each other precisely. He looks down the length of the jaws to confirm they close flush without gaps. Once satisfied, he sets the forged arms aside to quench, confident gripping ends align.

sharpening stone.name: sharpening stone
sharpening stone.description: It looks like a flat, oval rock worn smooth by running water. Its surface feels hard and grainy, with faint lines crisscrossing like dried riverbeds. One side is darker, almost blue-gray, while the edges show lighter speckles. When held, it feels cool and weighty, filling the palm with gentle curves. Tiny pits dot its face, and dust-like granules cling to its grooves, while earthy amber flecks shimmer across its body.

punch.name: punch
punch.description: A shallow basin of clear water glistens beneath dappled sunlight, its surface tinged with deep crimson hues as countless small orbs float effortlessly. A sweet, fruity fragrance wafts upward, mingling with earthy undertones of crushed leaves and sun-warmed stones. Tiny bubbles gather along the edges, bursting in soft whispers. Light dances through the liquid, casting flickering patterns on nearby rocks. The liquid beckons with vibrant color and gentle movement.

steps.description: He moves from the camp toward the skeletal remains left by a predator. He bends low to inspect bleached fragments scattered among the ferns. He selects the cleanest pieces, tapping them to ensure solid integrity. He carefully pries marrow from joints with a flint knife, then discards brittle shards. He bundles the larger bones in a woven grass carrier, binding them tightly with sinew. He returns to camp, guided by the sun’s path, carrying the gathered bones for further processing. He handles each fragment with care to preserve strength and avoid splintering.

The primitive human selects a sturdy piece of bone and secures it firmly against a flat grinding stone. He rubs the bone back and forth with steady pressure, revealing fresh surfaces and carving away uneven edges. His motions remain deliberate, rotating the bone to smooth all sides uniformly. As the shape emerges, he focuses on refining curves and tapering ends to match his intended design. He frequently checks progress by holding the bone up to the light, ensuring that each contour aligns with his vision. Fine adjustments require gentler strokes, reducing rough spots until the bone glows with a polished sheen. Finally, he inspects the work closely, satisfied with the even form.

shells.name: shells
shells.description: Along the water’s edge lie countless hard, curved fragments glinting under the sun. Some coil into spirals, each ridge forming a graceful swirl that narrows to a tight point. Others appear as smooth, shallow discs, their edges waving like the sea’s pulse. The surfaces catch light in pale creams, flashes of orange or deep browns. Washed by tides, they tumble among pebbles. Moving in gentle surf, they settle as markers.

steps.description: He rises with the sun, cinches a leather pouch holding his small ornaments. He shifts the strap over his shoulder, flexing arms. He steps off soft moss, toes sinking between blades, then picks his way across ground scattered with stones. He navigates around thorny shrubs, senses damp air drifting in on a faint breeze. He follows the sound of lapping water, quickening his pace until he reaches the surf.

He wades into shallow water at low tide, scanning the sea floor for half-buried fragments of carved white curves. With a sturdy stick he pries each piece loose from sand and rock. He picks up every hard, curved fragment, examining its shape and weight before dropping it into a woven basket at his side. He moves along the shoreline, pausing at rocky alcoves beneath broken cliffs where treasure hides. As the sun climbs, he gathers enough of these ocean-tossed bits for ornaments, tools, or decoration. Satisfied, he returns to camp to sort and prepare them.

gas engine.name: gas engine
gas engine.description: A hulking contraption of dark metal plates and tubular limbs stands on stumpy supports. Within its chest fierce clanking pistons pump in swift, rhythmic pulses. Hollow pipes jut outward, exhaling bursts of hot air that hiss like startled serpents. Beneath, a glowing hearth pulses orange as fluids shimmer inside blackened chambers. Steady vibrations thrum through the ground, as the smoky breath of this strange beast shakes the earth with fury.

steps.description: A primitive craftsman begins by shaping a furnace from clay and stone. He packs charcoal around the core to insulate heat. He builds a tuyere from fire-hardened clay and inserts it into the lower wall of the furnace, creating an opening for air flow. He attaches sturdy bellows to that opening. By pumping the bellows rhythmically, he forces air through the tuyere, raising the interior temperature above one thousand degrees. He then adds crushed iron ore and more charcoal in layers. The heat reduces the ore into molten metal while slag floats to the top. After several hours of sustained air blasts, he opens the furnace and pulls out a glowing bloom of iron. He hammers the bloom on an anvil to expel trapped slag and forge a workable bar of metal, ready for shaping. Before smelting, he washes the iron ore in cold water to strip loose grit and selects the richest fragments.

He begins by erecting a furnace chamber from fireclay bricks, lighting a charcoal fire within. He stokes the blaze with bellows, drawing air through iron tubes and intensifying heat until flames lick the chamber roof. He places pig iron lumps into a crucible and settles it into the glowing hearth. As metal begins to soften and glow a dull orange, he works the bellows in steady rhythm, raising temperature until the iron melts fully.

Once the metal flows like liquid, he uses tongs to lift the crucible free of coals. He skims off slag with iron rod, ensuring cleaner metal. He has prepared a mold from compacted sand and clay, shaped to the form of a multi-chamber cylinder housing. Before pouring, he warms the mold near the furnace mouth, driving out moisture and preventing steam pockets. He then holds the crucible over the mold opening and tilts it gently, letting molten metal fill every cavity.

After a patient wait, he allows the casting to cool. When the iron solidifies, he removes the mold casing and breaks away the hardened sand, unveiling a rough cylinder block ready for filing and finishing.

At the forge, the human heats a wrought iron billet until it glows bright orange. They pump the bellows to intensify the coals. With tongs, they lift the heated metal and place it on the anvil. They strike with the hammer to flatten and square the stock, working toward the rough dimensions of a crankshaft. They draw out one end to form the main journal, rotating the billet under successive blows to create a cylindrical shape. They then heat the opposite end and duplicate the process for the counterweight journal. Periodically, they dip the piece in water to crack off scale, then return it for cleaning and reheat. Between hammering sessions, they use chisels in the anvil’s hardy hole to mark crankpin locations. They reheat, hammering the web of metal between the two journals inward, forming the offset crank throw. They continue reheating and forging, refining the contours and ensuring concentric alignment by spinning the piece between tongs. They inspect alignment on a makeshift mandrel by spinning it, ensuring smooth rotation. Finally, they quench to lock in structure and refine the finish with a file. This forged crankshaft will serve as the heart of their power machine.

A smith sets a lump of iron in the forge until it glows bright orange. He lifts it with tongs and places it on the anvil. He strikes the billet with a hammer, flattening and lengthening it into a rough bar. He returns it to the forge and repeats heating until the metal bends easily under his blows. He then draws the bar to a precise length, forming a thick beam that will become the rod’s body. He heats one end again, then hammers it wider to shape a crankpin eye. He uses tongs to hold the hot jaw while he contours its inner face with careful hammer strokes. He checks alignment by sighting along its length, reheating and adjusting until the two eyes sit square and parallel. He works the other end to produce a matching big-end eye. He finishes by reheating the entire piece and plunging it into water to harden the iron. Finally, he polishes rough spots with a stone and tests fit on a wooden mockup.

A lone smith stands before a roaring forge, stoking glowing coals with wooden bellows. He grips a rough iron billet in stout tongs and plunges it into the heart of the fire. When the metal shines bright orange, he slips it free and lays it across the broad face of his anvil. With heavy swings of his hammer, he draws the iron into a stout cylindrical blank. The smith turns the piece frequently, tapping and twisting until it resembles a short, thick tube.  

He returns the blank to the forge for reheating, then drives the hammer around its center to form a shallow recess atop one end. This becomes the crown. Once more he heats the work until the iron glows evenly, then inverts it on the anvil’s horn to expand the lower skirt. Each hammer blow stretches the metal outward, creating a uniform wall thickness.  

Using careful hammering and controlled reheats, he squares off edges and smooths interior faces. He sets the piece upright in a hardy tool to straighten any warp. Finally, while still hot, he gives the exterior a few crisp hammer marks for fit, then dips the finished part in oil for a hardening quench. The result is a strong, accurately shaped piston ready for further assembly.

She mounts a cast iron cylinder blank in the lathe, centers and secures it with a four-jaw chuck. She uses a single-point cutting tool to turn the outer diameter to correct dimensions, then faces both ends for flatness. Next, she slides a boring bar into the headstock, positions it at the cylinder’s axis, and feeds it slowly into the bore. The single-point tool on the bar removes material in small depths of cut, producing a smooth, concentric inner surface. She measures the diameter frequently with inside micrometers or calipers, adjusting the toolpost to maintain tolerance. She applies coolant to wash away chips and keep the iron cool. She advances the cutting tool cautiously, ensuring an even finish and consistent wall thickness. Once the bore reaches its final diameter, she applies a fine feed to refine the surface finish. Finally, she deburrs the edges, leaving a precision cylinder ready for piston assembly.

He secures a cylindrical cast iron blank in the engine lathe chuck. He ensures the blank is centered by adjusting the tailstock. He selects a sharp lathe cutting tool and mounts it in the tool post. Turning the handwheel, he advances the tool to face off the end of the blank, creating a flat surface. He then brings the tool against the outer diameter, rotating the blank and removing metal to achieve the desired cylinder size. He measures frequently with calipers and micrometers. He drills a central bore with a twist drill mounted in the tailstock. He enlarges the bore to final size by boring with the cutting tool. He cuts grooves for the sealing rings, checking depths carefully. He polishes the inner and outer surfaces with a fine stone.

At dawn, the craftsman selects a sturdy iron bar and places it in the coals of the forge. He uses tongs to hold the metal and watches it glow orange. Once it reaches forging temperature, he transfers the bar to the anvil and strikes it firmly with a hammer, flattening the end into a rough disc and tapering the opposite side into a narrow stem. He returns the piece to the forge for reheating, then repeats the hammer blows until the overall form appears: a circular head and shank. He places the heated stem in a small hollow in the anvil and taps gently with the hammer to create a precise seat. After cooling he secures the piece in tongs and uses a chisel to trim any excess flange around the head, producing a neat circular profile. Finally, he applies a file to smooth the edges and ensure an exact fit within its chamber. The valve emerges from this process ready for installation.

He repeats this routine for each valve, reheating between strikes and checking dimensions against a simple gauge. For the sealing face, he hammers lightly into a slight dome on the anvil to form a precise curvature. A final file pass removes burrs and ensures smooth operation.

The primitive craftsman selects a solid steel bar of suitable diameter and marks out the positions of the lobes with a simple punch. Then he clamps the bar securely on a wooden block. He grips a coarse metal file and begins to remove material around each mark. By drawing the file across the steel surface he creates raised cam profiles. He rotates the bar and repeats the action for every lobe, constantly checking symmetry with a carved wooden gauge. After rough shaping he switches to a finer file to smooth the peaks and valleys. He also files both ends flat to ensure smooth bearing fit. Finally, he polishes the completed shaft with a strip of leather for a clean finish.

A primitive craftsperson begins by refining kaolin clay, quartz sand, and feldspar into a smooth, plastic mixing body. They sift the clay to remove large particles, then blend in finely ground sand and feldspar for strength and thermal resistance. Meanwhile, they smelt iron ore in a small charcoal forge until glowing and hammer it into two slender electrode rods. They also smelt copper ore into a short length of wire for the electrical connection.

Next, the craftsperson forms a small cylinder of the clay mixture to serve as a ceramic insulator. They press the body into shape by hand and then use a simple mold carved from wood to ensure uniform dimensions. With a hand drill fitted with a narrow drill bit, they bore a central hole through the clay cylinder, careful to keep the walls even. A slightly larger bit follows to widen the top end, creating a recess for the iron electrode head.

After trimming the piece with a wet blade, they let it air-dry until firm. Then they fire the clay in a pit kiln, using layers of charcoal and pottery shards to reach sufficient heat. Once the ceramic hardens, they tap threads by hand inside the central bore using a steel tap and gentle, steady turns. This thread will secure one iron rod as the central electrode.

Using pliers, the craftsperson screws the thicker iron rod into the ceramic insulator’s base thread. They bend the other rod at a precise distance above the tip to form a spark gap. Finally, they wrap the copper wire around the exposed end of the central rod and secure its free end with pliers. A quick jolt of static or a hand-cranked magneto against the electrodes creates a bright spark, proving the ignition device is ready.

The craftsman stands before the power device, fitting heavy iron cylinders onto the frame. He picks up his trusty wrench and places it on a bolt, then twists with care until each nut seats against its washer. He examines the leather strip he cut earlier, laying it atop the spinning axle as a flexible belt. Carefully, he threads hemp rope through holes in the frame to brace the cylinder in place, tying tight knots to hold it steady. He stirs soft tallow, warm from the fire, and rubs it onto each hinge and bearing to ensure smooth motion. With grease applied, he checks for any wobble or misalignment, using his wrench to correct any drift. As he turns the crank by hand, he watches the belt glide over the pulley and the shaft rotate with ease. Satisfied, he steps back and admires his finished mechanism, ready to harness power.

At sunrise, he positions the iron cylinder on stones near the hearth. He pours water into the shallow reservoir, then drips heated tallow into the tray below the spout. With coarse bellows, he pumps air through the chamber to mix vaporized tallow with steam. He places a flint near the ignition port and strikes it rhythmically. Sparks ignite the oily mist, and the piston shudders within its bore. Steam hisses as pressure builds, driving the rod up and down. He adjusts the air valve with a wooden lever and watches the crank spin steadily. Satisfied with the steady motion, he notes the rhythm and cools the metal with fresh water.

hemp.name: hemp
hemp.description: A field of tall, straight stalks rises from the earth, each slim stem reaching waist-high. Pairs of narrow, serrated leaves fan outward like fingers on a hand. Atop the branches, clusters of tiny, greenish buds hang in loose sprays. The stems feel strong yet hollow inside, with a rough, fibrous texture. Along the ground, small round seeds scatter beneath the stalks, their smooth shells glinting faintly in the sunlight.

single-point cutting tool.name: single-point cutting tool
single-point cutting tool.description: A slender, straight object of dark, gleaming material rests in your hand. One end tapers to a precise, needle-sharp tip that reflects sunlight like a star. Its surface is smooth and cool, with faint, even ridges spiraling along its length. The opposite end is blunt and solid, giving the piece unexpected heft. Despite its simple form, it exudes an uncanny perfection, as though shaped by forces beyond mortal hands.

steps.description: At dawn, the human moves to the riverbank, scanning for outcrops of flint or chert nestled among gravel. They crouch near the water’s edge, parting moss and mud to reveal smooth, dark stones. They pick each candidate, tapping them against another rock to hear a clear ring. If the tone is sharp, the rock likely breaks predictably. Satisfied, they cradle the chosen piece for shaping into a simple cutting implement.

At dawn, a primitive artisan kneels beside a flat rock surface, selecting a dense cobble as a hammerstone and a larger stone for shaping. He holds the raw stone core firmly against his thigh or on an anvil rock. With precise swings, he brings the hammerstone down at an angle, applying force to detach thin flakes. Each strike produces shards, and he inspects the emerging edge. He rotates the core to target different facets, adjusting the angle and force to control the flake size. Repeated blows yield a pointed bit. Once the shape is roughly formed, he lightly taps the edge to sharpen and refine the tip for cutting tasks.

He holds a chunk of flint against his thigh, bracing it near the edge. With a rounded stone in his other hand, he taps firmly along the margin. A sharp fragment shears away and lands in his palm. He lifts it to retrieve the new blade and brushes dust from its edge. He inspects the slender form under the light, gliding a thumb along ridges. Satisfied with its thinness and acute angle, he sets it aside for slicing wood or cutting hide and returns to the core for another blow.

tap.name: tap
tap.description: A cold, gray-metal cylinder protrudes from a flat vertical stone. Its surface gleams with unnatural sheen, perfectly smooth to the touch. Near its middle, a narrow neck curves outward then downward into a rounded tube. At the top, a wheel of solid metal sits, carved into even spokes radiating around a central core. The wheel’s edges are cool and hard. A circular ring surrounds the base, sealing it flush with the wall.

steps.description: A primitive human stands at the edge of a forest, examining the trees for straight trunks. He grips an axe, its edge chipped but sharp. He lifts the axe above his shoulder and brings it down with force against the bark. Deep grooves appear along the wood as chips scatter on the forest floor. He shifts stance and repeats the motion, each strike echoing through the trees. When the trunk begins to crack, he aims at the weakened point and continues swinging. Finally, the tree groans and topples, branches whipping through the air. He strips away smaller limbs, then hews the fallen trunk into logs, ready to carry to camp.

Beside a felled tree, the human selects a straight branch about thumb-thick. First, they choose a branch free of knots and rot. They use a sharp stone-edged knife to strip bark, exposing smooth wood. Holding the branch firmly, they carve one end into a long tapered point, shaving thin curls to ensure a snug fit. At the opposite side, they gouge a shallow channel around the circumference, creating a shoulder that prevents slippage. Next, they cut a narrow groove along the taper to guide fluid flow. Finally, they test the spigot by inserting it into a small hole in the trunk, adjusting the taper until it seats tightly and steady drips emerge.

He selects a straight branch two fingers thick and splits off side twigs, aiming for a smooth section. He uses a hammerstone to shape the tip into a peg. Then he scoops out a hole in the side of the trunk with a tool, carving a cavity that fits the wooden plug. He smooths walls with a flake, removing jagged fibers to ensure clean contact. He strikes the plug into the opening with firm blows until it seats securely. The plug protrudes slightly, allowing controlled drip when he removes it. He shaves rough edges with a flake, ensuring a tight seal. To test, he pours water into vessel and watches as a stream flows out.

feldspar.name: feldspar
feldspar.description: It protrudes as chunky, angular fragments set within rocky outcrops. Each piece glimmers with a soft sheen, displaying hues from milky white to blush pink or a pale, earthy green. Flat faces catch the light, revealing gentle, reflective planes that meet at near-right angles. The surfaces feel smooth yet slightly gritty under touch. Often it forms tight clusters in weathered granite, standing out against darker, coarser rock around it.

cast iron.name: cast iron
cast iron.description: A heavy mass of dull, dark grey stone sits in the clearing. Its weight presses downward, grounding the soil. Cool and solid to the touch, it feels more metallic than ordinary rock. Tiny specks of lighter grey scatter across its rough surface, like distant stars in a night sky. Edges are crisp yet slightly irregular, as if shaped by incomprehensible force. Sunlight reveals only a muted, almost oily sheen.

steps.description: At dawn, the hollow echo of a stone pick rings through a rocky outcrop. Primitive worker lifts a chisel-shaped fragment of flint, balancing it against a vein of rusty-streaked earth. With steady strikes, flint chips fly as the miner loosens chunks of mineral-rich rock. Kneeling beside fragmented boulders, the artisan pries beneath overhangs, feeling for pockets heavy with metallic redness. Sweat beads on a sun-warmed brow while selected lumps of iron ore fall into a basket of reeds. The miner repeats the rhythm of percussion and pry, gathering glinting fragments from the seam until the container brims with heavy, blood-colored stones. Then, the toilsome haul sets the stage for shaping.

A primitive smelter gathers clay, sand, and water. They pound the clay and sift the sand, then pour water in small amounts, stirring until the mixture reaches a thick, malleable consistency. They shape a round base on flat ground and stand a cylinder of the same mixture on top, pressing with the hands to seal gaps. They pack extra clay around the walls to reinforce the structure, then smooth the surface. They mark a small opening at the front for air flow and carve a hole at the top to release smoke. They leave the furnace to dry in the sun for a full day, checking for cracks. Once hardened, they touch up thin spots, ensuring the fire chamber holds hot coals and air, ready for heating ore with intense heat.

A primitive human builds a blast furnace of clay and stone, shaping a shaft that can withstand intense heat. He digs iron ore from a local outcrop and breaks it into small fragments. He layers charcoal and ore inside the furnace in alternating bands, ensuring the fuel surrounds each chunk. He positions a clay tuyere at the furnace’s base and attaches leather bellows to force air through the nozzle. As he operates the bellows rhythmically, the air gushes through the tuyere and intensifies the fire. Temperatures rise, and the ore begins to reduce, releasing impurities as slag. Molten metal droplets collect at the hearth’s bottom, merging into a spongy bloom. After several hours, he stops the bellows and allows the blast furnace to cool slightly. He extracts the bloom with tongs and hammers it over an anvil, expelling remaining slag and consolidating the metal into a solid mass ready for further forging.

A group of early humans gather lumps of iron ore and place them in a sturdy crucible. They set the crucible over a fire, blowing through a reed to feed the flames. As the heat rises, the iron ore melts, forming a glowing pool. Wearing leather aprons, they grip the glowing crucible with long steel tongs. One holds the vessel, the other steadies a mold carved from sand or stone. They lift and slowly tilt the crucible. Bright liquid flows like quicksilver into cavities shaped for tools or blades. The lead worker watches closely, guiding the stream to fill every nook. When the mold creaks with heat, they ease back the crucible. They wait for the metal to cool until steam rises softly. Finally, they break open the mold, revealing a solid iron form. When it cools, they chip away excess metal and quench it in water to harden its surface.

leather.name: leather
leather.description: Soft, yet firm skin lies before you, its surface smooth and slightly rough at the edges. The hue ranges from deep brown to pale tan, shifting in sunlight. It holds warmth and crinkles when bent, whispering faint echoes of life once held within. Pores dot its surface like valleys, and hair lines mark where fur once grew. The scent is earthy and smoky, reminding you of fire and living beasts.

steps.description: He kneels by the creature at dawn, knife carved from flint fresh in his grip. He approaches quietly, hand resting on coarse fur as he steadies his breath. He senses the heartbeat under the hide before driving the blade upward, slicing through soft flesh and arteries. The animal shudders and collapses, and he waits for its final breath to fade. He is sure it is still, and he lets the body go slack. He lays it on flat ground, then opens the belly with a practiced cut. With strokes he separates sinew and fat from the skin, peeling it free without tearing. He keeps his blade sharp for each incision.

First, the hunter flays the hide from the carcass, using a small stone chisel to slip the blade beneath tight edges. He works slowly, preserving its shape. Next, he scrapes the inner side to free fat and flesh, pulling it taut on a frame. Then he rinses the piece in a nearby stream, softening the fibers. He mixes crushed bark with crushed brains from the animal, rubbing the paste deep into every fiber. After a long soak, he wrings out excess moisture and re-stretches the hide. Finally, he secures it over a rounded log, flexing the material until it softens, then holds it above smoldering embers so light smoke infuses and protects the skin.

A person spreads a freshly skinned hide on a wooden frame. Using a bone scraper, they remove excess flesh and fat. They rub coarse salt into both sides, pressing it into the pores with firm strokes. They fold the hide flesh-to-flesh and leave it in a cool, shaded spot. After several hours, they unfold the hide and add more salt to any damp areas, ensuring even coverage. They let the hide rest overnight, then hang it to dry in the shade. They occasionally flip the hide to ensure uniform drying, stabilizing the material. This drying process draws out moisture and preserves the hide, preparing it for further softening steps.

The person unties the fresh hide and drapes it over a smooth rock near a stream. He submerges the hide fully in cold, flowing water. He presses it down with a heavy stone to keep it beneath the surface. The cold water softens and loosens blood, dirt, and bits of hair. He leaves the hide to rest in the stream for several hours, occasionally kneading it to help water soak in. He checks to ensure it remains covered. When he sees the water has turned murky, he lifts the hide out and rinses off grime. Then he spreads the soaked hide across a wooden frame, ready for the next treatment stage.

A person sits on a stump by a fire, spreading the hide over their lap. They grip the stone scraper in one hand, placing its sharp edge against the inner surface of the skin. Leaning forward, they use steady, controlled strokes, pulling the scraper toward them to lift away clinging flesh and fat. Each pass reveals a smoother, cleaner surface. They periodically rinse the scraper in a basin of water to clear away residue. After covering one area, they shift the hide, repositioning it to work on tucked corners. Their rhythm is deliberate, ensuring no fibers tear. When the entire skin gleams pale and free of debris, they stop.

A primitive human lays a fresh hide on a flat rock. They scrape off excess fat and tissue with a sharp stone tool. They rinse the hide in a river to remove blood and dirt. They gather brains from a freshly hunted animal and mash them into a pulp. They add water to the brain pulp and stir vigorously until it becomes a milky solution. They spread the brain mixture evenly across both sides of the hide, working it in with hands to ensure deep saturation. They fold the hide, pressing it between two wooden boards and leave it to rest for a day. They unfold and stretch the hide repeatedly over a frame, pulling each edge taut. They continue massaging and stretching until the hide becomes soft, supple, and preserved.

A primitive human kneels by a stump, laying a hide across its flat surface. She scrapes the skin with a sharp stone, removing tissue and hair. She rinses it in a stream, then mixes crushed animal brains with water. She smears the slushy paste across both sides of the hide, folds it and leaves it to soften. After a day, she unfolds it and pulls the edges, stretching and working the fibers. She dries it near embers, testing its pliability with her hands until it becomes strong and supple.

A primitive human sits next to a sunken pit filled with glowing embers. They stretch a freshly treated hide over a crude wooden frame. He places fresh green wood chips onto the coals, coaxing a steady flow of thick, fragrant smoke. The wisps climb around the taut skin, pushing out lingering moisture and embedding preservative compounds. They stir the embers and shift the wood to keep a cool, even smolder. After several hours of unbroken exposure, the hide comes out drier, tougher, and richly colored from the smoky bath.

quartz sand.name: quartz sand
quartz sand.description: Along riverbanks and windswept slopes, the ground is strewn with fine, pale grains that shimmer in sunlight like distant stars. Each fragment feels smooth and hard between toes, slipping easily through fingers. When wind sweeps across open flats, these countless crystals dance, rising in thin plumes that sparkle before drifting away. The surface underfoot is always shifting, a continuous carpet of miniature, translucent stones echoing the sun’s glow.

wrench.name: wrench
wrench.description: This strange object appears forged from shining grey metal. It is elongated, slender in the middle, then widening into two ends of different shapes. One end forms a curved opening like a half-moon with flat sides, the other end mirrors the first but larger. The surface is smooth and cold, with faint ridges and subtle angles. It seems balanced, its weight concentrated toward both ends. It feels remarkably heavy for its size.

steps.description: A rugged craftsman selects a solid length of iron bar, feeling its weight and checking for straightness. He places the bar on a sturdy anvil, then positions a cold chisel against a marked spot where the piece will be severed. Gripping the hammer firmly, he strikes the chisel’s head, driving its edge into the metal. Small chips of iron fly as the chisel bites deeper with each blow. He shifts the bar slightly, repeating hammer strikes until the metal finally parts cleanly. Lifting the fresh segment, he sets it back on the anvil face and begins flattening any rough edges with broad hammer blows. Working systematically, he smooths the surface and ensures the length matches his mark. Flicking away stray filings, he turns the piece over and repeats the process to even out both sides. At last, he holds a uniform, trimmed section of iron—ready for the next shaping steps.

The smith lifts a glowing lump of iron bloom from the forge with heavy tongs and sets it on the anvil. He works the bellows with one foot, feeding air into the fire until the bloom’s edges glow bright orange. He pounds the bloom with broad strikes of his hammer, driving out pockets of slag as sparks fly. After several firm blows, he repositions the iron bloom with tongs and returns it to the forge. The fire’s heat softens the metal and burns off remaining impurities. 

When the bloom reaches a consistent red heat, the smith pulls it back out and places it once more on the anvil. He hammers along its length, flattening the mass and folding it over itself to weld any fissures shut. Each fold traps slag inside, which he works out with repeated hammering. He alternates heating and hammering, watching the color to know when the iron is workable. 

Finally, the smith achieves a uniform billet of clean, compacted iron. He lets it cool slightly, then reheats just enough to forge a straight, smooth bar. This refined stock is now ready for shaping into its intended form.

A primitive smith heats a lump of iron in the glowing coals until it glows red-hot. He grips the heated bar with stout tongs and lifts it from the hearth. On a solid anvil, he strikes the heated tip with a heavy hammer, drawing and flattening the metal. He hammers evenly to form a long, flat section, turning the bar frequently to maintain uniform thickness. With firm blows, he forges a narrow neck just below the working end, creating a distinct shoulder. He returns the piece to the hearth for reheating when it cools. Once red-hot again, he shapes the upper section into a slender jaw, flattening and twisting it gently with the hammer. He uses precise taps to open the gap between the jaws slightly wider than the shaft. After achieving the basic profile, he sets aside the blank for further fitting and finishing. This simple forging process yields a sturdy foundational shape.

He heats a bar of iron in the fire until it glows orange. He grips the glowing rod with tongs and transfers it to the anvil. He positions the softened metal so one end extends beyond the edge. He delivers controlled hammer strikes to taper and spread the end, creating two jaw-like extensions. He rotates the piece and hammers again, ensuring both sides mirror each other. He refines the shape by drawing the metal out, narrowing the center and flaring the tips. When the basic form appears, he uses precise downward blows to deepen the gap between the extensions, creating a mouth that can grip objects. He smooths irregularities with lighter taps, keeping the surfaces even. Once satisfied with the size and symmetry of the opening, he lets the piece cool slightly, then adjusts the angle of the arms on the anvil horn. He quenches the iron to harden the crafted jaw.

The smith builds the coals in the forge and begins to stoke them with the bellows until a fierce glow emerges. He grips a slender bar of iron with his tongs and presses it into the heart of the fire. The metal glows orange and softens under controlled heat. He lifts the bar and hammers it against the anvil, shaping a long shaft with a flattened end and a curved head. As edges form, he returns the piece to the forge, using the bellows to maintain a scorching temperature. Once the tool reaches a bright cherry hue, he clamps it with tongs and plunges it into a bucket of water, hearing a sharp hiss as the liquid quenches the hot steel. This sudden chill hardens the tool’s surface. Finally, he reheats the piece to a lower glow, lets it cool slowly, and tests its strength, completing the heat-treatment cycle.

He holds the metal bar, gripping it against a sturdy stone. He moves a coarse file along the edges, pulling away ridges and shaping the flat faces. He checks each contour with his eye, rotating the piece to ensure even lines. He switches to a finer file, smoothing scratches and rounding corners. He rubs the surfaces until they gleam in the firelight. He wipes shavings away with a scrap of cloth. He tests the fit on a bolt, slipping it snugly into place. He finishes by polishing remaining marks, yielding a strong, precise tool.

tallow.name: tallow
tallow.description: In the hollow of a carcass, soft, white globs cling to ribs and around joints, nestled among sinews and muscle. Lobes gleam with a creamy sheen, surface smooth yet yielding to the touch. In cooler shade, each chunk cracks, revealing a finer grain. When the air warms, it becomes slick, sliding in slow ribbons over stone. The mass feels light but dense, with a pale, waxlike consistency streaked with remnants of blood.

steps.description: He stands over the carcass of a freshly hunted deer, gripping a sharp stone flake knife. He begins by cutting through the hide along the belly, pulling the skin aside to reveal the thick layer beneath. With careful slices, he peels away patches of yellowish flesh where the soft fat gathers around the kidneys. He uses the flake knife to sever the white lobes lodged near the inner organs, making sure to keep the meat intact. As he works, he inspects each piece, trimming away sinew or bits of connective tissue to leave only pure, oily material. He stashes the fatty pieces in a woven basket for the next step.

The human strips soft, whitish tissue from around the carcass, cutting it into small strips. He places a clay pot near glowing embers and sets the vessel atop a flat stone above low flames. He adds the fat pieces and waits as heat gradually melts the fatty tissue. The human gently stirs with a wooden stick, ensuring each piece warms evenly. Bubbles rise and impurities float to the surface, and he carefully skims off the foam. He maintains a steady glow under the clay pot, adjusting sticks to keep the temperature mild. After several hours, clear golden liquid settles at the bottom, and he pours it into a hollowed-out shell to cool.

A primitive gatherer works near a small fire. They heat cut fat in a vessel over the flames until it melts. They rest a strainer over a second vessel. They ladle the warm liquid through the strainer. Fibrous bits and larger particles remain in the weave. The clear fat collects in the lower container. They shake the strainer gently to remove the last droplets of liquid. They gather the trapped solids and discard or roast them for scraps. Then they pour the filtered oil back into the clean pot for further heating and final settling. This process repeats until the liquid is clear and no solids cloud its surface. Then it cools and sets solid.

He tears chunks of fat by hand into small bits. He fills a clay vessel with them and sets it among glowing embers. He warms the vessel until fat begins to soften and slowly drip. He lifts and tilts it so the melted fat pools on one side. Dark solids stay behind. He repeats pouring and heating until little residue remains. He pours the clear liquid onto a clean patch of ground. He returns the vessel to the embers for more fat. After the vessel empties, he leaves the pooled liquid to cool in the shade. As it hardens, it forms firm white blocks of cooling fat ready for use.

boring bar.name: boring bar
boring bar.description: A slender, gleaming rod of cold, heavy metal lies before you. Its surface is polished smooth, reflecting light in long, straight lines along its length. One end flares into a squared-off block, while the other tapers into a slender shaft with a rounded knob. Subtle ridges hint at where different sections meet. The weight feels evenly balanced, and the edges are sharp only in their clear-cut angles, without rust or natural blemish.

steps.description: They wander the forest edge, seeking solid tree limbs. They scan ground for fallen logs with straight, heavy grain. Each candidate is tapped gently, listening for a solid sound. They strip away bark to reveal tight, uniform fibers. They test heft, swinging the piece to check balance. They assess texture and weight, discarding brittle or knotted wood. They collect the best limbs and set them aside for later shaping.

He walks into the forest, scanning for a straight, sturdy branch. He spots a young oak, its trunk straight and unblemished. He grabs a sharp flint tool and carves away rough bark, exposing smooth wood beneath. He tests the grain for knots, seeking the longest, strongest segment. Satisfied, he wedges a pointed stone and splits lengthwise, freeing several rods. He trims shoots with his flint knife, then rubs the surface with rough grass to remove splinters. At last, he gathers these lengths beside him, ready for the next step.

The artisan first cures the raw bone by placing it near glowing embers, drawing out moisture until it becomes easier to strike without shattering. Once it cools, he lays the bone across a flat stone anvil and grips a simple stone hammer. He begins with firm blows, flattening thick areas and coaxing the shaft into a basic rounded form. After each strike he pauses to rotate the piece, ensuring uniform shaping. As the shaft narrows, he shifts to gentler taps, defining a tapered end and smoothing rough patches. He trims away small projections and hollows the core by striking lighter lines along the length. Nearing the final form, he makes delicate blows to refine the profile and then rubs it against a smooth pebble to remove any burrs. The result is a straight, balanced rod ready for further use.

He gathers a straight length of iron, then builds a small furnace with clay. He piles charcoal, ignites it with flint sparks, and waits for bright coals. He sets the metal in the fire, turning it with a y-shaped stick until it glows orange. Then he lifts it with tongs and plunges it swiftly into a wooden trough filled with cold water. The sudden chill locks the metal’s structure and makes it hard. He withdraws the rod and taps it with a hammer, listening for a clear ring before further work.

pig iron.name: pig iron
pig iron.description: Massive irregular lumps of dark grey metal cluster across a bed of black dust. The surfaces are rough and crumbly, jagged edges glint faintly under the sun. Some fragments display dull silver streaks along fractured faces, while pockets of reddish rust dot the crevices. The pieces feel dense and cold when touched. They lie scattered like broken stone, yet their weight and metallic sheen set them apart from ordinary rock.

steps.description: He begins by clearing a small area at the base of a rocky slope, brushing aside loose soil and pebbles. With a sturdy hammerstone in hand, he taps the surface of a reddish band of rock. Each strike produces sharp fragments and fine dust. He focuses on areas that glow with metallic sheen, pressing his fingertips to sense concealed pockets. He wedges a fragment into a crevice, then levers it free, using the hammerstone to crack it open. He repeats this process until he collects a pile of dense, heavy chunks. He then carries the raw pieces in a woven basket to the hearth, ready for smelting. He works at dawn to maximize his haul.

First, the builder gathers fine clay from a riverbank. They mix the clay with cool water into a smooth, pliable dough. They shape the walls of a tall, cylindrical shaft, leaving an opening at the base for air flow. They press a small tuyere into the lower wall to admit bellows air. At the top, they form a funnel-shaped opening to load charcoal and ore. They let the structure dry under the sun for days until it hardens. Next, they build a platform of earth around the furnace base. Finally, they light a charcoal fire within and begin blowings, raising the heat. They pack stones around the base for extra stability.

The smith first builds a sturdy furnace from clay and stone, shaping its interior into a narrow shaft. At the base, a hole accepts a sturdy tuyere: a clay pipe that links to a set of bellows. He installs the tuyere and positions the bellows at the side of the furnace, ready to supply air.

He gathers iron ore, broken into small chunks, and he crumbles charcoal until it is fine, adding handfuls of limestone. He layers charcoal and ore and a sprinkle of limestone inside the shaft. He lights a small fire at the base; when embers glow, he begins to pump the bellows briskly, blowing air through the tuyere and feeding the flames. Heat rises sharply, and the mix glows white-hot. Every few minutes he adds more charcoal and ore, maintaining a steady glow. He watches the dripping metal forming at the bottom of the shaft. After hours of steady work the molten metal pools beneath the mass of charcoal.

When the reservoir is full, he uses the tapping rod—a pin—to pierce a clay plug at the furnace mouth. The liquid metal flows out into a carved trench, leaving behind slag. He extinguishes the bellows, cools the furnace, and breaks it open to recover the raw metal.

By the glowing furnace, a primitive worker sets a clay pipe to channel molten metal. He pierces the heated wall with a wooden stick tipped in iron, prying open the spout. Luminous liquid runs down the trench toward an array of molds. Sparks and steam hiss as hot metal surges into each cavity, filling its shape. The laborer tilts the stick to control the flow, shifting his stance to steady the stream. When the flow slows, he withdraws the tool and seals the tap hole with damp clay. He waits for the glowing ingots to harden, then cracks the molds open to reveal their dense, rough surfaces ready for refining.

A smelter kneels by a low clay furnace, blowing through a reed tube to stoke glowing coals around rusty ore. He lifts a bowl of molten metal with a bent rod and pours it into a shallow sand mold. Steam hisses. At sunrise he breaks the mold to free heavy lumps, then hammers each red-hot mass to squeeze out slag, reheating and quenching it in water to harden.

kaolin clay.name: kaolin clay
kaolin clay.description: A seam of pale earth oozes from the bank of a slow river, its surface chalky and soft to the touch. When dry, it crumbles into fine dust that drifts in the breeze; when damp, it feels cool and sticky. Its periphery blends into deeper-colored soil. Patches of this chalky earth gleam in the sunlight, revealing a powdery consistency distinct from surrounding mud and sand. It glows pale against dark soil.

wrought iron.name: wrought iron
wrought iron.description: A dark heavy object lies before me like a slab of cooled lava. Its matte surface bears gentle curves and shallow ridges. Under the sun it gleams with subtle silvery streaks within a deep charcoal hue. It feels cool and unforgiving to the touch, its weight pulling steadily downward. Tiny pits dot its face, hinting at hidden veins of lighter shine. This solid, elongated piece stands rigid and stoic, unbending.

steps.description: At dawn a craftsman scans rocky hillsides and stream beds for signs of metal in the earth. He notes patches of reddened soil and scratches at the ground with a pointed stick, revealing ocher stones. He drops a stone on a rock, listening for a metallic ring. He tests fragments with a harder rock, crushing them to see red-brown dust. He traces a slow-moving creek, gathering heavy, rusty pebbles in his pouch. He examines boggy ground for iron ore nodules and alerts his companions once a promising seam emerges.

First, the human molds clay into a cylindrical shaft open at top and bottom. They leave a small tuyere hole near the base for airflow. They reinforce the outside with dried clay patches and let it cure. They pack charcoal into the shaft, alternating with crushed ore. They light the charcoal and blow air through the tuyere. The fire roars, reducing the ore into a spongy mass of metal with slag. After hours, they quench the bloom in water, then extract and hammer it to remove impurities, forming workable iron.

A primitive maker shapes a small furnace from clay and hot stones. He opens the furnace top and layers a handful of charcoal over the bottom hearth. A scoop of crushed ore follows, and he taps it in place with a wooden stick. He alternates charcoal and ore, building a compact column. Each layer wraps partly against the walls, leaving a narrow channel for air. Once he fills the opening, he seals gaps with clay daubs and lights the charcoal. His assistant works bellows, forcing oxygen through tuyeres at the base. The steady draft heats the mix, and the charcoal reduces the ore into a bright, glowing spongy bloom of metal.

He kneels before his fireboard carved from hard wood. He collects dry blades of grass and shapes them into a loose nest beneath a shallow notch in the board. Holding the spindle between his palms, he sets its tip into the notch. He presses downward and rubs the spindle back and forth, spinning it rapidly against the board. Friction heats the wood, producing fine char dust that gathers in the notch. After moments of steady motion, wisps of gray smoke rise. He maintains the rhythm, coaxing more smoke until a small glowing ember appears. He shifts his grip seeking more heat. With care, he lifts the board and sets the ember into the grass nest. He breathes gently, fanning the ember until it ignites, and the grass bursts into flame.

Standing beside a blazing hearth, the worker grips the handles of the bellows. With rhythm, he compresses the leather bags, forcing air through the tuyere and into the glowing coals. The blast quickens the fire, raising temperature and helping the ore to reduce. He watches the colors: bright orange sparks signal enough oxygen, while dull embers warn of suffocation. In chest, he times each push and pull, keeping a constant stream. Adjusting the angle of the tuyere, he prevents blockages and ensures even heat distribution. Sweat beads brow as the furnace rumbles. By maintaining this controlled airflow, he sustains a fierce flame that transforms raw ore into workable metal.

A primitive metalworker builds a small, clay-and-stone furnace and secures a hollow wooden tuyere at its base. He lights a bed of charcoal and, once embers glow, begins to force air through the tuyere with steady bellows. As the fire reaches white-heat, he layers crushed iron ore atop fresh charcoal, watching the bed ignite and flames climb. The constant blast of air raises the temperature, and carbon from the charcoal strips oxygen from the ore in a chemical dance. Molten slag forms and seeps away, while a spongy mass of nearly pure iron collects above. Periodically he taps the furnace, discards excess slag, and replenishes charcoal and ore to maintain the heat. After several hours of careful tending—stoking the fire, adjusting the tuyere airflow and skimming impurities—he withdraws a dense bloom. This bloom, still hot and malleable, holds the refined metal ready for further hammering and shaping.

At the end of a smelting batch, the primitive artisan holds a pair of iron tongs above the glowing embers. They grip the spongy mass, called the bloom, and pull it slowly from the furnace. Molten slag and scale cling to its surface in a blackened crust. They lift the bloom clear of the furnace mouth, letting liquid slag drip free and cool its outer shell. They tap the bloom gently against a stone block, using the tongs to crack and flake off loose slag. They repeat the process, swinging the glowing mass and knocking away fragments until the core reveals a brighter sheen. The bloom waits for further forging.

The primitive human lifts the glowing iron bloom from the forge with tongs and places it on the anvil. He strikes it with the hammer, sending sparks into the air. Each blow compresses the spongy mass, forcing trapped slag to run free. He fans the bellows to feed the fire, coaxing the coals into heat, and drops the bloom back into the forge pit. The metal glows bright orange as he monitors its color, knowing it will soften enough to fold without cracking. After a few minutes he withdraws the bloom again, gripping it with tongs. On the anvil he hammers out wrinkles and hollows, flattening the bloom into a bar. With measured strikes he folds the metal over itself, sealing pockets of impurity inside. He repeats the cycle of heat and hammer: fire, lift, strike, fold. The hammer shocks drive off slag, and the repeated folding refines the internal structure into a more uniform mass. By the fold the bloom sheds its coarse texture, and the bar looks solid and consistent. He allows the metal to cool, confident that it now holds the strength to become durable tool.

lathe cutting tool.name: lathe cutting tool
lathe cutting tool.description: Dark iron meets polished wood in this slender instrument. A sturdy stick of pale brown extends into a gleaming, wedge-shaped blade of smoky steel. The edge catches sunlight, reflecting a fine line along its length. Its body is straight, tapering gently to a precise point, while the opposite side broadens into a firm grip. Cold to the touch, the metal feels smooth except for small subtle grooves near its base.

steps.description: The metalworker kneels at the rocky outcrop, grasping a heavy hammerstone. He delivers solid strikes to the copper ore, each blow spalling the hard crust and exposing bright greenish copper veins. Rubble scatters around his feet as he chips deeper, prying away fragments of ore. When he deems the yield sufficient, he gathers the copper pieces in a woven basket. He then moves to a nearby tin deposit, repeating the same methodical pounding to free tin ore shards from their matrix. He spreads the mixed minerals on a flat stone and pours cool stream water over them, washing away lighter dust and clay. He discards the washed-off waste and inspects the remaining glimmering deposits. Satisfied with the final separation, he carries the concentrated ore to the small hearth for smelting.

A primitive craftsman builds a small clay furnace and sets charcoal inside. He lights the fire and waits until the coals glow white. He places a clay crucible into the furnace and warms it gently to remove moisture. Once hot, he drops in broken copper pieces and watches them soften and flow. Then he adds tin fragments in roughly one part tin to nine parts copper, stirring with a small wooden rod until the metals blend into a liquid. He keeps the temperature high, watching the molten alloy shimmer at the surface. When the mixture is smooth and uniform, he removes the crucible with tongs. He carefully pours the glowing liquid into a carved stone mold. After it cools and solidifies, he taps the mold stone and retrieves a solid ingot. The new metal block shows a bright, golden hue, ready for further shaping and sharpening.

He arranges a pile of charcoal inside a clay-lined forge and sparks a small fire. He pumps the bellows rhythmically, feeding air into the glowing embers until they burn white-hot. He grips a length of wrought iron in the tongs and holds it in the heart of the blaze. When the metal glows the color of fresh copper, he draws it out and sets it on the anvil. With measured strikes of the hammer, he begins to flatten and elongate the bar, working steadily along its length. When a thick ridge appears, he concentrates his blows to forge a defined cutting edge. He rotates the piece in the tongs to maintain an even profile. Each time the metal cools, he returns it to the fire to restore malleability. He harnesses the bellows in bursts to raise the temperature for precise shaping and bends the end to fit a wooden handle later. Once the planned silhouette emerges, he polishes the surface on a smooth stone, leaving a bright sheen. Finally, he tests the balance and refines the edge with fine hammer tapping, creating a durable implement ready for use.

The primitive artisan picks up a rough metal bit and moistens the grinding surface with water. He places the cutting edge against the stone and holds it at a steady angle. With firm pressure he pushes the metal forward across the rock, creating small sparks. He then pulls the edge back, ensuring even contact along its length.
