Periodically he splashes more water on the stone to reduce friction and wash away metal filings. The ritual continues as the edge becomes thinner, razor-sharp. He tests the cut on a wooden stick, adjusts the angle, and repeats the motion until the bit gleams and bites smoothly through fibers. He pauses, satisfied with the precise edge.

engine lathe.name: engine lathe
engine lathe.description: A strange assembly of polished iron stands before me, stretching wide on legs. A long, smooth cylinder spans between two clamps, glinting under sunlight. Wheels and cranks hang from its length. A narrow bed of metal rails supports the rotating shaft, and a shifting block with edges sits ready to press close. The whole structure emanates a quiet hush when set in motion, humming like distant thunder.

steps.description:
He stands at the forest’s edge with an axe slung over his shoulder. He scans the tall trees and drops low-hanging limbs to clear a path. He raises the axe and strikes the trunk of a mature oak, sending chips of bark flying. Each blow rings out as he fells sturdy trees, then he limbs and splits the logs into manageable lengths. He hauls the wood in crude sledges he’s built from saplings, stacking the beams near his work area.  

He shifts to rocky outcrops where veins of iron show dark streaks. He grips his pickaxe and chips away at the hard surface, prying loose chunks of ore. Sweat beads on his brow as he breaks more stone, listening for the telltale clink of pure iron. He piles heavy ore in woven baskets and carries them back to his smelting site. Nearby, he digs into a coal seam with a shovel, prising brittle lumps of black rock from the earth. He fills sacks with this vital fuel and hauls them to a dry cave for storage.  

Beside a shallow riverbank, he scoops away sand with careful strokes of his shovel. He rinses it in the swift current, stripping silt and leaving fine grains behind. He tosses the wet sand into woven cloth, wrings out the water, and spreads it on heated stones to dry. He ventures to another ledge where copper ore glints green and red in the sunlight. He strikes it repeatedly, freeing rough nuggets that he tucks into his pouch. Finally, he locates veins of zinc hidden in fractured rock, chiseling them free with steady hands.  

At day’s end, he returns to his shelter, each raw material laid out in neat piles. The wood, iron ore, coal, limestone from nearby cliffs, sand, copper ore, and zinc ore all stand ready. His efforts complete, he surveys the gathered bounty—essential ingredients for shaping tools and crafting complex machinery by fire and forge.

A lone craftsman gathers a pile of fine sand, gritty clay, and fresh water beside his rough-hewn workbench. He sets out a sturdy wooden pattern in the shape of the long, flat base he needs. Around the pattern he places a two-part molding flask, aligning the bottom half on the bench and setting the top half aside for now.  

He sprinkles dry sand and clay over the pattern, then adds a little water and begins to work the mixture with his bare hands. He presses the damp sand–clay blend into every contour of the pattern, building up an even layer in the flask. He taps the flask’s sides with a simple wooden mallet to help the grains settle, then packs more material on top until the pattern lies buried under a uniform “bed” of mold material.  

Once the base half is full, he smooths the surface with a flat board, wipes away excess, and flips on the top half of the flask. He fills this upper chamber the same way, pressing and tapping until the entire cavity around the pattern is solid. He lets the mold rest, then carefully separate the two halves. With gentle movements he withdraws the pattern, leaving a perfect negative impression in the sand–clay bed.  

Nearby, a small charcoal furnace glows. He lifts a crucible with tongs, pours in raw ore, and heats until it runs like liquid. Using a ladle, he scoops the molten metal and steadily pours it into the newly formed cavity. After it cools and solidifies, he breaks away the mold to reveal the rough-cast bed, ready for further finishing.

A primitive craftsman begins by heating a solid iron billet in a blazing forge until it glows bright orange. He seizes the heated bar with tongs and sets it on his anvil. With heavy hammer blows he spreads the metal into a rough rectangular block—the basic profile of a headstock. He returns the piece to the fire repeatedly, forging it step by step, refining its overall dimensions and thickening the base for rigidity.

Once the block reaches the desired outline, he marks the centerline and locates the future spindle bore. Using a sharp chisel and hammer, he scores guide lines for drilling and roughs out a shallow recess where the spindle bearings will sit. He clamps the cooled block in a simple vise or holds it firmly against the anvil horn with tongs.

Next, he selects a long drill bit and fits it into a wooden brace. Positioning the bit at the scored center, he turns the brace by hand, gradually boring a smooth, straight hole through the thickness of the piece. He pauses to clear chips and refit the block in the fire if the iron hardens or work-hardens.

After drilling, he returns the headstock to the anvil for final forging touches—flattening surfaces, tapering certain faces, and forming bolt lugs by chiseling small protrusions. A few precise hammer taps square up mounting faces. Finally, he reheats and tempers the assembly for structural strength. The result is a sturdy, accurately bored headstock ready to receive spindle components.

A primitive artisan begins by gathering iron ore from a rocky outcrop. He breaks the ore into small chunks and carries them to the furnace, where he builds a charcoal fire. Using the bellows, he breathes oxygen into the hearth, raising the flame so it glows white hot. After hours of steady stoking, the ore begins to yield molten metal. He ladles the glowing liquid into a clay-lined crucible held by heavy tongs.  

Next, he prepares a mould in the shape of the tailstock body. He mixes sand and clay with just enough water to make a firm but pliable paste. Pressing the mixture into a carved wooden pattern, he creates two matching halves that will form the casting cavity. Once the mould is dry and hardened by the warm sun, he dusts its surfaces with fine sand to ease separation. He clamps the halves together and fits in risers and gates to guide the flow of metal and release trapped air.  

With the furnace roaring, he once again heats the crucible until the metal inside runs bright and fluid. Carefully, he lifts it with tongs and pours the molten iron into the mould’s mouth. The metal courses through the channels, filling every curve of the cavity. He waits patiently for the cast to cool and solidify, tapping the mould to check firmness.  

Finally, he breaks away the sand–clay shell to reveal a rough block that bears the form of the tailstock. Using simple chisels and a hammer, he removes flashes and smooths surfaces. In this way, with only furnace, bellows, crucible, tongs, mould, iron ore, sand, clay, and water, he brings a functional tailstock into being.

A primitive craftsman fashions a heavy carriage casting in several simple steps. First, he measures fine sand and sticky clay in a shallow basin. He sprinkles water slowly, kneading the mixture until it holds shape without crumbling. This damp molding sand rests at hand beside his sturdy wooden pattern carved to the exact profile of the carriage body.

He sets a two-piece mold flask on a flat plank. In the lower half, he places the pattern and packs the sand-clay mixture firmly around every contour, tapping the flask walls with a wooden mallet to remove air pockets. When he peels back the top half, the carved pattern leaves a precise cavity. He removes the pattern carefully, brushes away loose grains, then replaces the flask lid, aligning sprue and riser channels for smooth metal flow.

Next, he piles iron filings and small lumps of iron ore into the crucible. He slides the crucible into the roaring furnace, coaxing bright orange heat with blows of air from a handheld bellows. After a quarter hour, molten iron fills the crucible and simmers. With long steel tongs, he lifts it out and steadies it over the sprue. He tilts the crucible with a ladle in his other hand, guiding a steady stream of metal into the mold cavity.

He waits patiently as the carriage casting cools and hardens. When the iron looks dull and no steam rises, he pries apart the mold flask. Chunks of sand and clay crumble free, revealing the rough grey casting. He scrapes off sprue remnants and files sharp edges smooth, checking the guideways for accuracy. The heavy iron carriage lies complete, ready for later assembly and fine adjustment.

A craftsman fits a length of iron rod between the headstock and tailstock centers on his simple turning machine. He spins the work by turning the hand crank, watching the rod rotate at a steady pace. He mounts a sharp chisel in the toolpost and positions it at the rod’s end. With each manual sweep, he feeds the tool along the spinning rod, carving a shallow helical groove. After several roughing passes, he swaps to a flat file, setting its teeth at the correct helix angle. He draws the file along the spinning rod, smoothing each thread crest and root. He stops occasionally to check the spiral’s pitch with a wooden gauge, then repeats filing until the screw thread matches the gear’s lead perfectly.

A primitive craftsman stands before a set of heavy cast parts that will form a metal-turning machine. He lifts the main bed onto wooden blocks and ensures it sits flat. He places iron brackets beneath the bed and threads bolts through mounting holes, adding washers beneath each bolt head and securing nuts with a wrench. He taps each bolt with a hammer to set it square before applying a final wrench turn.

Next he aligns the headstock on the left end of the bed, sliding it into place. He inserts long screws through its base flange, places washers, and tightens nuts. He uses the screwdriver to snug cover plates around the spindle housing, then tightens each bolt evenly with the wrench.

He moves to the tailstock, sliding it along the bed ways until it meets a straightedge against the headstock spindle. He drops in screws and washers, then clamps the tailstock by tightening a central bolt with the wrench. He adds two bolts through side brackets and secures them with nuts.

Finally, he positions the sliding carriage and secures its handwheel assembly by threading screws into predrilled holes and tightening with the screwdriver. He checks all fastenings with the wrench for firm contact. The metal-turning machine stands assembled, ready for shaping raw stock.

lathe.name: lathe
lathe.description: A long, polished beam rests on two sturdy supports crafted from natural timber or stone. A narrow, cylindrical piece of wood lies between two carved notches, fitting snugly at each end. A tapered stick extends from one side, suspended above the beam by a smooth rope loop. Its surface gleams where it slowly turns, reflecting sunlight in a steady circle. The supports hold it level, inviting mesmerized eyes to follow.

steps.description: The craftsman selects a straight, sturdy branch and uses his axe to split it into two hefty beams. He trims each beam’s ends square, then sets them parallel on the ground. With his axe he roughly carves shallow notches at evenly spaced intervals along the top edges. Next, he picks up his chisel and, holding it firmly against the notch edges, taps carefully to deepen and smooth each recess until they form neat, U-shaped troughs. He tests the spacing by fitting a long pole across the troughs, ensuring it rolls freely without slipping. If the troughs sit too shallow, he refines their depth with the chisel. Once satisfied, he sands the support surfaces with rough bark to remove sharp edges. Finally, he positions the two beams upright, anchoring their bases in damp earth so they stand firm as a turning cradle.

A crafty human begins by selecting a straight, sturdy branch and stripping away its bark. Holding the wood between two forked supports, they spin it back and forth with their free hand. With a sharp knife in hand, they shave thin curls from the surface as the piece rotates, carefully guiding each slice to maintain an even thickness. They work from one end toward the middle, checking frequently for balance. As the cylinder takes shape, they taper one end into a point and fashion the other into a bulb that will catch a cord or bow string. Finally, they smooth the wood by making light, precise cuts, producing a perfect spindle ready for fast, steady rotation.

He selects two tree trunks as uprights. He smooths surfaces by hammering with the side of his hammer. He shapes a crossbeam to span the uprights by striking away excess wood. He positions the crossbeam atop the posts and holds it. He bores holes through the joints with a sharpened wooden spike and hammers it to pierce the wood. He inserts wooden pegs in each hole and hammers them flush. He checks alignment by stretching a cord between the centers of the uprights. He cuts wedges of wood and hammers them beneath the crossbeam to remove any play. He tests stability by pushing on each side and tightens loose pegs.

He selects a straight, knot-free branch of hazel or ash and strips the bark with his knife. He trims each end to a rough cylinder, then mounts the stick between two small wooden blocks with shallow notches. Holding each block, he spins the wood rapidly by rolling the sticks between his palms. As the piece turns, he guides the blade against its surface, shaving thin curls and smoothing its length. He tapers one end to a sharp point and shapes the opposite end into a wide shoulder that will catch a cord. He continues to rotate and cut until the shaft is balanced and polished, ready for his next task.

First, the craftsman selects a sturdy branch and smooths it into an axle. He drills a central socket with a sharpened stone and carves notches at either end for support. He then shapes a wooden disc into a wheel, chiseling a groove around its rim to guide the cord. Next, he hammers wooden pegs into holes around the disc edge to anchor the belt. He spins flax fibers into a cord, twisting, braiding until it can bear tension. He wraps the cord into the groove so it catches each peg. He sets the axle ends into carved notches on two upright posts and drives in wedges with the hammer to lock them. Finally, he pulls the wheel, testing and adjusting the wedges until the mechanism spins evenly under hand movement.

stone pick.name: stone pick
stone pick.description: A roughly triangular fragment of dark gray rock fits easily in a human palm. One edge tapers to a narrow ridge, its surface flaking into irregular ridges and sharp angles, while the opposite end remains thick and rounded, worn smooth as a river pebble. Subtle striations whisper of impact upon stone. Scattered flecks of mica shimmer faintly in sunlight. Its weight is cool to the touch in midday sun.

steps.description: He climbs to rocky outcrops near riverbeds and scans the exposed cliff faces. He taps exposed nodules, listening to the ring. He examines the color and texture of the fractured surfaces, seeking fine-grained, flintlike nodules. He scoops away soil to reveal buried lumps and pries small pieces loose. He watches for angular rocks that shatter with a sharp edge. He evaluates weight and sound. He marks promising veins before returning with tools.

A primitive human stands before a raw flint core, examining its angles. They grasp a rounded hammerstone firmly in one hand, resting the core securely on a lower rock or supported on the opposite knee. With a careful, practiced eye, they position the hammerstone just above an edge that promises a neat flake. They deliver a controlled strike at an oblique angle, aiming to detach a thin, broad fragment. The impact cleaves a clean, sharp-edged blank from the core. They rotate the remaining core, seeking the next suitable platform. Repeating this percussive rhythm, they extract multiple blanks, each thin, flat, and ready for further shaping into cutting or scraping tools.

The primitive artisan grips a chunk of flint, selects a rounded hammerstone, and strikes the edge at about 30 degrees, removing sharp flakes. Each blow produces a curved fragment, and he inspects the form. He rotates the flint, tapping along its edge to establish a pointed profile. He focuses on creating a broad head, adjusting his force to maintain control. He uses softer blows to refine the contours, smoothing irregularities. Throughout the process, he watches for symmetry and checks the edge for durability. When the shape begins to resemble a wedge, he tests its balance. At last, he seats it into a wooden handle, securing it with animal sinew.

First the craftsman selects a straight hardwood branch about the length of his forearm. He uses a sharp flake to strip off the bark, exposing pale wood underneath. He then shapes the branch by striking edges with controlled blows, creating a smooth, tapering form. At one end he carves a shallow groove to seat a flake tool head. He gathers plant fiber from tall grasses and twists it into cord. He moistens the cord with fresh water to ease tight binding. He wraps the cord tightly around the grooved end, binding the tool head in place. He finishes by knotting the fibers securely, smoothing rough spots for a comfortable grip.

A primitive human selects a sturdy branch for the handle and a sharp, heavy rock for the head. They carve a notch at the top of the handle, fitting the rock’s curve. Then they gather flexible vines from plants, stripping off leaves and twigs. They wrap the vine tightly around the rock and handle, weaving a crisscross pattern to bind them firmly. As they pull each strand taut, they tie secure knots, ensuring no looseness. They cut away excess vine, leaving a solid tool ready for digging and chipping tasks.

blast furnace.name: blast furnace
blast furnace.description: A towering, obsidian-colored structure stands against the sky, its sides banded by thick metal hoops. At its summit, an unceasing glow pulses within a narrow opening, casting seething embers and flickering shadows. A harsh roar issues from vents near its base, as swirling winds dance around charred stones. Dark plumes of smoke curl upward in relentless spirals, while the earth beneath trembles with the rhythmic pounding of distant, hidden fires.

steps.description: He moves across the valley, eyes scanning for firm, level ground that will bear the weight of heavy stones and clay. He stays close to a source of fine clay and a cool stream, ensuring water for soaking clay and quenching metal. He seeks a stand of hardwoods upwind, where wind brings fresh air but carries embers away. He chooses a sheltered spot near iron-rich outcrops, allowing quick transport of ore.

Standing near a rocky slope, a lone craftsman picks up a chipped stone axe and strikes the earth. He loosens soil with a pointed stick, prying out clumps of clay and pebbles. He passes load after load to a helper who dumps it a distance away. He marks a rectangular outline with charcoal, then digs to firm ground, leveling the floor by pounding flat stones into place for a platform.

He marks a circular area and digs a deep pit to house the tall, tapered shaft. He piles handfuls of clay into a trough, pouring water little by little and stirring until the mixture reaches a doughy consistency. He scoops the clay mortar onto the pit’s edge, presses it into molds, and shapes uniform bricks. He layers the first ring of bricks around the pit, packing wet clay between each joint to seal gaps. He sets a sturdy ladder inside the ring and climbs to build higher courses. Each time he checks that the interior remains clear, sweeping away loose bits. He smooths the outer wall with a damp hand, ensuring each layer bonds firmly. The shaft now stands straight, ready for its role in heating ore.

He shapes a clay cylinder to serve as an intake tube. He uses his hammer and chisel to hollow out the hearth wall, carving a round port near the base. He taps gently with the hammer, guiding the chisel to produce a smooth opening. He fits the clay tube into the hole, adjusting its length so it reaches inside the chamber. He presses clay around the joint, sealing gaps with slurry. He tests the inlet by blowing air through the pipe, listening for even flow and watching for leaks. He lines the interior with a layer of clay to prevent collapse under heat. He smooths the inner surface with a pebble so air flows freely. Finally, he polishes the outer clay, making sure the inlet directs air into the fire.

He selects a straight-grained log and uses his axe to chop it into two flat boards. He aims for similar size and thickness, about a hand’s breadth wide and a span long. He uses the knife to trim splinters and smooth rough edges. Next, he lays the two boards face down and carves a shallow groove along their perimeters to hold the hide. With the awl he pricks evenly spaced holes along each groove, preparing for sewing. He drapes a tanned animal hide between the boards, pulling it taut and aligning its edges with the grooves. He threads a length of soaked animal sinew through his needle, tying one end securely. Starting at a corner, he stitches the hide into the holes, drawing sinew tight to seal every gap. As he works around the perimeter, the hide forms an airtight envelope that will expand and contract. Once the stitching is complete, he laces a hinge of sinew at the top ends of the boards, leaving the opposite ends free to open and close like a mouth. He smooths the wood handles and pumps the assembly, observing the hide inflate and collapse. Satisfied, he refines the handles for a firm grip, ensuring the tool delivers a strong rush of air with each stroke. He hangs it by the handles away from direct heat and sun.

The craftsman first carves a rectangular frame from seasoned oak. He fits two wide boards together, leaving space for a flexible bag. Next he cuts thick tanned hide and presses it between the boards. Using an iron nail, he pierces the hide along the edges, then hammers each nail flush. He folds the boards and clamps them with wooden pegs that he aligns through matching holes. A small iron hinge links the moving plank to the fixed board, forming a simple valve. He winds a leather strap around the hinge pin to ensure a snug seal. At the bottom, he drives an iron nozzle into a carved wooden socket. The nozzle points toward the fire chamber’s air hole. Finally, he positions the assembly so the nozzle slides into the inlet, and he locks an iron bracket against the wood with his hammer. Now each pull and push forces air into the hot coals.

ladder.name: ladder
ladder.description: Before me stands two long, straight trunks of wood bound together at regular intervals by stout, narrow branches. The poles run parallel, kept apart by the series of crosspieces woven in and lashed tight with rawhide fibers. Each crossbeam is evenly spaced, forming a repeating rhythm of sturdy steps. This construction slopes gently upward, its smooth surfaces scarred with bark patterns and the bindings’ knotted ends jutting outward like bristling fingertips.

steps.description: He crouches near a clump of young trees and hefts his stone axe. He strikes a slender trunk, then pries loose a straight branch. He removes smaller twigs and smooths the strip to reveal a clean pole. He repeats until he gathers several sturdy lengths. He strikes off rough bark with a sharp rock edge, leaving a surface more suitable for tying. Next, he moves to a thicket of vines winding over rocks. He pulls each pliable cord free, taking care not to snap it. He inspects each piece for knots or cracks, discarding weak strands. He coils the vines into neat bundles beside him. With his pile of poles and gathered rope, he prepares the next phase of construction. He rests briefly to survey his haul before moving on.

The craftsman stands before two sturdy trunks he selects from a nearby grove. He raises each beam and cleaves it with firm strokes of the stone axe, removing bark and shaping six evenly thick poles. He smooths each piece by paring the edges until he sees straight faces. Then he carves evenly spaced notches along the length of the side beams. He hews slender round pegs from a small branch and refines their points. He aligns one side beam, fitting a peg into its lowest notch before driving it firmly home. He repeats for each crosspiece. He checks the layout for symmetry and balance. He taps joints to test strength.

He cuts long strips of bark. He soaks them in water to soften the fibers. He peels away outer layers to expose strong inner strands. He twists the fibers between his hands to form flexible cords. He positions the rungs across two sturdy poles. He wraps a cord tightly around the joint where pole and rung intersect. He loops the binding multiple times, ensuring the rung sits firmly against the pole. He ties a final knot and tucks the ends beneath the wraps. The firm lashings hold the frame together.

animal hide.name: animal hide
animal hide.description: In a shadowed cave, a broad sheet of pale, mottled flesh hangs limply from a branch. Coarse hairs cling unevenly to its surface, matting in thick clusters. The edges are jagged and torn, curling as damp air presses against the fibers. Its scent is coppery, tinged with distant movements. Light glints off taut membranes, revealing faint veins and irregular patterns where muscles once pulsed. The surface feels cool and stiff.

steps.description: A lone gatherer moves through the grass at dawn, gripping a sharpened wooden spear. He spots a grazing deer and creeps forward, body low and steps silent. When he is within striking range, he plants his feet firmly, raises the spear, and lunges with all his strength. The point drives home just behind the shoulder, piercing vital organs. The deer staggers, muscles trembling, then collapses to the earth. Breathing heavily, the gatherer ensures it no longer stirs before easing the spear free. He lets the creature rest until life fully ebbs away, then begins the careful work of butchering and preparing the pelt for later use.

He sets the carcass on a flat rock, turning it so the flank faces up. He holds a flake in one hand and presses its edge against the flesh near the hind leg. With short, steady cuts he frees the skin from the muscle tissue, working around joints and drawing the blade close to the bones. He peels the loosened section back, paying close attention not to puncture the membrane. As he works toward the neck and belly, he adjusts his grip and uses the flake’s sharp tip to slip beneath connective layers. When the skin lies free, he spreads it over branches to dry, preparing it for further scraping and treatment.

A primitive worker places the fresh skin across a sturdy rock or stretched frame. He holds a sharp stone scraper firmly in his right hand, angling its chipped edge against the flesh side. With measured pressure, he drags the tool along the surface, cutting away fat, membrane, and stubborn tissue. As the scraper moves, scraps of sinew curl and pile at the edge. He rotates the skin, adjusting tension to keep the surface taut. Each stroke follows the grain, ensuring an even finish. Periodically, he wipes the blade clean before resuming. This method slowly reveals a smooth, flexible surface ready for further tanning. Eventually, the skin lies clean, with only its grain remaining.

The craftsman sets out to prepare a fresh hide. He places it flat on a wooden frame and uses a sharp knife to scrape away flesh and fat. He rinses the raw material in cool water to wash off blood and debris. Gathering a fresh brain from a recent kill, he mixes it with water until it forms a thin paste. He spreads the mixture evenly over both sides, ensuring every fiber receives nourishment. After massaging the paste into the skin, he folds the hide and lets it rest. He reopens the hide and works it by hand, stretching and twisting until it dries slightly but remains pliable. He repeats this process of wetting, rubbing, and stretching all day. Finally, he hangs the treated piece near a gentle smoke above the fire. This smoke prevents it from stiffening and infuses a subtle scent, leaving a soft, durable leather.

A primitive human suspends tanned skins on a wooden rack in a sunny spot near the dwelling. He stretches each piece firmly over notches carved into a bent sapling and secures edges with wooden pegs. Breezes flow freely, and he turns the skins every few hours to expose all sides to sun and wind. Fibers tighten as moisture evaporates, the piece turning taut and pale. He watches for uniform stiffness and rubs it with animal fat when dry. Once firm and cool, he removes it for final softening and storage.

animal sinew.name: animal sinew
animal sinew.description: A glistening bundle of pale ribbons weaves gently beneath the hide, each strand translucent, ivory-toned, and slick with moisture. When pulled apart, it reveals countless fine, delicate filaments that resist breaking under tension. The cords curve smoothly, supple yet strong, and in the morning light they shimmer with a subtle glow. Though hidden within flesh, their pattern of tiny cross-striations hints at an underlying strength, intriguing every careful observer.

steps.description: He moves silently through tall grasses. At dawn, he spots a herd grazing near a bend in the river. He grips his spear, its stone tip gleaming. He crouches behind a low outcrop, studying the largest creature. His breath steadies as he edges closer, following the wind’s direction to mask his scent. When the beast steps on dry leaves, he freezes. Then, with a burst of speed, he dashes forward, spear poised. He aims for the flank, thrusting in. The creature stumbles and falls. He watches its chest for breathing before approaching to ensure the prey lies still. Satisfied, he retrieves his spear and kneels at the carcass to continue.

He steadies his weight against the wind, gripping the sharpened wooden spear in his hands. He watches the grazing deer through swaying grass, breathing slowly to calm his heart. When the creature lifts its head, he locks his feet, raises the point, and drives forward in a forceful thrust. The blade pierces the flank, and the deer falters. He pulls the spear free, then steps back, his arms shaking. Blood seeps onto earth as he watches until movement ceases. He approaches carefully, checks for a final twitch, then turns the body over, ready for the next tasks: preparing the hide, separating strips of tough tissue for binding and cordage.

First, the hunter sets the carcass on a rock. He grips a knife and makes an incision near the joint, cutting through hide and flesh. With steady hands, he peels back the skin in long strips, following the contours of the muscle. The hunter separates the tough connective bands, sliding the knife along their length to free them from surrounding tissue. He holds each strip taut, trimming away bits of fat and debris to leave clean, flexible fibers. After stripping away the hide, he gathers these strands and lays them on a flat surface. He then softens them by twisting and rubbing until they become supple threads ready for binding.

He grips a tendon and lays it across a low stone. Pressing a knife along its length, he slices the outer membrane to reveal inner fiber bundles. He carefully peels back the tough covering, cutting away scraps to avoid tearing the strands. With the blade held at a low angle, he scrapes along the fibers to separate them cleanly. He repeats this motion until only a clean bundle of strong, flexible cords remains. He inspects each strand, trimming frayed bits with the blade’s tip so the finished cords lie supple and strong for binding. Then he stretches them between sticks over smoke to dry and harden before storage.

A hunter strips raw tendon from a fresh carcass, placing each piece in a small bowl of clear water. The strands soak until they soften, making the outer membrane easier to remove. He holds a soaked strip tight across his knee and uses a sharp knife to scrape gently along its length, peeling away bits of fat and loose fibers. He rotates the strip as he works, ensuring each surface is cleaned until only the tough white threads remain. He then rinses the cleaned fibers in fresh water, wringing out excess moisture. He threads the tidy threads between his fingers, pulling and rolling to separate them into thin, even strands. Finally, he lays the prepared strands across a flat stone to dry in the sun, ready for use as strong cordage.

A primitive craftsman begins by stripping thin strands of sinew from a freshly hunted carcass. He removes fat and gristle by scraping with a flint blade. He rinses the fibers in cool water, then lays them in the sun for hours, turning frequently to ensure equal drying. As the strands tighten, he gently stretches them between two sturdy sticks, keeping tension to prevent shrinkage. Once fully dry, he uses a stone to comb out any remaining impurities. The result is strong, flexible cord ready for binding, sewing, or bowstring work.

wooden spear.name: wooden spear
wooden spear.description: A long slender piece of pale wood rests on the ground, its bark stripped away to reveal smooth fibers that gleam faintly. One end tapers into a sharp point, splitting the fibers neatly, while the other end retains a rough texture. The grain runs straight along its length, and faint resin scent lingers. It feels balanced and solid, as though drawn from living forest growth. Subtle radial lines mark its surface.

steps.description: An early human stands at the forest’s edge, scanning for a straight, sturdy branch. He runs his fingers along trunks, seeking a length with uniform thickness and minimal curvature. He hesitates at knots and bends them slightly, listening for a rich, flexible crack. He selects one near his arm’s span, with bark intact but free of deep fissures. He snaps off smaller twigs, ensuring a single, unbroken shaft. He wipes away loose bark, smoothes minor protrusions with a stone, and prepares the branch for further shaping and sharpening.

He picks a straight branch about his height. He positions the thicker end on the ground and holds the other end in one hand. With a sharp-edged stone, he strikes along the tip, removing small chips. He then holds the branch horizontally and drags the stone along the wood fibers, shaving away splinters. He rotates the branch, repeating the scraping motion to taper the end into a point. He inspects the taper with his fingers, smoothing rough patches. When the shaft feels evenly slender toward the tip, he smooths any remaining splinters. He tests the point by pressing it against a soft log, adjusting until the end is sharp enough to penetrate.

stone scraper.name: stone scraper
stone scraper.description: A small, slender shard of dark, earthy rock lies amid fallen leaves, its edges gleaming faintly where thin chips have been removed. One side curves slightly outward; the opposite side bears shallow flake scars that catch the light. The surface feels cool and smooth to the touch, with occasional rough ridges along its margins. Its weight is modest yet solid, hinting at a hidden strength within its compact form.

steps.description: At dawn, the craftsman steps onto a rocky plateau. He scans the ground for nodules, eyes narrowing at the glint of flint in the sunlight. He crouches by riverbank pebbles, tapping them against larger stones, judging their fracture patterns. He traces his fingers along outcrops, noting spots with clean breaks. He moves, marking promising boulders with charcoal scratches. He maps a path to gather material to fashion his cutting tool.

First, he scans the rocky ground for a suitable piece of raw stone. He picks up stone chips and holds one to the light, noting its shape, color, and texture. He taps its edge, feeling its weight and listening for a sharp ring. He traces his thumb along its surface, sensing grain and hardness. He seeks a fragment with a broad, flat side and a fine, uniform structure. Once confident it has the right density and flaking potential, he sets it aside as the starting blank for his cutting implement.

First, the maker selects a suitable piece of raw material. He grips the core in his left hand and raises a hammerstone in his right. He holds the raw material at a steady angle. With a firm motion, he brings the hammerstone down against the edge of the core. The blow travels across the surface, generating a shock that fractures the material. A thin, sharp fragment peels away, separating from the core. He inspects the newly detached piece, noting its thickness and sharpness. If needed, he repositions the core and repeats the strike, creating multiple flakes. Each fragment becomes a small cutting implement, ready for further refinement and use quickly.

A primitive toolmaker selects a sharp-edged stone flake and holds it firmly against a leather pad or piece of hide. With a rounded hammerstone in the opposite hand, they retouch the edge by striking near the margin at a low angle, detaching tiny flakes. Each blow removes chips that blend irregularities, creating a consistent bevel. They rotate the flake, methodically advancing along the perimeter. Light pressure ensures small, controlled removals rather than large breaks. Periodic examination reveals a continuously sharper and more uniform rim. When the retouched margin attains a thin, durable profile, the tool possesses a finely honed cutting edge ready for scraping, slicing, and carving.

animal skin.name: animal skin
animal skin.description: It lies stretched and curved against uneven ground, its edges irregular and softly undulating. One surface is coarse, the other raw and fibrous. The color ranges from tawny brown to pale cream, mottled with stray darker spots. A faint, earthy scent of fur and dried blood lingers around its borders. It gives slightly when pressed, betraying a once-pliable thickness. Frayed remnants of hair cling in patches across its broad, flat expanse.

steps.description: The hunter moves at dawn, scanning the forest floor for signs of a fallen creature. He follows tracks, sniffing the air for decay. Eyes sweep broken branches, vultures circling overhead. Kneeling at a shallow pit, he uncovers scattered bones and matted fur. He inspects the surrounding underbrush, seeking fresh blood or paw prints. If the carcass lies hidden beneath leaves, he brushes aside debris, noting the state of the flesh. Satisfied the body remains intact, he cautiously sharpens his flint blade, eagerly preparing to strip the pelt from the frame.

A solitary hunter crouches beside a freshly felled deer. He grips a flint knife and slices along the belly, carefully piercing the hide from sternum to pelvis. His fingers part the tough membrane, loosening it from flesh and muscle. He works slowly, cutting around limbs and joints with precise motions. Each stroke follows natural seams, preventing tears. He pulls the hide downward, freeing it from haunches and shoulders. When the hide hangs loose, he sets it on a flat stone, scraping away fat and tissue with the knife’s edge. The resulting pelt covers the stone like a cloak. He folds it for transport back to camp and dries it by the fire.

A primitive human strips away flesh and fat from a hide using a sharp stone tool. They rub salt into every surface, kneading the layers until moisture seeps out. Then they stretch the hide over a wooden frame and secure it with sinew. In the air they turn the hide to catch the sun and wind, allowing each side to dry thoroughly. Once parchment-like, the hide is softened by working it between hands and rubbing animal fat into the fibers. The result is a durable dried hide ready for use.

brain.name: brain
brain.description: It lies moist and glistening, a soft mass divided into lobes by deep grooves. Its surface ripples with folds, each ridge slick and supple, like a damp sponge. Thin lines of red weave through its pale, marbled flesh, pulsing faintly. When touched, it yields easily, dripping clear liquid. Its scent is metallic, faintly sweet; it quivers under a gentle prodding. Without bones or firmness, it resembles a living puzzle of tender flesh.

steps.description: A lone hunter emerges at dawn. He grips a sturdy wooden spear, shaped from a young tree branch. His eyes scan the grassland as he crouches low, listening for rustling. When a deer steps into a clearing, he freezes, aims the spear forward. He takes a steady breath, steps forward with silent caution. The hunter shifts his weight, muscles coiled like springs. Then he lunges, thrusting the sharpened tip into the flank of the deer. The animal stumbles, but he holds firm, driving the spear deeper. Blood seeps over his hands as he follows the beast. When it falls, he waits for its last breath before cutting the shaft from its shoulder.
Unfortunately, the model refused to describe step {'step': 'split skull', 'tools': [], 'raw_materials': ['skull']}

He picks up the hammerstone, nestles the fresh animal head on a flat rock, and supports it with one hand. Striking firmly near the margin, he cracks the dome, listening for a sharp fracture. He repeats light taps until a jagged flap of bone lifts aside, exposing the soft grey mass within. With a small wooden spatula, he teases out the inner contents, scooping and scraping until the cavity lies empty. He shakes away any clinging tissue and rinses the interior with cold water. He inspects the clean shell, then places it in a basket. The removed mass joins other organs in a hide bag for pounding into paste.

skin.name: skin
skin.description: This thin living envelope covers every creature’s form, stretching gently over bones and flesh. Its surface feels cool to the touch, subtly moist yet resilient, varying from smooth and satin-like to rugged with fine lines. Under the sun it gleams softly, revealing spiral ridges and arches. When pressed it yields, then returns to shape. Here and there it bears tiny hairs, and its hues shift with warmth and chill.

steps.description: A lone hunter steps carefully through the dawn mist, senses alert for any hint of movement. He scans broken ground and bent grass, eyes trained on soft tracks left by a passing deer. He moves in silence, shifting weight from one foot to the other, barely cracking a twig. When the creature emerges into a clearing, he pauses, holding the shaft of his spear level, muscles taut. The beast raises its head, nostrils flaring. The hunter draws a deep breath, then hurls the spear with deadly precision. The projectile soars, striking true. The animal drops, and the man approaches slowly to secure his prize for further work with careful hands.

A lone gatherer kneels beside a fresh animal carcass, laid on a bed of grass. With a sharp knife held in a firm grip, they make shallow cuts around the ankle joints of each limb, carefully separating the thick outer layer from the underlying tissue. Starting at a corner near the haunch, they slide the edge of the knife under the covering, slicing and pulling the hide away in slow, controlled strokes. As the pelt loosens, they work methodically along the spine, cutting any stubborn attachments. When the entire covering peels free, they lift the clean pelt and drape it over a branch to dry, ready for further processing.

Standing before a rough-hewn frame, the maker grips a wet hide with one hand and a stout scraper with the other. He holds the edge taut and directs each stroke away from his body, drawing off flecks of tissue and under-flesh. He works along the curve of the hide, adjusting the angle to follow natural contours. As the tool catches and slides, damp bits smear on the blade. He rinses the hide in a shallow pool, then resumes scraping, alternating between firm pressure and gentle passes to even out thickness. He folds the treated hide to protect it from dust and wind as he moves on to the next piece.

First, the hide lies stretched over a wooden frame. The hunter spoon the fresh brain into a shallow bowl of water and stirs until the mixture thickens. He rubs the slippery paste over every inch of the flesh side of the hide, pressing firmly so that fibers soak in the oils and proteins. Next, he folds the hide, trapping air pockets, and uses a stick to work the material in rhythmic motions. As he bends and kneads, the hide becomes more pliable, its rigid fibers yielding under pressure. He periodically rinses with warm water, removes excess paste, and repeats the rubbing process. Throughout, he keeps the hide slightly damp to prevent cracking during manipulation. By the end, the hide hangs supple and ready for further crafting into garments or coverings.

A primitive human begins by cleaning the hide, laying it flesh side up over a wooden frame. The maker scrapes away excess tissue with a sharp flint tool, repeatedly rinsing the hide in stream water. Once clean, the hide is spread flat and rubbed with animal brains or crushed fat to condition the fibers. The artisan drives wooden pegs to maintain tension, allowing the hide to dry slowly in a breeze. As it stiffens, the worker gently flexes and stretches the material to keep it supple, finishing with a drape.

carcass.name: carcass
carcass.description: It lies open on the ground: limbs splayed beneath torn hide, white bones peeking through dark crimson flesh. The scent of iron and decay drifts on the wind, drawing flies that crawl over glistening meat. Nearby, tufts of matted fur cling to ragged skin, and a harsh buzz echoes in the heavy air. Warmth leaks from torn wounds, and sticky puddles pool beneath, inviting scavengers as the silent world watches.

carbon.name: carbon
carbon.description: A black powder drifts from burning wood, clinging to palms in smudgy streaks. Larger chunks appear as lustrous, hard fragments that sparkle under sunlight, yet easily flake into sooty dust. Some pieces hide within rocky seams, revealing dull, brittle lumps that crumble at a touch. In certain places, solid, glassy crystals shine sharply with a mirrored gleam. This dark material feels light when lifted, and lumps cluster in rocky cracks.

hydrogen.name: hydrogen
hydrogen.description: When water simmers in a heated bowl carved from stone, countless tiny spheres escape its surface, ascending swiftly toward the sky before fading into the bright air. At dawn, these spheres catch the sun’s early rays, glinting like fleeting sparks before vanishing. They emerge as silent breaths in bubbling springs and from damp clay along riverbanks, forming slender but restless clouds that slip through the fingers of whatever air embraces them.

nitrogen.name: nitrogen
nitrogen.description: All around me, a cold and invisible vapour shrouds the world. I feel it pressing gently against my skin and drifting through my hair without taste or scent. It does not burn or quench fire’s appetite. It dwells in every breeze, in the mist rising from the river, in the silent stillness before dawn. It slips through my fingers like a soft breath, unseen yet ever present through the air.

sulfur.name: sulfur
sulfur.description: Scattered among dark stones near steaming earth vents, this brittle mineral shines with a vivid mustard hue. It releases a sharp, eye-stinging odor like rotten eggs whenever it is cracked or breathed upon. The surface seems waxy and greasy, and it crumbles easily under pressure, scattering bright fragments. Some pieces show faint crystal faces, catching sunlight in flashes. The ground around it feels warm, and wisps of vapor curl skyward.

phosphorus.name: phosphorus
phosphorus.description: At the water’s edge after storms, I find pale, waxy lumps nestled among broken shells and bones. Each piece feels soft, cool, almost buttery to the touch. By day it hides in chalklike rocks, but at night it pulsates with a faint, ghostly glow, as if fire were trapped just beneath its surface. When warmed by my skin, the glow strengthens and hazy wisps of white smoke drift upwards.

oxygen.name: oxygen
oxygen.description: In the world around the wanderer, an unseen presence drifts through every living moment. It slips between fingers like a soft pale mist, touching skin without weight or color. When the wind stirs, it arrives in gentle sighs, carrying the scent of earth and water. It rushes into the chest, filling hollow spaces with cool fullness. Invisible yet essential, it surrounds all creatures, wrapping forests and fields in silent life.

drift.name: drift
drift.description: A long, gnarled shard of tree root or branch glides in on the tide. Its surface is worn smooth, pale and sun-faded, with deep grooves and splintery edges. Bits of bark cling in places, curling away from the wood’s rounded curves. Sand and tiny shells and encrusted barnacles stick to its damp frame. Each knotted twist hints at deep time; it rests half-buried where water meets land, silent and weathered.

steps.description: A primitive gatherer lifts an empty shell, steps away from the fire, and points toward the place where water meets earth. He turns his body toward the wide wet edge, takes firm steps over soft sand, and raises his arm to show direction. His eyes follow the curve where waves break, and his bare feet press into cool wet grain as he moves steadily closer to the water’s gentle roar.

She stands barefoot on a sandy shore as waves crash softly against pebbles. Eyes sweep along the water’s edge, searching for bleached logs and branches scattered among seaweed. Kneeling, she examines each timber’s shape, weight, and signs of rot. She grips the heaviest pieces, listening to the tide’s retreat for safety. Gathering several lengths, she hauls them up the beach, piling them carefully near her fire pit for later use.

He stands at the water’s edge, eyes a length of sun-bleached timber partially buried in damp sand. He crouches low, brushes aside loose grains, and grips the smooth, twisted log with both hands. His fingers press into cracks worn by tides as he leverages his feet to find solid purchase. With a grunt, he lifts the piece, feeling its soaked weight pull downward. Adjusting his stance, he shifts the wood across his shoulder, then turns back toward camp, ready to carry it to his fire pit for carving and fuel.

driftwood.name: driftwood
driftwood.description: A pale, elongated fragment of tree rests on the water’s edge. Jagged ends arch like sun-bleached bones, and its ridged surface is worn smooth by countless tides. Gnarled knots protrude like ancient scars, and fine grooves trace winding paths along its length. Sand clings to shallow depressions, and faint veins of darker grain show through bleached wood. Damp spots glisten where fresh swells have washed over it. Storms shape it.

vessel.name: vessel
vessel.description: A rounded object of dark, hardened earth emerges with gentle curves and a narrow base that widens into a broad, open mouth. Its sides are smooth yet bear faint ridges spiraling upward, like subtle fingerprints coiling around its form. The edge is slightly uneven, where the original maker’s hand pressed and smoothed it. Within its hollow heart, shadows linger, accentuating the depth of its cavity against the light, shifting subtly.

steps.description: The primitive human moves along the shoreline at dawn, scanning tide pools for large empty shells left behind by marine creatures. He kneels beside barnacle-encrusted rocks and plucks a sturdy conch from tangled seaweed. He tests its weight and thickness, discarding brittle or damaged pieces. After gathering several specimens, he rinses them in water to remove sand. He carries his finds back to the camp, laying each shell on a flat stone. Then he uses a hard pebble to smooth sharp edges and shape each one for holding water or food.

A primitive human selects a conch shell buried in sand. They carry it to a flat stone and use a flint scraper to chip away the rough outer surface, working around the rim to smooth jagged edges. Next, they grind the inner side with coarse sand and water, removing grit and shaping a clean hollow. To finish, they polish both faces with animal fat, rubbing gently with a soft hide until the shell gleams. The result is a lightweight, durable empty shell ready to carry water, grains, or seeds.

fat.name: fat
fat.description: Soft, pale wads cling beneath the skins of hunted beasts, nestled around organs and coating muscle. When cut, they offer a slick resistance, gleaming in torchlight like pale amber. Their texture is soft and yielding, almost gelatinous near bones, firmer in colder nights. The substance shifts and oozes, cool to the touch, leaving a slippery sheen on fingers. It gathers in irregular clumps, light in weight yet rich in layers.

pottery vessel.name: pottery vessel
pottery vessel.description: It emerges from a cluster of broken clay shards near a riverbank. Its form is round-bottomed with gently flaring sides, tapering to a narrow opening. The surface feels cool and hard under one’s palm, dusted with reddish-brown earth and faint smudges of ash. A subtle spiral indents its midsection, and hair-fine fractures trace random veins across its body. Despite its curved symmetry, tiny dimples and uneven ridges hint at a hand-shaped origin.

steps.description: He travels to the riverbank at dawn. He scans the muddy shore for rich, plastic clay. With a pointed digging stick carved from hardwood, he pries up chunks of soft earth. He tests each handful between his fingers, discarding gritty or sandy bits. He fills a woven basket with the finest clay lumps. Next, he searches downstream for a shallow pool of clear water. He dips a hollowed gourd to lift several measures and tastes it to ensure purity. He pours water into a bark-lined trough, then returns to the shelter carrying both basket and gourd to begin mixing. He drapes a damp cloth over the basket to preserve the clay’s softness.

A person digs clay from a riverbank in morning light. They test the texture with fingers, ensuring it breaks cleanly without many stones. They carry handfuls of clay to a shaded patch and knead mushy lumps smoothly until the feel is smooth. Nearby, they scoop water from a stream, filter it carefully through grass to remove grit, and pour it into a hollowed-out shell. They pinch off small bits of clay and dunk them in water, watching them soak and soften. Then the human tramples the moist clay on a flat stone, expelling air pockets and blending in enough water. Finally, they form a unified lump, ready for shaping.

He begins by taking a lump of clay and adding water drop by drop. He presses the clay between his palms until it feels soft, pliable. He rolls a coil in his hands, tapping and stretching it to an even thickness. He winds the coil around a flat base, pressing gently to attach the edges. He rolls another coil, stacks it and smooths the seam. He pinches and presses the walls to create a curve. He repeats coil stacking until the form reaches his desired height, then taps the walls to release air pockets. Finally, he smooths the surface with a wet finger, leaving it ready for drying and firing.

The primitive human forms a container from moist clay, smoothing the sides with a flat stone. They shape the opening with fingertips, then set the piece on a bed of grass near a fire. Over hours, the clay stiffens as air draws out moisture. The maker turns the vessel occasionally, brushing away cracks with a bundle of reeds. When it holds its shape, they leave it to air until hardened.

He takes the dried container and digs a pit beside the fire. He places branches and charcoal at its base, then sets the form upright within the embers. He piles kindling around, leaving gaps for air. He strikes flint to ignite the tinder, and flames envelop the surface, baking it through. He feeds the blaze with larger logs, letting coals glow red. He scatters ash over the embers to seal in heat before adding wood. After hours of heat, he lets embers fade before unearthing his hardened creation, ready for use.

stone flake knife.name: stone flake knife
stone flake knife.description: The fragment of rock rests on the ground, its silhouette slender and a tapered point that extends outward. One side is rough, with tiny chips revealing a darker core, while the other shimmers faintly where repeated striking has polished its surface. Light catches the fractured edge, sending small glints across the earth. When held up to the sky, its linear edge stands stark against the horizon of stones.

steps.description: A primitive human moves along a riverbed. They scan gravel bars, their eyes sweeping for nodules that absorb the sun’s glare, eager to find material for crafting a sharp edge. When they spot a smooth, rounded lump of rock, they pause. They kneel and brush away pebbles, letting their fingers trace the surface. They lift it, weighing the heft in their hand, pressing their thumbnail to test for hardness. When a crisp chip breaks under light pressure, they nod and grip the find, ready to take it back to camp.

He picks up the nodule in one hand and the hammerstone in the other. To strike the stone nodule, he holds the raw chunk by its narrower end and positions the hammerstone’s edge against the core at a slight angle. With a swift, controlled swing, he brings the hammerstone down onto the margin. A sharp flake shears away from the core, sending fragments scattering across the ground. He inspects the new cutting edge, then adjusts his grip and the hammerstone’s angle to remove another flake. He repeats this rhythmic striking motion, watching each detachment reshape the profile until he achieves a long, thin, razor-sharp edge.

strainer.name: strainer
strainer.description: It looks like a flat, shallow bowl of fine mesh, like the web of a giant insect but spun from gleaming, smooth threads forming regular tiny openings. Its edges are framed by a sturdy circular band. A slender rod juts out from one side, bent at a right angle. The metal surface catches pale, cold light, and the whole piece feels unexpectedly light and cool against the skin.

steps.description: He moves barefoot through morning dew and early sunlight, eyes scanning for long, sturdy grass. He kneels beside a patch of tall blades swaying in the breeze. With careful fingers, he grasps handfuls of green stalks, pulling them free at their base. He inspects each stem for flexibility and strength, discarding brittle or spotted pieces. His bundle grows heavy, stems bending but holding firm. He ties the gathered grass in small bundles with thin vine strips. He repeats this until his pile brims with enough strong, pliable fibers for weaving.

She harvests flax from the field and peels away the woody stalk. She dries the fibers in sunlight, then combs them with bone teeth to separate fine strands. She lays two sticks across upright stakes, stretching parallel strands. She dips each thin thread in water, then begins weaving across with a weft fiber. She passes the fiber over and under the stretched threads, keeping each loop snug at the previous row. She carefully tightens the mesh by pushing fibers close together and secures the edges by knotting the end threads.

The artisan selects a sturdy branch, trims off knots and bark with a flint-edged knife, and measures it against her hand span. She slices the branch lengthwise, balancing steady pressure to split a flat slat. She trims the slat’s edges into uniform strips, carefully planning their width and thickness. She carves shallow notches into each strip’s ends to allow interlocking. With precise cuts, she bends the wood gently over a glowing stone, coaxing it into a circular shape. Once the hoop holds its form, she shaves the interior edge smooth to remove splinters. Finally, she tests the fit of each segment, adjusting the curvature until the circular framework is even.

He cuts long lengths of flexible vine from the forest undergrowth, stripping away rough bark. He bends two stout lengths into a circular frame and fastens the ends by weaving a thin vine cord. He then splits several vines into thin strips and weaves them into a tight lattice. Placing the lattice across the frame, he ties each intersection firmly to the circular rim, using smaller vine fibers as lashings. He pulls each knot taut, trimming excess ends. This secures the mesh evenly across the opening, ready for its task.

tapping rod.name: tapping rod
tapping rod.description: A slender piece of pale wood drifts before the eye, its surface stripped of rough bark and polished by unseen hands. One end tapers to a fine point while the opposite sits gently rounded. Subtle grooves travel along its length, echoing the timber’s natural grain. Its straight form seems unnaturally perfect amid twisted branches, standing apart in smooth symmetry and quiet presence, touched by a soft, pale luster.

steps.description: He walks to the forest edge and scans the canopy for a young sapling with a straight limb. He traces his fingers along the bark, checking for smoothness and the absence of knots or cracks. He taps softly to test the wood’s density and listens for a clear tone. He chooses a section about his forearm’s length and the thickness of his thumb, where it feels sturdy yet flexible. He breaks off the branch with a quick, controlled force at the base, leaving a clean end ready for further shaping.

A person finds a straight, sturdy branch low on a tree. They choose a limb thick enough for their task. Grasping it near its base with both hands, they lean back and pull the limb outward from the trunk. They twist it sharply while bending it downward until the fibers at the joint give way. If the branch resists, they score the bark around the stem with a sharp stone before twisting again. At last the branch snaps free, leaving a rough stub on the tree and a fresh length.

He prepares a bed of glowing coals in a pit, shaping stones into a furnace. He heats a piece of iron until it gleams orange. Using tongs, he withdraws the metal and secures it on a flat anvil. With rhythmic hammer strokes, he flattens one end, sending sparks flying with each blow. He turns the bar, working along its length to stretch and straighten the iron, keeping an eye on its glow. As the rod grows longer, he hammers its sides to square the section and refines its edges.

When the center begins to cool, he returns the iron to the fire and repeats the process. At one end, he hammers a gentle taper to form a point. After several heating and hammering cycles, he leaves the shape uniform. Finally, he wipes away scale on a stone, inspecting the result: a straight iron implement ready for its next purpose.

tree branch.name: tree branch
tree branch.description: A slender limb extends from the trunk of a living wood, its surface rough and deeply grooved. Bark peels in thin, papery strips, revealing pale inner layers. Small buds dot its length, waiting to swell with fresh growth. Along its sides, veins of sap trace faint, meandering lines. Under the touch, it feels firm yet yields in a slight curve, its ends tapering to uneven twigs. Its bark holds scars.

steps.description: He steps into the dense woods, eyes fixed on sturdy limbs overhead. He scans low-hanging, straight shafts free of knots, testing thickness by eye. He listens for the snap of twig underfoot and inspects bark texture. He reaches high, gauging its length by stretching arms. He grasps a candidate, hefting it to check weight and balance. Satisfied with a smooth, solid piece, he prepares to break it free.

He moves carefully through the dense forest, eyes fixed on the thick bough above. His bare feet press softly against fallen leaves as he shifts toward its base. He pauses to steady his breath, raises an open hand to test the rough bark. Once certain of its strength, he crouches and leans forward, extending his reach to grasp the sturdy wood, readying himself for the next task.

He kneels beside a heavy wooden limb, pressing knees to the ground. Hands grasp its rough surface, fingers curling against bark. He shifts his weight, bending hips and knees to lower his center of gravity. With a grunt, he drives through his heels, straightening legs while lifting the limb’s weight. He leans back, arms braced, and swings it onto his shoulder. His muscles strain, and he rises for the carry.

fireboard.name: fireboard
fireboard.description: Hand-sized lightweight piece of pale wood, flattened into a short plank. One surface is polished smooth, glowing pale amber under daylight; the opposite side feels rough, with saw-tooth gouges. A shallow channel runs from one end to a round hollow near the center, inlaid with fine grooves. The edges are slightly blackened, as if kissed by smoke. It smells faintly of warm resin and dry earth when lifted up.

steps.description: He walks through the forest, eyes scanning for fallen branches. He touches bark with fingertips to gauge dryness and hardness. He seeks dense hardwood that rings when struck against stone. He inspects cracks for brittleness, avoiding damp logs near the ground. He lifts pieces, knocks them together to listen for a clear, resonant tone. He chooses a flat, straight section at least as thick as his palm. He breaks off small sticks to spin. He carries the chosen wood back to camp, ensuring it stays dry under leaves until needed.

A primitive human selects a straight section of wood and uses a sharp knife to shape a thin board. He carefully holds the branch firmly against a rock, then slices along its length, peeling away thin layers until a flat plank emerges. He smooths its surface by scraping with short strokes, removing knots and bumps. He lays the board flat on the ground and marks where the notch will go. He incises a small divot near one end, carving out wood chips until a shallow hollow forms. He tests the thickness, shaving off more wood until the plank flexes slightly under pressure. Now the simple hearth plank is ready.

He selects a straight, seasoned stick from hardwood. With a smooth, flat stone in hand, he holds the stick firmly and rubs its broad face against the stone’s worn edge. Applying steady pressure, he moves the stick back and forth in long strokes, removing ridges and irregularities. The continued abrasion wears away rough patches and hollows, gradually producing an even, level surface. He inspects the wood, turning it as needed to ensure uniform flatness along its length. When the face feels smooth to the touch and shows consistent grain patterns, he stops. He prioritizes maintaining wood’s structural integrity before moving on.

He grips a flat, dry plank of softwood in one hand and holds a sharp flint-edged knife in the other. He strikes the plank’s surface with controlled pressure, scoring a small notch near the center. He slices parallel to the grain, shaving away thin curls of wood. Slowly, he widens the cut, excavating a shallow, elliptical hollow. He occasionally removes loose chips, checking the depth with a fingertip. He sharpens the surrounding edges to prevent collapse. The cavity soon reaches about half an inch deep, its walls smooth and even. He examines every shaving. The craftsman inspects the hollow, ensuring it will cradle the rotating stick securely, ready for sparking.

pattern.name: pattern
pattern.description: Across the broad plain, the hunter’s eyes trace a row of dark and light stripes along the hide of the grazing beast, each stripe mirroring the next in width and curve. On the river’s bed, smooth stones lie in bands of shifting color, rippling beneath the flowing water. High above, the stars in the sky arrange themselves in neat rows, each pair set at equal distance. Petals around a flower’s center spiral in steady sequence.

steps.description: At dawn, a craftsman walks to the forest edge by a stream to collect sticks and fibers that will serve as templates. He examines branches for curved and straight fragments. He removes bark and trims twigs of varying thickness. With careful hands, he ties reeds into repeating units, adjusting lengths to form a guide. He seeks smooth stones to press into clay, leaving repeated marks. When the sun rises, he returns to his hut carrying bundles of these tools, ready to place them on wood or hide for decoration.

screws.name: screws
screws.description: A small, slender cylinder of polished metal emerges, its surface wrapped in a continuous spiral ridge, like a twisting vine coiling around a stem. One end tapers to a sharp point, while the opposite terminates in a flat disc etched with a crosswise groove. Light glints off its shiny, smooth, helical threads, and its weight feels solid. The spiral pattern repeats evenly along its length, promising a snug, interlocked fit.

steps.description: At dawn the artisan shoulders his worn pickaxe and trudges toward the rocky hill where veins of iron lie near the surface. He plants his feet firmly, raising the heavy tool overhead, and strikes the outcropping with practiced force. Chunks of mineral-bearing rock fracture and tumble to the ground. He pries them loose, tossing fragments aside until he reveals richer streaks of reddish metal. He chips away at the seam, gathering fist-sized lumps of iron ore into his coarse sack. Periodically he examines each piece, discarding dull stones and keeping only solid, dense specimens. By midday his sack grows heavy, promising enough raw ore for the hot forge.

A primitive craftsperson starts by breaking a small chunk of bronze from a rough ingot. They stoke the furnace until it glows with steady heat. Grabbing the bronze in tongs, they slide it into the heart of the fire. As the metal softens, it takes on a dull orange hue. Sliding the glowing piece onto the anvil, the maker pounds it firmly with the hammer, drawing the metal into a long, straight rod. Each blow stretches the material, slimming its profile while maintaining even thickness. When the rod reaches the desired length, they reheat the work in the furnace to keep it malleable. Returning it to the anvil, they strike a taper on one end, creating a point that will later guide a tight, twisting groove. On the opposite end, they hammer the bronze flatter and wider to form a primitive head, which will provide leverage when the fastening spiral is driven into a surface. Once the basic shape blank is forged—straight shaft, pointed tip, and crude head—the piece cools and awaits the next stage of refinement.

A primitive craftsman grips a solid wooden rod firmly against a rough bench surface. He takes a sharp chisel and aligns its cutting edge at a slight angle to the rod’s axis. With steady pressure and precise wrist motion, he drives the blade forward while rotating the rod slowly. This action removes a thin shaving along a diagonal path, creating a continuous spiral groove. As he works, light curls of wood shaving slip away from the blade. He checks the depth often, ensuring uniformity and a snug fit. Once complete, the crafted piece displays a perfectly winding channel. He then polishes the helix until each coil gleams cleanly.

washers.name: washers
washers.description: They see small, flat, circular objects of a cold, bright material, perfectly uniform. Each is a smooth disc with a round hole in the center. The rims gleam in sunlight, edges polished and unblemished, reflecting shards of light. They are unnaturally smooth and weigh more than stone of similar size. When several lie together, they echo like distant rainfall, a metallic sound that seems otherworldly in the wild.

steps.description: He descends into a shallow tunnel bored into a rocky hillside, the air heavy with dust. Clutching his pickaxe, he taps the stone face, listening for a hollow tone that signals mineral veins. He raises the iron head and strikes rock with steady blows, chipping away at the surface. Fragments of stone shatter and fall, each strike revealing streaks of metal embedded in the matrix. He pries out stubborn chunks with the pointed end and sweeps the scraps into a basket. He repeats this motion, swinging and gouging, until he frees a pocket of glinting material. With a blow, he dislodges a mass of raw ore, ready for the next step.

He gathers lumps of iron ore and crushed charcoal, then builds a small clay furnace on packed earth. He layers charcoal and ore inside the furnace chamber. He lights twigs at the base until flames lick the interior walls. Once the fire grows, he fits a clay tuyere into a side opening. He straps a pair of wooden bellows over the tuyere and pumps steadily. Air blasts through the nozzle, raising the temperature and forcing the charcoal to burn fiercely. Bright orange heat envelops the ore, melting impurities into liquid slag. He pauses the bellows, opens a small tap hole, and drains off the slag. Then he resumes blowing until a spongy mass of wrought iron forms at the furnace bottom. He tips out the bloom onto anvil stones and hammers it while still hot, folding and compressing the metal. This cycle of heating, tapping, and hammering yields a workable iron bloom.

A smith heats a solid iron ingot in glowing coals until it gleams bright orange. He lifts it with tongs and sets it on a sturdy die block. With strong, rhythmic blows of his hammer, he spreads the metal into a broad, thin sheet. He reinspects the glow, then turns and hammers the edges to keep the thickness even. When the plate feels supple and the gauge is right, he places it over a round cavity in the block. He centers a hardened punch atop the warm metal and strikes it sharply. The punch drives through, leaving a neat circular opening and tossing out a small disc. The remaining ring rests in the cavity. The smith repositions that ring on a shallower depression, then smooths its inner and outer rims with lighter hammer taps. He repeats heating and hammering until the metal cools smooth and flat. At last, he brushes the piece on rough stone to remove scale and reveal a bright, precise ring.

He sets the iron sheet at a comfortable angle, raising one edge on a block for support. Using charcoal and a sharp stick, he traces two concentric circles marking the width of the ring. He secures the sheet with his weight and lifts the cold chisel to the marked outside line, then strikes the chisel head with a heavy hammer. With each blow, the chisel bites into the metal, scoring a shallow groove. After scoring the full outline, he repeats the process along the inner circle. He then works the chisel under the scored edge at the outer line, delivering firm hammer strikes until the piece separates from the sheet. He finishes by trimming rough edges, driving the chisel lightly around both rims to smooth and refine the shape.

mold flask.name: mold flask
mold flask.description: It stands like a water-filled gourd of crystal, its lower belly swelling like some smooth fruit. A narrow throat rises from the rounded base, opening to a small, even lip. Light passes through its clear walls, gleaming with unnatural brilliance. The edges feel cool and hard to touch. Inside, a faint haze drifts along inner surfaces, clinging to the transparent curve of its shell. Tiny trapped air pockets float, paused in quiet suspension.

steps.description: A primitive human stands before a cluster of trees at the forest edge. He scans the trunks for straight, sturdy limbs and marks one with a notch cut by his stone axe. Swinging his blade, he works patiently, splitting the wood grain until the limb detaches. He inspects the fallen branch, discarding bark with a flake. Piecing a bundle, he secures lengths together with hemp cords. Shouldering the load, he treks back to the camp, his feet sinking in soil as he balances the timber to prepare it for shaping.

A primitive maker selects a straight-grained log and lays it across two low supports. He grips a heavy axe and brings it down in broad strokes, splitting the log into two roughly equal slabs. With the adze in hand, he swings close to the wood’s surface, scooping away chips to create a shallow cavity in each slab. Once the hollows take shape, he switches to a sharp chisel. Placing its edge against the cavity walls, he taps the handle with a hammer, peeling off small curls of wood to refine the curve and smooth uneven spots. He works around each edge, carving a uniform lip that will let the two halves press neatly together. As the interior nears the correct depth and fit, he returns to the axe for broad trimming of excess material, then shifts again to the adze for fine leveling. Throughout the process, he holds each piece to the light, checking that both halves mirror one another. Finally, he tests the fit by bringing the two wooden shapes together, ensuring a snug join before moving on to the next step.

He selects sturdy wooden boards from a hardwood tree. He trims each plank with a flint blade until its edges become straight. He carefully drills holes at the corners with a sharp stone awl. He threads leather thongs through the holes, pulling the boards tightly together. He fits a narrower plank on, evenly pressing it to create a container. He reinforces corners by wedging wooden pegs into gaps. He wraps bark strips around joints and binds them with sinew to keep the structure rigid. He tests stability by shaking it.

ladle.name: ladle
ladle.description: A long, slender arm of dark wood extends into a shallow, round bowl with gently sloping sides. The shaft is smooth and narrow, fitting easily between the fingers, while the rounded cavity curves inward like a small hollowed fruit. The surface bears subtle tool marks, and the joint between arm and cup is seamless. Sunlight glints softly off its polished skin, and it balances lightly when held at the center.

steps.description: He steps from his shelter at dawn into misty woodlands, scanning for a straight, sturdy sapling. He watches for signs of a healthy branch, free of knots and disease. He moves quietly, senses alert to animal calls. When he spots a slender trunk, he grips a flint knife, slicing under the bark to test the grain. Satisfied by the smooth fibers, he traces his hand along the length, feeling solid wood. He breaks off the chosen section at a natural joint, then carries it back across the clearing to his workshop.

A primitive craftsman selects a sturdy block of wood from a branch. He examines the grain, then grips a knife with a blade. He scores an outline around the rim to mark the shape. With controlled cuts, he removes excess wood to define the outer curve. Rotating the block, he pares away thin shavings, refining the form. Next, he drives the knife point into the center and carves concentric scoops to hollow the interior. He works from center outward, deepening the cavity. He shaves curls from surfaces, smoothing rough spots with strokes until the interior and exterior show even contours. The result is a simple hollow vessel ready for use.

The artisan grips a sturdy piece of hardwood, steady against a low stump. He selects a sharp chisel, its edge honed over countless strokes. Placing the blade against the wood, he taps the chisel’s back with a stone hammer. Small wood curls fall away in thin strips. He carves a gentle curve for the grip, rotating the block as needed. With patient precision, he deepens the concave groove along one side. He checks the symmetry by eye, shaving off high spots. After rough shaping, he smooths the surface using fine sanding stones. He pauses regularly to inspect balance. Finally, he polishes the handle with animal hide, revealing warm, golden grain.
