A primitive craftsman begins fashioning the outer housing from a brass sheet, marking a circle with dividers. He bores a blank on the lathe, cutting the outline with a saw. The lathe shapes the round form, and the file removes ridges. He uses an indexing plate to mark notches.

The maker next cuts a bezel ring from brass rod, parting it on the lathe. He drills holes for posts with a hand drill, then files the inner edge smooth. Dividers establish the correct width, and the indexing plate returns to guide decorative grooves carved into the ring’s face.

For slender hands, the artisan slices strips from steel strip with a saw, then files them down to taper. Dividers set matching lengths. A small hole at the base of each hand emerges from the hand drill. The file polishes their edges to a gleaming finish, ready for mounting.

To form the winding knob, he cuts a cylinder from brass rod on the lathe. A hand drill bores the central hole, and the screw plate pulls threads along the stem. He uses the file to ensure a snug fit and the indexing plate to engrave radial lines for grip.

For fasteners and pivots, the craftsperson turns steel rod in the lathe into tiny screws. He employs the screw plate to thread them and files each head into a miniature slot. Dividers repeat spacing tests, and the hand drill creates precise holes in the housing. The file smooths any burrs.

Finally, the artisan assembles all parts with taps, checking alignment of the housing, bezel, hands, and knob. He files any misfits, refines surfaces with alternating filing strokes, then polishes the brass to a warm glow. The assembled apparatus stands ready for final testing.

The craftsman picks up the brass main plate and sets it on a leather pad. Under the magnifying glass he inspects each pivot hole. He uses the staking tool to flatten burrs in the steel arbor seats. He grasps the tiny balance staff with tweezers and fits its pivots into the jeweled bearings. With a firm tap of the staking hammer the staff seats fully. He then positions the coiled hairspring atop the balance wheel, checking that each spiral remains concentric. He holds a steel pallet fork between tweezers and locates it against the escape wheel, turning a screw on the brass bridge with the watchmaker’s screwdriver until the clearance feels just right. Under magnification he confirms the fork’s prongs align to the escape teeth. He returns to the balance assembly, adjusting the regulating pins on the balance cock to center the hairspring. A gentle knock with the staking hammer secures the bridge’s brass plate, locking the balance wheel in place. Finally, he winds the mainspring barrel by hand, then releases the click so the spring engages. The timebase oscillates steadily, its steel and brass components working in harmony. He checks one last time under the magnifying glass to ensure perfect alignment. He listens for a rhythmic tick, knowing the device is ready.

He grips a slender steel lever with tweezers and inspects the tiny ends. The lever features a small hole near one tip for mounting. He inserts one end of a fine pivot pin through the hole using the tweezers to guide it precisely. Next he aligns the pivot pin within a matching bracket on the casing. He picks up a miniature screwdriver and tightens a tiny screw to secure the lever in place. He tests the movement by rotating the lever back and forth, listening for a clean click as it engages the mechanism. Satisfied, he carefully adjusts the screw tension. He makes a adjustment to eliminate any lateral play in the pivot, ensuring reliable operation. Finally, he inspects the lever tip alignment under natural light to confirm perfect engagement.

A solitary artisan gathers copper and zinc and builds a small furnace of clay and charcoal. He layers bronze shards deep in the embers until metal pools molten, then pours it into a flat clay mold. When the brass cools, he hammers it into a thin disc that will hold the markings. Meanwhile, he arranges silica, natron, and lime in a small crucible and heats them until they fuse into a glowing blob of glass. He removes it with tongs and cools it gently on sand, then polishes the clear sheet until it sits neatly over the brass face.

Back at the workbench, he grinds chalk with a stone pestle until it becomes a fine, white powder. Into it he stirs gum arabic and a drop of water, creating a smooth, opaque paint. He brushes a thin layer across the brass disc, waiting for it to dry under the smoke of a charcoal brazier. Once solid, he dips a sharpened quill into the gum arabic thinned further with water and carefully draws evenly spaced marks around the edge. Each notch stands out dark against the pale ground.

Finally, he fits the glass sheet atop the painted face and binds it with thin strands of heated brass, folding tiny clasps over the edge. The result is a readable face framed in gleaming metal, the display ready to receive its moving parts.

The craftsperson takes two metal plates shaped as case halves. They align the inner mechanism on the lower half, ensuring gears sit flush and springs rest freely. They place the upper half onto the lower, matching the notches. With careful hand placement, they slide the assembly under the case press. They position a flat metal die above and secure it in the press frame. They turn the lever, descending the die to apply uniform pressure. The force seals the edges of the halves, trapping the mechanism inside. After releasing the handle, they remove the newly enclosed movement and inspect the seam for gaps. Finally, they polish the joint to create a seamless finish.

lead.name: lead
lead.description: You find a heavy, dull gray rock. Its surface is muted, almost matte, until freshly broken edges gleam with a subtle shine. It feels unusually cool to the touch and yields to fingernails, leaving marks. When tapped, it emits a muffled, metallic ring that quickly fades. Tiny powdery fragments flake off under pressure, staining fingers dark gray. It often lies near riverbeds or embedded in seams of metal-rich earth.

cesium.name: cesium
cesium.description: Near the rocky shore of a shallow salty spring, gleaming lumps of pale, yellowish metal lie among stones. When touched, the soft metal yields under pressure, leaving dark gray smudges on skin. Dropped into the water, it hisses and bursts with bright flashes, sending droplets flying in mysterious spray. The lumps seem alive, eagerly leaping and singing as they vanish into vapor, their brilliant sheen startling against the barren landscape.

copper sheet.name: copper sheet
copper sheet.description: A broad, flat slab glints with a warm, reddish-orange glow under sunlight. Its surface gleams smoothly, cool to the touch, reflecting shapes like water. Edges appear straight and uniform, betraying unnatural precision. Tiny ripples catch the light in shifting patterns, while the unbroken plane resists scratches. Under the earth, it shows a duller hue, flecks of greenish powder hinting at change. It feels solid, yet oddly malleable in slender form.

steps.description: A hunter-gatherer wanders along stream banks, scanning rocky outcrops for greenish streaks and stains. He observes weathered stone and crumbles small fragments, feeling for heavy, dense flecks. He bends to test hardness with a sharp flint tool, tapping surfaces and listening for a metallic ring. He tastes damp dust on his finger, noting a metallic tang. He watches plants that thrive in rich soil, following patches of moss and lichen that cling around veins. He gathers promising ore fragments, stores them in an animal-hide pouch, and marks each site with rock piles.

A primitive human approaches a rocky outcrop and locates a vein of copper ore. He grips a hammerstone and raises it overhead, then brings it down onto the nodules, shattering the rock around embedded metal. He repeats this motion, moving across the vein, dislodging lumps of ore. His palms grow sore as he sweeps the angular fragments into a basket. He inspects each piece, discarding dull, heavily veined waste. Once the basket fills, he carries it to a grinding area, where he pounds the chunks against a flat stone, reducing them into coarse granules. He winnows away lighter debris with fanned breaths, leaving behind concentrated metallic particles ready for smelting.

A solitary craftsman gathers broken stones of copper ore and crushes them with a heavy rock until he sees glints of metal mixed with the reddish dust. He shovels charcoal into a simple clay-and-stone furnace, piling it around the crushed ore in alternating layers. Using a hollowed-out animal horn or a wooden blowpipe as a tuyere, he forces a stream of air into the glowing coals, feeding the fire with a steady breath. As the temperature climbs, the charcoal burns fiercely and reduces the ore’s oxide, releasing oxygen as smoke. Red-hot droplets of metal form at the bottom of the furnace, pooling in a small crucible. After several hours of careful bellows work, he breaks open the clay, lifts out the crucible with a pair of tongs, and pours the molten metal onto a flat stone. The metal cools into a thin, malleable disc ready for further working.

An early artisan begins by gathering raw copper fragments and charcoal. He lights a simple pit furnace by stacking charcoal and ignites it with hot embers. When the fire glows steadily, he fits a clay tuyere into a side aperture and fans air through it, raising the temperature. With sturdy tongs, he places a small clay crucible into the furnace’s hottest zone and fills it with copper pieces. The metal slowly softens, turning from dull red to bright orange before liquefying. As molten metal collects, he uses the tongs to lift the crucible free and carries it to a preformed mold. This shallow cavity, carved in cooled clay or packed sand, is cut to a flat, rectangular form. Holding the crucible pivoted carefully, he pours the glowing liquid into the mold’s contours, watching it flow to every corner. Once the molten metal cools and solidifies, he taps the mold’s edges or plunges it into water to free the newly cast plate. He then inspects its surface, readying it for subsequent reheating or hammering to reach the desired thinness. He works with patience, ensuring each casting forms without cracks or voids to ensure quality.

A primitive metalworker heats a small copper ingot in a charcoal fire until it glows dull red. He sets the hot metal on a flat stone slab used as an anvil, positioned atop a sturdy log. With a round hammerstone in hand, he strikes the heated bar with firm, rhythmic blows. Each impact flattens and widens the metal, thinning its mass into a broad, even plate. When the surface hardens and cracking appears, the artisan returns the piece to the fire to anneal it, restoring its malleability. He then resumes hammering along the edges and across the center, rotating the work to maintain a uniform gauge. Finally, he brushes the cooled, widened disc with an abrasive stone, removing scale and smoothing the surface for further shaping or decoration.

scribe.name: scribe
scribe.description: A thin, straight rod of dark-gray, cold metal stands out among rough stones. Its surface is smooth and cool, reflecting faint light in long, narrow glinting bands. One end narrows to a precise, sharp point, while the other retains a slightly broader, flat butt. Along its length, faint ridges and grooves suggest careful forging, and the metal feels weighty yet balanced in the hand, against raw earth and wood textures.

steps.description: He wades into the marsh, his feet sinking in the soft mud. He scans the tall reed stalks swaying in the breeze, seeking straight and sturdy shafts. He grips a cluster of reeds and lifts them from the water. His knife flashes as he slices through the tough stems, pruning away leaves and side shoots. He selects the firmest culms and trims off knobbly joints with swift strokes. He strips the outer skin to reveal the pale inner core, then splits the shafts lengthwise into halves. He carefully arranges the cut pieces in a bundle for transport, brushing away mud and debris. Satisfied, he shoulders his load and heads back.

He selects a stout reed from the riverbank, its hollow core ideal for holding pigments. He grips the reed in one hand and draws the knife blade along its length, slicing away the outer rind. He trims the edges with careful strokes, peeling thin strands until the shaft narrows to a fine point. The cut end emerges sharp and narrow, revealing a slender tip for marking surfaces. He rotates the reed and repeats the process, keeping the blade at a low angle to ensure a smooth bevel. With each precise pass, the tip grows slender and firm. Finally, he tests the point, ensuring it glides across soft clay without splintering.

He selects a straight hardwood branch and grips it firmly. He holds the sharp blade in his right hand and trims away the rough bark with a series of controlled strokes. Carefully he angles the knife against the grain, shaving off thin curls of wood. He rotates the shaft, sculpting the tip into a slender point. Each cut is steady, each shaving precise, as he tests the wedge with his thumb to ensure smoothness. When the shape begins to taper evenly, he switches to finer cuts, knocking off any remaining splinters. Finally he runs the blade lightly along the tip, polishing the wood into a neat, sharp nib ready for inscription.

compass.name: compass
compass.description: A small circular disk of bright, cold grey metal catches the light. On its top, a thin, transparent cover shields a pointer that floats atop a central pivot. Around the edge, faint carvings fan out at even intervals, each a slender mark, slightly worn. The pointer’s tip glimmers silver, the other end darkened, and it consistently aligns itself over the carvings. The disk feels cold and solid in the hand.

steps.description: He digs along riverbanks, smashing rocks and scooping gravel into a hide sack. He rubs a slender shard of wrought iron against each stone to test for hidden power. When a stone jerks toward the metal, he pauses. He taps the heavy rock with a small hammer, exposing a fresh face. He rubs the iron shard again, noting a stronger tug. He gathers chunks of lodestone that cling to bits of iron. After filling his satchel, he marks the earth with a carved stick to remember the ore’s resting place.

A hunter-gatherer selects a smooth chunk of magnetite and carves it into a thin, balanced shard. He suspends the shard on a twig or floats it on water. He watches as it swings and settles, pointing always toward the same direction. Trusting this silent motion, he marks a path that leads straight along its pull. He follows this alignment day after day, until the forest floor opens onto iron. He holds his magnetite shard close and sees it tremble as it pulls toward the buried mass, revealing the iron meteorite.

At dawn, a craftsman selects a smooth fragment of meteorite from last night’s find. Sitting on a flat rock, he grasps a small lodestone in his hand. With careful strokes, he draws the meteorite piece along the lodestone’s surface. He uses the same direction each time, repeating this motion dozens of times. Sweat beads on his brow as tiny sparks of energy pass between stones. After patience, he tests the meteorite’s edge near iron filings. The filings begin to cling and align, showing success. He cleans the stones with cloth then stores them for rituals on distant trails. In the flicker of firelight, he feels the metal pulse in his hand.

They approach a quiet pond and kneel by the water’s edge. They scan for a broad, firm leaf that lies atop the surface and supports a small weight. They prefer one with smooth, unblemished edges and a gentle curve to cradle the piece of metal. They test each candidate by laying it upon the water and ensuring it remains buoyant and stable. They avoid torn or thin leaves that sink or flip. Once they find a leaf that floats steadily, they pluck it carefully by the stem, keeping its shape intact.

The maker selects a fresh, broad leaf from a nearby plant, rubbing it gently between fingertips to remove dirt and moisture. They gather a shallow bowl carved from stone and peer into the clear water of a pool, removing twigs or pebbles. Holding the bowl at waist height, they tilt it to draw water slowly, filling it nearly to the brim without causing ripples. With a steady hand, they bring the leaf close to the surface and gently lower it, taking care to avoid splashes. The leaf settles and floats at the center. The maker steps back and watches, ensuring the leaf drifts freely until it slows and points steadily.

In a shallow bowl of still water, the human selects a broad leaf, its surface smooth and buoyant. He gently rinses the leaf under a trickle of cool stream water, removing any specks of debris. Holding the leaf by its stem, he lowers it onto the water, where it floats freely. Next, he reaches for the small, iron-rich stone, the meteorite cooled from ancient fire. Balancing the stone carefully between thumb and forefinger, he lowers it center on the floating leaf. The meteorite settles softly, and the leaf remains afloat, bracing the metal. He watches as the assembly turns, guided by unseen forces. He tilts his head, noting the rotation.

rosin.name: rosin
rosin.description: On the trunk of towering evergreen trees, irregular droplets of viscous, golden gum seep from cracks in the bark. They pool into congealed, glassy nodules that catch sunlight, glowing with warm, honeyed hues. When touched, these sunlit globs feel tacky and pliable, adhering to fingers with tenacious stickiness. Over time, they harden into brittle, amber shards that fracture with a sharp snap, exuding faint, pine-scented vapors carried on the breeze.

glassblowing lathe.name: glassblowing lathe
glassblowing lathe.description: A low wooden frame stretches before me, carved stout legs sinking into the earth. Between them, a slender metal rod runs lengthwise, glinting in sunlight. At one end, a hand crank juts outward, its handle weathered. Gears of iron, toothed and meshed, stand nearby, their teeth forming a jagged circle. A sturdy iron wheel, worn and smooth, is fixed to the rod. The contraption hums softly when nudged, its parts poised and balanced.

steps.description:
They strip bark by running the saw’s teeth along each beam, loosening fibers they flick away. They mark and cut with care to produce four equal uprights.

A primitive craftsperson shapes the uprights into a sturdy frame. They position two thinner planks between each pair to form cross beams. They align the edges carefully, hold the pieces steady, then drive iron nails through the wood with a hammer, binding legs and beams. They add diagonal braces at each corner for strength, cutting shorter strips of wood and securing them at an angle. They check for level and right angles, adjusting joints until the frame stands firm. They measure spacing by eye, ensuring equal distances. They lay the frame on level ground, pressing corners into the earth to check stability. They reinforce critical joints by adding an extra nail or two, then step back to inspect the structure’s symmetry.

A craftsman lays a sturdy plank on a flat workbench and aligns his rule and square along its edge. He marks two uprights of equal length, each roughly shoulder high, and draws clear lines for cutting. With his handsaw, he follows the pencil marks, slicing through fibers in slow, steady strokes. The rough posts sit on the bench while he planes every face until it gleams smooth and perfectly flat.

Next, he measures and marks notches near the top of each post, using rule and square to ensure right angles. He scores the waste wood with his chisel, then taps gently with the mallet until the shallow pockets break free. He checks depth by sliding a scrap block into the gap; it rests flush. Repeating on both uprights, he creates identical slots.

He cuts two crossbars to fit snugly between the uprights. With the handsaw he rough-saws their length, then planes all sides until they sit tight in the notches. He marks mortise holes on the uprights that match tenon shoulders on the crossbars. Using chisel and mallet, he carves clean mortises, then trims the tenons until each joint fits without wobble.

Finally, he lays the assembly flat and taps wooden pegs through pre-drilled guide holes with his hammer, locking every brace firmly in place. He runs the plane one last time over every surface, ensuring a crisp finish that resists dust and wear. The result is a pair of rock-steady supports, ready to hold a spinning rod or wheel with unwavering strength.

A craftsman selects a length of wrought iron rod and places it in the forge. He stokes the coals until they glow white, then thrusts the rod into the heart of the heat. When the metal shines orange, he withdraws it with tongs and sets it upon the anvil. With firm blows of the hammer, he flattens one end, gradually shaping a thickened collar to act as a shoulder. He returns the rod to the forge to maintain working temperature, shifts it so that one end extends beyond his anvil block. He hammers this protruding tip, tapering it into a long, slender shaft. Reheating and hammering, he achieves the correct diameter and smooth taper along the spindle’s length. He polishes ridges by peening the hot metal, spinning it on a softer surface to round the shaft. He shapes a small tenon at the end by compressing the iron between hammer and polished anvil horn, creating a snug fit with its counterpart. The spindle turns freely, ready for its task.

He begins by selecting a straight-grained hardwood plank, free of knots or cracks. With the hand saw, he marks and cuts a rough circular blank roughly one foot across. He flips the disk, trims the opposite face, and ensures both sides lie flat and parallel. Clamping the blank upright in a simple vice, he fits the brace with an auger bit sized to the main spindle. He drills a clean hole dead center, holding the brace steady so the bit runs perfectly true. Next, he fits the rasp in both hands and works the outer edge, brightening the rim and knocking off sharp corners. He shapes a gentle bevel around the spindle hole, coaxing the timber into a snug, wobble-free fit when slipped onto the axle. Long, even strokes of the rasp smooth the wheel’s circumference, then he carves a series of shallow grooves to help the drive cord grip. He turns the wheel by hand, shaving tiny high spots until it spins evenly. Finally, he rubs the surface with fine wood dust and a little animal fat, polishing the drive wheel until it turns true and steady.

A solitary artisan gathers rough-hewn beams of wood and heavy bars of iron on a simple workbench. He positions two stout wooden beams parallel to each other, leaving just enough space for a slender iron shaft between them. He hammers wooden pegs through predrilled holes to lock the beams in place, then checks alignment by eye. Next, he slides the iron shaft into carved notches atop each beam, ensuring a smooth, even fit. He uses a wrench to tighten iron collars around the shaft, preventing any unwanted shift during rotation. At one end, he secures a small iron wheel, turning the wrench until the metal grips the shaft firmly. He fastens a curved metal bracket on the opposite side, using a screwdriver to drive flathead screws into the wood. He cuts a length of tanned leather into a narrow strip and drapes it over the wheel and shaft, creating a flexible belt. He adjusts belt tension by twisting a wooden peg and testing the pulley action with a gentle push. Finally, he smooths rough edges on both wood and iron, ensuring the mechanism runs without a hitch. The simple turning device stands ready for use.

They lay out the main wooden beams on a firm, level ground and mark guide lines in chalk. They press a straightedge along each length, extending the chalk marks until every line runs perfectly straight. Next, they set a square into each corner where beams meet. If the legs of the square rock or leave uneven chalk traces, they erase the line, shift the beam, and redraw until the square lies flush against both faces.

To ensure vertical posts rise true, they suspend a plumb bob by a short length of hemp from a crosspiece. When the bob settles still, its fine line brushes the beam below, leaving a chalk mark that shows true vertical. They repeat this at several points, confirming each post aligns without lean.

With dividers they step off equal distances between supports, scribing small chalk notches so every component maintains the same interval. They tighten a hemp rope around intersecting beams, snugging each lashing until the frame holds its shape. If a beam sits slightly out of line, they tap it gently with a wooden mallet, then recheck with straightedge and square. Finally, they verify the diagonals: measuring with dividers from corner to corner, they confirm both spans match, proving the assembly to be perfectly square, straight, and upright before locking all hemp bindings.

vacuum pump.name: vacuum pump
vacuum pump.description: A pair of smooth, gleaming hollow pillars stand side by side, bound tightly by curved bands of darkened metal. Each pillar opens at one end, one capped by a ridged disc, the other by a slender spout. A narrow metal rod slides within each shaft, joining at a central lever topped with a simple crossbar. Thin tubes coil between pillars like vines. Its cold surface and perfect symmetry suggest careful shaping.

steps.description: A smith heats the iron bar in the forge until it glows bright orange. He grips the glowing bar with tongs and carries it to the anvil. The smith places the bar on the anvil’s face and strikes it with a hammer, flattening one end into a wide disc. Turning the bar, he shapes the disc’s edge into a thick rim. Reheating in the forge restores the metal’s malleability. Back at the anvil, he hammers the rim inward, forming a shallow depression. With heats and blows, the cavity deepens into a form. He reposes the workpiece in the forge until the metal is hot enough for further forging. Next, he drives a hollow drift through the depression, opening and elongating the cavity into a straight cylinder. He hammers around the drift, ensuring uniform wall thickness and a smooth bore. Periodically, he re-heats the cylinder to maintain malleability. Once the interior reaches the desired diameter, he withdraws the drift and trims any uneven edges on the anvil. Finally, he gives the cylinder a last heat and gentle hammering, achieving consistent thickness and true roundness. The completed iron cylinder awaits fitting of components.

He gathers rich copper ore and calamine ore from a rocky ledge near the river. He builds a bloomery furnace beside his forge pit. He stows charcoal and ore inside and ignites a hot fire. He pumps air through the bellows until the interior glows fiery orange. He uses tongs to withdraw a soft bloom of brass, combining copper and zinc-rich calamine into a workable metal lump.

He returns the glowing bloom to his anvil. He grips it with tongs and lays it on the horn. He hammers firmly in an even rhythm, driving out slag and welding internal particles. He reshapes the lump into a long cylindrical billet. Periodically he returns the billet to the forge, reheating until it glows bright.

Once the metal is supple, he cuts off a section and plates it thin for a smooth sliding face. He reheats the piece and nests it inside a brass sleeve he forged earlier. He uses the anvil and hammer to draw out a perfect cylindrical cavity. He fits the inner core carefully, ensuring a movable fit.

Finally, he polishes the assembled piston with fine sand and cloth, testing its glide against the anvil horn. The forged piston rings fit closely, and the piece slides freely, ready for assembly.

A smith selects a square bar of iron and heats it in coals to orange heat. With tongs, he places the billet on the anvil. He strikes the metal with a hammer, flattening it into a thin plate. Rotating the plate, he hammers the edges sharply to form a raised rim. He reheats and hammers until the form is even. At forging heat, he sets the plate on a shallow anvil depression and strikes the center with the peen of his hammer, driving a hole through the metal. He then lays the disk over a small dimple on the anvil face and taps the rim outward to give the valve disk a dish that will allow tight seating. With light taps, he smooths irregularities. He forges several valve disks, each smooth and true. He tests the fit of each disk against its seat, ensuring an airtight seal.

He scrapes animal fat into a bowl warmed by coals. He soaks strips of hide in the melted oil to create a flexible seal. He presses the greased hide around each junction between wooden tubes, smoothing it with his fingertips. He fits a ring of bark over the seam and rubs more fat into the edges. He wipes away excess, heats the joint over low heat. The fat seeps into every crack, hardening into a gasket as it cools. A waxy layer prevents air from escaping at the connections.

He selects a sturdy plank of oak and hews it into a rectangular base. With a chisel and mallet, he carves a straight channel down its center. Next he forges a hollow iron cylinder over a red-hot fire, hammering it smooth until its bore is even. He fits the cylinder snugly into the wooden channel and drives small iron nails through flanges to hold it firm. From a cured hide, he cuts a circular diaphragm and stretches it over one end of the cylinder, fastening it in place with leather strips laced through tiny holes around the rim. He trims the edges to lie flush. At the opposite end, he fashions a sliding leather seal that will move inside the cylinder. Finally, he melts tallow and brushes it liberally onto all moving surfaces, coating the leather and iron to reduce friction and seal gaps. With each piece joined, the device stands ready for its first test.

native copper.name: native copper
native copper.description: Bright, metallic nuggets lie scattered among rough gray stones, their surfaces smooth and gleaming in the sunlight. Each chunk bears a warm, reddish hue that deepens to a rich red-brown along fractured edges. The hard, dense clumps vary in size from tiny pebbles to fist-sized lumps. When struck or scraped, they reveal shiny inner streaks that glow like dying embers. They feel cool and heavy in the hand.

hair.name: hair
hair.description: Soft, slender filaments sprout from the skin of creatures, clustered in shifting layers that catch sunlight. They vary in color from dark to pale, each strand as thin as a grass stem yet supple like a young vine. When wind stirs, these filaments ripple together, forming waves across bodies. They cling to hide and scalp alike, forming thick mats around neck and shoulders. Their texture feels both silken and wiry under fingers.

steps.description: At dawn, a tribesman gathers strips of raw meat and fetches cool water from the stream. He rips the flesh into thin shreds and soaks them in the water for hours, allowing the fibers to swell. After pulling the soaked strips onto a flat stone, he beats the pulp with a wooden club until it forms a paste of fine strands. Then he dips his fingers in the cloudy liquid and spreads the strands across his scalp in neat lines. With careful pats and soft presses, he firmly secures the new growth. The damp paste slowly dries, clings to skin, and sprouts soft thin fibers that symmetrically cover his head.

The primitive artisan sits beside the fire, grasping a small tuft of fibers with worn fingers. She leans forward, selecting a single follicle at the nape of the hide. With a firm pinch between thumb and forefinger, she pulls sharply, extracting it from the skin. She repeats this, choosing each fine filament with care, discarding those too thin or broken. Each strand tugs free in a crisp motion, collected and laid gently onto a stone. Once enough threads gather, she smooths them into bundles, preparing for softening and weaving.

meat.name: meat
meat.description: A lumpy mass of sinewy tissue clings to a length of exposed bone, deep red in color and glistening with moisture. Thin strands weave together in layers, some streaked with pale ribbons of fat. It feels cool and supple to the touch, warm from the sun’s touch. Tiny veins mar the surface, pulsing faintly. The glossy sheen and raw, fibrous texture suggest flesh torn from a recently fallen creature.

steps.description: He kneels at daybreak along the riverbank, peering into the misty trees for signs of hoofbeats or rooting snouts. He scents the air, noting damp soil and distant odors of fur. His fingers tighten on the hafted flint blade as he spots a grazing boar through ferns. He crouches low, moving quietly over mossy stones to close distance without startling it. Silence guides his careful approach before the final leap.

He stands at dawn, scanning the grass for a deer. He grips a flint blade and a wood club. The hunter crouches low, approaching with measured steps. When he closes in, he hurls his spear into the animal’s side. Hearing the thud, he strikes the head with his club. The creature collapses. He drags the carcass to camp. Placing it on rock, he cuts the hide and slices into the torso, opening the cavity. He removes entrails, rinses flesh with stream water, and readies it for the fire.

He kneels beside the fallen creature, blade gleaming faintly in dawn light. He grips the handle firmly and draws the edge along the animal’s hide, slicing through tough skin. He peels back the hide and lays it aside. With careful cuts, he severs sinew connecting limbs to torso. He pulls apart joints, exposing slabs of lean muscle. He works methodically, removing organs and separating rib bones. He sections long strips of tissue, stacking pieces on a smooth stone. Each stroke is deliberate, minimizing waste. He discards unwanted bits, gathers usable portions, and ensures no strand goes to fuel the fire or feed the wolf pack. Day breaks as he completes his task.

malachite.name: malachite
malachite.description: A deep, vibrant stone emerges from rocky outcroppings, its surface swirling with rich, leaf-green bands that catch the sunlight. The curved layers form smooth, rounded nodules within dark, copper-stained rock. When held, it feels cool and heavy, its glossy sheen contrasting with the dull earth around it. Fine veins trace lighter-green patterns, and occasional patches of chalky residue fill tiny pits on its lustrous curves. Deep shadows pool in its recesses.

calamine.name: calamine
calamine.description: Along rocky ledges, a pale dusty rock sits nestled among gray stones. Its surface glints faintly with pinkish-white hues, lines of rust-red weaving through its chalky body. When touched, it feels powdery and crumbly, leaving fine pink dust on rough palms. The weight is light, its edges easily worn away by fingernails. A faint earthy scent rises from freshly broken surfaces. It often breaks into pale flakes that scatter in gentle breezes.

obsidian.name: obsidian
obsidian.description: A dark, glassy shard nests among coarse volcanic stones. Its surface gleams like still water under sunlight, reflecting a deep midnight hue. Edges curve in smooth, swirling patterns, inviting light to catch on every polished facet. When held up, slender rims glow with a faint clarity, revealing an almost hidden depth within the opaque body. Each fragment seems born of fierce fire and sudden cool, its sheen striking in the rough landscape.

botanic cord.name: botanic cord
botanic cord.description: A long, slender strand emerges from the undergrowth, each thin fiber gathered and spun with others into a twisting rope. It dangles from branches, its color ranging from pale cream to deep brown. The surface feels rough and fibrous to the touch, and its length stretches several paces. When sunlight filters through leaves, its woven strands catch glints of light, revealing a pattern of interlaced lines along its sinuous form.

steps.description: He rises with the dawn and steps into the damp marsh. He moves quietly, scanning masses of reed-like plants. He eyes the straightest stems, those with firm, fibrous cores. With a steady grip at the base, he bends each stalk, snapping it clean below the nodes. He strips away side leaves and thin branches, discarding weak or rotted lengths. He ties a simple knot of flexible vines around each bundle, securing ten to fifteen stems each. He carries the load on his shoulder back to camp, ready for further processing.

They grasp three or more slender stalks at one end and align them parallel. They hold bundles in each hand and twist each bundle away from the center core. They fold one twisted bundle over the other, slipping it under before pulling tight. They repeat twisting each bundle and then folding them together, keeping the fibers taut and even. They smooth frayed ends by rubbing them between the palms, and secure the ends with knots or tucking one strand under the twists. They continue until they reach the desired size.

First, the maker gathers the last few inches of twisted bark strips and holds them between thumb and forefinger. With a short extra piece of bark, they form a slip knot around the bundle. They loop the strip once, pass its end under the loop, and pull tight, drawing the knot snug against the main length. Then they wrap the remaining tail around the knot base several times and tuck its tip under the final wrap. Finally, they tighten each coil with a firm pull, securing the end so it cannot unravel.

bone awl.name: bone awl
bone awl.description: A slender, elongated object of pale ivory hue emerges from the firelight with a gently curving shaft tapering to a sharp point. Its surface bears faint striations where sinew once clung, now buffed smooth by hands. One end holds slight widening, knot of marrow peeking through its polished exterior. In the flickering glow, it rests light in the palm, cool, as if formed by the bones of a beast.

steps.description: He scans the area around fresh butchery sites, searching among discarded remains for a long, sturdy femur or leg fragment. He inspects the surface for signs of decay or fractures, favoring dense sections that promise durability. He pries flesh from the bone with a flake of stone, washing it clean in a nearby stream. He selects pieces free of cracks, sizing them by heft and length against his palm. Once he finds a suitable shaft, he carries it back to his work spot, ready for shaping into a piercing tool.

A primitive craftsperson selects a sturdy bone from a kill. They scrape away any remaining flesh and sinew with a sharp stone flake, using repeated strokes to remove tissue. They wash the piece in clear stream water, shaking it to release blood and debris. They bury it atop warm ash for one day, allowing heat and alkali to draw out oils and whiten the surface. They rinse again and leave the bone to air-dry in sunlight. When fully dry, the surface appears pale, smooth, and ready for shaping into tool.

He sits on a low rock and sets a thick limb fragment on a flat bedrock. He grips a hammerstone with a firm hand. With a swift motion, he raises it overhead and brings it down to crack the cortex. Tiny shards fly as the dense material yields to precise blows. He rotates the piece, striking edges to split it along natural lines. Fragments break away, revealing a fresh interior. He discards irregular bits and saves elongated splinters. Again, he strikes to remove protrusions and shape the fragments. The repeated impacts fracture the hard tissue cleanly. When the piece has a pointed, smooth tip, he stops and cleans the surface.

The maker selects a sturdy fragment of bone and brushes away dirt with a dry stick. He then holds the piece firmly against a flat river cobble and scrapes its surface at an acute angle. Sliding the bone back and forth he removes rough ridges and exposes a fresh edge. Next he positions the work on a larger slab of stone and grinds its tip in gentle circles. This produces a slender point that pierces hide with ease. Finally he polishes the edge using a piece of rough sandstone in a sweeping motion. This smooths away micro serrations and strengthens the tip. The finished implement serves as a reliable tool.

stalks.name: stalks
stalks.description: Long, slender green shafts rise in clusters from the soft earth. Their surfaces feel smooth, sometimes ribbed with faint vertical lines. They sway gently when the breeze ripples across the open field. Each extends from a narrow base, tapering slightly as it reaches upward toward the sun. Dew beads cling to their glossy sides at dawn, reflecting pale light. The tips end in tiny hairs or husks, barely moving in the wind.

steps.description: At dawn a man moves through the marsh, eyes sweeping over the tall grasses. He crouches when he spots a stem, tests its strength with two fingers, and snaps it at the base. He examines each piece for uniform thickness, drops any curved or weak ones, and tosses the good ones into a basket. He repeats this motion, shifting his weight to avoid startling birds as he gathers material.

The figure approaches a stand of thick, fibrous plants. He grips one stem near its base, kneels, and digs his fingers around the roots. He tugs the stem free from the soil in a single motion. He lays the length on a rock and strips away leafy tendrils with a sharp flake of stone. He shakes loose dirt, sorting strong segments from brittle bits. He bundles the firm pieces and ties them with twisted grass. He carries the load back to camp, ready to soak and soften the material for weaving.

bucket.name: bucket
bucket.description: This object stands tall like a squat cylinder, its sides smoothly curved and joining at a flat bottom. It feels cool and rigid, made of a dark metallic skin that reflects faint light. Around the top rim wraps a thick, arched rod secured by two sturdy loops. The whole shape conveys solidity, with a hollow heart that holds still air and softly echoes sounds when tapped by a stick.

steps.description: He roams near riverbanks seeking a naturally hollow form from wood or hardened clay. He scouts fallen logs with decayed heartwood, tapping each to discern solid walls. He tests their contours, ensuring symmetry and sufficient depth for carrying water. He lifts several candidates, shaking them to detect escaping droplets. He examines their interior, ensuring smooth surfaces and no fractures. He finally selects the sturdiest vessel to shape for daily use.

A primitive human draws a sturdy log beside a rock. He lifts a flint-tipped axe and positions it against the wood. He strikes with force, splitting the log along its grain. After blows, the trunk divides into two curved halves. He sets aside shavings and smooths interior curves by angled cuts. He carves a rounded base and hollows the block, removing chips to shape a cavity. Then he trims the outer walls into even thickness. He uses pressure to snap off jagged pieces and finishes surfaces until they are smooth to the touch. He fashions a pair of handles by shaving branches and lashing them to the sides with cord.

A primitive craftsperson selects a straight-grained log and strips off excess bark with a sharp knife. They mark the outline of the desired form on the wood surface, then begin cutting away large chips to shape a rough cylinder. Holding the vessel firmly, the maker uses the knife to gouge into the center, carving out a deep cavity. They work in circular motions, shaving thin curls to hollow the interior evenly. Periodically, they tap the walls to test thickness and adjust pressure to avoid piercing. With careful slicing, they refine edges. Finally, they rub the surface with a damp leaf or sand to remove splinters, creating a sturdy hollow vessel.

Each morning, a craftsman collects resin from pine bark and heats it over glowing coals until it softens and darkens. He scrapes impurities and kneads the sticky mass with leafy fibers to improve flexibility. Then he applies a thin, warm layer along inside seams of the wooden container halves, pressing the edges firmly together. As the resin cools, it hardens into a watertight bond, filling cracks and gaps. The artisan then polishes the joint with a smooth stone, ensuring no holes remain. When finished, the vessel holds liquid without leaking.

He inspects a length of hardwood for knots and cracks before carving to ensure strength. He selects a flexible branch of sturdy wood and uses a sharp chisel to carve a long, gently curved strip. He holds the wood firmly against a stump and taps the chisel with a small mallet to shave away excess material, shaping a smooth arch. He carves shallow notches at each end to guide the bindings. He gathers several lengths of tough vine, then soaks them in water to increase pliability. He weaves the vine tightly around the notches, wrapping each turn with tension. He ties secure knots and trims the vine ends, pushing them flush against the wood surface. Finally, he rubs the entire handle with a smooth stone to remove splinters, creating a comfortable grip.

He starts by selecting a length of flexible vine. He strips bark to expose fibers. He cuts two even lengths with his knife, each long enough to span the vessel’s mouth. He carves notches at the rims to anchor the ends, then smooths the vine tips before draping one length across the gap so fibers lie snugly flush against the rim. He pulls the ends downward, wrapping them tightly around the rim posts and twisting to prevent slipping. He uses a second vine length to reinforce the first wraps, weaving over and under. He finishes by carefully trimming excess vine and tucking the final tail into the coil.

bronze bar.name: bronze bar
bronze bar.description: A narrow, elongated block of cold, dense metal sits before the observer. Its surface gleams with a warm, golden-brown shimmer under sunlight. The edges are straight and sharply defined, contrasting with the rough stones nearby. Despite its sleek finish, subtle pits and streaks hint at fluid movement before solidification. The object feels surprisingly heavy in the hands and retains a cool temperature against the skin. A greenish tarnish clings near its corners.

steps.description: He weathers the distant rocky hillside, scanning the earth for veins of dull green and silver glints. His fingers brush loose stones, seeking seams of copper ore. He follows trickling streams, noting glints of malachite in the sand. He tastes clay from riverbanks for metallic traces. At sunrise he climbs to higher slopes, where eroded gullies reveal red-brown streaks. He marks promising outcrops with charcoal, carefully mapping future excavation sites.

The primitive human approaches a rocky outcrop that bears veins of copper ore. He grips his hammerstone with muscle and aims at protruding lumps. He smashes the ore against bedrock, sending shards flying. He inspects the shattered pieces, searching for heavy glints. He discards lighter bits of waste. He pounds larger fragments into gravel with rhythmic blows. He washes the debris in a shallow stream, letting sediment and rock dust wash away. He repeats the smashing and rinsing until only dense, copper-tinted grains remain. He then shifts his efforts to a nearby deposit of tin ore. He cracks the white-gray rock in similar fashion, separating heavier specks from lighter waste. At last, he gathers both kinds of metal-rich fragments for the next stage. He hefts shards to judge density by feel.

A primitive metalworker gathers copper ore and tin ore from outcrops. He lights the furnace with charcoal, building a clay chamber. He arranges layers of ore and charcoal inside, then inserts the tuyere into a side opening. He blows air through the pipe until flames roar. The heat intensifies, melting the copper ore first, then the tin ore blends into the pool of molten metal. He stirs the liquid with a wood rod, ensuring the two metals mix evenly. When the mass flows freely, he removes the tuyere and tilts the furnace. He pours the glowing metal into stone or clay molds carved with depressions. Sparks fly as the hot liquid fills the cavities. He leaves the ingots to cool and solidify. Once firm, he breaks open the molds and chips away excess slag. He polishes the metal lumps by rubbing them on rough stone, ready for shaping.

The human kneels beside the shaped earth mold. He traces his fingers over the cooled clay surface, feeling for the depth and outline where the metal will gather. He brushes away stray debris and pebbles, revealing the subtle hollow beneath. He uses a pointed stick to lightly press around the edges, confirming the walls are solid. Once he senses the cavity is clear and defined, he prepares to begin the next step.

On a cleared earthen floor, the smith lights a charcoal fire beneath a clay‐lined pit. In a sturdy crucible he places small copper nuggets and crushed tin ore, stirring them over the heat until they fuse into a molten, golden alloy. When the metal gleams, he raises the crucible with carved wooden tongs, his arms steady against the heat. He positions it above a stone mold carved with shallow grooves. With a deliberate tilt of his wrist, the glowing liquid flows in a narrow stream, filling each channel in the rock. Tiny sparks jump as the alloy meets the cooler surface, and he pauses to let any dross rise to the top. When the cavities brim, he lowers the crucible and lets the excess drip back into the pit. He waits as the casting cools, then taps the mold to release the newly formed ingot. Hot metal hisses as it hardens beneath his careful gaze.

He sits beside a shallow pit, blowing on red coals through a leather tube. He gathers bronze fragments, heats them in a clay furnace until they glow molten, skims impurities from the liquid, and pours the metal into a carved stone mold. Then he lifts it and plunges it into a cool stream. Steam hisses as the glowing ingot hardens. He drags the cooled metal from the water, wipes it clean, taps the piece with a stone hammer to test hardness, and admires the smooth ingot for his next tool.

The craftsman sets a sturdy wooden plank on the ground and places the cooled ingot at its center. He grips a sharp chisel by the handle, positioning its tip against the seam between the cast form and the solid metal. With his free hand he lifts a heavy hammer, raising it above his shoulder. He strikes the chisel’s butt firmly, driving the edge into the joint. Small chips fly free as he repeats each measured blow, working his way along the length of the ingot. As the connection loosens, he shifts the chisel under the freed edge and applies gentle prying force. The chunk finally separates cleanly from the mold. He steps back, then taps the newly freed piece to clear away lingering flakes and shards.

plumb-bob.name: plumb-bob
plumb-bob.description: A slender rope of twisted fibers. At its tip dangles an ovoid chunk of dark metal, gleaming in daylight. Its surfaces are smooth and cool to touch, narrowing to a blunt point below. The cord passes through a small hole at its top, leaving the weight suspended. The stone-like metal mass hangs nearly perfectly still, its side contours subtle and precise, catching sunlight as it sways gently against the breeze.

steps.description: He kneels by the river’s edge, fingers sifting through rounded pebbles of varying heft. He lifts each stone, gauging its mass by the pull in his palm. He selects one smooth, dense piece that feels heavy yet balanced. With a flint chisel he chips small flakes to fine-tune its bulk. He ties the finished stone to a length of sinew and lifts it to test the steady pull downward. When the cord hangs straight, he is satisfied. He repeats small adjustments until the cord hangs perfectly vertical.

A primitive artisan breaks copper ore into small pieces and places them in a clay crucible. He builds a fire of charcoal beneath it, tending bright coals until the crucible glows red. With iron tongs, he stirs the molten mass, skimming off dark slag that rises to the surface. As flame warms the room, pure metal pools at the bottom. When the liquid flows freely, he grips the crucible with tongs and tilts it, carefully pouring the glowing copper into a hollow stone mold carved in a teardrop shape. He taps the mold’s side to coax out air bubbles, ensuring the metal fills every curve. He moves the mold aside and lets it cool in the embers, watching as the bright orange hue turns to deep brown. Once solid, he pries open the mold with tongs and lifts out a heavy, balanced weight. Using a rough stone, he grinds and polishes its surface, then drills a small hole at the top so it can hang freely on a cord.

A primitive craftsman selects a dense stone fragment that can serve as a simple weight for measuring vertical alignment. He shapes the stone by striking edges against a harder rock to form a roughly rounded block. Next he readies a slender drill bit carved from bone and fits it into a hand drill. He holds the shaft between his palms and rotates the bit against the stone face. He sprinkles sand and water on the bit to act as abrasive and speed drilling. With steady pressure and rhythmic motion, he deepens the small indentation into a full perforation through the weight. Finally, he clears debris from the hole and polishes the surface to finish the simple measuring tool. He tests the hole by threading a plant-fiber cord through it, ensuring smooth movement.

He digs up mature flax stalks and binds them into a bundle. He soaks them in running water for days until the woody rind loosens. He pulls stalks free and lays them to dry in the sun. He crushes dry stems under a stone, then rubs them on a rough rock to free long fibers. He combs fibers with wooden combs, aligning them. He takes a small bundle and rolls it on his thigh, twisting fibers into a strong thread. He doubles and twists threads into a sturdy cord.

The craftsman gathers long strands of dried grass and inner bark. He moistens fibers until pliable. He twists pairs of fibers together, then doubles these twisted cords and spirals them to form a strong rope. At one end of the metal weight, he finds a small notch and threads the cord through it. He pulls it tight, wraps the loose end around the main line several times, and ties a simple overhand knot. He trims excess fibers and smooths the knot against the notch, ensuring a secure, lasting connection.

lime.name: lime
lime.description: The object hangs like a small orb among glossy, deep-green leaves. It measures roughly like a fist, its skin puckered with tiny bumps and glowing a vibrant bright green. When held, it feels cool and heavy, emitting a sharp, fresh scent that stings the nostrils. A thin yet tough peel envelops a pale, translucent interior divided into wedge-like chambers filled with tangy, moist flesh and a few smooth, cream-colored seeds.

watchmaker\u2019s screwdriver.name: watchmaker’s screwdriver
watchmaker\u2019s screwdriver.description: A slender cylinder of cool, gunmetal-gray metal rests lightly in the hand. One end tapers to a tiny, flat wedge that gleams under the light. The opposite end widens into a knurled grip patterned with fine, spiral ridges. A seam runs along its length. Its balance feels precise: weight centered near the middle, giving a steadiness. The polished surface catches reflections, while its unassuming shape hints at careful, exacting craftsmanship.

steps.description: The primitive smith gathers rough chunks of iron ore and places them inside a small clay furnace he has built by stacking stones and sealing gaps with mud. He packs the ore between layers of charcoal, then strikes flint to ignite the fuel. He stands beside the furnace, pumping a pair of bellows in steady rhythm to drive air into the glowing embers. The rising heat melts impurities and frees droplets of metallic iron, which trickle down to form a soft, spongy bloom at the furnace base. After hours of steady stoking, he pauses, cools the bellows, and carefully pries open the furnace to reveal the bloom. He removes the compact mass of metal, hammers it to squeeze out slag, and repeats the smelt until the iron becomes dense and malleable.

At dawn, a primitive craftsman gathers iron ore from rocky outcrops, breaking the nodules into fist-sized fragments with a hammerstone. He prepares a pit furnace by stacking rough stones into a cylinder, sealing gaps with clay. At its base, he fashions a tuyere, an air passage lined with clay, and positions it at a slight angle. Outside the pit, he sets up leather bellows filled with air. Alternating layers of charcoal and crushed ore fill the furnace. Two assistants rhythmically pump the bellows, forcing steady blasts of air through the tuyere. The charged charcoal glows bright red, then white-hot, as it reaches temperatures above eleven hundred degrees Celsius. Carbon in the charcoal strips oxygen from the iron ore, producing molten metal that trickles to the bottom while lighter slag pools above. After several hours of sustained heat and airflow, the interior holds a spongy bloom of wrought iron. He cools this mass in a water trough, then hammers away the encrusted slag, revealing a workable iron lump ready for forging.

A primitive human heats a small steel billet in glowing coals until it blazes bright orange. He grips the heated steel with tongs and carries it to the anvil. He positions it on the anvil’s face and brings the hammer down firmly, flattening and shaping the billet. With each strike, the metal refines and aligns internal grains. He re-heats as needed, ensuring the steel remains malleable. Next, he hammers one end into a slender shaft while forming a tiny, precise tip at the opposite end. He rotates the billet, keeping each blow purposeful, sculpting a slender tool that tapers smoothly. Once the basic shape emerges, he plunges it into water, quenching the steel to harden its structure. Returning the piece to the fire for a brief tempering, he restores toughness and reduces brittleness. Finally, he polishes the forged implement with rough stones, revealing its bright, sharp form ready for delicate tasks.

He places the flat whetstone on a stable rock. He pours water over the stone’s face, letting moisture settle. He holds the short rod of hardened steel at its base, pressing the tip against the stone’s surface. With steady pressure, he drags the steel across the moist stone in shallow arcs. Each stroke removes tiny fragments, smoothing rough edges. He re-wets the stone as needed, keeping it slick. He adjusts the angle slightly to refine the taper, repeating the motion until the tip narrows to a fine point. When sliding cleanly without catching, the surface feels sharply polished. He taps the tool lightly to listen for a ringing tone, signaling uniform thinness. He rinses both stone and metal, wiping away grit. The result is a finely honed bit.

A solitary toolmaker holds a small steel rod with iron tongs and slides it into the glowing embers of a simple hearth. He watches the metal turn a bright cherry red, waiting for an even glow. Once the entire piece radiates heat, he lifts it swiftly with the tongs and plunges it into a shallow bucket of cool water. The metal hisses and steam curls from its surface as it hardens in the quench. After a few moments, he withdraws the rod and returns it to the edge of the hearth, exposing it to gentler warmth until the steel shifts to a pale straw color. Satisfied, he lets it cool slowly in the open air. The result is a tough yet slightly flexible point, ready for fine, precise work.

After he carves a socket into a wooden shaft, he files the iron bit with a stone until it fits snugly. Before binding, he tests the fit by twisting the metal gently to check for any wobble. He soaks hide strips in a stream until they bend. He wraps the base of the forged iron shaft tightly with wet hide bands, overlapping each strip to bind metal to wood. Next he smears melted pine resin over the lashings, pressing it into fibers to fill gaps and harden the bond. As the resin cools, he draws the bands tight to seat the bit in the carved handle core. Once set, he trims loose ends and smooths rough edges with a flint blade. This wood-metal union endures small turns and exact pressure.

potash.name: potash
potash.description: In shallow hollows near burned wood piles, a pale, powdery crust coats the earth where ashes have washed down. It appears as a fine, chalky film that glimmers under sunlight, clinging to stones and clay lumps. Underfoot, it crumbles into soft, glittering shards that drift away on a breeze. When damp with morning dew, it darkens slightly before drying again into brittle, ivory fragments that scatter across the ground.

gum arabic.name: gum arabic
gum arabic.description: Clinging to the rough bark of a twisting tree, pale droplets emerge in irregular clusters. They glisten like dew but hold thicker firmness. When sunlight filters through leaves, they shine with soft milky translucence. Over days, the outer layer hardens into brittle shards that flake off on a tap. Each drop seems to ooze slowly, as if the tree bleeds clear resin that dries in tiny pale pearls.

staking hammer.name: staking hammer
staking hammer.description: You see a heavy, solid object. Its body glints like a river of cooled iron, casting dull gray reflections. One end is broad and squared, its flat face scarred by faint, concentric rings of wear. Opposite, a tapering spike juts forth, narrow and pointed as a bird’s beak. A thick shaft links the ends, wrapped in smooth, dark leather that warms under a grasp. The whole feels balanced, weighty in hand.

steps.description:
A craftsman begins by gathering copper ore from nearby streambeds, selecting dense, dark nodules that promise rich metal. He then collects tin ore from a shallow vein in a hillside, choosing pale chunks with a slight sheen. Back at his workshop, he breaks both ores into smaller fragments using a hammerstone, making them easier to smelt. He lights a fire beneath his clay-lined furnace and stokes it with dry wood. Once the coals glow red, he positions his bellows to blow air into the chamber, raising the temperature until the interior walls glow white-hot.

He loads crushed copper ore into a small clay crucible and adds just enough tin ore to create a workable bronze alloy. Using his bellows, he maintains the heat until the ore melts into a silvery liquid. With tongs held at arm’s length, he lifts the crucible and skims off floating slag with a simple wooden paddle. When the metal runs clear, he tilts the crucible and pours the molten alloy into a stone or clay mold shaped roughly like the tool’s head. The metal flows into every corner, filling the cavity.

After allowing the casting to cool for several minutes, he uses tongs to lift out a solid bronze blank. He taps it lightly to test solidity, then sets it aside. This crude form will later be trimmed and hammered into its final shape.

A primitive craftsman seeks a sturdy piece of wood for the handle. He finds a straight branch from a fallen tree, choosing one roughly palm-thick and free of knots. He uses a flint blade to strip the bark along its length, revealing pale inner wood. He trims off smaller twigs and shapes the thicker end to fit through the head opening. He rubs the wood against a coarse stone to smooth the surface and remove remaining bark fibers. Once the blank is smooth and straight, he sets it aside for final shaping.

He grips the red-hot bronze billet with stout iron tongs, setting it firmly on the anvil’s flat face. He raises the hefty hammer above his shoulder and drives it down, each blow flattening and spreading the metal into a rough oval. The rhythm of strike and lift echoes in the workshop as he turns the billet with the tongs, checking thickness and shape. He taps the edges selectively, coaxing a gentle curve. His foot braces the anvil’s horn so the metal won’t slide. When the piece cools, he slides it back into the glowing charcoal fire, watching sparks dance and the color deepen to bright orange. He retrieves it, cleans the dark scale with a few sharp strikes, and resumes hammering. Using focused blows at the center, he narrows the eye area while tapering the perimeter. After several heating, hammering, and turning cycles, the bronze takes on a balanced, symmetrical head blank, ready for refinement. Beads of sweat gather on his brow as he works, mindful of each strike’s angle and force.

He selects a straight branch of sturdy hardwood and scraps away loose bark with his stone flake knife. He trims the ends to a workable length, marking a center line along the grain with light incisions. Holding the wood firmly, he slices thin curls of wood, gradually reducing the diameter toward the grip area. He twists and turns the blank as he carves, removing knots and irregularities. At the opposite end, he flares out the section that will meet the head, ensuring a tight fit. He checks for straightness and balance, feeling each contour with his hand. When the surface is smooth and even, he sets the blank aside for further refinement.

steps.step: attach head blank to handle blank
steps.description: He selects a sturdy hardwood piece for the head blank and a straight sapling for the handle blank. He uses a chipped hammerstone to peck and rub the head blank into a rectangular form, then bores a central hole by grinding with the stone’s edge. He carves the handle blank narrower at one end and splits it slightly to accept a wooden wedge. He passes the narrow end through the head blank’s hole until the shoulder fits snugly. He drives the wedge into the split with firm strikes from the hammerstone, forcing the wood to expand and lock the head in place. Finally, he trims excess wood and tests the assembly’s firmness.

dividers.name: dividers
dividers.description: Two slender, straight sticks of shining, cold metal stand connected at one end by a small circular hinge that lets them pivot apart or close together. Their tapered points glint sharply, each ending in a fine tip reminiscent of claws. When held by their joined top, they resemble an insect’s legs splayed wide, catching light on polished surfaces. The joint secures them at any chosen angle between fully closed and fully spread.

steps.description: He steps into the narrow canyon at dawn, holding a sharpened flint knife. He follows faint seams of metal shining in rock faces, testing each with a few gentle taps. When the ore flakes free, he pries loose a jagged fragment of copper-rich stone. He pockets it carefully. He wipes sweat from his brow as he selects larger nodules. Next, he wades through grassy slopes to a shallow stream bed, where dark, heavy tin ore lies among the pebbles. He uses a carved wooden scoop to gather the denser shards into a woven basket. At day’s end, his pack holds rough chunks of both metals, ready for smelting and shaping into precise measurement arms.

He lifts the bronze rod and holds its midpoint between his forefinger and thumb. He presses one end against the rough surface of a coarse grinding stone and applies careful pressure. He rotates the rod slowly, keeping the edge aligned with the grain of the stone. He sweeps back and forth, maintaining a consistent angle to shape a sharp tip. He pauses to examine the form, brushing away metal dust with his sleeve. He resumes grinding, gently increasing the angle to refine the point. He turns the rod and repeats the process on the opposite end. He inspects both tips until each gleams with a sharpened edge, ready for use.

He presses a sharpened point into the plank of oak, his muscles straining as he twists the bone awl in slow circles. The tool bites deep into the grain, furrowing a small cavity. Each steady rotation loosens slivers of wood that he then clears with the awl’s tip, opening the passage further. He shifts his grip and repositions the point, guiding it along measured marks. With careful taps of a stone hammer, the awl edges deeper until the hole reaches proper depth. He pauses to brush away wood dust with a soft brush of animal hair. Satisfied with the clean, round opening, he moves to the next spot. He works slowly.

He crushes copper ore and tin ore into powder with stones and washes away lighter bits. He builds a small pit fire and smears charcoal around clay edges to form a makeshift furnace. He layers ore and charcoal then fans the flames until molten metal pools at the base. He draws off the bronze with a clay ladle and pours it into a shallow mold shaped like two narrow arms with flattened ends. When it cools, he hammers each arm to straighten and taper the tips. He drills small loops at rounded ends and weaves a thin bronze pin through both loops, securing the arms so they swing freely around the joint.

screw plate.name: screw plate
screw plate.description: A flat, rectangular slab of cool, pale metal rests among stones. Four evenly spaced circular openings pierce each corner, their rims smooth and slightly raised. The surface bears parallel grooves, faint scratches, and rust flecks. Its straight, precise edges contrast with nearby rocks, forming a symmetric shape unnatural to the landscape. The piece feels rigid and uniform, with subtle stamped impressions and a muted silvery sheen catching light between moss and grass.

steps.description: An artisan stands before the roaring fire, eying a sturdy iron bar. He grips the bar with his tongs, feeling its weight and expecting the heat it will hold. First, he heats a segment until it shines dull red, then moves it onto the anvil. Using the chisel, he positions its edge at the chosen spot and strikes sharply with the hammer. Metal yields with a sharp ring as the piece separates. He returns the fresh end into the flames, softening it again. With firm strikes on the anvil, he begins to flatten the heated segment into a stubby plate. The ringing blows adjust its thickness and spread its edges evenly. Between hammer blows, he rotates the blank with tongs, inspecting its shape. Once it reaches the desired approximate size and thickness, he sets it aside to cool briefly. With this roughly formed piece in hand, he completes the first essential stage of preparing his metal object. The artisan wipes sweat from his brow and surveys the raw material with satisfaction.

A primitive smith places a heated iron chunk upon the anvil, then raises the hammer high and brings it crashing down onto the glowing metal. Sparks fly with each impact. He rotates the work to strike each side evenly, flattening the bar into a rough plate. Periodically, he returns the metal to the fire until it glows dull red. Back on the anvil, he guides the shape until length and width match the desired proportions. Using the hammer’s face and edges, he refines the contours. He listens to the tone of each blow, sensing when the iron thins. With steady rhythm, he alternates heavy strikes and light taps to smooth the surface. When the metal lies flat and even, he cools it in water, concluding the flattening process.

He lifts the rough iron plate and sets it on a firm oak block. He eyes the longest sides and scores two shallow lines from corner to corner, watching where they intersect. He aligns the tip of the center punch with the crosshairs, holding the tool perpendicular to the metal. He swings the hammer in a steady arc, striking the punch sharply to leave a clear dimple. He inspects the mark and repeats the strike if needed to deepen the indentation. By producing this small recess at the exact midpoint, he guides the drill bit when piercing the metal. The act of marking ensures accuracy and keeps the bit from wandering. He repeats the process on the reverse side. Satisfied with the result, he readies the piece for the next stage of shaping.

First, the maker selects a flat sheet of iron and clamps it to a wooden bench. He marks the center of the desired opening with a sharp punch, leaving a small dent to guide the bit. He then inserts a steel drill bit into the crank-style hand drill’s chuck and tightens the jaws. Holding the drill at a right angle to the metal, he presses the bit into the punched mark and turns the handle in a smooth, clockwise motion. The bit’s cutting edges bore into the iron, producing fine metal shavings. He pauses to brush away debris and applies a drop of oil to reduce heat and friction. Once the bit pierces through, he reverses rotation to withdraw it, leaving a clean, precise opening.

He works beneath the flicker of an oil lamp, grasping a hardened-point scriber in calloused hands. He sets a thick iron plate on a stone slab. He marks the exact center with a punch. He plants the scriber’s tip firmly into that center, using a leather strap as a pivot. He leans forward, exerting gentle, even pressure as the tip scores the metal. He traces a slow, outward curve, guiding the tool into a shallow groove. Each pass deepens the spiral precisely. He sweeps away curled metal filings with a strip of cloth, then continues until the spiral reaches the edge. He inspects the groove, ensuring it is uniform and continuous.

A primitive craftsman begins by heating a forged iron rod in a charcoal-fired forge until it glows bright orange. He withdraws it and hammers the end on an anvil to form a cylindrical shaft. Once cooled slightly, he secures the shaft in a vise. He takes a circular die with internal threads and positions it at the rod’s end. Applying a thin film of animal fat, he turns the die clockwise while holding the rod steady. The hardened edges of the mold bite into the metal, carving a uniform helix around the shaft. Periodically he reverses direction to clear shavings, ensuring crisp ridges. He cleans and polishes the threaded rod.

A primitive craftsman inspects the shaped iron edge and spots rough protrusions. He clamps the piece in a simple wooden block to steady it. Grasping a coarse file, he places its teeth against each burr and exerts firm, even pressure, pushing the tool forward in straight strokes. He adjusts his grip to maintain control. He repeats the motion, varying angles to catch every uneven spot. As small filings collect, he flicks them away with his fingers and listens for the rasp to smooth out. When the edge feels more uniform, he swaps to a finer file and continues working until the metal is consistently smooth, with no jagged fragments remaining.

indexing plate.name: indexing plate
indexing plate.description: A rectangular slab of gleaming gray metal rests on the ground, its surface smooth. A neat grid of circular pits punctures the face, each hole identical in size and perfectly spaced. Along one edge, tiny raised ridges form subtle lines, evenly divided. The object catches stray sunlight, reflecting a muted, silvery glint. Its corners are sharply cut, and the geometry feels precise, unnatural amid the rough stones and fallen leaves.

steps.description: He gathers iron ore from rock outcroppings, breaking it free with stone hammers. He sorts nodules and grinds them with a mortar and pestle to separate chert and waste. He builds a stone furnace, layers charcoal and crushed ore, and blows air through a reed pipe. Over hours of heating, the ore reduces into a spongy bloom. He retrieves the hot mass, then repeatedly hammers it on an anvil to expel slag. He refolds it under heat, flattening the metal into a thin sheet ready for further shaping.

An ancient craftsman stands before a roughly forged circular iron blank, ready to lay out a precise pattern of holes. He first uses a flat stone to smooth the face until it shows a faint sheen. Grasping a pair of dividers, he opens them to the desired radius and plants one point firmly at the exact center of the disc. Swinging the other point around once, he scratches a fine guiding circle across the surface. Next, he resets the dividers to the spacing required between holes. Beginning at one point on the guide circle, he steps off equal angular divisions all the way around, leaving tiny tick marks with a sharp scriber. With each mark in place, he picks up a center punch and positions its tip squarely in the middle of a scribed mark. He raises a hammer in his other hand and delivers a single, controlled blow, creating a shallow dimple in the iron. He repeats this action at every scribed location. When he finishes, the blank bears an even ring of small indentations, each ready to guide a drill bit without wandering.

He shapes a flat copper disc and lays it over a solid stone base. He lifts the brass-tipped punch above the copper sheet. With careful aim, he strikes the punch firmly with the hammer head. Each blow drives the punch’s hardened point through the metal, forming a neat round opening. He repositions the punch mark by mark, striking firmly until the copper yields. As he works around the outline, he removes small fragments of metal, clearing the hole. He smooths rough edges by seating the punch lightly and turning the work, drawing burrs inward. He repeats these steps at measured intervals, creating a ring of uniform openings. He checks alignment visually under daylight for accuracy. When finished, the copper plate bears evenly spaced holes, ready to guide rods or pegs.

He holds the freshly pierced iron disk in one hand and grips a coarse file in the other. With steady pressure, he applies long strokes along the rim to shave off tiny metal shards. Focusing on each drilled hole, he switches to a narrow triangular file to smooth interior edges. He works in bright daylight, spotting glints of remaining burrs and targeting them with gentle, rhythmic passes. As rough bits yield to his patient effort, the edges grow rounded and safe to touch. He pauses to brush away shavings with a straw bundle, then inspects the surface carefully by feel, repeating filing until the iron disk feels clean and snag-free.

staking tool.name: staking tool
staking tool.description: An elongated, slender rod of grey metal lies half-buried in the soil, a stark contrast to surrounding moss. One end tapers to a fine, sharp point, while the opposite end coils into a twisted loop. Its surface gleams with a cold, unnatural sheen, marked by spaced ridges where the metal was shaped. The whole object feels surprisingly heavy and smooth, as if forged by unknown hands beyond the forest’s offerings.

steps.description: At dawn, the human steps into the forest, scanning the ground for trees. He crouches by fallen limbs, noting the straightest angles. Eyes roam the undergrowth, seeking sturdy branches free of knots. Fingers brush moss, probing bark for signs of strength. He tests each limb, lifting it to gauge weight and balance. He taps wood against a rock, listening for a clear, solid ring. He inspects the grain, favoring tight, straight lines. Once he finds a branch that meets his criteria—firm, unblemished, and long—he grasps it, ready to shape.

He gathers a sturdy branch of hardwood, selects a flat surface. He holds the wood firmly on a stable stone, then raises a rounded hammerstone above his head. He brings it down with force to crack and split the wood. He repeats strikes along the grain line, moving the hammerstone precisely to break the wood into smaller lengths. He shifts the position, reorienting the wood to target weak points. Each blow chips off splinters, revealing straight, sharpened edges. He discards irregular fragments, focusing on uniform pieces. He tests each segment, applying pressure to check for a clean break. He continues until he obtains sections of the desired shape and size.

He kneels by a fallen branch, gripping a knife in his strong hand. He places the blade near one end of the wood and draws it toward him, slicing into the bark.
