He repeats the motion along the length, angling the edge just enough to undercut the outer layer without cutting the wood. He peels away the loosened bark with his free hand, exposing smooth inner wood. He inspects the surface and works any stubborn bits, using short, controlled strokes. He moves around the piece, attending to rough patches. Slowly, the entire branch becomes stripped. He pauses, feeling the cool, bare wood beneath his fingers, ready for further shaping.

A primitive artisan selects a solid chunk of flint and holds it firmly against a sturdy support such as a stump. He lifts a hammerstone in one hand and brings it down sharply on the flint’s edge, driving off large flakes to rough out the general form. With each controlled blow he reduces bulges and shapes the mass into a slender profile. When the outline approaches the desired shape, he switches to a thinner, sharper stone flake tool held at an angle. Using this flake tool, he applies precise pressure and small taps along the edge to refine the contour and create a sharp ridge. He works methodically, inspecting each edge for symmetry and sharpness. In the end, the flint object bears a sleek, pointed shape ready for use.

With firm grip, the human presses the dull edge against the rough stone. They apply steady pressure and slide the blade along at a low angle. Friction wears away tiny fragments, gradually forming a sharp margin. Starting at one end, they stroke back and forth, then flip the piece to hone the other side. Periodically, they pause and run a fingernail across the edge to check for burrs. When both faces show a consistent bevel and the edge bites into soft wood easily, they deem the process finished.

steel rod.name: steel rod
steel rod.description: A slender shaft lies upon the ground, its surface gleaming like moonlight on still water. It runs straight and even for its full length, lacking knots or irregularities. Its touch is unsettlingly cold and unyielding, resisting dents from rocks or fallen branches. The edges are sharp and precise, as though carved by spirits. Light dances off its silvery-gray hue, revealing a texture smoother than any stone and unnaturally uniform and unbending.

steps.description: A primitive worker approaches a rocky outcrop known to contain iron ore. He lifts a heavy hammerstone and strikes at the rock face, delivering firm blows that crack open the surface layers. Fragments of rich, reddish ore fall free as he chips away at seams and veins. He discards shards of barren rock and continues to target the ore-rich pockets, concentrating his efforts on the denser, heavier pieces. He pockets larger chunks and inspects them for purity, then gathers the collected ore into rough bags made of animal hide. Occasionally he adjusts his stance, wipes sweat from his brow, and repeats the rhythmic swing until he has enough material for smelting.

He gathers iron ore near the river bed. He breaks the chunks with a stone hammer into pebble-sized pieces. He layers charcoal and ore into the clay furnace, alternating thin strata to maintain even heat. He stands to one side and pumps the bellows, forcing fresh air into the coals. The fire intensity climbs until the furnace interior shines bright orange. As the ore softens, slag begins to drip downward. He keeps the bellows moving in a rhythm, watching the color change to bright yellow. When the bloom looks malleable, he uses tongs to pull it free. He drops the mass onto the anvil, hammers out excess slag, then reheats and repeats. He keeps water nearby to cool his tools between heats. Finally, the clean metal lies ready for shaping.

A lone smith heats an iron bloom in a simple charcoal fire until it glows bright orange. He slips hot tongs around the spongy mass and lifts it onto a rough-hewn anvil. Braced firmly, he strikes the bloom with a heavy hammer, driving out pockets of slag and compacting the iron fibers. After every few blows, he turns the bloom, seeking stubborn inclusions. When the surface cools and cracks, he returns it to the fire, reviving its glow. As the bloom becomes more solid, he hammers more deliberately, folding and shaping it into a long, flattened bar. Each reheating softens the metal and allows further consolidation. He watches the texture, listening for changes in tone as slag escapes in sparks. Finally, he brings the bar to a uniform thickness and length, then lets it cool slowly. The result is a clean, forged bar of wrought iron, ready for finer refinement.

He prepares a furnace built from clay and stone. He places iron bars on a bed of glowing charcoal inside the chamber. He fills gaps around the iron with more powdered charcoal, sealing the space to limit oxygen. He lights a fire at the base, feeding small branches to raise temperature steadily. Over hours, the charcoal gases penetrate the hot iron surface, adding carbon to the metal. He tends the blaze, watching the embers turn white-hot. When the iron glows bright orange throughout, he stokes the charcoal bed one final time. He then breaks open the furnace, using tongs to pull out the heated iron. He plunges the glowing bar into water or oil to lock in the new carbon-enriched structure, producing a more uniform, harder, more resilient metal.

A primitive smith lifts a glowing steel ingot from a low wooden bench and carries it over hot coals into a simple furnace. He slides the ingot inside and uses a bellows to feed air, raising the internal heat until the metal glows bright orange. When the piece reaches full heat, he opens the furnace door with long iron tongs, pulling the malleable mass free and settling it onto a heavy anvil. He braces his feet firmly, then raises a hefty hammer and brings it down with precise, rhythmic blows. Each strike thins and lengthens the heated metal, driving out internal flaws and refining its shape. Periodically he returns the work to the furnace for reheating, maintaining the correct temperature to avoid cracks. After several cycles of heating and hammering, the bar grows uniform in diameter and straightens under the smith’s practiced eye. Finally, he rests the nearly finished piece in a shallow basin of water to quench and harden it. With careful inspection, he sets the cold, sturdy bar aside to await final polishing and tempering.

brass sheet.name: brass sheet
brass sheet.description: They discover a flat, gleaming slab whose surface reflects sunlight in warm, golden tones. It feels cold and hard to the touch, its edges sharp but uniform. When tapped gently, it gives a bright, clear ring that echoes briefly. The surface bears faint parallel lines from shaping, yet it holds no rust. This unexpected, unnatural fragment lies alone among stones and leaves, glowing strangely in the firelight.

steps.description: Before dawn, he kneels at the crag to let morning light guide swings. He grips a sturdy hammerstone in calloused hands. He strikes the weathered rock face again and again, sending chips of green copper carbonate scattering at his feet. He locates veins of malachite gleaming in sunlit cracks. He chips away at the hard surface until he loosens each fragment. He scoops the rough prisms of calamine from nearby nodules, breaking them free with precise blows. He gathers any powder that falls from crushed pieces, letting it settle in a woven basket. He sorts the stones by color and hardness, discarding barren rubble. He loads his haul onto a shoulder pole, ready to carry his ore back to the workshop for further heating and mixing.

He breaks calamine ore into coarse fragments and sprinkles them into the glowing copper melt. As the ore contacts the liquid, zinc vapors rise and sink into the copper, coloring it golden. The smith stirs with an iron rod, scraping the crucible walls to blend evenly. Sparks burst as impurities float to the surface. He skims off slag with a wooden paddle, then listens to the sizzle, senses the odor of burning charcoal and metal vapors, and judges by the glow. When he sees a golden sheen, he slows his stirring and waits for the molten mixture to calm. This uniform melted metal is ready for hammering into thin plates.

The artisan kneels on the earthen floor before a simple hearth built from clay and river stones. He arranges small nuggets of pure copper beside crushed calamine ore. Using heavy tongs, he places copper pieces into a clay crucible, then adds calamine powder atop. With a swift motion he adjusts red-hot coals, inserting the crucible into the heart of the fire. The craftsman grasps wood bellows, pumping steady breaths to feed the flames, pushing oxygen beneath glowing embers. Sparks dance as the heat intensifies; the metal inside glows cherry red. He watches the fusion carefully, raising the tongs to tilt the crucible and ensure even mixing. Flames lick the crucible’s rim, and molten alloy gathers at the bottom. After a long vigil, the craftsman withdraws the vessel, letting its contents cool slightly before pouring the liquid into a flat stone mold. The glowing layer spreads thinly, and the final band of metal settles over the surface. He lets it harden while tending the dying fire, his face lit by embers’ last glow.

A primitive craftsman begins with a small lump of brass he places into the glowing coals of a hearth. Once the metal reaches an orange glow, he transfers it using fire-hardened wooden tongs onto a stone anvil. Holding a heavy hammer in his hand, he repeatedly strikes the heated mass, spreading and thinning its form. He shifts the metal between blows to keep thickness even and listens for changes in sound. Each blow spreads the material outward, creating a larger and flatter panel. When the metal cools and work hardens, he returns it to the fire to soften the interior. After several heat-and-hammer cycles, the metal grows broad and delicate. Finally, he polishes the surface with hide to remove hammer marks, leaving a smooth, thin plate ready for further use.

metal.name: metal
metal.description: Before the primitive eyes stands a solid, hard mass unlike any stone. Its surface gleams with bright light, catching the sun in flashbright rays. It feels cold and unyielding to the touch, smooth but densely heavy, resisting any indent or scratch. Edges are crisp, straight, forming an unnatural shape. No cracks or grain mark its form; its uniform sheen and weight set it apart from all familiar earth and rock.

brass rod.name: brass rod
brass rod.description: It gleams with a pale, golden glow unlike any stone or bone found in these parts. Smooth and straight, its surface is cold to the touch, reflecting light in crisp lines along its length. Its ends cut clean and sharp against the uneven forest floor. No knot or grain mar its form; it feels heavy and dense, yet strangely lifeless, as if forged by unseen hands far from the sunlit clearing.

steps.description: He sets out at dawn, scanning nearby hills for greenish or bluish stains on rocks. He taps stones to hear metallic echoes, sifts riverbeds for heavy, reddish-brown pebbles, and notes rock fractures for glimmering flecks. He follows old toolmakers’ debris and tastes water for a metallic tang. He heats small samples in glowing coals to watch color shifts and trusts his senses to guide him toward rich copper seams.

He kneels before a vein of copper ore lying in a rocky seam. He grips a hammerstone, its weight solid in his hand. He raises the hammerstone and brings it down on the ore, striking with steady force. Fragments of metal flake away, revealing a gleaming interior. He shifts his grip, targeting cracks and softer layers. He chips and pecks until larger pieces give way. He gathers the broken chunks and inspects them for purity, discarding dull or mixed rock. He repeats the process along the seam, gathering enough bright ore for the next stage. With each strike, he learns the stone’s rhythm and the ore’s secrets. Dust rises with each impact.

He stands by a rocky streambed, scanning gray stones stained soft green. He kneels to inspect veins of powdery, yellowish-green mineral in crumbling rock faces. He remembers tales of glowing ore in hills where copper metal takes a strange shimmer. He marks promising outcrops with charcoal, tracing seams along eroded ridges. He gathers samples for further processing. He sniffs fresh fractures, noting an earthy scent before carefully weighing shards in his palm.

At daybreak, the gatherer walks along rocky hillsides in search of calamine ore veins. He kneels before pale rock walls and uses a sturdy hammerstone to strike firm chunks from weathered faces. Each measured blow chips away surrounding stone, revealing yellowish ore. He pries loose fragments with the hammerstone’s edge, separating ore nodules from waste rock. Piling broken pieces nearby, he examines each shard and discards dull, non-ore fragments. Once he gathers several stones, he crushes them against a flat slab, pulverizing lumps into coarse grains. He sifts the crushed material through woven baskets, letting fine sand and dust fall away. The heavier ore grains he reserves for further processing.

The human gathers fragments of copper ore during the day. He breaks the rock into smaller pieces with a stone hammer. He builds a small furnace from clay, stacking stones around a hollow chamber. He kinds a fire inside the furnace with charcoal and dry twigs. Using a pair of wooden bellows, he blows air through a clay pipe into the base of the fire, raising the temperature. Red-hot coals glow inside the furnace as he monitors the heat. Then he shovels crushed ore into the blazing chamber. The intense heat melts the copper, causing molten drops to collect at the bottom. He stops blowing when the metal flows freely and uses a stone ladle to pour the liquid copper into a simple mold. The cycle repeats with new ore.

A primitive craftsman gathers a small ingot of copper and a handful of crushed calamine ore. He cleans and weighs each material on a simple balance. He lights a bed of charcoal and places his iron crucible above the glowing embers, steadying it with stones. He breaks the copper into fragments and drops them into the crucible, then adds the powdered calamine. As heat intensifies, the minerals release vapors and meld with the molten copper. He uses an iron stirring rod to keep the blend uniform. Once the liquid shines with a pale golden hue, he withdraws the crucible carefully with tongs. He pours the molten alloy into a carved groove in a stone mold. After cooling, he retrieves the solid piece and polishes it smooth, ready for later shaping.

He holds the heated crucible in sturdy tongs and moves it close to the long, cylindrical mold. The molten alloy inside the crucible gleams bright yellow as he tilts it carefully. A steady ribbon of liquid metal pours into the open channel of the preheated mold. He watches the level rise, making sure the stream neither sputters nor spills. As the cavity fills, he eases back to avoid any overflow. When the last drop enters, he taps the mold gently against a stone to release trapped air bubbles. Using the tongs, he sets the empty crucible aside on a heat-resistant ledge. He leaves the filled shape to rest until the metal hardens. Thin wisps of steam drift from the cooled surface as the new form solidifies. Once the metal feels firm to the touch through thick leather gloves, he pries the two mold halves apart. Inside, the fresh cylinder holds its exact shape, smooth and unbroken. He withdraws it carefully and carries it to the workbench, ready for further shaping and polishing.

A primitive smith pulls the glowing bar from the coals once the native copper and crushed calamine mixture melts and blends. He sets the tongs around one end and heaves upward, freeing the glowing bar from its bed. The metal resists, but he twists and jerks until it loosens. Sparks flare as he lifts it high then sets it into a trough of cool water. Steam hisses and he watches color shift. He draws the now solid piece from the bath and taps it with a stone to chip away slag. He wipes the surface with a cloth, revealing a straight, gleaming form. He lays it aside to cool fully.

case press.name: case press
case press.description: A compact, rectangular block fashioned from sturdy, cool metal. Its surface is smooth, with straight, exact edges and faint ridges where it folds. A hinge runs along one of the long sides, marked by a thin seam. On the opposite edge, a tiny, raised catch juts out, awaiting contact. The sides bear embossed symbols and a slight sheen, reflecting bright light in crisp angles. It feels solid and sealed.

steps.description: A lone craftsman gathers chunks of iron ore and breaks them into smaller pieces with a hammerstone. He shovels charcoal into a small clay furnace and layers in the crushed ore. Slinging leather bellows over his shoulder, he puffs steady air into the furnace’s tuyere. With each pull on the bellows, flames leap higher and the temperature climbs. Wisps of black smoke curl from the chimney as the charcoal glows white-hot. After several hours of stoking, the ore begins to shed its rocky form and coalesce into a spongy mass of metal and slag. Gripping long-handled tongs, the worker plucks the glowing bloom from the furnace and sets it on a flat stone. He strikes it gently with a hammer to drive out impurities, then returns it for one more blast of heat and air. At last he holds a solid, rust-colored lump of workable iron, ready for shaping into tools or weapons.

Early in the day, a lone artisan selects a sturdy plank from a freshly felled oak. He uses a coarse abrasive stone to scrub away rough bark and knots, applying firm, rhythmic strokes along the grain. As debris falls away, the wood’s surface grows more even. He tests the texture with his palm, then switches to a finer-grained rock. Each pass of the smoother stone removes microscopic ridges until the wood gleams. He dampens the surface to raise stubborn fibers, then repeats the motion, drawing the stone in widening arcs. Finally, he wipes the board with a dry cloth, revealing a flawless, polished surface ready for assembly into his simple lever device.

A primitive craftsman selects a sturdy oak branch as raw stock and strips away bark with knife. He splits it into a thick plank and removes rough sections by careful slicing, smoothing surfaces for better fit. He marks two rectangular blocks and carves shallow cavities to cradle the item to be squeezed. He fashions long, tapered wedge from birch, shaving it thin until it fits snugly between the blocks. He drills a hole by twisting a sharpened stick to insert wooden peg prevents slipping. He assembles the blocks, slides the wedge in, and taps it with another piece of wood, drawing the blocks together until the grip is firm.

The craftsperson selects a sturdy piece of hardwood for the frame and slices it into four straight lengths using a flint blade. They carve each beam until the faces are flat and the corners square, fitting the pieces into a rectangular outline. Next, they cut a sheet of tanned hide and punch spaced holes along its edges with a sharpened bone awl. They stretch the hide taut across two parallel beams, pulling it tight before stitching each hole with thongs. They bind the corners of the frame with extra strips of hide, knotting them firmly. They test the tension, adjusting each thong until the structure holds firm and stable.

steel strip.name: steel strip
steel strip.description: A long, narrow ribbon of cold, glimmering gray lies before the observer. Its surface is unbroken and smooth, catching shafts of light in a bright flash. The edges are dangerously sharp, running in perfect parallel lines and tapering to a uniform thickness along its length. It feels heavy and rigid, yet yields slightly when bent. No natural material shows such consistency of shape, shine, and strength in one piece.

steps.description: Standing at the rocky cliff face, the primitive forgemaker swings his pickaxe with steady rhythm. He digs deep into the earth, chipping away solid rock to reach the veins of iron ore. Each strike sends small fragments tumbling to the ground. He pries loose heavier chunks, tests their weight, and loads them onto a crude wooden carrier. Sweat beads across his brow as he repeats the motion, uncovering richer seams hidden beneath layers of stone. The clinking sound of metal against stone echoes in the narrow pit. After hours beneath the open sky, he hauls the gathered ore back to the camp. He sharpens the pickaxe and returns to dig.

A craftsman kneels before a crude clay furnace, placing lumps of charcoal at its base. He shovels crushed iron ore atop the burning coals, layering materials carefully to maintain an even heat. Grasping wooden handles, he opens the bellows and forces blasts of air into the glowing fire. Each pulse feeds oxygen to the coals, sending sparks dancing and raising the temperature inside the chamber. He watches the ore begin to glow dull red, then shifts to a bright orange hue. Maintaining a steady rhythm, he alternates bellows strokes and adds small handfuls of charcoal to keep the blaze lively. After a long period, the ore softens and begins to separate from impurities, forming a spongy mass. He taps the furnace walls and removes the bloom of refined iron, still hot and malleable. He works methodically, mindful of the fire’s ebb and flow, and prepares to shape the metal while it remains pliable.

A primitive smith shapes a crude clay and stone furnace near his fire pit. He loads charcoal inside and lights it, watching orange flames lick the hearth. He places iron blooms—rough nuggets—inside a tiny clay crucible and nestles it among the blazing charcoal bed. He keeps bellows at his side, pumping air into the furnace to raise temperature. After an hour, the metal glows bright with heat, and carbon-rich gases from the charcoal rise through the crucible, infusing the iron with fresh carbon. The smith maintains steady heat and ensures charcoal surrounds the crucible completely. He tests the glow through the furnace opening, adjusting bellows to reach a red-white hue. After several cycles of heating and rest, the metal draws in sufficient carbon. Finally, he withdraws the crucible with tongs, cools the metal to lock in properties, and readies the newfound alloy for forging. This simple carburizing method transforms the iron into a tougher, more workable material.

Smith kneels before a low hearth, glowing coals licking the raw metal. His bare feet press into the dirt floor as he pounds, feeling each reverberation through his body. Using tongs, he seizes a block of steel and plunges it into the red heart of flame. He holds it until it glows bright orange. He withdraws the heated bar and seats it on the anvil. With broad swings of a hammer, he beats the metal, flattening and lengthening it into a flat ribbon. He moves the glowing metal, turning and drawing it with firm blows, working its thickness down evenly. When the shape grows long and thin, he returns it to the hearth for another heat. Again it shines with ember light. Back on the anvil, he applies rhythmic hammer strikes, smoothing out irregularities and refining its form. He rotates the bar with tongs, ensuring uniform thickness. After several cycles of heating and forging, the metal emerges slender and even, a clean, flat ribbon of refined steel, ready for further shaping or tempering.

chalk.name: chalk
chalk.description: A small, pale bar of stone rests lightly on the ground. Its color is a soft, dull white, like dewdrops frozen in rock. The surface bleeds into a fine, ghostly dust at every touch, and the edges flake into powdery whispers. The texture feels powdery, cool and delicate, crumbling beneath gentle pressure. Each fracture reveals a barely uniform, milky core, slender shards that scatter like fallen ash in the wind.

magnifying glass.name: magnifying glass
magnifying glass.description: A circular disk of clear, shining stone sits within a slender band of metal. It feels smooth and cool to the touch, curved gently on both faces. When it catches sunlight, bright rays fracture into glimmering lines that dance on nearby surfaces. The transparent crystal holds no color yet seems to capture light, forming a bright, luminous window. Held aloft, its thin edge glows with a soft halo.

steps.description: He roams windswept ridges, scans rocky outcrops, eyes flicking over pale glints. He crouches by a stream, fingers sifting sand until a small quartz vein catches his attention. He chips away loose stone with a sharp flint, revealing a clear shard. He lifts it, turning it in sunlight to check for clarity and even thickness. Satisfied with its size and purity, he tucks the crystal carefully into a leather pouch.

A primitive person selects a chunk of milky quartz. They hold the quartz firmly in one hand and strike it with the hammerstone. Sharp flakes break away, revealing translucent patches inside. They chip around the desired section, removing rough outer layers. Each blow is measured; they watch for glittering shards that promise clear transparency. Once they expose a smooth, glassy portion, they tap gently along its edge to separate a thin plate. They rub the fragment against sandstone to smooth major ridges. They inspect the piece in sunlight, turning it until they find the clearest area. Satisfied, they set aside the shimmering crystal for later shaping and solar light testing.

A primitive craftsperson selects a piece of clear quartz crystal and chips it into smaller fragments with a harder stone. He places fragments into a shallow mortar, sprinkles coarse sand over them, and drips in water to form a gritty slurry. Using the pestle, he grinds in a circular motion, crushing quartz shards and mixing sand until the mixture thickens into a fine paste. He pauses to clean excess grit from the edges of the mortar and adds fresh sand and water to maintain abrasiveness. After an hour of grinding, the paste develops a uniform consistency. He then presses the slurry between two shaped stones, rotating them so that the quartz paste carves a smooth, curved surface. He inspects the form against sunlight, marking thicker areas with a small flake of quartz before grinding again to achieve uniform curvature. He rinses away residual grit with water and examines the emerging curve. Next, he wraps a soft leather strip around a rounded pebble, dips it in water, and uses it to polish the rough stone form in strokes. Through repeated polishing, the curved surface becomes translucent and smooth, revealing an optical element ready for use.

A hunter-gatherer seats a roughly chipped lens blank on a flat slab of coarse sandstone. He wets the stone with water and rubs the blank in gentle, back-and-forth strokes, wearing down every bump and ridge. When the surface grows uniformly smooth, he shakes loose a handful of red hematite nodules and pounds them into a fine powder. Mixing that powder with a few drops of water, he creates a thin, gritty paste. Dabbing a strip of soft animal-hide cloth into the slurry, he rubs the lens in tight, circular motions. With each pass, the hematite grit wears away microscopic scratches, and the glassy surface gleams more clearly. Periodically he rinses the lens in a forest stream, inspects it against sunlight, and returns to the cloth for another cycle. After hours of careful polishing, the curved disc catches and focuses a beam of light into a bright, dancing spot.

iron plate.name: iron plate
iron plate.description: A flat, dark slab lies half-buried among stones and grass. Its surface feels unnaturally smooth, reflecting faint glimmers of sky when wet. The edges are sharp and uniform, unlike jagged rocks nearby. A cool, heavy weight presses into tender palms. Tiny patches of reddish dust lie in slight pits, contrasting with the deeper grey. The whole thing seems foreign to earth and bone, as if born of fire and sky.

steps.description: The human scans rocky hillsides for exposed mineral veins, noting streaks of reddish-brown rock. He scratches at weathered outcrops with a stone tool, tasting dust to detect metallic flavor. Along riverbanks, he pans sand and gravel, watching heavy black grains settle. Curious fragments ring out when struck together, guiding him toward richer deposits. He also marks sunlit ledges where rock cracks reveal metallic glinting seams. He follows weathered gullies inland.

A rugged artisan stands before a rocky vein. He swings his pickaxe to chip away at the stone, sending shards of rock scattering. With each precise strike, he pries loose fragments of mineral-rich iron ore embedded within the bedrock. He pauses occasionally to inspect the emerging seams, brushing away dust with a worn cloth to reveal darker metallic streaks. Once he identifies a suitable section, he continues to pound methodically, widening a shallow cavity. He scoops the freshly freed ore chunks into a wooden basket, ensuring none slip back into the crevice. When the basket is filled with heavy, reddish-brown lumps, the laborer hauls it toward the forge site.

A primitive human gathers iron ore nodules from a rocky outcrop. He builds a small furnace of packed clay and broken stones. He arranges charcoal inside the furnace to create a hot, reducing fire. He inserts a tubular clay tuyere through one side of the furnace. He uses a pair of woven-leather bellows to force air through the tuyere. The constant blast heats the interior to temperatures above 1200 °C. He carefully adds more ore and charcoal in layers as the heat grows. Molten slag forms and drains away from the ore as it softens. The denser metal accumulates in a spongy bloom at the furnace bottom. He taps the bloom out once the ore fully reduces to metal. He repeatedly heats and hammers the bloom to expel slag. The resulting mass of forged metal awaits further shaping. He watches the glow fade and allows the metal to cool slowly in the ashes.

The smith holds the glowing bloom with tongs and lays it on the anvil. He raises the hammer and brings firm, rhythmic blows down onto the hot mass. Each strike spreads the metal outward, expelling pockets of slag and closing internal voids. After a dozen blows, he rolls the bloom with tongs, turns it, and strikes again, driving out impurities. The smith watches the color shift from bright orange to dull red, judging when to return the piece to the fire. He reheats briefly, then resumes hammering, alternating edges to keep thickness even. As the lump thins and widens, it begins to resemble a rough sheet. He smooths the surface with lighter taps, refining the texture and flattening small irregularities. When the metal cools too far, he reintroduces it to the coals for a final heating. By steady repetition of heating and hammering, he transforms raw bloom into a uniform sheet of workable metal.

The smith lifts the glowing mass from the hearth with sturdy tongs and sets it upon the anvil. He taps its red-hot surface with a broad-faced hammer, driving out slag and flattening the lump into a rough disk. Each strike sends sparks dancing into the air as he rotates the metal with the tongs, exposing every edge to the hammer’s blow. When the form begins to widen and thin, he returns it to the coals for reheating until it shines with an even, fiery glow. Back at the anvil, he works more quickly now, guiding the hammer to spread the material outward in uniform sweeps. He watches the thickness grow consistent, listening for a steady ring under each impact. As the shape nears the desired dimensions, he eases his force to refine the surface, smoothing out imperfections. Finally, the craftsman pauses, holding the finished sheet aloft in the tongs to survey its even flatness before cooling it in water.

scriber.name: scriber
scriber.description: It appears as a slender, rigid sliver of shining gray metal, oddly cold to the touch. One end tapers to an almost unnoticed, deadly-fine point, while the other remains blunt and unadorned. Its surface gleams like fractured obsidian, etched with faint grooves where light flickers along polished facets. It holds a subtle weight in the palm, smooth except for the ever-present hint of sharpness at its tip.

steps.description: At dawn the tribal artisan moves to the marsh, scanning for tall, straight-stemmed reeds. He steps through shallow water, eyes fixed on stalks rising above the mud. He looks for firm, unblemished stems with smooth surfaces and hollow cores. He tests potential pieces by bending them lightly to check flexibility and strength. Satisfied, he snaps a sturdy stalk beneath his fingers, stripping away leaves and broken tips. He selects the longest, strongest pieces, bundling them carefully. Then he carries the gathered reeds back to his work area, ready for shaping.

A primitive human selects a robust piece of seasoned hardwood from a fallen trunk. The craftsman places the block on a firm, flat stone surface. He positions a sturdy wedge at the wood’s end, aligning the taper with the grain. Raising a heavy hammer, he strikes the wedge’s blunt top, driving the taper deep into the fibers. He pauses to inspect the emerging split, tracking its progress along the grain. He repeats firm hammer blows, adjusting the wedge’s angle to guide the crack. Gradually, the block splits cleanly into two thinner slabs. He removes the wedge and smooths the rough edge with a scraper. Each board receives a fresh wedge mark to ensure uniform thickness before further work. The artisan selects each split with care, valuing straight fibers. The boards lie ready for further shaping.

A solitary artisan kneels beside a low charcoal fire, copper nugget glowing dull orange at the edges. He grips the metal with tongs and holds it above the flame until it softens. With a steady hand, he moves the heated bar onto the anvil. Each strike of his hammer flattens and elongates the metal, forcing out impurities and refining its shape. When the bar lies thin and straight, he returns it to the coals and lets it cool slowly. Next, he raises one end above the fire until it gleams bright. Clamping it again in tongs, he hammers the tip into a sharp point, twisting the shaft slightly to produce a comfortable grip. Finally, he dips the tool in water to harden the copper, then rubs it on a smooth stone to remove scale and sharpen the edge. In his rough workshop, a simple yet durable marking implement stands ready for use.

They take a coarse grinding stone and add drops of water to create a fine slurry. They hold the rod at a low angle against the stone’s surface. Slowly they move the tip back and forth, applying gentle pressure. The wet abrasion removes small bits, shaping the point into a fine edge. They pause to wipe the surface, checking for a consistent sharpening. If necessary, they refresh water and resume grinding. They rotate the rod to sharpen all sides evenly. Finally, they rinse the stone and the tip, dry the tool, and test it on a wood block. The point is now keen and ready for precise marking.

center punch.name: center punch
center punch.description: A small, solid object lies on the ground. It feels cool and heavy in the hand, its steel surface dark gray and polished smooth. One end tapers to a sharp point while the other flares into a broad, flat disk. Faint rings encircle its length near the center, as if crafted by turning on a spinning tool. Light flickers off its polished curves, making a clear metal song when tapped.

steps.description: At first, the maker scans stream beds and rocky slopes for heavy, dense stones with a fine grain. They crouch by the water and fish out multi-toned pieces of quartzite or basalt, checking their weight and texture. Each candidate feels solid and emits a clear ring when tapped. The craftsman holds it close to his ear, strikes it lightly against another rock, and listens for a sharp, ringing tone. He discards dull-sounding fragments and sets aside those that show no visible cracks or flaws, ensuring a sturdy starting piece for shaping.

A primitive human takes a small ingot of copper, places it on a sturdy stone anvil. He wields a heavy hammer in his strong hand. With firm even blows, he stretches and tapers one end, gradually narrowing the metal into a sharp point. He rotates the workpiece between strikes to maintain symmetry. The repeated hammering compresses the copper, refining its shape and strengthening the tip. Once satisfied with the profile, he smooths rough edges by tapping lightly all around. The result is a sturdy pointed rod ready to impress marks into wood, bone, or soft stone. Fired copper displays resilience under force, ensuring the tip will hold its form through use. The entire process unfolds using only heat, hammer, and anvil, guided by human skill and requires care and patience.

wedge.name: wedge
wedge.description: Thick and heavy, the object tapers smoothly from a broad, blunt end to a narrow, sharpened edge. Its surface is hard and cool, mottled with grains of varying color—gray and brown streaks running lengthwise. Light from a fire glints off its thin side, highlighting a crisp, straight line. Though embedded amidst rough stones and soil, this piece seems intentionally shaped, its two sloping faces meeting in a precise, slender ridge.

steps.description: The early human scans the riverbed for a moss-covered boulder or sun-baked outcrop. They grasp a heavy hammerstone in one hand and feel its weight as they approach the chosen surface. With a firm stance, they bring the hammerstone down sharply on the rock’s edge, aiming to detach a sharp fragment. They repeat strikes around the target area, shifting angles to control the break. Each impact yields a flake that they examine for size and shape. When the piece meets their needs—sharp and sturdy—they clean and set it aside for later shaping.

He selects a sturdy stone fragment from the riverbank and reviews its grain. He holds the block firmly against his leg and raises a rounded hammerstone in his other hand. He strikes a precise point along one edge, detaching a thin flake. He realigns the fragment and repeats the blow, shaping an elongated profile with a gradually thinning end. He feels the contour with his thumb, then adjusts his angle and delivers controlled strikes. Small chips fly away as he refines both faces, balancing form and sharpness. He inspects the outline, smoothing rough spots. He works patiently. When a slender, tapered point emerges, he pauses, satisfied with the final result.

stone flake tool.name: stone flake tool
stone flake tool.description: A triangular shard of dark, glassy stone catches the light, its edges glinting in the sun. One side is smooth and flat, the other deeply grooved where it parts from a larger mass. Tiny chips and ridges trace along its perimeter, creating a jagged outline. Its weight lies solid in the palm, cool to the touch. The surface feels both ancient and freshly broken, whispering of great forces at work.

steps.description: He scans the riverbank, eyes alert for pale gray nodules of chert nestled among pebbles. His hands sift through loose gravel, feeling for smooth, glassy surfaces. He walks atop rolling hills, gauging the outcrops of quartzite where blooms of broken rock glint in the sun. At a dry wash, he crouches beneath a jutting cliff, brushing away dust to expose pale quartz nodules. His gaze sweeps the horizon, seeking weathered ledges where resistant rock fractures naturally. With patient steps, he follows animal tracks that often cross mineral-rich zones. By reading the land’s patterns and listening to the river’s song, he locates the raw materials needed to craft sharp cutting implements. He notes color shifts in cliff faces, follows fallen boulders blocking gully floors, and examines rock fragments left by other tool makers as hints to richer seams.

He stands before a piece of stone, gripping it in his off hand. With the hammerstone in his dominant hand, he inspects the edge to find a ridge and selects a platform that sits at about a 60-degree angle. He raises the hammerstone and brings it down in a swift but controlled strike, aiming inward to initiate a Hertzian cone fracture. Upon contact, a sliver of material detaches cleanly, leaving a fresh cutting edge on core and flake. He examines the new flake, noting its thickness and sharpness, then rotates the core to a new spot. He continues the process, adjusting force and angle, to produce sharp edges.

quartz.name: quartz
quartz.description: Bright shards protrude from a rocky surface, each glinting like frozen water caught in sunlight. The smooth faces meet at sharp angles. When held up, light slices through the translucent shapes, casting prism sparks across rough hands. The cluster feels cool and heavy, its edges unyielding and smooth. Though rooted in stone, the piece gleams with hidden depths, as if capturing the very light of day within its solid, glass-like form.

chert.name: chert
chert.description: A nodule lies embedded in pale, chalky hillsides, its surface smooth against the skin. Its color ranges from smoky gray to deep black hues, occasionally streaked with milky white veins. Clusters of these nodules litter creekbeds where softer rock wears away. When struck, it emits a dull, resonant ring. Jagged, sharp fragments glint along broken edges, revealing a glassy luster beneath the matte exterior. The stone feels heavy and unyielding in the hand.

calamine ore.name: calamine ore
calamine ore.description: A rocky seam exposed in a sunlit cliff shows compact masses of chalky stone. Its surface glimmers with pale blush and soft yellow patches, mottled by a dusty white film. Under fingers it feels crumbly yet firm, crumbling into fine powder. Tiny, sandlike grains cluster together, giving a rough but slightly smooth touch. This lumpy rock lies encrusting darker bedrock, seeming awkwardly yet subtly blended into the landscape’s bare outcroppings.

leather strip.name: leather strip
leather strip.description: It is a long, narrow piece of hide, dark brown and slightly curved. The surface is smooth yet firm, streaked with natural grains and faint lines. When bent, it yields with a soft creak, then springs back. It feels cool and supple under the skin, edges slightly rough. A faint scent of earth and animal lingers, warm, whispering of life once held beneath its fibers. Subtle variations in shade hint at its origin.

steps.description: At dawn, the gatherer scents game. He loosens the sinew bindings on his wooden spear and crouches low behind a copse. With steady breath, he eyes a deer grazing near the riverbank. He grips a stone flake knife in his right hand. The blade gleams in the dawn light. He advances quietly, pausing as a twig snaps beneath his foot. He raises the knife, hooking it beneath the animal’s chest. With a swift, practiced motion, he drives the blade through bone and sinew, severing the heart. The deer exhales its final breath. He steps back and watches the lifeless body slide to the ground, ready for the next task.

A primitive craftsman spreads out a cured hide on a rough-hewn wooden frame. He inspects the flesh side for debris. He grips a sharp flint-edge chisel in one hand and tethers it to maintain tension. He positions the chisel blade at the inner margin where the flesh side meets the epidermis. With steady pressure, he drives the chisel along the edge, separating the layers as he moves. He tilts the blade to keep a shallow angle, ensuring the hide remains intact beneath. He glides the chisel, peeling away portions in long strokes. Adjusting tension and angle, he works his way across the surface until the hide is cleanly removed.

A hunter holds a freshly flayed hide over a wooden frame, stretching it tightly by hand. Using a sharp-edged stone scraper, the person runs firm strokes along the flesh side, shaving away bits of tissue, fat, and membranes. With each pass, the scraper chips off gristle and tough fibers, while the hider rotates and adjusts tension for a smooth surface. After clearing the thick patches, the hide grows uniformly thin and supple. The worker rinses the surface with clean water, removes any remaining scraps, and dries the skin in the sun, occasionally flexing it to keep softness. When fully dried, the preparer has a clean, workable hide ready for further crafting.

A craftsman soaks a fresh hide in clean water until it becomes soft and pliable. He lays the wet skin over a simple wooden frame, positioning its edges evenly. With wooden pegs, he secures the hide’s perimeter, driving each peg firmly into pre–drilled holes. As the hide begins to dry, it tightens across the frame. The maker checks the tension and gently pulls any slack out toward the pegs, ensuring an even stretch. When sections start to harden unevenly, he spritzes them with water to keep the fibers flexible. Throughout the day, he taps the hide with a flat bone tool or his hand to maintain suppleness. Once the entire surface feels firm but not brittle, he leaves it to air dry fully, continuing to adjust pegs so the skin remains flat and uniformly stretched. Finally, he removes the wood pins and lifts the treated piece, now ready for cutting into narrow bands.

A craftsman removes hair and flesh from a section of hide using a flint scraper. He soaks the hide in a mixture of wood ash and water, then rinses it thoroughly. Next, he stretches the wet material over a sturdy frame, securing it with wooden pegs. As the sun warms the hide, he periodically flexes and scrapes it to maintain softness. Once it dries stiff, he applies animal fat to restore pliability. He smooths the surface with a bone tool, producing a durable hide ready for use in clothing or shelter.

The primitive human lays the prepared hide over a smooth rock or wooden board, smoothing out wrinkles. Grasping a sharp flint knife, they align its blade with an imaginary guideline. They press the blade firmly against the hide, scoring a shallow groove from end to end. Then they angle the knife deeper and draw it steadily along the groove, slicing cleanly through the material in a long, continuous motion. They repeat this action at regular intervals, creating multiple narrow bands of equal width. If necessary, they adjust their grip or rotate the hide to maintain straight edges. With careful control of pressure and angle, they transform a single hide into uniform hanging bands.

mortar.name: mortar
mortar.description: A viscous gray paste clings to the palm, cool and damp. Tiny grains give its surface a coarse texture, yet the whole feels smooth like wet sand mixed with finely crushed shell. Pressed between rough stones, it holds shape, filling crevices with a firm, buttery mass. Under the sun’s warmth, it slowly stiffens, transforming into a solid seam with edges as rigid as if the earth itself has grown new rock.

steps.description: First, the primitive human scans the riverbank for smooth, durable stones. She follows the flowing water, listening for clacking pebbles. She crouches and tests each rock’s heft, seeking pieces that resist fragmentation. With a sturdy wooden stick, she pries out hidden boulders from the sand. She discards small, crumbly rocks and pockets heavier, coarse-grained stones. Each candidate bears a grainy surface and feels solid. She carries a woven basket, balancing the load on her shoulder. When she assembles enough stones, she returns to her shelter and readies them for grinding.

A primitive human chooses a firm sandstone nodule. They grasp a rounded hammerstone and deliver measured strikes to one side, chipping off fragments. With each impact, a shallow pit emerges. They shift the stone’s position, directing blows to deepen the center and thin the walls. Fragments fall free, revealing a curved cavity. The maker taps gently along the rim to smooth irregular bits and even out the thickness. They continue striking and rotating for hours, watching the hollow grow more pronounced. Small chips scatter around as the interior surface gains a gentle curve. Finally, the stone has a bowl-like hollow, ready for carrying and mixing. This simple container holds water, grains, or seeds.

hematite.name: hematite
hematite.description: A smooth, heavy stone rests in hand, its surface gleaming with a metallic sheen. In bright light, it carries a dark silver color, shifting to charcoal in shadowed angles. When lightly scraped across soft earth, it leaves behind a fine rusty-red dust that contrasts with pale soils. It feels unnaturally dense. It catches light even in dim gloom. Its edges often appear worn smooth, as though shaped by unseen forces.

pestle.name: pestle
pestle.description: The object appears as a stout, elongated piece of smooth stone. It measures roughly twelve inches from end to end, its surface cool and unyielding. One extremity is slightly bulbous, the other subtly tapered. Gentle curves run along its length, bisected by faint striations and tiny pits. Its weight is steady in the hand, neither top-heavy nor awkward. In diffused light, mottled gray hues glint with specks of darker mineral.

steps.description: He scans the riverbank at dawn, eyes tracing the water’s edge for a suitable stone. He crouches beside currents, lifting leaves and sand to reveal hidden boulders. He tests weight with his hand, judging heft and balance. He taps surfaces to listen for resonant tones, favoring dense, solid rocks. He rubs his palm across smooth faces, checking for cracks. He scans stones lodged between larger rocks, prying with a wooden stick. Once he finds one heavy enough to crush seeds yet comfortable to hold, he drags it back to camp.

He crouches beside a riverbank strewn with rocks. He scans the ground carefully, eyes fixed on shapes that feel heavy in his mind. Spotting a roughly oval rock about the size of his forearm, he reaches forward and extends his fingers around its cool surface. He tests its weight, lifting slightly to gauge whether it will rest securely in his palm. Confident, he grips it firmly, pressing his thumb into the natural indentations. With a steady hand, he hoists the rock to his chest, preparing it for further shaping.

quartz crystal.name: quartz crystal
quartz crystal.description: It gleams like trapped water turned to stone, emerging from the earth in jagged clusters. Each facet catches sunlight, sending shards of brightness across the surrounding stones. Translucent planes reveal cloudy swirls and occasional rainbows dancing deep within. The surface feels smooth yet fractured, as if sharp enough to split the skin. Rooted among gravel and sand, it stands clear and steadfast, a silent, enduring facet of the rocky landscape.

wooden pegs.name: wooden pegs
wooden pegs.description: Lying slender, tapered sticks hewn from pale wood. Each is smooth along its length, save faint tool marks that catch sunlight. One end comes to a gentle point, while the opposite end remains squared off, revealing grain patterns. Their surfaces are free of bark, showing ridges where fibers once ran. Gathered in a neat row, they appear identical in size and shape, as if cut from a single branch.

steps.description: A primitive human scans the forest edge for sturdy young saplings and limbs. He tests branch density by bending small twigs between his fingers, seeking straight, lengths. Using a hand-held stone axe, he strikes the bark and splits the wood into manageable sections. He discards pieces with knots, keeping only straight-grained sticks. Next, he trims off side branches and cuts each stick to a uniform thickness. Finally, he bundles these straight strips and carries them back to his shelter for further crafting. He weighs each bundle to test its heft.

A primitive craftsman selects a straight branch and trims off irregularities with a chisel. He first marks equal lengths by scoring shallow lines along the grain. He places segment against a sturdy log, holding it firmly. With measured strikes from a stone mallet, he peels away bark and knots, revealing pale inner grain. He dips the blade along the edge, paring thin shavings to refine the circumference. Rotating the stock between blows, he forms a uniform cylinder. At one end he carves a conical tip for easy insertion. At the other, he cuts a slight shoulder to prevent over-insertion. Finally, he smooths the surface against river sand, leaving a perfectly tapered fastener.

wooden frame.name: wooden frame
wooden frame.description: A cluster of straight, slender branches joins at right angles, forming an empty rectangle suspended among damp ferns. The bark’s pale surface is scored with tool marks, revealing lighter wood beneath. At each corner, the sticks meet with precise alignment, held together by thin, twisted vines. Moss begins to crawl along its lower edge, softening the angular shape. Against the forest floor’s mottled shadows, it stands ordered amid wild growth.

steps.description: He scans the forest, stepping between ferns and underbrush to find a tree suitable for his project. He observes bark thickness and checks trunk straightness, tapping lightly to judge solid sound. He considers species known for strength, bending a leafy branch to assess flexibility. He crouches to inspect root stability, ensuring it stands firmly in earth. Satisfied, he marks the trunk with a charcoal stroke, ready to fashion beams soon.

The primitive human grips a sharp stone flake knife and circles the tree’s base. He slices through bark and sapwood in a shallow incision, removing loose chips. Step by step, he deepens a notch on the sunward side, carving a V-shape that guides the tree’s fall. At waist height, he cuts downward strokes, turning and sharpening the blade on a rough stone as needed. On the opposite side, he carves a small back-cut to loosen fibres and direct the fall. As the notch grows, the tree creaks. He leans back, stepping aside as the trunk gives way, crashing to earth. He then trims limbs for transport back to nearby camp.

He selects a sturdy branch from a fallen tree and leans it against a rock. He holds a sharp flint blade in his right hand and saws through bark and inner wood, scoring a straight line. With a firm grip he snaps off a segment, then repeats the motion three more times along the same limb. He strips bark by scraping with a bone tool, revealing a clean surface. Finally he smooths each piece against a coarse stone to ease rough edges, yielding four straight sticks ready for assembly.

The primitive craftsman holds a straight stick horizontally, balancing it on his knee. He grips the knife firmly in his dominant hand, blade angled slightly. With short, controlled strokes, he carves away uneven bark and rough splinters. He rotates the stick slowly, shaving until the ends form a flat surface. He checks the cut by pressing the trimmed end against another stick, ensuring a snug fit. He repeats the process on the opposite end, matching lengths precisely. He uses the knife tip to nibble out a small notch or tenon. His movements remain deliberate, the blade biting cleanly into the wood fiber, creating smooth, even stick ends ready for assembly.

He gathers a handful of long, straight sticks from the forest floor. He brushes dirt off each piece with cloth. He lays two sturdy sticks parallel on the ground. He selects thinner sticks and places them crosswise, spacing each. He nudges a stick into position until it aligns with the support sticks. He repeats this in a pattern, adjusting lengths so each end sits flush. After completing a row, he adds more cross pieces, stacking them above. As he works, the structure gains strength and order with each new stick.

He chooses four sturdy sticks and lays them into a rough rectangle on the ground. He picks a length of flexible vine, stripping away leaves and bark. At each corner, he loops the vine under and over the crossing sticks, pulling it tight. He winds the vine around the joint several times, then wraps it back through the loops to lock the binding. He trims excess vine and moves to the next corner. With each binding made firm, the poles hold their shape, and the primitive structure gains strength and stability.

sticks.name: sticks
sticks.description: Fallen lengths of weathered wood lie scattered across the forest floor. Each piece is thin and elongated, ranging from narrow pointed tips to thicker segments. Their surfaces are rough with cracked bark that peels in irregular flakes, revealing pale, fibrous wood beneath. Many bear small knots where offshoots once grew. Some are slightly curved, others nearly straight. They feel hard but brittle, and their color shifts from dark brown to grayish tan.

steps.description: He stands among the trees, surveying fallen limbs and slender branches. With practiced eyes, he seeks a length of wood that promises straightness and lightness. He brushes away detritus, examining each timber for cracks or knots. Slender and sturdy, one fragment catches his attention. He bends it gently, checking its flexibility, then snaps it off close to the trunk. He taps it against the ground to test dryness. Satisfied with his choice, he hoists the wooden shaft and carries it back to the fire pit in camp.

The crouched figure extends one arm toward the ground where a slender piece of wood lies amid the leaf litter. Fingers spread, then tighten around its middle. He sinks his weight slightly, using a firm grip and flexes his wrist, lifting the item off the earth. He holds it close to his chest, eyes narrowing in thought as he readies the crude tool for shaping with focused intention and careful deliberation.

lodestone.name: lodestone
lodestone.description: This rough, dark stone glints with metallic specks in flickering firelight. It feels unusually heavy and cool to the touch, its surface pitted with tiny hollows and bright sparkles. When brought near bits of iron-rich sand or small metal shards, those fragments creep and cling as if drawn by an unseen force. It lies still and silent, a mysterious, ancient, ominous, enduring rock formed deep within the earth’s hidden veins.

auger bit.name: auger bit
auger bit.description: A slender rod of gleaming metal spirals from tip to tail. Its cool surface is smooth except for the sharp point at one end and a shaft at the other. The spiral rises in regular, precise loops like a twisting shell or root but far more consistent than any vine or bone. Its polished sheen reflects sunlight in ribbons along the helical curve, and it feels unnaturally heavy in hand.

steps.description: He approaches rocky outcrops along a riverbank. He studies the stone layers for nodules with conchoidal fracture patterns. His practiced eye notes color changes and banding that suggest hardness. He selects a promising nodule and uses a hammerstone to strike it lightly, listening for a bright ring that signals a compact interior. When a piece pops free, he examines the freshly broken face for smooth, glassy surfaces and absence of cracks. Content with its quality, he gathers more nodules from the same strata, testing each with his hammerstone. He repeats this along exposed ledges and streambeds to locate the richest seams. He piles small stones beside each nodule to mark its spot.

Upon finding a promising seam of copper-bearing rock in a shallow outcrop, the craftsman crouches beside it. He grips a heavy hammerstone in one hand and a pointed pick in the other. He first clears loose stones and soil with the hammerstone, revealing the faint reddish sheen of metal. He positions the pick at cracks and taps its shaft with deliberate force, chipping away hardened mineral. Small shards break free under each strike. He then uses the pick’s tip as a lever to pry out larger nodules from the host rock. As pieces detach, he sweeps dust aside and inspects each fragment, discarding dull bits. Sweat beads on his brow as he repeats the ritual, striking, prying, and sorting until a sizeable heap of ore glints in the sun, ready for refinement.

A primitive human first selects green malachite nodules and dries them in the sun, then smashes them into small chips. They build a simple pit furnace lined with clay and river stone and pack charcoal within. Using a clay tuyere connected to tethered animal-hide bellows, they blow steady air into the base of the fire. They layer ore and charcoal in alternating strata and tend the blaze carefully. As the fire reaches red-white heat above 1000°C, malachite releases carbon dioxide and reduces to copper droplets. Molten copper pools at the furnace floor, sinking into a bed of glowing coals. The metal blooms into a spongy mass, which they extract with tongs and hammer on an anvil stone. Slag flakes away under repeated strikes. The resulting copper chunk cools, ready for reheating and forging into a drill-like shaft.

He builds a small forge and lights a charcoal fire, feeding it air through the tuyere until the coals glow bright orange. He selects a length of copper rod and holds it in tongs, rotating it slowly in the heat until it becomes malleable. He removes it from the fire and places the hot metal against the anvil. With strong strikes of the hammer, he taps and flattens one end into a flattened, tapered point. He returns the piece to the coals, reheating it until it is uniformly soft. Again at the anvil, he hammers the tapered end in a twisting motion, creating a sharp, conical tip suited for penetrating wood. He adjusts the length by reheating and cutting off excess with a chisel-like edge on the anvil. Finally, he crisply defines the spiral groove by careful hammer blows and gentle twisting between the tongs, working in short bursts of heat and hammering. When satisfied with the shape, he polishes the tool in cold water, quenching it to firm the copper and reveal a smooth, shining surface ready for use.

rule.name: rule
rule.description: Emerging from the undergrowth, a slender piece of olive-brown wood extends a foot in length, its sides perfectly parallel and edges unnaturally straight. Along its top surface, a row of tiny, shallow grooves follows a precise rhythm, each marking spaced at equal intervals. The smooth texture contrasts sharply with the rough bark and the evenly polished finish catches the light at a uniform sheen. It feels deliberate, its symmetry unsettling in the wild.

steps.description: A primitive gatherer steps into the forest and scans trunks for solid wood shafts. He tests bark patterns, tapping each piece with a stone and listening for a clear, resonant tone. He grips the shaft, gauging its heft and balance, and flexes it gently to check for resilience. He examines knots and cracks, avoiding warped or damp sections. He traces the grain with his fingers, seeking a long, unbroken fiber. Satisfied, he cuts the chosen wood free with a sharp flint and carries it back for crafting useful simple tools.

A primitive human stands beside a sturdy oak trunk. His calloused hands wrap around a heavy stone-headed axe, the haft bound with sinew. He plants his feet wide, firm on uneven earth. Lifting the tool overhead, he draws a slow breath. The blade thuds into the wood, splinters flying as fibers part. He repeats the motion, each swing carving a deep gouge across the grain. Sweat gleams on his brow as he adjusts his grip, driving the blade deeper. Fissures run lengthwise, the log weakening under steady blows. At last he pries sections free, shaping rough planks that will serve as beams for building or fuel for a warming fire.

A primitive artisan selects a flat plank of wood and prides himself on creating a straight, narrow edge. He smooths its surface with a sharp flake, then readies his divider. The two pointed legs meet at a simple hinge of sinew. He opens the points until they span the length he wishes to divide. Placing one point at the plank’s start, he presses the other to leave a small indentation. He then shifts both points together and repeats, each motion adding another tiny mark. His steady hand and careful eye ensure the spacing remains true along the length. Soon the timber holds a series of equal divisions, ready for further shaping.

square.name: square
square.description: The object is a flat surface of uncanny regularity, bounded by four straight edges of equal length. Each corner meets at a precise right angle, forming a frame of perfect symmetry. Its surface reflects light evenly, offering no irregularities or curves. Against the wild backdrop of rocks and foliage, it stands out as an unnatural apparition, with stark geometry that defies the organic shapes of trees, stones, and flowing water.

steps.description: He kneels and reaches for a hefty branch, drags it across the ground to loosen pebbles. He lifts stones and tosses them aside. Using a flint scraper, he digs at stubborn roots, pulls them free. He sweeps leaves and twigs into a pile with a flat rock. He pats the soil with his hands, fills low spots with loose earth. At last the area lies even and open.

The primitive human kneels before the wall, picks up a chunk of ochre in one hand and a small stone in the other. He powders the red mineral by grinding it against the rough surface of the rock, releasing fine dust that coats his fingers. He taps the rock lightly, scattering flecks of pigment across his palm. Then he presses the ochre-laden finger against the grainy wall, starting at the lower left corner. He drags his finger upward, depositing a continuous ribbon of red along the surface. He pauses to inspect the evenness of the pigment, adjusts pressure, and continues the motion until he achieves a straight, visible mark.

steps.step: draw second line of same length at right angle from one end of first line
steps.description: He draws a straight line in the dirt using a chunk of charcoal held in one hand. He takes the cord and lays it out alongside the stroke, marking one segment equal to the line’s length. He holds one end of the cord at the near end of the line and swings the other end in a gentle arc. When the cord cuts across the ground at a clear, right angle to the first mark, he presses another charcoal spot at the point where his segment reaches its length. He then connects this new dot back to the original endpoint, creating a second line of equal length standing perfectly upright.

steps.step: draw third line of same length parallel to first line from the other end of second line
steps.description: He places a stick as a straightedge. Using it, he marks the first line between two points. He opens his compass to this span. He sets one point at the first mark and draws a second line at right angle along the straightedge. He then moves the compass to the far end of that second line and swings an arc. Next, he positions the compass at the other end of the second line and swings a second arc so the arcs cross. He aligns the straightedge through that crossing and the end of the second line, then draws a third line matching the first and parallel to it.

steps.step: draw last line of same length connecting ends of first line
steps.description: Primitive artisan kneels before a flat clay slab. They grasp a narrow wooden stylus, smoothing the wet surface. They place a flat stick as straightedge against the clay’s face. With the stylus, they scratch a first bar. They lift and rotate the straightedge to mark a second bar, turning from the first at a right corner. They repeat to make a third bar, each shallow groove matching the length of the first, forming an open angular frame. Now they align the straightedge between the free ends of the first and third incisions. They place the stylus at one tip and draw a final line along the edge, joining the two points. The new side spans the exact same measure as the opening mark, enclosing a perfectly balanced form.

He stands before a flat stone slab, holding a length of straightedge carved from wood. With charcoal in his other hand, he rubs it against rough rock to sharpen its tip. He has already scored two connected marks that meet at one corner. Now he prepares the third. He lays the straightedge so its ends touch the free ends of those first two lines, forming a right angle where they join. He presses firmly, keeping his elbow steady, and drags the charcoal tip along the tool’s edge. A dark, even stroke appears on the surface. When he reaches the opposite corner, he lifts the charcoal and steps back. He inspects the new line’s length against the first, ensuring each edge will align perfectly at every corner.

plane.name: plane
plane.description: A vast, gleaming form hovers high above the earth, its polished skin catching sunlight like a mirrored stone. Two broad, flat appendages stretch wide, balancing a slender, elongated body. A tall, upright fin rises at the rear. A low, thunderous roar echoes from throats beneath, shaking distant ground. Round eyes line the sides, reflecting the world below. Dark smoke drifts from its belly as it glides silently across the sky.

steps.description: A solitary craftsman stands by a forest edge. He selects a tall pine with a straight trunk. Using a flint axe, he strikes a sharp notch near the base. He repeats blows until the trunk topples. He chops off side branches and splits the log into manageable lengths. He chooses a straight-grained piece roughly the length of his arm. He trims bark and smooths irregularities by scraping with an antler knife. He inspects the billet for knots and cracks before proceeding. He carries the harvested billet back to his workshop, ready for further shaping.

He selects a sturdy chunk of hardwood and places it on a flat stone. With the mallet, he strikes the chisel to shave away bark and knots. He secures the block with his foot and taps carefully to form a flat sole. He chisels out a shallow recess near the center and carves a wedge-shaped groove for a sharp iron. Using a series of precise blows, he hollows the cavity beneath the wedge slot to allow wood shavings to escape. He refines the shape, squaring corners and rounding edges. Periodically, he tests the fit of the blade and adjusts the slot depth. Finally, he smooths the body with light percussion, creating a tool that will glide across wood surfaces, shaving thin curls, producing long spirals of delicate fibers and leveling imperfections effortlessly.

At dawn, a craftsman selects an oak block. He draws precise lines on the bottom surface where a narrow mouth will form. Gripping his chisel firmly, he positions the blade tip on the first pencil mark. Raising the wooden mallet, he brings it down in measured taps, carving into the grain. He begins to carve the mouth, focusing on straight sides. He works from both ends toward the center, prying out small curls of fiber. Each strike releases a sliver, deepening the cavity. He pauses to brush away debris and examines the depth with a steel gauge. He straightens any bowed edges by shaving with light chisel strokes. As the slot grows, he tests the seated blade blank, confirming a fit. He hones the lip cleanly, achieving a precise opening.

The primitive human heats a chunk of steel until it glows orange in the forge. He grips the heated metal with his tongs and moves it to the anvil. He strikes the steel with his hammer, driving it outward to form a tapered edge. Each blow spreads the metal and thins the center, shaping the length and profile of the blade. When the form grows uneven or cools, he returns it to the forge. The heat restores its malleability. Back on the anvil, he uses lighter hammer blows closer to the edge, refining the taper. He flips the work in the tongs, ensuring symmetry. With rhythmic hammering, he creates a flat surface along the spine, smoothing. To craft the bevel, he positions the hot metal at an angle under the hammer, drawing out an incline down each side. After several heating and hammering cycles, the edge becomes narrow and sharp. He returns the blade to the forge for heating, then quenches it in water, fixing its shape with a chill.

The artisan rubs the forged iron blade on a rough stone to refine its edge. He holds the carved wooden beam in one hand and aligns the razor-thin metal strip along its central groove. He drives the blade into the slot so that its sharpened edge protrudes at an even height. He braces the beam against his thigh and taps a small wooden wedge between the blade and the housing until the fit feels snug. He uses a flint knife to trim the wedge flush and then scrapes excess wood with a bone scraper. Finally, he coats the joint with resin for added grip. The blade now sits ready for use.

A primitive artisan shapes a chunk of metal into a sharp edge by striking it with a stone hammer near a glowing fire. He cools and reheat the steel several times, then grinds it against a rough stone until it gleams and bites into wood. Meanwhile, he carves a solid length of hardwood into a snug cradle for the blade, hollowing a slot at the top and shaping its sides to hug the steel. He drives slender wooden wedges into the slot beneath the blade, widening the wood to lock the edge firmly in place. Finally, he trims and polishes the block and tests the setup on a splintery board.

plumb bob.name: plumb bob
plumb bob.description: In shifting light, a small, tapering object hangs from a slender, twisted strand of plant fiber. Its surface gleams with a dull, silvery glow, darkened by tiny scratches and faint mottling. The form narrows to a sharp point at the lower end, while the upper flares slightly before the cord’s knot. When still, it hovers motionless, yet even a breath of air makes it swing in slow arcs, tracing smooth curves.

steps.description: He kneels by the stream, passing stones through his fingers. He looks for a piece that feels solid and dense, one that he can balance easily. He tests each candidate, feeling its heft and gauging its symmetry. He dials in a weight that pulls the cord taut when suspended. Rough and irregular stones fail the test. He favors a small, pointy pebble that drops straight down without wobbling. Satisfied, he holds the chosen rock up, watching how it dips perfectly vertical before he wraps it with sinew and hangs it.

A primitive craftsman selects a dense river stone and holds it firmly in one hand. He lifts a hammerstone in the other and begins a series of controlled strikes on the chosen core. Each impact chips away at unwanted protrusions, guiding the emerging profile toward a compact, symmetrical form. He rotates the piece, striking edges in turn to maintain even thickness and avoid cracking. Periodically, he lifts the stone, feeling its heft and balance, adjusting his blows to target areas that feel too light or heavy. As shaping nears completion, he rubs the stone on coarse grit to smooth rough edges, producing a balanced weight ready for suspension on a fiber line.

First the craftsman selects a dense stone that will serve as a weight. He cleans its surface, smoothing irregularities by rubbing it against sandstone. Next he positions the awl at the stone’s apex, applying pressure and twisting the sharp tip. This action wears away tiny fragments, gradually puncturing the rock and creating a hole. He continues pressing and rotating the awl, periodically withdrawing it to clear debris. He repeats until the opening reaches sufficient diameter for cord insertion. Then he polishes the pierced edges with a flake, ensuring fibers do not snag. Finally, he threads fiber through the hole, tying knots. This simple tool, when suspended, reveals true vertical alignment.

He harvests and cleans flax stalks. He soaks them in water to loosen fibers. Afterward, he spreads them in warm sun to dry. He breaks the stalks with a wooden mallet to crack the woody core and scutches them by scraping against a board to remove debris. Next, he combs the fibers with bone-toothed tools to align them. Holding a small bundle, he spins between thumb and forefinger, applying a steady twist to form a single strand. He then doubles and twists it again for strength, finishing with a secure knot.

He buries his fingertips in a bundle of peeled bark fibers and combs them until each strand separates. He twists the fibers together, forming a sturdy length. He creates a small hole through the top of the stone weight using a sharp flint. He threads one end of the cord through the opening and loops it back underneath. He pulls tight, securing an overhand knot. He trims any loose ends and tests by tugging the line. When firm, he lets the weight hang, ready to align true vertical. This simple connection endures repeated use.

nails.name: nails
nails.description: Slender, elongated shapes lie scattered across the ground, each gleaming faintly in sunlight. They are rigid and cold to the touch, smoother than any rock or bone. One end tapers to a sharp, precise point, while the opposite side flares into a thin, flat disk. Their surfaces hold a quiet, metallic shimmer that catches the eye. They feel unnaturally uniform, as if crafted rather than formed. They lie half-buried in dirt.

steps.description: At daybreak, the craftsman steps into the rocky ravine, scanning cliff faces for green stains of copper. He crouches by debris, runs a finger over rough surfaces, feeling for flecks of metal. In shallow streambeds, he overturns stones, searching for tin’s silvery sheen. He strikes suspect rocks with a hammerstone, listening for a dull ring that hides beneath the shale. He tests heft and color, tossing fragments into his sack. He studies patterns of local shrubs that grow near mineral veins. He follows gullies where water carves channels, spotting shards of green and blue-green copper minerals. He wipes sweat from his brow, guided by memory of past finds.

At dawn the primitive miner approaches the rocky outcrop where copper ore veins lie near surface. He lifts the hammerstone in one hand, grip firm, and holds the sharp pick in the other. He strikes the pick against the ore seam, chipping away flakes and fragments. He shifts his weight, swing after swing, driving the pick deeper into the stone. When large chunks loosen, he uses the hammerstone to break them into smaller lumps. He wipes sweat from his brow with a scrap of hide and returns to peeling away rock with care. He sets aside waste stone and gathers the copper-rich fragments. He tests each piece by striking it light, listening for the dull ring that signals metal content. He fills his hide bag with the ore, ready for smelting.

At dawn, the craftsman selects a hardy stone furnace dug into the earth’s bank. He gathers the richest ore, crushing it by hand against a flat boulder. He layers charcoal and ore within the hearth, alternating until the chamber is full. Using a blowpipe fashioned from hollow reed, he intensifies the flames, reaching searing heat. Molten metal drips through a hole at the furnace’s base into a lined stone trough. He carefully measures charcoal and ore for consistent purity. As the liquid metal solidifies in simple clay impressions, he taps each piece free with a hammer forged from river rock. Finally, he inspects every length for uniform strength, ready for further forging.

The primitive smith grasps a copper rod in iron tongs and holds it over glowing embers until it glows orange. He then shifts it to an anvil and strikes the heated section with a hammer, working around the circumference to flatten one end into a rudimentary flange. Rotating the rod, he hammers a taper toward the opposite tip, creating a slender point. Periodically he reheats the metal to maintain malleability. Once the desired length and shape emerge, he places the rod back into the fire for a final softening, then plunges it into cool water to harden the copper. The result is a sturdy metal spike ready for fastening wood. Throughout this process, hammer and tongs remain his constant companions, guiding each blow to shape the product. He tests each piece for durability before use in construction.
