With each percussion, the cutting implement takes form. Finally, he uses the hammerstone to remove tiny bits, refining the edge until it cuts cleanly. The tool now stands ready for detailed work.

He stands at the edge of a clearing, barefoot on damp earth. His spear is sharpened with flint, its shaft wrapped in sinew for grip. He noses the breeze, smelling damp foliage and distant hoofprints. He crouches low, moving slowly among ferns. He spots a deer grazing under a birch, unaware. His grip tightens. He supports the shaft with both hands, steadying his aim. He draws the spear back and steps forward, each breath steady. He thrusts, driving the point deep between ribs. The deer staggers, muscles twitching. He follows, pressing the tip further until its struggles fade. He eases back, heart pounding, watching the life slip away before raising the spear in triumph.

The primitive human kneels beside the fresh carcass, grips the knife in a steady hand. He positions the blade at the base of the skull, taking care to align the edge with the spine. With measured force, he slices through sinew and skin, pushing the metal deeper until bone appears. He probes the cut to find the gap, then shifts the blade to one side. The knife sawing through vertebrae severs the spinal column. Blood seeps from the wound, pooling on the ground. Finally, he lifts the detached unit free in one swift pull, exposing a clean stump ready for further processing. He wipes it on a strip of hide.

leather jacket.name: leather jacket
leather jacket.description: A strange hide lies draped over a branch, cut to mimic a torso. Its surface is smooth and tanned, dark as wet earth but dry to the touch. Crisscrossed stitches trace out symmetrical panels, while small flaps and slits appear where limbs might fit. A stiff band circles one edge, and narrow metal teeth line a single seam. It emits a faint smoky, oiled scent, unnatural to the forest floor.

steps.description: A primitive craftsman tracks a deer through the woods at dawn. He follows fresh footprints under tall pines. He approaches quietly, clutching a flint-edged knife sharpened by stones. When the deer pauses to graze, he draws his blade and plunges it between ribs. The animal collapses, and he approaches calmly. He lays it on a clear patch of ground and readies his knife. He makes an incision along the belly, cutting through hide and tissue. He peels back the skin with steady hands, keeping the blade close to the flesh. He works methodically, separating hide from muscle and sinew. When the hide comes free, he inspects and trims rough edges.

Early morning, the craftsman lays a fresh hide across a sturdy wooden frame. They run cool water over the surface, soaking dried blood and softening tissue. Using a curved stone scraper, they begin on the flesh side, pressing firmly to remove fat and membrane in broad sweeping strokes. When most residue is gone, they rinse the hide, patting and re-soaking until the water runs clear. Next, they flip the hide and angle the scraper nearly flat to shave off hair gently, moving from center outward to prevent cuts. They periodically dunk the hide into a shallow basin, kneading to loosen remaining bits. Once both sides appear smooth and free of debris, the hide remains damp and uniform in thickness, ready for tanning.

With two shaped hide panels laid on a flat stone, the craftsman aligns the raw edges carefully, ensuring that the shoulder seams match. He rests the awl at the edge and presses its tip through both layers, punching a neat row of perforations. With sinew threaded on a slender needle, he pulls the first stitch through the holes. Steadying the layers, he makes tight whipstitches along the shoulders, drawing the panels into a single piece. He ties off the sinew securely, creating small knots against the hide. Turning to the side seams, he repeats the process: awl, perforate, thread, and pull sinew, moving steadily down to the hem. He doubles the thread where stress will be greatest: armpits and hem. After trimming excess sinew, he smooths the seam with a rubbing stone, resulting in a sturdy garment ready for wear.

piano.name: piano
piano.description: A large rectangular block of dark wood, its massive curved side meeting a flat top bearing two rows of smooth, ivory-like protrusions. Delicate metal strings coil inside, visible through a slender opening, stretching between shining pins. Four stout legs hold it off the ground. Below, three heavy, brass-colored prongs stand in a row beneath the body. Polished surfaces reflect light faintly. Its glossy finish glows under sun.

steps.description:
A lone craftsman works steadily to shape a sturdy rectangular skeleton from heavy slabs of wood. He begins by laying two long beams side by side and measures precise distances with a carved bone ruler. With a sharp saw, he slices through the fibers of each beam, producing straight, even edges for the top and bottom rails of the frame. Next, he cuts four shorter uprights to form the vertical posts. 

He marks mortise locations where rails and posts will join. Using a chisel and a wooden mallet, he carefully chips away wood to carve clean mortise cavities. He then fashions tenon ends on the rails by trimming excess wood with the saw and refining their shape with the chisel. When each tenon fits snugly into its mortise, he removes stray shavings to ensure a flush, gap-free joint. 

To lock everything tightly, he applies a bit of sap-based glue into each cavity and presses the pieces together. He positions a sturdy clamp around opposing corners and tightens it until the frame sits rigid and square. Finally, he leaves the assembly to rest, allowing all parts to bind firmly into a single strong structure.

A lone craftsman stands before a slab of spruce. He marks the outline of two broad panels, each spanning the length he deems ideal for his resonating vessel. With his saw, he cuts them free. He planes each face until they lie flat, then draws a gentle arch across the length of the upper panel. Using a chisel, he hollows the underside, shaving thin curls of wood until the curve forms a smooth arc. Along the edges he planes a shallow rabbet, preparing a joint.

He scoops water into a trough and submerges the panels to render them more pliant. He fits them into a stone mold carved to his desired profile. He secures the panels within the mold using clamps of woven sinew, pressing them against the form. Next, he crafts internal braces from spruce, shaping each with his plane and chisel. He seats these braces inside the cavity, aligning them to support the flat surface. He reclamps the assembly, holding it firm against the mold’s curve. With a scrape of his plane and a test tap on the surface, he confirms the resonator’s clear, ringing tone.

The artisan gathers raw lumps of iron and feeds them into a roaring furnace. He strikes sparks to ignite charcoal at the base and stokes until the interior glows white. After the iron softens to a glowing red, he carefully lifts a heavy crucible by its side handles. He sets it in the furnace hearth and waits as the lumps dissolve into a molten mass. When the metal attains proper fluidity, he removes the crucible with a long metal hook. Next, he brings forth a sturdy ladle forged from iron. He dips it into the crucible, letting the glowing liquid fill its bowl. With hands he carries the ladle to a clay mold shaped with the desired profile. In one fluid movement he tips the ladle, and the molten iron flows, filling every channel. He pauses to hear the hiss as the metal meets cool clay. After time, he returns to let the piece solidify, striking the mold to release the rough casting. The formed section stands ready for finishing.

He lays out the soundboard and wooden frame on a sturdy workbench. Before joining, he examines each piece for fit and smoothness. With a clamp, he holds a long side rail flush against the base. He uses a handcrafted screwdriver to turn iron screws, fastening the rail firmly. Next, he fits the opposite rail and secures it the same way. He positions wooden crossbeams inside the case, applying the clamp to keep each beam aligned. Then he swings a hammer to tap in small nails where screws cannot reach, reinforcing the beams. He adjusts the metal plate and fastens it with the screwdriver. With care, he mounts the keyboard assembly on the frame, securing hinges with screws. Finally, when strings and hammers are in place, he uses the tuning hammer to twist each string pin, tensioning them to the correct pitch. At last, the body takes shape, sturdy and true, ready for tonal testing.

Standing by a rough-hewn wooden frame, the craftsman grips a tuning hammer forged from iron with a copper-wrapped handle. He sets its head onto an iron pin that secures a taut copper string. He applies measured force to rotate the pin, pulling the wire tighter or allowing it to slacken, thus altering its vibration. He plucks the copper strand and listens closely to its pitch, making incremental turns until the tone stabilizes. Moving systematically from one pin to the next, he watches how each coil layers evenly into its anchor hole. He feels subtle vibrations with his fingertips, detecting the slightest slack. The interplay of iron and copper yields clear resonance as the network of wires finds perfect balance through patient, precise adjustment. A crude oil lamp casts flickering light across the wires.

A primitive craftsman tightens metal strings stretched across a wooden frame. He places a tuning lever over a pin linked to a string. With the lever in hand, he applies force to turn the pin, increasing tension and raising note’s pitch. He listens as strings resonate, adjusting until the desired tone emerges. If the note sounds too sharp, he loosens tension by easing the lever in the other direction. He repeats this process string by string, refining intervals and harmonies. By changing tension, he ensures strings align in perfect tuning.

spruce.name: spruce
spruce.description: A tall tree rises high above the forest floor, its trunk cloaked in gray-brown bark that cracks into rough scales. Slender branches extend outward in regular tiers, bearing stiff, needlelike leaves that feel prickly to the touch. The needles cluster around the limbs, pointing in all directions like miniature green spikes. Small, elongated seed pods hang downward, covered in overlapping petal-like scales. A faint scent envelops the air around the foliage.

tuning hammer.name: tuning hammer
tuning hammer.description: One wandering the woods finds a small, cold piece of black stone, shaped into a rounded block with a thin arm extending downward. Its surface gleams with unnatural smoothness and metallic weight. Where the arm meets the block, a narrow neck flares into a straight rod ending in a loop. The rod is silver-gray, cool to the touch, and retains a precise, symmetrical form no bark or bone could match.

steps.description: The primitive human grips a pickaxe with both hands, stance steady as he approaches the rocky outcrop. He lifts the tool overhead, then brings it down sharply onto the mineral vein. Fragments of stone and raw iron ore scatter across the ground. He pries loosened chunks free with the pick’s pointed tip, then lowers them into a woven basket. Sweat beads on his brow, but he works in steady swings, each strike chiseling away at the hard rock. Dark dust rises around him as he uncovers glints of reddish-brown ore. Periodically he pauses to examine each piece, selecting the richest fragments to haul back for forging. His arms burn as the basket grows heavy with dense lumps.

A primitive human kneels beside a clay furnace built from mud and stone. They place glowing coals inside and stir them with a stick until the fire grows fierce. They hold crushed iron ore above the heat and let it fall into the center of the furnace’s core. They work the bellows with rhythm, blowing air through the fire to raise its temperature. Sparks fly as the heat climbs and the ore begins to melt, trickling molten metal to the bottom of the hearth. They pause to skim away slag that forms on the surface, keeping the molten mass pure. They add more charcoal and ore, maintaining a glow. Finally, they pour the molten metal into a stone mold, letting it cool into a bloom. Once cooled, they extract and shape the iron.

A primitive blacksmith kneels beside a roaring forge, stoking glowing embers with a bellows until the fire burns white-hot. He picks up a chunk of raw iron with tongs and holds it in the heart of the blaze. After a few minutes, the metal glows bright orange. Lifting the iron, he places it upon a flat anvil. With strong hammer blows, he flattens one end into a broad, thick face. Turning the heated piece, he hammers the opposite side to taper the neck. He reinspects the shape, returning to the forge to heat any cold spots. Once the face and neck form, he moves to refine the edges. He hammers the perimeter of the block, rounding corners and squaring axes for balance. Between heats, he plunges the work into a water trough, noting the hiss that signals cooling. He then gives a few light strikes on the anvil to correct minor warps, producing a sturdy iron block with a defined face and neck, ready for further finishing.

A primitive smith crouches before a low stone hearth, blowing air through a hollow reed to coax the coals into life. He lays the iron head over the roaring forge and shifts it slowly, rotating the mass so every face gleams with even heat. As the metal glows bright red, he seizes it with crude iron tongs and lifts it free. Holding the head upright, he inspects the fiery hue to confirm it has reached peak temperature. With a resolute grip, he plunges the searing mass into a waiting bucket of cool water. A fierce hiss erupts as steam billows skyward. Underwater, the metal’s internal structure reorganizes, locking hard. After several seconds, he lifts the cooled piece, immerses it once more for uniform strength, then places it on a rack to air dry, ending the ancient cycle of fire and quench.

He stands at the edge of the forest, scanning for a sturdy trunk free of rot or disease. He sharpens the axe blade against a stone, ensuring a clean cut. Then he grips the wooden haft and raises the tool overhead. He swings with steady rhythm, striking the tree’s base just above the roots. Wood fibers split and crack under repeated blows. As the trunk leans, he shifts his stance, guiding its fall away from other trees. Once it rests on the ground, he removes branches and strips bark with strokes. Finally, he chops the log into manageable lengths and carries them to the work site near his simple shelter.

The craftsman selects a sturdy piece of wood from a fallen branch and secures it against a rock to ensure stability. He grips a sharp knife and begins by slicing away rough bark, revealing the pale grain. Turning the piece in his hands, he carves shallow grooves that will guide his shaping. With measured strokes, he rounds the outer edges, removing thin shavings of wood. He then hollows the center to form a comfortable grip, testing the thickness with his fingers. Patiently, he refines the contours until the handle rests naturally in his palm, free of splinters and ready for the next stage of assembly. Each stroke of the blade ensures a balanced form.

The artisan chooses a solid hardwood shaft and a forged iron weight shaped like a head. He splits the top of the shaft by driving an iron wedge beside the grain with his hammer. He hammers the split open until the slit matches the hole in the iron piece. Then he fits the shaft end into the head’s central eye. Using his hammer, he strikes the head—each blow tightens the wood within the eye, drawing the fibers outward to grip firmly. Once the head sits flush, he trims any excess wood flush with the iron. Finally, he drives small wooden pegs into side holes around the joint with his hammer to lock the parts together. The implement stands ready.

tuning lever.name: tuning lever
tuning lever.description: A slender iron bar, a rigid hand’s length long, hosts a short wooden wrap near its midpoint. One tip forms a squared, hollow end, the other a smooth, rounded stub. The dark metal feels cool, its surface faintly pitted yet worn gleaming dimly by torchlight. The wooden grip is dark and warm to touch, scarred, solid, and burnished by many hands, lying silent and inert among scattered stones.

steps.description: A primitive craftsman selects a solid rod of cold steel from a small stockpile. He examines several pieces by eye, judging diameter and straightness. He grips the chosen rod with wooden clamps, then places a hand-forged saw blade against the metal. With steady, even strokes, he saws through the steel, pausing to clear filings and realign the blade. He maintains a firm, level motion to ensure a straight cut. Once the desired length is separated, he inspects each end, ensuring a clean, even surface. He then bevels remaining burrs by angling the saw blade, creating a safer edge. He tests its balance by rolling it on a flat surface, confirming uniform shape.

The craftsman selects a straight iron rod and secures it in a simple wooden vice carved from hardwood. With a coarse iron file, he begins filing along its length, applying firm, even strokes. He grinds away irregularities, checking his progress by eye and touch. The rod gradually tapers to a uniform diameter, its surface smoothing under the patterned grooves of the file’s teeth. He rotates the rod steadily, ensuring all sides wear down equally. Periodically, he wipes away filings with a rough cloth to inspect the contour. As the shaft nears the desired profile, he switches to a finer file, refining the shape until the lines are crisp and the finish gleams with a subtle sheen.

A craftsman moves through a forest, searching for a straight limb. He selects a branch from an oak, noting its thickness and smooth texture. Using a sharp flint blade, he trims away small twigs and excess wood until the branch reaches a comfortable grip. He strips the bark with repeated strokes, revealing solid wood. He uses a grindstone to smooth out irregularities and round the edges. Testing its weight and balance in his hand, he sets the handle aside for fitting, ready for integration with the rest of his design.

The craftsman selects a sturdy branch of hazel or ash and trims away twigs. Placing the wood on a flat stone, he uses his sharp knife to pare away bark and rough irregularities. Holding the wood firmly, he whittles along the grain, creating a gradual taper toward one end. He curves the edges for a comfortable grip, rotating the piece with one hand and slicing thin shavings with the knife in the other. He incises shallow grooves for better hold, carefully removing excess fibers. With smooth strokes, he refines the contour, ensuring a balanced shape. Finally, he rubs the surface with animal hide to smooth any rough spots, revealing a well-formed wooden handle.

A primitive craftsman sets glowing iron rods atop a flat stone, gripping them with tongs. He uses a stone hearth to heat each piece until it glows orange. Placing two bars side by side, he aligns their ends and grasps a short iron pin. He positions the pin through a small hole punched at the joining point. Holding a stout hammer in his other hand, he strikes the pin head firmly, driving it flush through the metal. He turns the assembly and hammers the protruding end into a rounded cap, locking the bars together. Finally, he smooths the joint with repeated taps, ensuring a snug and solid bond.

can of tuna.name: can of tuna
can of tuna.description: It is a small cylinder of hard, smooth metal, its curved sides reflecting light like water. The top bears a faint spiral ridge circling a dull, raised disc. When slit, a seam parts with a hiss, revealing pale, oily strips of fish held in shimmering brine. The flesh is soft and slippery, exuding a faint saltwater scent. The vessel’s edges are sharp, the contents locked within its thin, cold walls.

steps.description: A solitary gatherer pushes a wooden hull across a calm sea at dawn. He grips a sharpened stone-tipped pole firm in calloused hands. He scans rippling waters, watching for dark shapes gliding below. The hull drifts into deeper currents where tuna patrol schools of smaller prey. He halts the drift and lowers a paddle, holding still in silence. When a large tuna arcs toward the surface, he raises the spear overhead, muscles coiling like bowstrings. He lunges forward as the fish breaks the water’s mirror, driving the point true. Water splashes and the creature twitches against the shaft. He hauls it aboard, victorious. He secures the catch before swiftly returning.

A primitive human kneels beside a freshly caught tuna and holds a sharpened knife. He slices along the backbone, separating two muscular fillets from the spine. He drops the spine and trims away the head, tail, and fins. He lifts one fillet and runs the blade beneath the skin, peeling it away in long strokes. With careful cuts, he removes the belly cavity and releases all dark red flesh. He divides the white flesh into smaller pieces, discarding any remaining bones. He lays the clean chunks on a broad leaf and rinses them with cool stream water. Satisfied, he moves the trimmed fish toward the hearth for cooking or storing.

A primitive craftsman gathers tin ore from rocky outcrops, selecting the richest nodules of metal-bearing rock. He breaks the ore into small pieces using a hammerstone and washes away loose earth. He then builds a small furnace from clay and heat-resistant stones, shaping an opening at the base for airflow. He shovels the crushed ore into the furnace chamber, layering it with charcoal. Working the bellows, he forces air into the fire, raising the temperature until the charcoal glows bright orange and the ore begins to melt. He carefully pumps the bellows in steady rhythm to sustain the heat. When molten metal pools at the furnace floor, he tilts a clay crucible to pour the liquid tin into prepared molds. After cooling, he extracts solid tin ingots, ready for further shaping.

A primitive maker takes a thin sheet of tinplate and smooths it over a small anvil. He places a cylindrical mandrel atop the anvil and lays the metal strip around it. Gripping a simple hammer, he taps along the overlapping edges, forcing the tinplate to curve tightly around the form. With each gentle blow, the metal yields, wrapping ever more snugly until it holds its round shape without assistance.

Next, he shifts the cylinder back onto the flat anvil face and uses the mandrel’s end to press the lower edge inward, creating a neat inward curl. He then hammers along this curl, tightening the metal lip until it forms a sturdy rim. Turning the piece over, he repeats the inward curl at the opposite end, using the mandrel’s taper to guide his blows. Finally, he inspects the new vessel under sunlight, ensuring its walls are smooth, its seams are secure, and its shape is perfectly round.

First, the gatherer selects caught tuna. He cleans and scales pieces, removes bones and skin. Then he cuts the flesh into thick slabs and sprinkles coarse salt between layers to preserve flavor. Next, he fills a hollowed wooden container with slabs. He uses a stone mallet to press the tuna, driving out air pockets and compacting the flesh. He builds alternating layers of tuna and salt, then covers the top with a carved wood lid. Finally, he seals edges with pine resin and stores the container in a cool place.

A solitary food crafter balances a metal body on a carved stone block. She presses a flat lid down over its rim, aligning the edges with care. Reaching for the simple can seamer, she secures its base over the joint where body meets lid. With hands on the lever, she draws the tool’s rollers inward. As the handle turns, the rollers trace the rim, curling the lid flange around the can body. She repeats each rotation, moving steadily to seal the edge without gaps. A faint metallic ring echoes when the flange locks in place. She wipes stray shavings from the rim with a scrap of cloth, removing all metal dust. Once complete, she inspects the seam, ensuring it is even and airtight. Her primitive workshop yields a fully sealed package, ready for storage.

He picks up a small metal box packed with oily fish and grills it over a low wood fire. He scoops glowing coals with a flat stone and piles them around the container’s sides. He watches the edges of the metal warm, rocking it carefully with a split stick. When steam hisses from the lid’s slit, he pulls the box back, knowing the fish inside is hot and ready to eat.

tuna.name: tuna
tuna.description: Blue-gray creatures slip through sunlit waters in shimmering shoals, their bodies sleek and elongated like slender torches of silver. A darker stripe runs along their backs, blending into paler underbellies as they glide with graceful, powerful thrusts of crescent tails. Their skin glints under rippling waves, reflecting shafts of light that dance across scales pointed and smooth. They travel swiftly in tight groups, cutting through currents with unwavering strength and fluid precision.

tinplate.name: tinplate
tinplate.description: Before you lies a flat, gleaming, impossibly thin sheet of metal, its surface as smooth as polished stone. The edges are sharp yet uniform, and the material shines with a pale, silvery light. It feels cold to the touch, hard and rigid, yet bends under pressure. Sunlight glitters off its even plane, and fine scratches trace over it, hinting at the force that shapes this thin slab.

steps.description: A primitive craftsman builds a clay-lined furnace and lights a small fire with charcoal. He crushes iron ore into coarse powder, then loads it into the hot furnace. One assistant pumps the bellows, feeding air to raise the fire to white heat. The ore begins to smelt, releasing slag and molten iron. He taps the furnace and collects droplets of metal in a stone mold. After cooling, he breaks the mold and retrieves a small bloom. He returns it to the hearth, heats it until glowing red, and hammers it on an anvil. The repeated heating and hammering expel impurities and flatten the bloom into a thin, workable sheet. Throughout the process, he relies on precise bellows rhythm and careful fire management to achieve a smooth, solid piece of metal.

He heats a rough chunk of iron in glowing embers until it shines dull red. Grasping the metal with his tongs, he lifts it onto a flat anvil. With a firm stance, he strikes the iron with a heavy hammer, driving each blow directly downward. After a few solid hits, he twists the piece in his grip and hammers again, working it thinner and wider. When the metal cools too much, he returns it to the coals for a fresh glow. He repeats the cycle of heating, gripping, and hammering, rotating the heated bar to maintain even thickness. Gradually, the once-rough billet transforms into a broad, flexible sheet. He checks for weak spots or cracks, reheating and hammering small areas as needed. Finally, with the iron laid out nearly paper-thin, he uses a gentle tap to smooth out minor undulations, producing a uniform metal sheet ready for the next stage of workmanship.

A small firepit furnace stands hollowed out in clay and stone. A slender craftsman shovels broken charcoal into the chamber, packing it around a core of crushed tin ore. He sorts grey tin ore, breaking it into small fragments to expose fresh faces. He operates hide bellows, driving air through leather nozzles to stoke the embers. With each pump, the flame grows fierce, licking the blackened walls. The worker pours handfuls of tin ore over the white-hot charcoal, watching the rough fragments begin to glow. Under the rising heat, the metal separates from its rocky host and flows downward. He angles the furnace spout and slides a heavy clay crucible beneath, catching the molten stream. Bubbles rise to the surface, carrying waste that he skims away with a paddle. When the flow slows, he stops pumping and lets the crucible cool. He then reheats the ingot to purge slag and casts it in a clay form. The cooled metal shines with a smooth sheen, ready to coat crafted tools and containers.

At the hearth, the primitive smelter arranges charcoal and stone to form a small furnace. He places his heavy clay crucible at its center and sets a batch of coarse tin fragments inside. Using a stick, he fans the charcoal burn, raising the heat. The interior glows fiery red as the furnace reaches a bright incandescence. The artisan grips long iron tongs and inserts the crucible into the roaring heat. He leans forward, monitoring the metal; the tin turns from dull gray to a shimmering, molten liquid. At this stage, he skims off any scum or impurities that rise to the surface, ensuring a pure pour. Carefully, he withdraws the crucible with his tongs, balancing the vessel above the glowing hearth. The molten tin ripples in the clay pot, ready for casting or coating. This process transforms the solid ore into a pliant, flowing metal.

The craftsman lights a small fire beneath their clay-lined hearth, placing a handful of lead-gray tin fragments into a rough clay crucible. When flames lick around the vessel’s sides, he uses charred-stick tongs to adjust the heat until the metal melts into a silvery liquid. Meanwhile, he rubs an iron sheet with ash to remove scale and brighten its surface. Once molten metal flows freely, he lifts the crucible with the tongs and tilts it carefully, allowing a thin stream to run across the heated iron. He spreads the coating by angling the sheet diagonally, guiding the sheen toward its edges. Excess drips back into the fire pit. To ensure even coverage, he dips one corner of the glowing iron into the crucible and swirls it briefly before withdrawing. With a cloth, he fans cool air over the sheet, solidifying the glossy layer. Finally, he inspects the surface for smooth, protective finish.

The primitive craftsman lifts the heated iron sheet from the clay pot of glowing molten tin and holds it steady above a bed of damp sand. He lets the metal rest, allowing the molten coating to firm at its surface. With careful taps along the edges using a wooden mallet, he encourages any excess liquid metal to drip back into the pot. Then he gently rubs the warm sheet with dried grass to smooth the layer. As the iron cools fully, the pale coating hardens into a bright, protective skin.

can seamer.name: can seamer
can seamer.description: A squat shape of heavy iron rests on a wooden board, its base casting a low stance. A thick, cylindrical spindle rises from this, crowned by a grooved wheel that glints in the firelight. Curving arms branch outward, each ending in a smooth roller, when still. A slender handle juts from one side, its worn wood contrasting the cold metal. Gear teeth peek from channels, waiting to bite into motion.

steps.description:
A primitive craftsperson gathers iron ore from creek beds or rocky hillsides and carries it to a simple stone furnace. They build a mound of charcoal inside, layering ore and fuel between clay-lined walls. Using a pair of bellows, they pump air into the base of the furnace, stoking the charcoal to reach glowing temperatures. As the fire climbs past red heat, the ore begins to release its oxygen, leaving behind a soft, spongy bloom of metal.

After several hours, the craftsperson uses tongs to extract the silvery bloom and places it on a flat anvil. With a sturdy hammer, they strike the mass repeatedly, expelling impurities and forging the bloom into a more compact shape. When the bloom cools, they return it to the furnace for another heating cycle, alternating with hammering sessions until the metal achieves greater density and fewer slag pockets.

Finally, they reshape the refined iron under the hammer’s blow, producing a solid bar of wrought metal. With this bar, they prepare to fashion tools or reinforcements, marking a foundational step in early metallurgy. This process yields iron suitable for blades, nails, or simple farm implements.

A primitive craftsperson heats a chunk of iron in a glowing forge until it glows bright orange. Using sturdy tongs, the artisan lifts the iron from the coals and sets it carefully on the anvil. With a heavy hammer in hand, the maker delivers firm, controlled strikes, flattening and elongating the heated metal into a flat bar. The iron cools quickly, so the craftsperson returns it to the forge again and again, alternating hammer strokes and reheating until the desired shape emerges.  

Next, the artisan cuts the bar into smaller lengths, each destined to become functional parts. One segment turns into a curved hook, formed by hammering the heated end around a cylindrical mandrel on the anvil. Another piece becomes a rectangular block with a central groove; repeated hammering and precise chiseling create the groove that will guide moving elements. Between blows, the craftsperson uses tongs to rotate and adjust each part, maintaining symmetric profiles.  

Finally, the maker polishes the parts against a rough stone, removing scale and sharp edges. The finished components--springs, guides, and rollers--stand ready for assembly into a device that will seam metal lids tightly onto containers.

He clears a wooden bench and lays out iron plates, rods, and fasteners. He holds the baseplate upright and fits the vertical frame over its edge. With the wrench, he twists the first bolt until it seats firmly. He aligns the curved iron guide at the top of the frame, using the screwdriver to drive each screw into the predrilled holes. Next, he inserts the rotating roller onto its axle and places it into the frame’s brackets. He taps the roller shaft with the hammer, ensuring it sits fully before tightening the brackets with the wrench. He then attaches the lever arm to the roller’s end, driving a screw home with the screwdriver. He taps the hammer against each joint, checking for any wobble, then adjusts the gap between guide and roller until it moves smoothly. Finally, he wipes off shavings and inspects every seam, ensuring the tool stands ready for operation.

can body.name: can body
can body.description: As they approach, they see a tall, slender hollow form gleaming silver in the waning light. Its sides curve in a perfect circle, and fine raised ridges trace its length in even intervals. Smooth and cold to the touch, its edges appear sharp where the top and bottom have been removed. Light dances off its metallic skin, revealing scratches and fingerprints. It resonates with a hollow ring when gently struck.

steps.description: A primitive craftsperson heats a piece of iron in a charcoal fire until it glows bright red. They grasp the heated iron with tongs, lifting it carefully from the flames. The craftsman places the heated bar onto a sturdy anvil and raises the hammer high. They strike the iron firmly and evenly, and the blow spreads the metal outward. Each hammer stroke rings out in quick rhythm, echoing across the forge. After several decisive hits, the surface grows flatter and broader. Tongs hold the work firmly as the craftsperson rotates the bar, ensuring uniform thickness. When the iron cools too much, they return it to the fire, reheating the metal until it regains a glowing hue. Once the piece reaches the desired dimensions, the smith gently smooths minor imperfections with lighter hammer taps. Finally, the iron sheet cools slowly to prevent cracks. The smith inspects the flat, gleaming sheet, ready for the next phase of shaping.

A primitive metalworker stands before a heavy mandrel and secures a heated iron sheet. Using a crude hammer forged from river stones and animal bone, he taps the sheet against the mandrel’s curved form. He begins at the center, striking rhythmically to bend the edges around the mandrel’s shaft. The repeated blows cause the metal to wrap smoothly into a cylindrical contour. As the sheet cools, he re-heats it in a small charcoal fire. He alternates heating and hammering, slowly refining the round shape. He shifts the piece, rotating it by hand to ensure even thickness along its length. Finally, the cylinder releases easily from the mandrel. He inspects the seam, hammering out minor irregularities until the piece stands uniform and seamless. Then he hollows one edge for tight fit.

First, he shapes a sheet of tin-lead alloy into a curved panel. He bends it around a mandrel to form a cylinder. He trims overlapping edges for fit. He cleans the mating surfaces to remove impurities. He secures the seam with clamps. He heats the soldering iron, dips the tip in solder, and applies flux along the gap. He presses the soldering iron tip against the seam. Molten alloy flows into the joint, fusing edges. He moves the soldering iron along the length, keeping a consistent bead. After cooling, he files excess solder and smooths the joint. He wipes the bead with a damp cloth, then checks for gaps. If any voids appear, he reheats and adds solder. He buffs the surface with an animal hide for a smooth finish.

He cuts a disc of iron sheet roughly the size of the top of the intended container. He hammers the edges against a small portable anvil to even out any irregularities along the circumference. Holding the disc on the anvil’s rounded horn section, he taps around the rim repeatedly with the hammer’s peen, coaxing the metal outward and upward in a smooth, narrow lip. He flips the workpiece and repeats on the other side to ensure uniform thickness and height. Next, he sets the flanged disc flat on the anvil’s face, lightly striking the ridge to harden the flange and sharpen its angle. Finally, he inspects the finished edge, smoothing any uneven spots with controlled hammer strokes until the flange forms a consistent metal collar ready for later joining.

boat.name: boat
boat.description: Near calm water margin emerges a narrow, elongated shell hewn from joined wood slabs. Its hull curves upward at each end, forming symmetrical points that slice through the water. Rough lashings bind overlapping planks along its spine, creating a continuous vessel-like cavity within. The smooth underbelly contrasts with the ribbed interior arches. A network of twisted fibers trails alongside, attached to each side, tapering toward slender poles poised above the cavity.

steps.description: At first light, the craftsman selects a massive timber by examining trunk diameter and straightness. He grasps a stone-headed axe, lifting it high above his shoulder. With measured strides, he positions himself to face the tree’s intended lean. He swings the blade in rhythmic arcs, scoring deep notches on the side facing his stance. Each strike chips away fibers, gradually widening the opening until a V-shaped notch appears. Turning to the opposite side, he begins a back cut, aiming several centimeters above the notch’s base. Fresh shavings fall in spirals as the cut deepens. Finally, the trunk yields with a cracking roar, dropping to the earth with a controlled crash.

A craftsman selects a sturdy, straight log from a felled tree. He places it on supports, securing it against rolling. With a stone-sharpened adze, he raises each swing above his shoulder, then brings the blade down into the wood. The iron blade bites deep, carving out shavings. He works along the center line, groping out the pith and carving a concave channel. Each strike rings clear, and he clears chips with his hand. After initial gouging, he reverses the tool, using the back edge to pare away rough ridges. He smooths the interior with finer cuts, inspecting depth and symmetry. Finally, he polishes the cavity with sand and water.

He gathers resin from pine trees, heating it gently by embers until it softens into a sticky liquid. He grinds moss into thin strands, ensuring it is dry but fibrous. He lays the fibrous moss into seams between planks, pressing it firmly to fill gaps. He dips a bundled twig into the resin, then drips it carefully over the moss, covering every crack with a thick protective layer. The resin bubbles and cures, fusing with the moss to create a waterproof seal. He smooths the surface with a stone, removing excess material. He warms the resin before each application to maintain pliability. He tests each seam with keen attention for any damp spots.

can lid.name: can lid
can lid.description: A small circular disk of cold, gleaming metal catches the light, its center rising in a gentle dome beneath a narrow curled rim. The thin surface bears faint concentric rings and tiny scratches. A few rust spots dull the silver-gray sheen. Smooth yet rigid under any blade, it stands in stark contrast to the soil and leaves around it. A faint metallic echo rings when it taps lightly on stone.

steps.description: A small group gathers suitable chunks of iron ore and tin ore from a shallow pit. One person places a lump on a flat stone surface and brings down a hammerstone again and again, cracking the hard exterior. With each powerful strike, small flakes of ore chip away from the surrounding rock. After several blows, the person discards the broken waste and collects the heavier, metal-rich fragments. Next, they grind those fragments into coarse granules by rubbing them across a flat rock with the hammerstone’s edge. Periodically they pour the granules into a shallow stream, gently swirling water to wash away lighter sand and clay. Denser metallic grains settle quickly, and they retrieve these at the bottom. Finally, they carry the cleaned powder and fragments back to camp, ready for the next stage of heating and forging.

A primitive human gathers iron ore from a rocky outcrop. He builds a simple furnace using clay and heated stones. He shapes a bowl of clay around a cavity then reinforces it with stones. He lights a fire beneath the furnace and feeds wood charcoal to burn. When the interior glows white hot, he places the iron ore inside on a bed of charcoal. He uses a clay nozzle to direct bellows and increase airflow. The intense heat separates the metal from impurities. After sustained burning, molten metal seeps onto the floor where he collects glowing blooms of iron. He hammers the blooms with stone tools to remove excess slag.

A primitive metalworker arranges rough stones in a circle to form a hearth on bare ground. He fills the hearth with charcoal and small sticks and uses dry leaves to kindle a fierce fire. He breaks copper ore into chunks with a hammerlike stone, discarding rock waste. Crushing the copper ore into gravel, he repeats the process for tin ore and separates metal fragments by tapping on a wooden tray. Using sturdy iron tongs, he lifts a clay crucible and fills it halfway with copper ore fragments. He adds tin ore to form a simple alloy that melts at lower temperature. He forces the crucible into the heart of the blazing hearth and stirs with a slender iron rod until the ore glows molten. He skims off slag from the surface and wipes the crucible lip with coarse cloth. Then he lifts the crucible and tilts it, pouring the liquid metal into a shallow stone mold carved to shape. After cooling, he taps the mold to release a solid disc ready for finishing. He smooths edges with an abrasive stone and polishes the surface using fine sand.

Facing the glowing iron ingot, the smith raises a simple hammer. He sets the red-hot piece on a flat anvil, without modern mold or guide. With steady force, he delivers heavy blows, each strike flattening and fanning out the metal. As the ingot grows thinner under repeated hits, he turns it, ensuring even thickness. Sparks fly as the hammer head meets the heated surface, and occasional reheating in coals restores pliability. His hand guides the hammer’s arc, controlling depth and shape. When the form approaches the desired size, his strikes grow lighter, refining edges and smoothing irregularities. Finally, the plate emerges thin and uniform, ready for fitting. He listens for ringing to judge when density evens out. The entire process relies on rhythm, heat, and the simple bond of iron, hammer, and anvil.

He lays the tinplate flat on a wooden board and uses charcoal to sketch a circle matching the intended diameter. He clamps one hand at the center to steady the plate, while the other uses tin snips to make a notch along the outline. He follows the charcoal line, rotating the sheet in small increments and making controlled cuts to maintain a smooth curve. He keeps the blades aligned at a slight angle to reduce bending. As the circle nears completion, he adjusts cutting pressure for finer detail. Once freed, he inspects the disc, using the snips to trim any jagged bits along the edge, ensuring a clean, shape.

The primitive artisan sets a flat tinplate disc into a simple rolling mill. They clamp the disc in place, ensuring its rim lies between the hardened rollers. They turn the handle slowly, drawing the disc forward so the roller edges curl the thin metal upward. The tin flange forms as the disc travels through the gap, producing a uniform, rounded lip. They watch the edge closely, adjusting roller pressure to prevent cracks. The gradual pressure shapes the metal smoothly, reinforcing the rim. After a few passes, the edge stands neatly rolled. They inspect the result and repeat as needed until the curled border is even and secure.

log.name: log
log.description: A stout section of a fallen tree lies across the forest floor, its bark rough and dark-brown, marred by cracks and patches of green moss. The cut end reveals tightly coiled rings, each a record of past seasons. Tiny beetles and wriggling larvae find shelter in its crevices. Its surface feels firm yet absorbent of moisture, and its weight presses down the leaf litter beneath, blending seamlessly with its woodland surroundings.

steps.description: The primitive person moves through shade of oaks and pines, scanning bark textures for straight grain and strong fibers. Their eyes trace the angle of trunks toward the sun, seeking growth. They pause at each rustling branch, sniffing resin scents. Hands brush moss from rough bark, seeking signs of sturdy core. When a promising giant emerges ahead, they root feet, certain of choice and ready to claim shelter and fuel.

A primitive human stands before a tall tree, gripping a stone axe bound to a wooden handle with sinew. They tap the blade against the trunk, searching for weakness in the wood. With steady arms, they drive the sharp edge into the bark, carving a deep notch on the windward side. They move around, chipping away on the opposite side to guide its fall. Small fragments of wood scatter at each blow. Sweat beads on their brow as they sink the blade deeper. When the cut nears completion, the trunk creaks and shifts. They back up swiftly as the tree finally surrenders, crashing to the ground in a thunderous roar.

With feet planted on uneven ground, a human grips a stone axe’s sturdy handle. They press its sharp edge against a protruding limb, angling the blade where wood fibers run. In a single, controlled arc, the axe head bites in, severing a chunk of branch. Rotating the trunk slightly, they repeat the motion along the same notch, deepening the cut until the limb gives way. With each new shoot, they reposition their stance for optimal leverage, matching their swing to the grain. Fragments scatter as stripped sections lie beneath.

A primitive human stands by a trunk, gripping a stone axe with both hands. He plants his feet and positions the blade at an angle against the bark. Raising the axe overhead, he swings down forcefully, driving the sharp edge into the wood. He repeats these blows along a line, rotating to maintain a groove. He shifts to a sawing motion, pressing the axe edge into the cut to deepen the section. Wood fibers split and splinter under each impact, sending chips scattering. At last, the trunk yields with a loud crack, and a section separates. He lifts this piece of timber and sets it aside for further work.

A human kneels near a cut section of trunk. He wedges a forked branch under one end and heaves upward, shifting the weight onto his shoulders. Another gathers vines to lash shorter branches into a yoke. He loops these around his neck and drags the timber across the clearing, using saplings as rollers beneath. Each time he lifts the beam onto the next support friction lessens. When the wood reaches the riverbank, he rolls it into the shallows and floats it downstream, guiding the cylinder toward the settlement.

moss.name: moss
moss.description: A dense carpet of tiny green sprouts clings to stones, fallen wood, and damp earth. Each cluster forms a soft, velvety cushion that glows with moisture after rain. Its slender stems stand just a finger’s breadth tall, crowned with feathery leaves. When damp, it feels cool and spongy under touch, releasing faint mist as sunlight warms it. In sheltered hollows and shaded crevices, these emerald mats blanket the ground in abundance.

trunk.name: trunk
trunk.description: Bright sunlight glints off broad, flat panels of weathered wood bound by dark, rusted bands. The shelter-like shape rises low to the ground, its rectangular body defined by stiff, angular edges and seams. Its surface feels rough and cold, with faint ridges where planks meet. A thin, raised lip runs along one side, interrupted by rusty loops and pins. It stands solitary, silent, and obscure against the open earth.

steps.description: Early foragers move into the forest edge, eyeing mighty oaks and sturdy pines. They grip a chipped stone axe and strike at the base, chipping away bark and scattering wood shavings. Once they bring down the timber, they lash saplings together to create leverage, splitting logs along grain lines. They carve smooth planks by dragging a flint blade across the surface, peeling thin strips in even strokes. Sunlight dries the boards as they rotate them on stakes. With woven straps and wooden pegs, the panels firm into shape, ready for assembly.

He selects a sturdy fallen log. He lifts his stone axe, tests its heft. He brings it down against thicker branches, severing them one by one. He chooses the straightest section for later work. He inspects the log’s surface, looking for knots and rot. He taps each section, listening for hollow or damp spots. With controlled strikes, he cleaves the wood into manageable sections. He lays a section on two stones to hold it steady. He picks up the sharpened stone scraper. He holds it at a low angle against the wood. He pulls firmly, peeling away bark and rough fibers. He repeats until the surface is smooth and clean. He gathers the offcuts and discards chipped bits at the edge of camp. He readies pieces for the next shaping step.

The woodworker selects sturdy planks and places one on the ground as a base. He lines up a side plank against the edge, holds it firm, and taps a nail through the boards with his hammer. He listens to the sound of the metal striking wood to ensure each join is tight. He repeats this for all four sides, checking that corners form right angles. He fits a lid frame on top, aligns it carefully, and fastens it with nails driven flush into the surface. He wipes away loose wood chips and tests the structure for strength. He admires the completed box, noting its solid walls and sturdy form.

grape.name: grape
grape.description: Bright orbs cluster along slender vine tendrils, each smooth sphere glistening with dewdrops. They range from pale green to deep violet, translucent flesh pulsing beneath taut skins. When caught by sunlight, they shimmer like tiny lanterns amidst twisting leaves. A faint, sweet fragrance drifts on the breeze, mingling with grassy scents. As fingers brush these soft spheres, they yield slightly under gentle pressure, cool and inviting to the touch.

torch.name: torch
torch.description: A gnarled branch, its end bound in oily fibers that smolder bright amber, stands alight in the darkness. Fiery tongues dance along the ragged cloth, crackling softly as they send sparks arcing into the night sky. A sweet, pungent odor of burning pitch drifts on the air, mingling with wisps of gray smoke. Its fierce warmth pulses outward, casting wavering shadows against stone and bark, bathing the surroundings in trembling, golden light.

steps.description: A primitive human walks into the forest clearing. He searches for a straight, sturdy branch approximately arm-length. He lifts a sharp flint blade and slices through the sapwood, detaching the stick from the tree. He checks the piece for moisture, selecting a dry sample that will burn well. He scrapes away any moss to reveal clear grain. Next, he wades into the marshy area, pulling loose sections of inner bark from fallen logs. He peels long strips, then removes wet patches to ensure even smoldering, before piling them on flat stone to carry. Finally, he approaches a resin-laden pine stump and uses a pointed rock to pry chunks of sticky, amber material loose. He places the resin into his woven grass pouch, securing all gathered elements before he returns to camp.

He selects a sturdy branch and trims away its side twigs using a sharp flint blade, leaving a smooth shaft roughly a foot long. He then scrapes the bark from one end, exposing the fresh wood grain. Seeking a strong binder, he collects sticky resin oozing from pine bark and kneads it between flat stones until it softens into a pliable paste. Next he hunts for damp green moss beneath rocks, plucking handfuls of fibrous strands. He coats the moss lightly with resin and presses it firmly onto the prepared tip, layering until it forms a dense, fluffy head. Finally, he spreads extra resin around the base of the moss and smooths it into a compact ball that will ignite easily when struck by a flint spark.

First, the human selects a straight piece of wood to serve as a handle. They cut a notch and drill a small depression in the fireboard. Holding a dry spindle between their palms, they rub it rapidly back and forth, forcing friction into the notch. Fine dust collects at the base of the groove and slowly heats. White smoke curls upward as an ember glows.

Meanwhile, they gather dry grass and weave a loose bundle. When the ember glows bright, they transfer it carefully onto the grass fibers. They cup the bundle and blow gently, coaxing flame to life. Tiny orange tongues lick through the dried strands. Finally, they grasp the handle firmly and with eager anticipation lift the cluster high, ready to carry a living fire into the night.

soil.name: soil
soil.description: They see a dark, crumbly layer covering the ground, shifting under their fingers. Fine particles cling together in damp clods, and dry granules flow like coarse sand between their hands. A faint, earthy aroma rises as they disturb the surface, releasing the scent of decay and life. Flecks of pale grit, tiny stones, and bits of decayed plant matter dot the mixture. It feels cool and loose beneath their bare feet.

drill.name: drill
drill.description: A smooth, oblong form lies on the forest floor, its cylindrical body coated in uniform dark tones. A sturdy grip arcs from its center, ending in a curved guard-like projection. At one tip, tight coils of cold metal spiral inward, catching sunlight in glints. The opposite end bears a flat, disc-like cap. Its polished surface feels unnaturally solid and warm, interrupted by tiny vents that emit subtle warmth and a faint hum.

steps.description: A primitive human gathers a straight stick from a nearby grove, selecting one that fits comfortably between the hands. They strip away the bark with a sharp flake of stone, revealing pale wood. Next, they lay the shaft on a flat rock and use another sharp stone to carve out knots and irregularities, shaping the end into a smooth, rounded taper. They scrape the surface against rough stone to even it and remove splinters. Once it is uniformly straight and free of cracks, they set it aside for further work.

A person kneels near a small pit filled with coarse sandstone fragments. They select a flat slab that offers an even abrasive surface. Holding a length of flint, they press the rough edge against the stone and push it forward in firm, steady strokes. The sandstone wears down tiny bits of the flint, smoothing the surface and creating a precise, tapering tip. The artisan periodically rinses the flint in water to clear grit, then inspects the point under daylight. They adjust the angle slightly, focusing on stray chips and dull spots. After many minutes of controlled grinding, the flint tip takes on a slender, razorlike shape that glints in sunlight.

meteorite.name: meteorite
meteorite.description: A mysterious dark, heavy rock lies half-buried in the hard earth. Its surface is rough with pitted hollows and ridges, as if scarred by fiery heat. In the dim light it gleams with metallic glints, and when struck, it rings with a sharp, ringing tone unlike any other stone. Heat seems to have once flowed over its edges, leaving them smooth and glassy. It feels colder than the surrounding stones.
